From:         Kevin Magee <poetry@HYPOBOLOLEMAIOI.COM>
Subject:      10-11
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

From page 68 of PACIFIST:

"Peter Yakovlevich Chaadaev (1794-1856). Western-oriented Russian
philosopher.  His major work, The Philosophical Letters, began to
circulate in manuscript when Chaadaev was in his later twenties. While
the original was written in French, the First Letter appeared in a
Russian translation in The Telescope in 1836. Public outrage and the
censorship under the regime of Nicholas I caused Chaadaev to be
declared officially insane and placed under house arrest for a year
and a half; it caused the permanent suspension of The Telescope and
the exile of the editor, N.I.  Nadezhdin. Four Letters and the
'Apology of a Madman' (1837, Chaadaev's last philosophical essay
[Chaadaev was freed in 1838 on the condition that he not write again])
finally appeared in a bilingual Russian-French edition in Russia in
1913-14: M.O. Gershenzon (ed.), Sochineniia i pis'ma P.Ia. Chaadaev
(Moscow, 1913-14).  This was undoubtedly Mandelstam's text. Only in
the early 1930s did D. Shakhovskoy (a distant relative of Chaadaev's)
discover the remainder of Chaadaev's Letters and publish them in a
Russian translation in Literaturnoe Nasledstvo, Vols. 22-24, 1935.
For more information and an English text of the Letters and the
'Apology,' see Mary-Barbara Zeldin, Peter Yakovlevich Chaadaev
(Knoxville, 1969)."

To the extent that a culture can be said to be obsessed with the
signifiers of its own past, might it also be said that this obsession
extends to the problem of transmission, represented here by the
meeting of two books, Agamben's Infancy and History, published in 1978
in Italian and in 1993 in English, and Mandelstam's The Complete
Critical Prose and Letters, translated into English in 1979 (the
translator's preface is written from the University of Pittsburgh,
June 1978) from writings in Russian that span the same period of time
as those by Walter Benjamin.

What is it that Western culture doesn't want to know about its past,
and is it possible that this is where the fascination with destruction
draws its force, "like the architectural skeleton of a house in
flames." (Agamben, 145). This simile, an application of the "arsenal
of devices, commonly known as tropes" (Mandelstam, 387) where poetry
enters, and makes its home, terminates a sentence defining the
"destruction of destruction" as the making visible of the "categorical
structures of Italian culture," in which the "destruction of the mode
of transmission, which marks our culture fundamentally, is
dialectically brought to light." (Agamben, 145). In the absence of
true historical continuity, the site of culture as negative
determination must be burned by fire to illuminate the historical
structures whose narration the dialectical image immobilizes.

_____________


[External intervention, 5.4.03]:

The gesture here, to expose the bad metaphoricity at work among the
discursive prose of Agamben's Infancy and History, where there is
language which bears a high degree of fascination with the flawed
concept of historical time in Benjamin's writings.

Whether or not intensifying magnitudes of destruction can be
assimilated into contemporary historical consciousness, so that the
ground which begins to be prepared threatens the capacity of language
to articulate its refusal to accept this reality which is not fate.

Political reality is infinitely modifiable, like a chain of phonemes
rattling the cage of the social syntax.

From:         Joe Amato <joe.amato@COLORADO.EDU>
Subject:      Re: nader
In-Reply-To:  <FJEBIAECHLLAMEPOJPGECEDNCMAA.rova@rova.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0

david, of course i wouldn't wish to wish away gore's complicity in
his own demise... but we can't wish away nader's role in this,
either...

now i said i wasn't going to get into this, but ok:

you recall nader arguing, post-election, that 'the country would rise
up' in the wake of the election to activate for a safer environmental
(etc.) reality than we had at the time?... his implication being, if
you watched these post-election interviews, that his having run for
election had ipso facto created a better political-social situation,
a greener u.s.... you also recall gore's stance on the environment?
(and no doubt gore was a hawk, for that matter)... can anyone
possibly say at this point that the environment is safer than it was
four years ago?... was nader right or wrong about this?... would gore
have provided us with a stronger environmental program?...

apologies for the rhetorical questions... i could ask much the same
questions re tax cuts and the like... and yes, of course, we have
gore/clinton and, perhaps above all, dick morris to blame for the
lousy centrist agenda that's blurred dem/repub distinctions...

hey, i'd love a sea change in government too (i think!)... but if i'm
to hold gore accountable for his failures (which i do---gore was
hardly my favorite candidate of all time, lord), then i'm going to
hold nader accountable for his misreadings of the public domain...
and from where i sit, he committed some huge errors as a politician,
and as a public servant (ditto for gore)...

so if you voted for nader, i think you have at least to admit that
your candidate was indirectly instrumental in bringing into power
bush & co, all for the sake of that 5% he needed in order to get fec
funding... and further, that nader has never quite come to grips
publicly with this fact, at least to the satisfaction of someone like
yours truly... that gore was instrumental in bringing bush & co into
power was of course a direct consequence of his failed candidacy...
i.e., most of us who voted for gore know and understand our
candidate's failures, but we're still waiting to hear from the nader
folks where they think they went wrong...

in any case i think it's pretty clear now, isn't it? that the left is
going to have to make some political compromises, candidate wise, in
order to oust the right wingers from the oval office... personally i
would prefer to see the dems move further away from centrism, b/c i
think otherwise they'll find themselves behind the 8-ball again...
and obviously i simply don't hold to the notion that "there's no
difference" twixt the two major parties, albeit i wish there were far
more difference than there is...

best,

joe

From:         Halvard Johnson <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      "Centcom Briefing Sonnet #2"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Centcom Briefing Sonnet #2

The first and final image is of an ammo dump near Baghdad,
which illustrates our approach to reviving the Iraqi economy
by planting trees all around, using the combined waters
of Lake Huron, Lake Superior, and Babylon to flourish them.

Where centuries twist toward the light, and special operations
forces have also been effective interdicting movements into
or out of Iraq, single-purpose vehicles wheel along at a nice clip.
There is no future for the regime or anyone who supports it.

We've made that statement clearly a number of times, and we'll
continue to say it. We'd be happy to guarantee that they have no
future. Will they fight to the death? Probably. We're seeing that
in a number of places. Alarms have passed. The sun travels on.

Those who are indeed in the open have everything to lose
and will lose it. It's better to err on the safe side and destroy them
than to do otherwise. We want to ensure that no capability can
come up, especially from western airfields. They were in the open

and they were attacked, and the trees often vary in both color
and substance. Flame more or less comes and goes.


Hal

Halvard Johnson
===============
email: halvard@earthlink.net
website: http://home.earthlink.net/~halvard

DESERT WATER: POETRY FESTIVAL '03 will launch its eleven-day,

nineteen-event, city wide gala this coming Tuedsay at Skylight Books,

LosFeliz district.  Saturday night, April 5th on KXLU 88.9 f.m.

Christine Palma talks to director Suzanne Lummis about some of

the highlights, featured readers, and how this year's festival took shape.

from other poets in the festival.

=46rom the LA Weekly Good Times Section by Mary Beth Crain:

The Line Starts Here

"Poetry," observed Robert Frost, "is a way of taking life by the throat."
Yes, poets are, first and foremost, warriors, marching into territory
unknown and untried as they cast words like matches upon the imagination,
hoping to ignite the fire of new awareness. And in today's thoroughly
confused world, where making money and making war take precedence over
making sense, they are even more needed as keepers of the flickering flame
of sanity. So let us give thanks for National Poetry Month, and for this
year's Los Angeles Poetry Festival, an attempt to remind us of the critical
role poetry, and all forms of art, play in the development of the
intelligent, compas sionate, fully conscious society. Entitled "Water in
the Desert: Poetry for Our Times," the festival - an 11-day bash of events,
readings and appearances by some 100 poets - takes life by the throat and
shoves reality down the throat. You'll get to hear award-winning Nigerian
poet/novelist/ playwright Chris Abani, whose writings led to his
imprisonment and torture under Abacha's rule, and whose latest book of
poetry, Daphne's Lot, has been hailed as "an event of history, myth and
knowledge in the event of war and the ongoing turbulence of being human."
National Book Critics Award winner Amy Gerstler and Tufts Kingsley Award
winner Charles Webb read at "Jump Into the POOL!," the introduction of a
new Los Angeles magazine. "Poetry From the Picket Line" features readings
by janitors from Local 1877, en espa=F1ol. Chinese-American poet and Pushcar=
t
Prize nominee Carol Lem is one of the featured poets at the opening event,
"Brand New - Poetry 2003." Other participants include director and
co-directors Suzanne Lummis and Laurel Ann Bogen, Jack Grapes, Liz
Gonzalez, Harryette Mullen, B.H. Fairchild, and on and on . . . The L.A.
Poetry Festival is not for the conservative, the disinterested, or the
unquestioning - or maybe it is. Just think what would happen if everyone in
the military had to read Webb's "To Make My Countrymen Love Poetry," which
begins: "I wrote a priceless poem, a poem so precious/Burglars broke into
my house three times/A day looking for it, and bankers begged/Me to deposit
it with them, and women/Clamored for it instead of a ring . . ." Or if
George W. had to analyze and discuss Gerstler's "Siren": "I have a fish's
tail, so I'm not qualified to love you/But I do . . . The turn of centuries
or the turn/of a page means the same to me, little or nothing/I have teeth
in places you'd never suspect . . ." Why, maybe they'd all start writing
poems themselves - and then what would happen to the world?

-Mary Beth Crain

Los Angeles Poetry Festival, various locations citywide; April 8-19; this
week's events include "Brand New - Poetry 2003," featuring poets Dorothy
Barresi, Carol Lem and Jim Natal, at Skylight Books, 1818 N. Vermont Ave.,
Los Feliz, on Tues., April 8, 7:30 p.m., and "Just Us Chickens: A Salute to
Red Hen Press" hosted by Laurel Ann Bogen, featuring poets Chris Abani,
Terry Wolverton and J-son Wooi-chin, at Barnes & Noble at the Grove,
=46armers Market, Third St. & Fairfax Ave., on Thurs., April 10, 7:30 p.m.
Info, (323) 255-5223 or www. lapoetryfest ival.org.

=46rom Poetix - Interview by Jack Bowman


Jack Bowman spent some time with Suzanne regarding this years Los Angeles
Poetry Festival.  Here are the results...
I participated in one of the 1st readings of the LA Poetry Festival at
Pierce College about 10 or 11 years ago, how has the festival changed over
time?
=20
My, if it's been that long we should try to get your name back on the
brochure for next time.  I think your turn should come around again. The
festival doesn't seem to proceed steadfastly along some upward incline;
instead, each festival reflects something of the character of the Los
Angeles poetry monde at that moment, the sensibilities of the particular
organizers involved that year, and my own state of mind.  We've never
before had such somber colors as on the upcoming April '03 brochure,
because (I can testify with some authority on this) the mood of the
festival director is somber.  And so is, I might add, the mood of much of
the country and world.
=20
Still, the readings have about them a vigor and spirit.  Along with some
political readings-"Poetry from the Picket Line" at the Janitor's union
office, and Poetas En Contra de la Violencia a la Mujer (Poets Against
Violence to Women) at Avenue 50 Studio in Highland Park, we have "I Do, I
Do," celebrating love and marriage on April 13, "Play Ball! (The CD) Poets
take on the American Sport," a presentation of authors from Red Hen Press
and the new Los Angeles area literary magazine "Pool".  And the Playa Vista
sponsored Freshwater Marsh Ecopoetry Celebration on the last day of the
festival, April 19, includes a smashing line-up-with visiting poets Carolyn
Kizer, Jack Gilbert, Pattiann Rogers, Willis Barnstone, and a number of Los
Angeles area poets.
=20
I think this year's festival seems like a blend of sweetness and
gravity-with some joy, too, because many wonderful new publications are
being celebrated.  It's not the biggest or the richest festival we've ever
had, but it's one of the best and most substantive.
=20
One respect in which the festival has clearly changed and evolved is in the
quality of the poets we're able to showcase.  There are far more
first-rate, really talented poets in L.A. now than in 1989, our first
year.  In part this is because some marvelous poets have moved here, but
also in this span of time a generation of poets has come into its own.=20
=20
Isn't it difficult to be all inclusive with this large an area and  diverse
cultural population?
=20
Oh my, we aren't.  Not "all-inclusive" that is, because that implies that
everyone's included.  If some entity would like to give the Festival a
$50,000 budget to work with we could present all the poets in the city.
We'd need to schedule readings around the clock for a month straight.
=20
It's funny, there's actually no contract with any funder, and no agreement
with Cultural Affairs, that all styles and sensibilities of poetry must be
presented in every festival.  Some years have not featured any formal
poetry, some years no purely performance-oriented work.  Etc.
=20
Do you know what our contractual obligation is to Cultural Affairs this
year?  I'll bet you'll be surprised.  It's to present three readings in
three separate venues in Los Angeles, with different poets in each
reading-some newer, some veterans.  Obviously we've gone way beyond that
minimal requirement.
=20
What's important to me is that each festival should offer a kind of
snapshot of the city's literary monde at that moment.  Though it can't, of
course, feature all the terrific poets and great venues, it can give an
expressive and suggestive cross-section.  And the themes of the readings
vividly suggest what kinds of topics and concerns are on the minds' of
poets in that year.
=20
But still, I haven't quite answered your question have I?  One way we can
be certain to achieve variety is by involving a variety of organizers.=20
This year twelve organizers put together nineteen events.  When no one on
the regular organizing committee's an expert in a particular area we'll
involve an independent poet from the community.  For example Carlye
Archibeque, who hosts a series at Eric Garcetti's council office, proposed
a "Best of the Urban Poets" event, and in this way got some new names into
program.
Another sort of variety involves bringing together poets who might not have
many opportunities to share the same stage.  The year's festival reprises a
lovely event we've had once before-at the Korean Cultural Center.  We
invited two non-Korean poets, and Sung Yi is now translating their poems
into Korean.  They will read with two bi-lingual Korean poets, and the
audience will hear all the poems in both Engligh and Korean.  Liz Gonzalez
and William Archila will join Hye Ryung Kim, Yung Kyo Kim, and Sung Yi,
Tuesday, April 14.=20
=20
What is planned for this year? Is there a theme?
=20
I guess I've touched on some of the readings.  There's not a theme exactly,
but the festival's title, "Desert Water," is followed by the phrase "Water
from the Desert / Poetry in Our Times".  I'd been looking for a way to
acknowledge the larger context in which these readings are taking place,
but without using predictable or polemical language.  To me, the language
of polemics and propaganda is the opposite of poetry; it consists of words
and phrases that are already stale by the time they reach us.
I was helping another poet think up a title for a reading, and playing with
the idea of water/desert, desert/water, when I came upon the notion that
felt closest to my own sense of how poetry-at its best-fits into the
national and global predicament.  I like the quietness of the phrase. It
shimmers across our field of understanding.
=20
What / Who are your muses?
=20
Well, here's a list you don't often see grouped together: Joan Didion,
Raymond Chandler, Hamlet-that is, Hamlet the character, the guy-Kevin
Eubanks (yes, the band leader for Jay Leno), those diametric opposites,
Syliva Plath and Elizabeth Bishop, Roy Jones (yes, the great
light-heavyweight), Richard Rodriquez, the late actress-comedienne Madeline
Kahn, Oscar Wilde (even before the Oscar Wilde craze), Christopher Hitchens
(well, sort of), Toni Morrison, Goya, Emma Thompson, Michael Caine, my
contemporaries Lawrence Raab over in MA, Dorianne Laux up in Oregon, those
"Y" chromosome poets Charles Webb, Ron Koertge and Pete Fairchild wandering
around here somewhere, Cecilia Woloch who's great fun at a party, all my
students, and all the wonderful people I love but don't have time to thank
because the band is starting up, everyone in my favorite movie of all
times, "The Year of Living Dangerously" and its director Peter Weir.=20
That's all. Thank you, thank you . . .

What is this I hear about a tribute a Spanbauer novel at this year's fest?
Could you explain why a tribute to a novel, and why this one in particular?=
=20

Oh too bad the Administration has rather ruined the phrase "a constellation
of reasons".  But they coined it I guess, or brought it into popular
currency, so it's theirs to keep.=20

Therefore I'll have to site a lily pond of reasons why I chose the Tom
Spanbauer novel in particular.  And why I began passing it along to other
poets to see who might be interested in presenting it, along with one poem
by each participant, at the April 11th reading at Otis School of Art and
Design.=20

I think when I met and read with Tom up in the Nye Beach Writer's Series in
Oregon, I'd already come to feel the Festival could now open up a bit, and
explore the connection between poetry and the other language arts.  And I
was struck by Tom's own interest in poetry and the way poets work, and --
even more importantly -- how this engagement with poetry showed up in his
writing.=20

I do think it's tricky to call a certain prose style "poetic," because we
have to think 'poetic in what respect?' What kind of poetry does it
resemble?  That is, there are poetries with a pared down, understated way
of working, or poetry that's almost flat in its language, so the
designation "poetic prose" seems vague.=20

In Tom's case, his style bears a kinship to a poetry right after my own
heart -- a head-long, moving, shifting, charged way of working.  (Though I
could name other kinds of poetry equally "after my own heart").=20

Also, the book explores gender identity, individual and collective/
historical moral consciousness, and the protagonist's struggle to separate
out the truth from a morass of lies, half truths, and deceptions -- both
those self-imposed and those planted by outside forces.  And it's very
American, very much an attempt on the part of the author to find his own
way back into the history of the West.=20

Here are the book's three opening paragraphs:=20

          "If you're the devil, then it's not me telling this story.  Not
me being Out-In-The-Shed.  That's the name she gave me not even knowing.

She being Ida Richilieu, and later, after what happened up on Devil's Pass,
they called her Peg-Leg Ida."=20

          "Hey-You and Come-Over-Here-Boy were also what I thought were my
names.

          First ten years or so, I thought I was who those ""tybo"" words
were saying.  ""Tybo"" being "white man" in my language.  My language being
some words I still can remember.=20

          "My mother was a Bannock and she worked for Ida, cleaning, and
whenever a man took a fancy for a breed.  That's how I came about -- or so
I thought.  My mother called me ""Duivichi-un-Dua"" which means
something,... which means I was somebody to have a name like that -- not
like Out-In-The Shed."=20

On April 11, at Otis School of Art and Design, the poets will introduce
themselves with one poem of their own then read  from the book -- passages
that particularly speak to them.=20

There is a huge Poetry against the War movement, How do you see
Social-Political Poetry?=20

Starting April 3 I'm teaching a UCLA Extension class which I designed
several years back, but it's never been so relevant as it is now.  It's
called "Further Explorations" and its takes students through a three
approaches to poetry; the last stage -- and for me, in this class, the most
important -- involves the socio-political poem. It begins with the "I," the
autobiographical, memory based poem, but this is the first step in a long
running approach to the far more difficult type of poem -- the poem that
takes on problems and concerns larger than the individual life.  It's
difficult because one must rise above rhetoric and predictable
proclamations.=20

I conceived of the class in part because I felt irritated with local
writers for their inability to compose striking or memorable poems after
the '92 riots.  To be sure, the city has far better poets now. Think about
it, though -- can you remember one poem that stays with us among all those
written and declaimed after that civic trauma?  (O.K., accuse me of ego,
braggadocio and other acts of public nuisance but I think "Empty Shell,
L.A. '92" is unlike any other poem that emerged from that time.  I lived
right on Vermont; I saw plenty.  But it ends up as a harsh referendum on
poets. I was really angry at poets. Pretty shocking admission, huh?)=20

Back then, I felt many people wrote carelessly and thoughtlessly.  I guess
they were quickie Press-On poems produced for the situation, but few of
them were made to endure.  Today -- and it's perfectly all right if the
entire rest of the world disagrees with here -- I'm most interested in
poetry that by virtue of its unexpected take on things, by something
persistent and persuasive in the voice, by its stark economy, or by strange
lushness, can stand up season to season.=20

Did you see this gem from 13th century Rumi?  It was e-mailed to me and I'm
sure others got it also.  As follows:=20
- Rumi=20
Be quiet
And sit down.
You are drunk,
And this is the edge of the roof.=20

It's hard to write great short poems.  (Hell, it's hard to write great long
poems.)  But I think this one does in a few syllables what many fail to do
in a page or more.=20

I've come upon a number of strong poems that respond to the latest
unnerving turn of events.  I do love the two I posted in my March column,
and of course the Jane Hirschfield poem was not written about a war, yet it
applies.  Sometimes one doesn't need to write about a subject head on.=20
Remember how Roethke advised his students to "come at the poem sideways"?=20

There is a free website that had quite a bit of controversy this week
regarding posting pro and anti war stances, as well as defamation of
homosexuality and liberalism as anti-moral, how would you deal with such
serious issues if controversy occurs during the festival? =20

Gee wow, we've never come up against anything like that.  You mean if
someone at a Festival reading attacked homosexuality and liberalism in
their poetry?  I'm figuring a display like that could only take place at
one of the open readings, and in an open reading pretty much anything
goes.  I know nearly all the scheduled readers for the upcoming festival,
though, and it's unlikely we'll be hearing any attacks on homosexuality and
liberalism.=20

I can think of a particular Festival reading some time back where a lot of
things were said from the stage that I considered rash and uninformed.  But
that's how it goes -- the Festival's a mix of things. So far nothing of the
sort of thing you describe has become a problem.






____________________________________
Christine Palma

and Leopold Sedar Senghor's (part 1)

Camp 1940
    A Abdoulaye Ly

Saccage le jardin of betrothal in a sudden tornado evening
Mown down les lilas blancs, faded the fragrance of muguets
Departed the betrothed for the Islands of breeze and the Rivieres du Sud.
Un cri de desastre a traverse de part en part the cool land of wines
    and song
Like un glaive de foudre dans son coeur, from the East to the West 9

C'est un vaste village of mud and boue et de branches, a village crucified
     par deux fosses de pestilences.
Hatreds and hunger fermentent dans la torpeur of a mortal summer.
C'est un grand village under the tyranny of four itchy machine guns.
Et les nobles warriors mendient des bouts de cigarette
Ils desputent the dogs for the bones, they fight each other for dream
     dogs and cats
But they alone have kept le candeur of their laughter, they alone
     the freedom of their ame de feu.
And evening falls, a sob of blood qui libere la nuit.
They watch over les grands enfants roses, the grand infants blonds leurs
     grands enfants blancs
Qui turn and turn again in their sleep, possessed
     by the fleas of anxiety and the lice of captivity.
The stories of black night-watchers cradle them, et les voix graves
     that espouse the pathways of silence
And the lullabies gently, lullabies sans tamtam et sans no pounding
     of black hands--that will be for tomorrow...


(in/trans: William Rees)

From:         Taylor Brady <cartograffiti@MINDSPRING.COM>

In-Reply-To:  <BAB4D056.3595%cris@slang.demon.co.uk>

Cris,

Do you have a link available for this? I'd like to read more, as it
(sadly) seems to confirm a suspicion I've been having since the buildup
to this imperialist adventure started (well, started publicly) last
year, and which if true needs to be more broadly understood as a
background of anti-imperialist and anti-war politics in the years to
come. Briefly, it's seemed to me that most Left opposition to the war,
at least in the U.S. where admittedly the ability of public discourse
to critically unravel political economy is terribly and deliberately
underdeveloped, has centered around models of trade monopolization and
primitive accumulation, i.e., that the U.S. is simply after grabbing
Iraq's nationalized oil and making it "ours" to trade at quasi-monopoly
prices. (That is, where this opposition hasn't simply -- and
simplistically -- assumed that it's U.S. consumers' ungodly high
personal consumption of petro-chemicals driving the whole thing. And
not that this is not a factor -- but I think our current crop of war
criminals have their sights set on something larger).

The problem with even the more sophisticated version of this argument
-- i.e., that the war is "about" primitive accumulation -- is that it
ignores the crisis of over-accumulation "coincident" with the drive to
this war. You don't, if you're a good capitalist, aim at setting
overaccumulated capital back in motion simply by pumping more money
into the system, at least not in the short run, as it will only
exacerbate the crisis. And oil, given its exceptionally high
fungibility, is practically money under these circumstances.
(Especially if U.S. interests succeed in maintaining the dollar as the
OPEC trade standard). It's not that this grab for super-profits isn't
part of the equation, but that a particularly bloody kind of groundwork
has first to be laid to ensure the ability to productively invest all
that fresh surplus. So alongside the simple grab at "the other guy's"
capital, there has to be an outlet for productive investment, and this
I think is where the destruction of buildings, infrastructure,
production facilities, etc., comes in. It's a fairly well-established
function of war under capitalism to destroy large swathes of an enemy's
fixed capital in order to pump your own money capital into its
"reconstruction." Bush's statement earlier this week about the U.S.
promise to make Iraq a "modern nation" is actually true in this respect
-- that is, true in terms of the appalling lie which grounds it in the
first place. Iraq was, of course, perhaps the _most_ modern Arab
nation, from an economic perspective, prior to the 1991 war, though
severely damaged by the war with Iran (another hinge point of U.S.
policy in the region). The entire Anglo-American policy since 1991 has
been one of deliberately undermining and reversing this modernization
in order to set the stage for being able to redo it ourselves, on our
own terms, and for the profit of our own corporate clients. (Though
Blair must be having night-sweats now, seeing how much of his political
credibility he's traded away, not to mention the sheer murderousness of
what he's signed on for, all for a list of beneficiaries that now seems
to be composed entirely of U.S.-based corporations). In this respect,
the current war needs to be seen as a continuation of that policy -- a
dramatic escalation of its bloodthirstiness, certainly, but not a
qualitative departure from what "we" have been up to all along with the
sanctions and embargoes, bombing of water systems and other "soft
targets," etc.

So while it's shocking to read what you've posted today, I can't say
I'm surprised. Even without assuming explicit coordination between the
Pentagon and the planners of rebuilding during the coming occupation,
it's been clear over the last twelve years that military policy was
being set by just such an emphasis on the "creative destruction" of
Iraqi infrastructure, productive capacity, communications, et al. That
the war would continue and intensify this tendency stands to reason, if
one can speak of reason within a system of political economy that's
anything but reasonable. A focus on this policy -- and an
acknowledgment that the U.S. and the U.K. have been at war with Iraq
continuously since 1991 for exactly such purpose -- needs to come into
sharper focus as one of the fronts on which opposition to the current
war (and the coming ones) makes itself felt and organizes its political
resources. The wider dissemination of a more fully-documented version
of what you've posted today might be one place to start.

Peace,
Taylor Brady

10 of Diamonds


"I don't want to speak about his divinity; I'd rather speak of his humanity"

Projection minus reflection equals conjecture
an injection no muscle can reject

"The demon girl was like and unlike what I imagined one
of them to be. She seemed like a dwarf copy of her aunt and her
red face looked like a lantern that had been filled with blood"

their barred hymnal, but there were often denials of several
years when a moon declined and when his bad got hipped
hum. There was a symmetry where the coughings were temporally barred

"I heard one person compare it to being on the moon.
It was that kind of desolate feeling - just looking at
huge hills of rubble: of brick and broken wooden slats
that had once been houses. On top of the piles we would
see the random collection of things that had survived"

"The streets of Baghdad were deserted, except for an occasional
car speeding along. One imagined the driver painfully aware of the
thin veneer of metal and fabric over his head, useless against
huge fragments of metal roaring down silently from the sky.  The
buildings waited obediently. I found myself choosing one to look at.
Would the roulette ball stop on this slot, or skitter on one more?"

If I have t choose between shock
and awe, I choose shock that anyone's awed
by the awful barrage on Baghdad.  Anyway you look -
show again and again over all the networks - death
is death, black and white, never beautiful,
more awfully precise
than any million dollar American munitions

Centcom Briefing Sonnet #3

Ground truthing by Centcom has now suggested that both
the Tigris River and Euphrates River basins can be rendered
suitable Chinook salmon spawning habitats once sediment
sizes larger than fines can no longer adversely affect sac fry

emergence. Still, we continue to see brutal acts by the regime
and the forces loyal to it. One example comes from an outpost
in front of  1st Marine Expeditionary Force a day ago. And the
story goes like this. During the daylight hours, two vehicles

approaching a psychological checkpoint were taken under fire
when they failed to stop. At the same time, our maritime guys
continuing their work of keeping open the waterways found
some mines in the shallow waters of Khor Abdullah as they

continued expanding the channel way. Those mines have been
destroyed, making the salmon stocking project a definite go.
The maritime component continues to search any vessels
remaining to ensure that there are no threats. Dangerous work,

but important work, and it's necessary to ensure that anything
that's in the ports is safe. Okay, ladies and gentlemen, thank you.


Hal

Halvard Johnson

website: http://home.earthlink.net/~halvard

>> the Pentagon today admitted that companies awarded contracts
>> for the reconstruction of Iraq are being consulted in the selection of
>> certain strategic targets
>
> I wish statements like this weren't made without giving sources.
>
>
> -Joel W.

Hi Joel, Taylor, Robin and all

I read it in a Three Little Heretics Press Release.  I don't know if it was
some kind of punning on the word "opportunity" or not.  Words must mean what
they say on the Buffaloed Poetics list Jack Straw. Taylor Brady is right.

I've been glued to footage and commentaries that suggests though this
observation is not at all unlikely. Not simply a move for the petro-dollar
in opposition to the petro-euro (after Hussein's windfall in that switch and
some evidence of twitchiness from other oil producers). Nor simply about the
trade afforded by surplus currencies. Nor about Russia showing an interest
in the euro, nor Turkey joining the EU. More than all of that it's about
acculturation to economic habit through imposition of compliant
infrastructure.

I read this in the Pentagon's fancy for Ahmed Chalabi, US-educated ex-banker
with Jordanian conviction for fraud, who is seen by Rumsfeld as 'malleable'
(profile of Jay Garner by Paul Vallely in The Independent  5/4/03). He might
not get appointed but . . . there's an indication of intent right there.

Take a look at the companies that have been awarded the contracts. I'm sure
that many of you have.

I'm not sure any more if my little post was disinformation or information.
The fog that this war (the rolling one  -  on 'terror') will endear will
take a heck of a while to *blow over.

love and love
cris

O'Leary, Peter, The Gnostic Contagion: Robert Duncan and the Poetryof
Illness, Middletown, CT, 2002, p. 2: "We might also call them, following the
use of one of Duncan's favorite designations of the activity of the poet,
psychotic, as in 'of a psychosis,' meaning, literally, 'the soul in
process,' from the Greek psyche, for soul, and the suffix -osis, for
process.  The suffix -osis also designates disease, or the process of
disease, or the process of disease, as in neurosis and  psychosis, which
Freud intriguingly differentiates in the following way: "neurosis is the
result of a conflict between the ego and its id, whereas psychosis is the
analagous outcome of a similar distrubance in the relations between the ego
and the external world.' (Sigmund Freud, "Neurosis and Psychosis," of The
Standard Edition of the Complete Psychological Works, vol. 19, London,
Hogarth Press, 1977, p. 149)


Zimbardo's discontinuity theory
http://www.zimbardo.com/articles/disthry1.pdf  Cognitive and Social Searches
for Rationality and Normality May Lead to Madness

From:         Harrison Jeff <worksonpaper01@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      The Imperious Foam Buffalo
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

you,
bed-fellow of blood depressions,
unlearned of money with acres of the sun for dinner,
whose fog spear loosed the vine, know this:
The One To Come, The Hirsute One, The
Imperious Foam Buffalo, is HERE!

the City is pokeweed, north millions!
the mocking-bird's for strong-breasted sails
the factories at ebb ostent emotion
the winds are re-cohering this large mystery of world,
The Imperious Foam Buffalo, The Hirsute One shall
whirl bear eidolons out of our sphere!
The Horizon Of Pinnacles has returned, returned is
The Boundless Is Ever-Newer!

the trackless night is His backyard,
pairing the jelly-bearded with the dead,
with the tender lawlessness of hunted eyes,
the breast exits the blood at last,
His skin perfects the hands of all you possess,
The Divine is Six Poems With Lines Bent Surely As A Ship-Joiner,
yet bashful as water!

tell the palace baker "Evolution starts today!"
away foreign corpses!
those that pleased tigers will not please The Sunrise -
shall their sweat speckle The Sun?
shadowy carpentering made courtly the steaming trade,
still they passed around their printed plan of sugar'd intent -
shall their sweat speckle The Sun?
their show wine is fit now only for ogre-washing:
The One To Come, The Hirsute One, The
Imperious Foam Buffalo, is HERE!

Subject:      statistics regarding Iraq & US
Mime-Version: 1.0

http://www.liberalslant.com/jt040203.htm

Operation Iraqi Invasion, By the Numbers

By: Jackson Thoreau - 04/02/03
NOTE: This is a variation of a question-and-answer piece on the
relationship between Iraq, the U.S., Europe, and military campaigns
circulating through cyberspace. I set it up as an easier-to-read numerical
column and added a few items of my own. The numbers speak for themselves.

Percentage of the world's population living in the U.S.: 6.
Percentage of the world's energy resources used in the U.S.: 30.
Rank of Iraq among countries in the world for the largest oil reserves: 2
[behind Saudi Arabia].

Military spending, worldwide: $900 billion.
Percentage of worldwide military spending by U.S.: 50.
Percentage of worldwide military spending by Iraq: 0.0015.

Percentage of Iraq's military capacity U.S. claimed it destroyed in 1991
Persian Gulf War: 80.
Percentage of Iraq's post-1991 capacity to develop weapons of mass
destruction the UN claimed to have discovered and dismantled by 1998: 90.
Percentage of U.S. military spending that would ensure basic necessities to
everyone in the world: 10.

Number of Americans who have died in wars since World War II: 92,212.
Number of people living outside U.S. who have died in wars since World War
II: 25 million.

Years that Iraq has had chemical and biological weapons: 20.
Number of U.S. and European corporations that supplied Iraq with materials
and knowledge to make chemical and biological weapons since the early
1980s: 150.
Number of Western nations that condemned Saddam Hussein in 1988 immediately
after he used gas in the Kurdish town of Halabja in 1988 to kill an
estimated 5,000 people: 0.
Number of pounds of Agent Orange and other herbicides U.S. dropped in the
Vietnam War: 100 million.

Value of worldwide weapons trade: $800 billion.
Percentage of weapons dealt by U.S. companies worldwide: 50.

Estimated number of Iraqi civilian deaths in the 1991 Persian Gulf War:
35,000.
Estimated number of retreating Iraqi soldiers buried alive by U.S. tanks in
1991 War: 6,000.
Estimated number of Iraqi civilian deaths Pentagon predicted in the 2003
war: 10,000.
Estimated number of Iraqi civilian casualties in the 2003 war so far: 800.
Percentage of Iraqi civilian deaths that are children: 50.

Tons of depleted uranium left in Iraq and Kuwait after the 1991 Gulf War: 40.
Percentage increase in cancer rates in Iraq between 1991 and 1994: 700.

Number of years the U.S. has engaged in air strikes on Iraq: 26.
Pounds of explosives U.S.-led coalition dropped on Iraq in 1991 Persian
Gulf War: 177 million.
Pounds of explosives U.S.-British pilots dropped on Iraq between December
1998 and September 1999: 20 million.
Estimated pounds of explosives U.S.-British pilots have dropped on Iraq
since the start of Operation Iraqi Invasion in March 2003: 200 million.

Years Iraq has lived under economic sanctions imposed by the UN: 12.
Iraqi child death rate in 1989 [per 1,000 births]: 30.
Iraqi child death rate in 1999 [per 1,000 births]: 131.
Number of Iraqis estimated to have died through 1999 due to UN sanctions:
1.5 million.
Percentage of them children: 50.

Number of UN inspections conducted in Iraq in November-December 1998: 300.
Number of those inspections with problems: 5.
Number of UN weapons inspections conducted in Iraq in 2003: 500.
Number of UN resolutions Israel violated through 1992: More than 65.
Number of UN resolutions on Israel that U.S. vetoed between 1972 and 1990:
More than 30.
Number of UN weapons inspections Israel has ever allowed: 0.

Number of nuclear warheads U.S. has: More than 10,000.
Number of nuclear warheads Israel has: More than 400.
Number of nuclear warheads Iraq has: 0.

Number of countries known to have nuclear weapons: 8.
Number of countries that have used nuclear weapons on another country: One
[ the U.S.].
Jackson Thoreau, a contributing writer for Liberal Slant, is co-author of
We Will Not Get Over It: Restoring a Legitimate White House. The
110,000-word electronic book can be downloaded at
http://www.geocities.com/jacksonthor/ebook.html or at
http://www.legitgov.org/we_will_not_get_over_it.html Thoreau also
co-authored a book on Dallas history from the perspective of
African-Americans, civil rights advocates, and others.
His articles can also be found at: www.americaheldhostile.com Thoreau can
be emailed at: jacksonthor@yahoo.com

THE UBUWEB :: ANTHOLOGY OF CONCEPTUAL WRITING
Edited and introduced by Craig Douglas Dworkin


What would a non-expressive poetry look like? A poetry of intellect rather than emotion?
From the modernist experiments of Gertrude Stein and Samuel Beckett to the neodadaism of
Fluxus, they hint at the range of alternatives and challenges that have been presented to
the Romantic lineage of expressive poetry. This collection intends to both recall those
traditions and complicate their multiple and intersecting histories. Includes works by
Vito Acconci, Art + Language, John Baldessari, Robert Barry, Samuel Beckett, Christian
Bök, George Brecht, Victor Burgin, Donald Burgy, John Cage, Hanne Darboven, Alan Davies,
Dan Graham, Michael Harvey, Douglas Huebler, Joseph Kosuth, Tomoko Minami, Robert Morris,
Taddea Oscuro, Paul Pechter, Adrian Piper, Robert Rauschenberg, Richard Serra, Robert
Smithson, Gertrude Stein, and Lawrence Weiner.

THE UBUWEB :: ANTHOLOGY OF CONCEPTUAL WRITING  can be accessed at:
http://ubu.com/concept/

From:         Dan Machlin <daniel.m.machlin@VERIZON.NET>
Subject:      Futurepoem announces Fall 2003/Spring 2004 selections
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v551)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed

Futurepoem books is pleased to announce our forthcoming Fall
2003/Spring 2004 publications, selected by our editorial board during
our recent open call for manuscripts:

Jo Ann Wasserman, THE ESCAPE

Merry Fortune, YES, STARS

The editorial board for these selections was:
Anselm Berrigan, Brenda Coultas, Laird Hunt and Dan Machlin.  Exact
publication dates are not set yet, but will be announced shortly.

JO ANN WASSERMAN is the author of two chapbooks of poetry: what counts
as proof (Sugarbooks) and we build mountains (a + bend press). Her work
has appeared in journals including: "The World", "the east village",
"canwehaveourballback?" and "Grand Street." She was the managing editor
of "How2", on online journal of innovative writing by women from
1998-2000 and worked at the Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church in
several different capacities from 1992-1997. She recieved an M.F.A.
from the New College of California in 2001and currently lives in New
York City where she works for Granary Books.  This will be her first
full-length book.

Poet-writer/musician and Green Party supporter MERRY FORTUNE is editor
of the on-line version of Pagan Place w/ Robert Martens and a former
coordinator for the Poetry Project Monday night reading series. A
limited edition collection of her poems & stories Blind Stints was
distributed by Linear Arts Books. Her work has appeared in Brooklyn
Review #18; Lungfull!; The Outlaw Bible of American Poetry; The
Portable Boog Reader; Six ; The World; The Unbearables Self-Help
Anthology, The Unbearables Worse Book Anthology; the webzines Big
Bridge; Canwehaveourballback? and the Poetry Project Archives. She has
a collaboration w/ musicians Don Christensen, Pat Place & Julia Murphy
(FAT) on the 3-CD compilation State of the Union (Electronic Music
Foundation) produced by Elliott Sharp and is in the process of
producing an avant-pop recording titled the Love Dogs of Misfortune
featuring musicians Barry Seroff, Dee Pop, Daniel Carter, Dave
Sewelson, Marc Ribot, and Drew Waters.  This will also be Merry's first
full-length book.

Many thanks to all who submitted work during this past open call.
Dates and editorial board members for the next open call for Futurepoem
books will be announced shortly.

Futurepoem books is supported by the kindness of strangers.  More
information on the press is available at http://www.futurepoem.com.

Subject:      To America

By Iraqi poet Saadi Youssef

To America

I too love jeans and jazz and Treasure Island=20
and John Silver's parrot and the balconies of New Orleans.=20
I love Mark Twain and the Mississippi steamboats and Abraham Lincoln's =
dogs.=20
I love the fields of wheat and corn and the smell of Virginia tobacco.=20
But I am not American.=20
Is that enough for the Phantom pilot to turn me back to the stone age?=20
 . .=20
America:=20
let's exchange gifts. Take your smuggled cigarettes=20
and give us potatoes.=20
Take James Bond's golden pistol=20
and give us Marilyn Monroe's giggle.=20
Take the heroin syringe under the tree=20
and give us vaccines.=20
Take your blueprints for model penitentiaries=20
and give us village homes.=20
Take the books of your missionaries=20
and give us paper for poems to defame you.=20
Take what you do not have=20
and give us what we have.=20
Take the stripes of your flag=20
and give us the stars.=20
Take the Afghani Mujahideen beard=20
and give us Walt Whitman's beard filled with=20
butterflies.=20
Take Saddam Hussein=20
and give us Abraham Lincoln=20
or give us no one.=20

 . .=20
We are not hostages, America=20
and your soldiers are not God's soldiers ...=20
We are the poor ones, ours is the earth of the drowned gods,=20

the gods of bulls=20
the gods of fires=20
the gods of sorrows that intertwine clay and
blood in a song...=20
We are the poor, ours is the god of the poor=20
who emerges out of farmers' ribs=20
hungry=20
and bright,=20
and raises heads up high...=20
America, we are the dead.=20
Let your soldiers come.=20
Whoever kills a man, let him resurrect him.=20
We are the drowned ones, dear lady.=20
We are the drowned.=20
Let the water come.=20

Saadi Youssef

"our thinking"
(based on allen bramhall's "thought process"
which appears at the end of this work)

a slinking toward the wall
toward the wall
toward the wall
toward the wall
the airy lightbulb of regime
of regime
of regime
indeed the war is an idyll
is an idyll
is an idyll
oh that these numbers are all that remain
all that remain
all that remain
too much left out of tribute
out of tribute
out of tribute
how does the diamond remain in the earth
in the earth
in the earth
changes occur, albeit without thought
without thought
without thought
we have drunk of the water
of the water
of the water
of the water
bitter is the brightening of conviction
of conviction
of conviction
squiring neural laity
laity
laity
our thinking has a gash
has a gash
has a gash
has bleeding, has lost a day
lost a day
lost a day
this shoreline seems so far engaged
far engaged
far engaged
far engaged
furtive for your finery but longboats in the distance
in the distance
in the distance
rational excesses hire a drum
hire a drum
hire a drum
hire a drum
something can be changed and enhanced
and enhanced
and enhanced



august highland
04-07-03

=========================
"thought process"
by allen bramhall

as if a brand of thinking, the airy lightbulb of regime, in which
verities are fraught with public perception. indeed the war is an
idyll, furtive for your finery but longboats in the distance. we went
to the water and drank.

it was similar, a rarity, a guiding of news and go between, still
marshy and combined. we couldn't be enclosed with such desperation but
the saving of numbers. oh that these numbers are all that remain.

too much left out of tribute, a slinking toward the wall, away from the
water. this shoreline seems so far engaged, a wall in which we are met
with thought. how does the diamond remain in the earth, frozen
spitefully, after so much time?

changes occur, albeit without thought. news conditions the moment.
there will be no desperation forever. we have drunk of the water.

we feel our weird and wired, that the cage grows more morose with every
bitter year. bitter is the brightening of conviction. something can be
changed and enhanced, squiring neural laity. our thinking has a gash,
has bleeding, has a lost day.

rational excesses hire a drum.

From:         Todd Swift <todd@TODDSWIFT.COM>
Subject:      Open Letter to Poets Against The War - A Challenge to Celebrate
              All Anti-War Poetry Now
Comments: To: "Undisclosed Recipients"@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

{Please Forward Widely - Editor of 100 Poets Against The War calls on Poets
Against The War to make May 1 a day to celebrate all the many peace poetry
collections and campaigns of the last few months}

April 7, 2003

Dear Poets Against The War,

While asking poets and activists to organise readings on your "behalf", buy
your t-shirts, and make donations, in your impressive emails, why do you not
mention the other fine anti-war anthologies (not for profit) currently
available, such as Irish Poets Against The War, A Common Sky (Canada) and
the global, and original poets against the war anthology (from which a good
number of your poems were cc'd, as you may recall), 100 Poets Against The
War?

I applaud the excellent work Poets Against The War has done.  However, you
should recognise that the world-wide poetry protests against US military,
political and (yes, cultural) unilateralism/exceptionalism were not all
hosted in the name of your umbrella organisation, nor to perpetuate one
group at the expense of a greater good.  There has been a more complex,
richer and greater multiplicity of voices and editors - a global grassworks
network - at work - than your monolithic announcements seem to recongnize or
celebrate.

Some history, before your previously-announced "documentary" is completed.
The term "poets against the war" of course is originally from the Vietnam
era.  On January 27, 2003 - after a week of email requests - the first
global anti-war anthology - "100 Poets Against The War" came from
www.nthposition.com; January 28, your organisation put up its poets against
the war website; we were happy to send countless poems your way, and often
received ones people had shared with you as well.

That month, tens of thousands of people downloaded, printed up, and read
from the nthposition books, and staged peace readings world-wide.  Often,
they referred to these events as "poets against the war" events, but read
from our books, or their own poems.  As Poets Against The War time and again
identified these nthposition readings, from Japan to Germany to Ireland, as
solely theirs in press messages, we became bemused, even proud to share the
global stage with such grand friends.

Importantly, for the wider cause of peace protest, all the "against the war"
events, including our ground-breaking ebooks for peace, were widely
reported, globally, on CNN, and in The Times, and Guardian, and on the BBC,
CBC, NPR, and so on.  It did not seem to matter - then - what good people
called it, so long as we all worked for peace.

But since the war began, what should have been unities of purpose have
broken down, as marketing, branding, and personal goals seem to have
obscured a wider, more vital community purpose.  The irony of American peace
protests using rugged-individual, entrepreneurial methods is notable.  This
is not the time or place to indicate exactly how some anti-war poetry
publishers have failed the greater good, or each other, but I shall say that
a Babel was introduced when consensus and co-operation would have been
perhaps more impressive.  In plainer terms: the plot was lost.

While Poets Against The War's efforts have been inspiring - they would be
exponentially more graceful and appropriate, if you actually agreed to
co-ordinate promotion, launch and reading, efforts with the other anti-war
poetry publishers, which I and others have requested on several previous
occasions.  There are poets behind each poem, and these people deserve to
reach the widest audience with their fine message.

I call upon you, Poets Against The War, on your May Day (May 1) day of
international poetry against war, to use your powerful PR machine to mention
and promote the other - indeed all - anti-war poetry anthologies - released
during this fraught period of terrible war.  And to invite poets from these
many other collections to read with you.

I do this in a spirit of camaraderie - knowing as you do, how many unpaid
hours we all put in to this struggle to write, edit, publish and promote,
good poems for a greater cause.  All our poems should be now celebrated and
all our anti-war books known.  Poets Against The War should be big enough to
contain such multitudes, and share credit, where it is due.

best wishes

Todd

ps Thanks to an illegal war fought by the US and UK governments, over 1,200
Iraqi civilians have been murdered since March 20, 2003.  Poetry is not, in
itself, the main message, now.

______________________________________
Todd Swift
www.nthposition.com

Editor
100 Poets Against The War
The Original and Global Poetry Book Against War In Iraq
Published March 3, 2003
Salt, Cambridge, UK

100 Poets Against The War Peace Readings:

From:         Christine Murray <cmurray@UTA.EDU>
Subject:      History as BTW: Quasimodo & "tombs of rubble"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

and from Quasimodo,

19 January 1944

I read you the soft verses of antiquity
and the words, born of the vineyards
and tents on the banks of eastern
rivers--how mournful they fall
and desolate in this profoundest night
of war where no one flies
the sky of the angels of death,
and we hear the wind thunder with ruin
shaking the metal sheets that up here
divide the balconies, and gloom rises
from the dogs howling in gardens
at the rifle shots of patrols
on the empty streets.  Someone is alive.
Someone, perhaps, is alive.  But we, here,
absorbed in listening to the ancient voice
seek for a sign that outreaches life,
earth's dark sorcery
where even among the tombs of rubble
the malign grass rears up its flower.

(trans. Jack Bevan)

Translated reports of russian intelligence from the Iraq region can be found
here:

http://www.aeronautics.ru/

and here

http://www.iraqwar.ru/

At a glance, the reports certainly give a different view of things, free from
hysteria and the information minders of both sides. Certainly, the russians have
a bias - the russian view maybe summed-up by a quote from Kissinger (who was
quoted in today's Guardian) speaking of the Iran-Iraq war, "Ideally we'd like
both sides to lose" - but it's seems to me to be a useful counterweight against
the prevailing mood of the media.

Roger

______________________________________________
Peer Seminars for MSA-5 Birmingham 2003

What is a Peer Seminar?
Seminars are small-group discussion sessions (of no more than 15 people) fo=
r which participants write brief "position papers" that are read and circ=
ulated prior to the conference. Seminars generate lively and valuable exc=
hange during the conference and in some cases have created a network of s=
cholars who have continued to work together. Further, the peer seminar mo=
del allows most conferees to seek financial support from their institutio=
ns as they educate themselves and their colleagues on subjects of mutual =
interest.


Seminar Registration
Deadline for Seminar Registration: 30th May 2003
Individuals may submit a ranked list of three seminars (including the name =
of the seminar leader) in which they would like to participate. Since we =
can accept only a limited number of panel proposals, we encourage all pro=
spective participants to consider joining one of the peer seminars listed=
. Seminar assignments will be made on a first-come, first-served basis; t=
he sooner you submit your selections, the better your chance of receiving=
 your first choice.  The leader of your seminar will contact you in early=
 June with details of how to submit your position paper.=20

The MSA 5 Program will indicate seminars available for auditors.=20

Please email ranked seminar selections and panel proposals to Samantha Skin=
ner at sjskinner@yahoo.com and include summer contact information.

Subject:      Salerno/Hollo read in Boulder April 11
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The Left Hand Reading Series presents:

ANSELM HOLLO & MARK SALERNO
8:00 PM APRIL 11 at the Left Hand Bookstore (1200 Pearl St. #10) in
Boulder.
Free and open to the public.

Mark Salerno earned B.A. and M.A. degrees in English and Comparative
Literature from Columbia University, and an M.F.A. degree in Creative
Writing from Otis College of Art and Design. His poems have appeared in
hundreds of magazines, including Chicago Review, Denver Quarterly,
Skanky Possum, Zyzzyva, sub-TERRAIN (Canada), Jejune (Czech Republic),
Talisman, Explosive, First Intensity and Exquisite Corpse. He is the
author of the full-length books Hate (96 Tears Press, 1995) and Method
(The Figures, 2002), and of the chapbooks For Revery (a+bend press, 200)
and Matters (The Dozens, 2002). Later this year, Red Hen Press will
bring out his new full-length book, So One Could Have. From 1993 to
1999, he edited Arshile: A Magazine of the Arts. He is currently the
reviews editor of The New Review of Literature and the poetry editor of
The Los Angeles Review. He teaches English and Creative Writing at West
Los Angeles College.

Anselm Hollo is the author of 36 books and chapbooks of poetry including
Maya, Sojourner Microcosms, and Pick up the House. Recent books include
Caws and Causeries and Notes on the possibilities and attractions of
existence : selected poems, 1965-2000. His work has been widely
anthologized and he is a recipient of an NEA Fellowship in poetry, two
grants from The Fund for Poetry, and the government of Finland's
Distinguished Foreign Translator's Award. Authors whose works he has
translated include Paul Klee, Bertolt Brecht, and Jean Genet. He is also
a founding member of Boulder's School of Continuation.


For more information call: (303) 443-3685
The Left Hand Reading Series is an independent series presenting
readings of original literary works by emerging and established writers.

From:         Halvard Johnson <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Meanwhile back in Afghanistan . . .
Comments: To: Crew <crewrt-l@interversity.org>,
          Cafe-blue <CAFE-BLUE@wiz.cath.vt.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  Taliban Reviving Structure in Afghanistan
  By KATHY GANNON
  KANDAHAR, Afghanistan (AP) - Before executing the International Red Cross
worker, the Taliban gunmen made a satellite telephone call to their superior
for instructions: Kill him?

  Kill him, the order came back, and Ricardo Munguia, whose body was found
with 20 bullet wounds last month, became the first foreign aid worker to die
in Afghanistan since the Taliban's ouster from power 18 months ago.

  The manner of his death suggests the Taliban is not only determined to
remain a force in this country, but is reorganizing and reviving its command
structure.

  There is little to stop them. The soldiers and police who were supposed to
be the bedrock of a stable postwar Afghanistan have gone unpaid for months
and are drifting away.

  At a time when the United States is promising a reconstructed democratic
postwar Iraq, many Afghans are remembering hearing similar promises not long
ago.

  Instead, what they see is thieving warlords, murder on the roads, and a
resurgence of Taliban vigilantism.

  ``It's like I am seeing the same movie twice and no one is trying to fix
the problem,'' said Ahmed Wali Karzai, the brother of Afghanistan's
president and his representative in southern Kandahar. ``What was promised
to Afghans with the collapse of the Taliban was a new life of hope and
change. But what was delivered? Nothing. Everyone is back in business.''

  Karzai said reconstruction has been painfully slow - a canal repaired, a
piece of city road paved, a small school rebuilt.

  ``There have been no significant changes for people,'' he said. ``People
are tired of seeing small, small projects. I don't know what to say to
people anymore.''

  When the Taliban ruled they forcibly conscripted young men. ``Today I can
say 'we don't take your sons away by force to fight at the front line,'''
Karzai remarked. ``But that's about all I can say.''

  From safe havens in neighboring Pakistan, aided by militant Muslim groups
there, the Taliban launched their revival to coincide with the war in Iraq
and capitalize on Muslim anger over the U.S. invasion, say Afghan officials.

  Karzai said the Taliban are allied with rebel commander Gulbuddin
Hekmatyar, supported by Pakistan and financed by militant Arabs.

  The attacks have targeted foreigners and the threats have been directed
toward Afghans working for international organizations.

  Abdul Salam is a military commander for the government. Last month he was
stopped at a Taliban checkpoint in the Shah Wali Kot district of Kandahar
and became a witness to the killing of Munguia, a 39-year-old water engineer
from El Salvador.

  After stopping Munguia and his three-vehicle convoy, gunmen made a phone
call to Mullah Dadullah, a powerful former Taliban commander who happens to
have an artificial leg provided by the Red Cross.

  Mimicking a telephone receiver by cupping a hand on his ear, Salam
recalled the gunmen's side of the conversation.

  ``I heard him say Mullah Dadullah,'' he said. ``I heard him ask for
instructions.''

  When the conversation ended the Taliban moved quickly, Salam said. They
shoved Munguia behind one of the vehicles, siphoned gasoline from the tanks
and used it to set the vehicles on fire.

  Munguia was standing nearby. One Taliban raised his Kalashnikov rifle and
fired at Manguia.

  Then they told the others: ``You are working with kafirs (unbelievers).
You are slaves of Karzai and Karzai is a slave to America.''

  ``This time we will let you go because you are Afghan,'' Salam remembered
them saying, ``but if we find you again and you are still working for the
government we will kill you.''

  In the latest killing in southern Afghanistan, gunmen on Thursday shot to
death Haji Gilani, a close Karzai ally, in southern Uruzgan province. Gilani
was one of the first people to shelter Karzai when he secretly entered
Afghanistan to foment a rebellion against the Taliban in late 2001.

  International workers in Kandahar don't feel safe anymore and some have
been moved from the Kandahar region to safer areas, said John Oerum,
southwest security officer for the United Nations. But Oerum is trying to
find a way to stay in southern Afghanistan. To abandon it would be to let
the rebel forces win, he says.

  The Red Cross, with 150 foreign workers in Afghanistan, have suspended
operations indefinitely.

  Today most Afghans say their National Army seems a distant dream while the
U.S.-led coalition continues to feed and finance warlords for their help in
hunting for Taliban and al-Qaida fighters.

  Karzai, the president's brother, says: ``We have to pay more attention at
the district level, build the administration. We know who these Taliban are,
but we don't have the people to report them when they return.''

  Khan Mohammed, commander of Kandahar's 2nd Corps, says his soldiers
haven't been paid in seven months, and his fighting force has dwindled. The
Kandahar police chief, Mohammed Akram, said he wants 50 extra police in each
district where the Taliban have a stronghold. But he says his police haven't
been paid in months and hundreds have just gone home.

  ``There is no real administration all over Afghanistan, no army, no
police,'' said Mohammed. ``The people do not want the Taliban, but we have
to unite and build, but we are not.''

Date:         Mon, 7 Apr 2003 13:31:15 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Jonathan Skinner <jskinner@ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Subject:      Robert Kocik Statement
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

A version of this was read at the SUNY at Buffalo Poetics Against the War
Reading (March 5, 2003)

JS

=B3Without doubt it is we, the poets and thinkers, who are to blame for this
bloodbath and who have to atone for it.=B2 (Dadaist artist Hugo Ball)

I call it the OTHER FRONT UNDERFOOT.

I=B9d like to forgo my opinion of this possible war=8Ato take a position
relative to impossible war.

(By not having stopped war from arriving at this brink, poets have already
failed. Have long failed. What recourse within ourselves and our materials
does this compel?

(Now that the potential problem with stopping the war is stopping stopping
war.)

At this point, to protest war is reaction and compulsory. I=B9d call it peace
conscription. A citizen=B9s as distinct from a poet=B9s action.

To instinctively stay within an efficacy particular to the materials of
poetry. The language we=B9d be fighting for peace for.

We don=B9t live in a world where the use of force is unviable. It=B9s chronic.
It=B9s called the war to end war over and over. It may one day be
terminal--the war that ends all. But it can=B9t be made acute=8Blike a fever
that breaks and takes away the sickness  from then on. It=B9s a terminal
condition kept chronic. We can=B9t just, as a species,  get it over with.

Recovering but not cured. Getting hungry again.  Back in the saddle. War is
likely. It=B9s back in vogue. Entertainable. (If not this war then some other
war.)

Is it a law of nature or just a rule of thumb?

Threat of the use of force in order to empower negotiation, is already war.
Poetic failure--specifically because the language of threat is =8Clanguage=B9.
Once the language of threat is unleashed, no poetic operation can
retroactively unengender it.

Once reactionary, it may even be tempting to react further=8Bto subvert
aversion=8Bcome out in favor of war, in the sense of sobering oneself with
reality in an unbiased, disinterested sense=8Bor exuberantly admitting war as
vital, life renewing, as creation=B9s ritual creativity. (Not pro-war in the
narrow, passionate sense of having belligerently taken one=B9s own side=8Bwhich
has nothing to do with artwork.)

As Long As The Body About To Be Blown Up Is Not YOU Or YOURS? Too late for
artwork to take effect. Artwork not a viable last minute strategy.

What would poets place in the world to bring us to the point where we could
even find out if it=B9s possible to live without force? Apparently not poetry=
.

What poem?

Looking as little like a poem as unlike a weapon.

As little like a poem as the language of war it would apply in order to be
preemptive.

Preempt was a poet=B9s word (and is now a Wolfowitz word)=8Ba word poetry could
have given to the populace so that it would be unavailable for military use=
.
Preempt is another word for portend or prophesize=8Bto materialize, which is
to poeticize.

Fighting against has never yet worked.  What I fight against is (explicitly=
)
not that which I fight for. Nor is fighting for what I fight for. It gets
called =8Close/lose=B9. Mutual exclusions.

To fight against is to fight for that which to fight against denies.

To fight for, in the fighting against, is to forfeit that which is fought
for.=20

So, just let roll over me that which would deny the positive goods living
without war would be a matter of?

The positive goods, if provided, would disallow war as well as its verge.
THAT POEM. (How many and of what sort would it take--while conscientiously,
arduously, all-out-resourcefully undertaking it=8Bwhile at peace (as the
Orient goes to the doctor in times of health=8Bthe crisis, calling up our
total reserves, is all=B9s well)--to write, that poem, our rewiring?)

(The Surgeons General admits a great deal is known about sickness while ver=
y
little is known about health. How many pages went into Paradise Lost, and
how few could be provided for Paradise Regained? What about us necessarily
dims at the brink of peace?)

Fighting against, at most, waylays the occasion (the occasion poetry has in
fact forfeited) to implant the moral and vital equivalent de-necessitating
that which is fought against. NOT THAT POEM.

(These words are made of my father=B9s death. He does not have to die on a
battlefield to die in glory or fill me with courage. It would simply be
misplaced, misleading, malicious and maddening to believe so in even the
slightest sense.)

Should poets usurp the means for war=8Bi.e. reason, righteousness, rage,
results; knowing that each mental mode is at base a writing genre. To fight
against fighting, are we repelled by warlike languages while these very
languages have in fact been taken from us in order to wage war=8Blanguages
which now seem nonnative to poetry and naturalized to power and aggression?
All uses of the language belong to poetry because the proper object of
poetry is all of the language=8Ball of the languages within the
language--because language is a property of poetry.

If not, we can no more than plant geraniums in helmets evermore. Way too
post pre emptive. Swords to plowshares re-belligerent.

With our backs to the wall, what=B9s called Comic Warfare is viable. Comic
Warfare is the appropriation of the terms of war toward contrary ends=8Bto
stand people back up. Covert, unidentifiable poetry. Conversion not coercio=
n
of materials.  Overt, disarming poetry.

If poetry has never once kept us from the brink of war, why are we now
concerned with conserving its identity (of conserving our identities) in th=
e
face of war? Is not the face of war occasion to be less concerned than ever
over the conserving of the recognizable poem? If we keep looking strictly a=
t
what poetry has done, war remains inevitable. What it has not done, allows
war to happen. If there were ever a world only poetry could put in place,
war would be no more.

Get out of, not type of genre, but genre itself. Take hold of agency,
office, infrastructure and construction in ways that are not redundant to o=
r
reiterative of power.

Comic Warfare doesn=B9t underdo or undo the controls=8Bit outdoes them,
comically. If, for example,  determinism is killing us, the comic poem coul=
d
extradetermine=8Bone last loop around or lace straight through the =8Cpoint=B9 an=
d
it is outdone. So overfacilitate the fraud of the ineluctability of
force=8Bthat upon its next step it fall flat on its face.

(As in my opening quote by Hugo Ball) even the dastardly, reproachful
language of incrimination and vindication can be applied with considerable
and unexpected poetic efficacy. While blame is the blunt instrument of
belligerence, Ball, by blaming himself and his kin, declares personal and
total empathy with the catastrophe. He calls on blame to make a ludicrous
claim real.)

I=B9m more than ok with that.

How? To overprovide:

how about adding an adversely active attribute to an antagonistic category?
Extemporize predetermination. Alleviate axiomatics. Unbias theophanics.
Experientialize expertise.

Haywire teleology. Contradictory is complimentary . Demilitarize security.
Concretize Wesenschau.

Up the ample: aestheticize ascetics. sediment the transcendent.
Suprasensitize empiricism. Be a munificent, bemuddled mechanist.

Maybe betray your own: actualize inexplicable. Eroticize R&D.

How about disinterested self-help? Rambunctious reductionism?

Or, delve into the extra delectation of overdoing the doubly debunked (a
term discredited inside and outside its field): demonstrably vitalist. Add =
a
negative or double debunk to a double debunk: support dead-beat behaviorism=
.

Although the above operations are stop-gap and not quite occlusive---
belying beatified materiality (globe: as below, so above)--they are
nonetheless solid steps toward fighting neither for nor against. Anything
but perversity for perversity=B9s sake--steps pertaining to the impending
perpetual peace.

(The obvious danger in appropriating the terms of the oppressor=8Bdriving
deeper behind enemy lines to directly undo an unwanted world may distance
artists from =8Cnative=B9 aesthetics of a wanted world (yes, like watching the
domestic budget dwindle). One example that comes to mind=8Bthe NYC-based
artist collective rTmark adopts corporate and free market methodology in
order to sabotage advanced global capitalism. RTmark hijacks corporate and
political identities  in order to snare the unaware. To cite but one
instance=8BrTmark parodies the WTO website by using similar graphic elements
as the official WTO site. The confused guest stumbles upon a directory of
direct action initiatives that challenge the neo-liberal juggernaut. In
another instance, rTmark channeled funds from a military veteran=B9s group to
the Barbie Liberation Organization which used the investment to switch the
voice boxes of  Barbie and G.I. Joe dolls. )

How might poets, with their open identities, remain pertinent between
breakaway utopia and turning into their own antithesis?

Is a poet nothing in particular?  Because a poet is nothing special (last
nonspecialist), something denatured, denurtured, one card not contained in
the deck can be played.
=20
Poets aren=B9t people. Poets may be citizens--but not necessarily people. I
can=B9t do as a citizen what I can only do as a poet. Politicians are
people=8Bthough failed people. Speaking for the people with the voice of the
people is at best, approximate. Switzerland is full of people. A consensus
cult. If I=B9m speaking, as a poet, with the voice of the people=8Bjust how cut
off from my material am I--from the shift only I as non-democracy can
effect. Like the first fool eukaryote that let in an organelle that we migh=
t
one day breathe. As opposite elitist as democratic (the requisite agent).

The problem with the MUST of throwing one=B9s prosdized body before the war
machine=8Alosing limbs with which to perpetually jam up the Great Big Biocide
of which war is a speck and spectacle. (I=B9d call it =8Cgetting Saddam
Lewinskied=B9.

By means of all the possible actions of the poet of unconserved identity=8Bor
even a poem on a piece of paper or a poem read out loud (the point at which
the least a poem can be becomes its most) through Comic Warfare, this time
brought to a fair fight in the fantastic asymmetry of artwork vs. warworld.
(Our publicity will never be as powerful as theirs). The asymmetric strike
is quintessentially (quintessence, another recoverable ordure) poetic=8Bpoeti=
c
scale and odds. A line on a piece of paper up against biocide. Auspicious
enough=8Bthe gross imbalance beckons ungraspable tactics. Impregnable bubble
all around, with a little package delivered directly to the door by one=B9s
own pet. Just a box cutter or the bottom of a shoe will do. As only an act
from an asymmetrician can pose a serious threat to the peerlessly,
imperially empowered.

And provided poets hit their stride in their fight without side, make it
terminal may apply not to people but war.
