From:         Aaron Levy <adlevy@SLOUGHT.ORG>
Organization: Slought Foundation
Subject:      Tonight, 4/10: "Digital Fever" with Dworkin, Goldmsith, Levy,
              Wershler-Henry, Stefans
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

-----Original Message-----
From: Slought Announcements [mailto:info@slought.org]



Please join us at Slought Foundation for:

"Digital Fever: Case Studies in Archiving Art and Poetry"

A Public Conversation with Craig Dworkin, Kenny Goldsmith, Aaron Levy,
Darren Wershler-Henry, and Brian Kim Stefans

Thursday April 10, 2003; 6:30 pm - 8:00 pm

A critically-oriented roundtable on digital media and the future of
archiving, featuring alternating models for poetry and visual media
currently operating online.


Information online: http://slought.org/toc/calendar/display.php?id=1144
This event will be recorded; Event is free to the public.


For more information, contact:

SLOUGHT FOUNDATION
4017 Walnut Street
Philadelphia PA 19104-3513
Ph/fax: 215.746.4239
info@slought.org
http://slought.org/



Biography:

Craig Dworkin edits Eclipse (www.princeton.edu/eclipse) and is the
author of _Reading the Illegible_ (Northwestern U.P.), a critical
investigation of the politics of misuse. Recent articles have appeared
in October, Sagetrieb, and American Letters & Commentary.
_Signature-Effects_, a book of visual poetry, is available from Small
Press Distribution, and _PARSE_ is forthcoming from Atelos Press.
Currently editing the selected poems of Vito Acconci and working on a
book tentatively entitled _Misreading: A User's Manual_, he teaches 20th
and 21st century avant-gardes in the Department of English at Princeton
University.

Kenneth Goldsmith is a poet living in New York City. He is a music
critic for New York Press and a DJ on WFMU. He is founding curator of
Ubu.com

Aaron Levy is Curator and Executive Director of Slought Foundation, an
arts organization, gallery, and archival resource engaging contemporary
life through critical theories about art. His curatorial projects
include ongoing lecture series, conferences, exhibitions, publications
and recordings featuring artists and theorists, also online. As of this
event, 8945 minutes (149 hours) of recorded media are currently
available online in the Slought Foundaton archives at
http://slought.org/

Darren Wershler-Henry, the former senior editor at Coach House
Books/www.chbooks.com, is a writer, critic, and the author of two books
of poetry, _NICHOLODEON: a book of lowerglyphs_, and _the tapeworm
foundry_, shortlisted for the Trillium Prize. Darren is also the
author/co-author of five books about technology and culture, including
_FREE as in speech and beer_ and _Commonspace: Beyond Virtual
Community_. Darren teaches in the school of Communications Studies at
York University.

Brian Kim Stefans runs the media mini-empire www.arras.net, which
includes arras.net, Free Space Comix: The Blog (www.arras.net/weblog)
and Circulars (www.arrras.net/circulars), a multi-author anti-war blog
maintained by poets. He is the author of three books of poetry, most
recently Angry Penguins (Harry Tankoos, 2000). He edits the /ubu series
of poetry ebooks on ubu.com (www.ubu.com/ubu), and his forthcoming book
of essays, Fashionable Noise: On Digital Poetics, will be published by
Atelos in the April 2003. He is a prolific critic and writes for the
Boston Review among other publications. New work, including an
interview, will soon be appearing on the Iowa Review web
(www.uiowa.edu/~iareview/).



----
Slought Foundation encourages new futures for contemporary life through
critical theory and dialogue about art. Our live events, exhibitions and
publications engage alternative curatorial and artistic practices.

8945 minutes (149 hours) of recorded media are currently available
online in the Slought Foundation archives: http://slought.org/

Here is the official, complete, fabulous version of the seven-city
schedule of the first monthly Perpetual Motion Roadshow, this month
starring transtastic troubadour Charlie-girl Anders from Boston/San
Francisco, cute comix artist Marc Ngui from Toronto, and spondaic
spoken-worder Corey Frost from Montreal/NYC, and friends.

All shows will feature great readings, books, music, pictures, funny
voices, and Heimlich demonstrations. We hope to see many of you at one,
some, or all of these events. If you have any troubling thoughts, visit
the PMR website at www.nomediakings.net, or email Corey. Tell us if you
have any road trip advice. Also, check out the Pay Phone Tour Diary on
the website every day during our week of motion.

Day 1: Mon., April 14. Brooklyn. Soft Skull Shortwave Bookstore*, 71
Bond  St., corner of State. 7 pm. Special Guest: Wanda Phipps. It's
FREE.

Day 2: Tues., April 15. Cleveland. Mac's Backs Bookstore, 1820 Coventry
Rd. 7 pm. Special Guest: Wred Fright. It's FREE.

Day 3: Wed., April 16. Cincinatti. Sitwell's Coffee House, 324 Ludlow
Ave. 8 pm. Special Guest: Brian Garry. It's FREE.

Day 4: Thurs., April 17. Chicago. Quimby's Bookstore, 1854 W. North Ave.
8 pm. Special Guests: Emily Vey Duke and Cooper Battersby. It's FREE.

Day 5: Fri., April 18. Toronto. Clinton's Tavern, 693 Bloor St. W. 8 pm.
Special Guest: Novel Amusements. $5 at the door.

Day 6: Sat., April 19. Montreal. Zeke's Gallery, 3955 St. Laurent. 7:30
pm. Special Guest: The World Provider. $Pay what you can.

Day 7: Sun., April 20. Boston. Oni Gallery, 684 Washington St. 8 pm.
Special Guest: Toni Amato. $5 at the door.

Day 8 EXTRA! On Mon., April 21, Marc and Corey will appear with local
performers in Peterborough, Ontario. Cinema 379, 379 George St. N. 8 pm.



*Directions for New Yorkers:
To get to Soft Skull Shortwave: Take the A/C/G to Hoyt-Schemerhorn. Walk
1 block east on Schemerhorn to Bond Street. Make a right on Bond and go
1 block to State Street. OR Take the F to Bergen Street. Walk 2 blocks
east on Bergen to Bond Street. Make a left on Bond and go 4 blocks to
State.

--
Corey Frost
cfrost@gc.cuny.edu

Date:         Thu, 10 Apr 2003 19:12:44 +0100
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         wildhoney <poetry@WILDHONEYPRESS.COM>
Subject:      Byrne review
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

The following review appears in the latest edition of the Burning Bush, ed.
Michael Begnal, 3 Newcastle Road, Galway, Ireland.

Mairéad Byrne, Nelson & the Huruburu Bird (Wild Honey Press), reviewed by
Michael S. Begnal

A back cover blurb by one Alan Dugan succinctly describes this collection
"Mairéad Byrne is an Irish poet in America. She's not an immigrant. She's
just here. She writes with love and fury about what's right and wrong about
Ireland, plus some swipes and kisses at America..." Nelson & the Hun~buru
Birds is a compendium of three unpublished full collections, distilled into
one book, which leads me to wonder: If she was going to have a book
published, why not publish one of these collections first, then (hopefully)
release the others succeedingly in due course? Are these simply the best
poems from each of the three, or were they chosen because they were felt to
interact with each other in some particular way? Minor points, to be sure,
but it did make me curious about where Byrne sees this volume in the scheme
of her overall work.
 But whatever about that Nelson & the Huruburu Birds is a pretty damn good
book in itself. It is more immediately accessible than many readers of the
Wild Honey imprint will be used to. In a way I missed having to struggle
with the intricate texts of Healy or Scully, but at the same time it was
nice to be able to relax a bit and simply soak up the lush imagery and the
idiosyncratically observed details of life and memory. "Lying Awake with the
Windows Open" is a perfect example of what Byrne is capable of: "I heard
shiny green / leaves load with raindrops and spill. / I beard the town
grumble deep in its throat. / I heard darkness congregating in clumps / like
infantry at ease, the nervous gear- / shifts of drivers circling for
cigarettes." Elsewhere, in "The Pools," the darkness is described thusly "I
am talking about dusk, / how it bit like ink into blotting
paper; / night was a big soaked wad. / It was spongy as that. / I could chew
it." Yeah!
 A lot of Irish people, understandably, know America only through the medium
of television or film, even though Saint Brendan is rumoured to have
discovered the place. Byrne's "The Irish Discover America" captures that
moment of arriving, the juxtaposition of reality and media image: 'We hit
land and suddenly / everyone has an American accent. / How did I get here? /
I traveled the few inches, thousands of miles, / in my own skin boat, my
currach, my Boeing. / For the first time I look at the outside world." A
very Irish feeling, I think, finds expression in "Commercial Street": "This
is not home and I don't have to stop / to pass the time of day or night with
you / or anyone. I'm free of that, home too..."
Ireland does figure prominently here, however, in childhood reminiscences
like "Cycling to Marino," or in the "found poem" "Briathra Comónta sa
Teanga/ Common Verbs in the Language" (says the note: "I found this partial
list of Irish language verbs on a table in the staff smoking room in Newpark
Comprehensive School, Dublin..."). (Byrne is quite fond of found poems,
including several others such as a page from a Christie's catalogue, and
screen directions from John Huston's film script for The Dead.) But her most
sustained and penetrating view of Ireland is in "The Pillar," a long major
poem that was previously published by Wild Honey as its own pamphlet. Sizing
up Ireland's post-colonial complexes back through young eyes of 1966, the
year Nelson's Pillar was blown up by the IRA, Byrne gives us a revealing
portrait of a country bogged down in its own history-. "The Pillar had shot
its wad / and we stood in its spume / knee-deep in rubble / not knowing to
take credit or what."
The latter section of Nelson & the Huruburu Birds is wet with streams of
consciousness, and I was occasionally reminded of the early Ferlinghetti.
This is a great book from a poet whose primary talent is description, and
the ability to paint, in 'words, the everyday revelations that lay people
are often immune to.

(?12.95/$12.95/£8.9, Wild Honey Press, 16a Ballyman Road, Bray, Co.
Wick-low, Ireland / www.wildhoneypress.com)

Announcing:

Joel Schlemowitz and His Grand Magic Lantern Exhibition!

Including cinepaintings and other film installation pieces, and a
multi-projection environment of seven 16mm film loop projectors, seven
mirror-balls, gilt-edged projection screens, and a series of frenetic
film loops with images from 19th Century magic lantern slides.

The Courthouse Gallery
Anthology film Archives
2nd Avenue and East 2nd Street, NYC
April 11 - 19
Hours: 6pm-9pm

Artist's Reception 6pm, Friday Aprill 11


And

The Perpetual Motion Roadshow an Indie Press Tour Circuit with monthly
stops in Toronto, Montreal, Boston, Brooklyn, Cleveland, Cincinnati &
Chicago.

...FEATURING...lively performances by

lazy Crossdresser Charlie-GIRL Anders from Boston!

Crafty CARTOONIST Marc Ngui from Toronto!

anti-travel travelwriter Corey Frost from NYC & MONTREAL!

And as if that wasn't enough NYC's marvelous & mellifluous Wanda Phipps

Shortwave Bookstore
Mon. April 14, 7pm
(71 Bond Street--take A or C Train to Hoyt/Schermerhorn, Downtown Brooklyn)

It’s Free. OUR GUARaNTEE: No Boring Readings or your Money Back!

Listen to their tour diary at www.NoMediaKings.net!

Marc Ngui is cartoonist/amateur diagrammatician currently hacking it out
in the professionaljungles of Toronto. He's been making zines since his
teens,these being mostly self-published under the Bumblenut Pictures
imprint. Marc willattempt to bring to life the endearingly demented
little world of his graphic novel Enter avariz using various biological
and electro-mechanical devices. (http://www.bumblenut.com)

Charlie Anders makes way more sense if you listen to the director's
commentary instead of the main audio track. Her writing has appeared in
Salon.com, the SF Bay Guardian, Anything That Moves and dozens of other
magazines, anthologies and ransom notes. She's the author of the Lazy
Crossdresser,a style manual and manifesto for slack trannies,and
co-publisher of other magazine,the magazine for people who defy
categories.Charlie will be ranting,reading short stories,gender-busting
and possibly singing. (http://www.charlie-girl.com)

Corey Frost is the author of My Own Devices,a book of stories about
traveling as yourself, as well as several chapbooks, such as Tonight
You'll Have a Filthy Dream and I Feel Perfectly Fine. If people often
refer to him as a poet, it is because of his widely-appreciated spoken
word performances using music and images. He will be performing
selections from his CD,Bits World: Exciting Version, including a story
about the ethical dimension of eating a Plum.
(http://www.attcanada.ca/~coreyf)

The Perpetual Motion Roadshow runs entirely on volunteer power. Those
who like their culture free of that oily corporate taste are invited to
get involved. To keep it going, we need a supply of AGENTS in each of
the cities, VENUES to rock, and CREWMEMBERS to go on tour IN future
Roadshows. Sign up and find out more at www.NoMediaKings.net

--
Wanda Phipps

http://users.rcn.com/wanda.interport

poetry, music and more!

From:         Halvard Johnson <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      "Irregular Verbs Used Against Iraqi Positions"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Irregular Verbs Used Against Iraqi Positions

Torrents of verbs flow into and out of Kuwait City, out of Doha
in Qatar, out of the Pentagon, out of Whitehall. Regular air and

ground verbs, such as target, bomb, destroy, fly over the arid stretches
of Iraqi desert to find their marks in Basra, in Mosul, in Baghdad.

The irregular verbs are shot through with patterns: blow-blew, throw-threw.
Not that we'd expect any less from a laundry list of arbitrary items.

However, the terrorizing, indiscriminate, experimental, and often long-
lasting nature of these verbs make for horrible and illegal battle tactics,

while not causing as many civilian casualties as do regular verbs, with or
without their participles dangling or infinitives spit out there in broad desert

daylight, for all to see, by rockets' loud blare, without night-
vision goggles, even.


[with a little help from texts by Simon Helweg-Larsen and Steven Pinker]



Hal

Halvard Johnson

email: halvard@earthlink.net
website: http://home.earthlink.net/~halvard

From:         Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Adams dishes Pulitzer / Muldoon
In-Reply-To:  <000201c2fed3$d0052d70$c6f5f343@Dell>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Peter Davison's review of Muldoon is perhaps worth looking at too, albeit
for a different reason.  Beneath Davison's cloying praise for Muldoon as a
clever, "fun" writer there is the suggestion that his poems are basically
nonsense verses without any real emotion or force.  This judgment is one
that I think many people make about Muldoon, and it seems related to
judgments (or  resentments) that have been directed at quite different
poets such as Merrill, Ashbery, Heather McHugh, among others.  Basically,
the judgment is that these are technically brilliant writers who have
wasted their gifts in stupid, narcissistic play.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/13/books/review/13DAVISOT.html?ex=1050120000&en=b
8371cbaa0e5f633&ei=5070

One contemporary poetic ideal -- with champions in every camp -- seems to
be a verbal dexterity so adroit and dazzling that it can dance over all the
embarrassing and banal reasons why people actually read literature in the
first place.  Academics have worked out a professional discourse that
avoids all these topics (while pretending to explain everything).  It would
be encouraging if poets weren't so eager to follow suit.

I'm reminded again that one of the great things about Creeley is that he is
willing to take the risk of writing about dangerously commonplace or banal
subject matter, emotions, situations, etc.

Andy Rathmann



Adams: "most if not all of these genuinely creative spirits have been
passed over year after year, often in favor of --> ACADEMY <-- composers
who have won a disproportionate number of prizes."

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/09/arts/music/09ADAM.html

From:         JT Chan <chan_jt@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Centrality
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Centrality


six breaths
per minute

necking
verticality

I outdo
the bridge-

guised
lie


I have been avoiding horizontal connection, affinity for one heady mix to
another.

You, who were there, are still there.
I, who was here, am straining to see, finally on the ground.


-Jill Chan

I sent this message to the list of all City Council members with email,
printed below (Feel free to use the list!!!):

Dear City Council Representative,

This morning I was a "media person" for the protest against the Carlyle
Group -- the multi-billion dollar corporation headed by former Secretary of
Defense Frank Carlucci, and board members George H.W. Bush, James Baker and
other power-packed war profiteers.

I was appalled at the aggressive tactics of the NYPD, and I am writing to
request three things:

1) That you immediately call 1 Police Plaza and let them know that you want
all the arrestees released immediately;

2) That you again hold hearings on the ongoing pattern of police harassment
of antiwar activists  in this case, many who were intentionally standing
across the street and away from the site of the planned civil disobedience
to avoid confusion and arrest.

3) That police commissioner Ray Kelly be subpoenaed to testify at the
hearings.

Below is an accurate story posted to IndyMedia. Please note that some of
those who were manhandled and arrested for WATCHING the protest from across
the street are in their late 70s and already have severe health issues;
others who were on their way to work; and still others who were doing media
interviews at the time they were arrested!

On behalf of the NY State Greens/Green Party of NY, and on behalf of our
members (and everyone else) who was victimized by the police this morning,
I urge you to take action to preserve civil liberties in our City, and make
absolutely clear that abuse by police will not be tolerated.

Thank you,
Mitchel Cohen
Brooklyn Greens / Green Party of NY

Jonathon:

thank you, thank you, thank you!!!

I'm not going to reproduce the whole thing here,
but if you're reading this and you haven't seen
jonathon's post, please scroll down to find it.

the pieces included here articulate exactly not
only the ultimate good of nader's campaign, if
taken in the context of the entire progressive
movement, but also the short-sightedness, some
might even say brain-washedness, of those on the
left who continue to chastise nader for running at
all. that stumblebum al gore managed to squander a
huge lead (which, remember, was in the double
digits as late as august 2000) in the polls and
then bungle the p.r. campaign in florida should
not be laid at nader's door.

third party candidates have ALWAYS been about
raising issues that the big parties don't want to
talk about. if there is ANY HOPE at all of
breaking the corporate-military stranglehold on
power in this country and establishing a real
grass-roots power base, it lies not with the dems
but with local campaigns and third-party
candidates. far from continuing to flagellate
itself for nader's run, the left ought to be
threatening the dems with another vote-draining
campaign, if that's what it takes to get them to
come to the table and bring them back to their
traditional core constituency -- the poor, the
working class, the immigrants, etc.

DH

Phenomenology of commencing - gloss on Chuang Tzu vi\8


Nan (south)
 bo (lord, chief)
 Tzu
 [ ] -k'uei said (asked) .  . alone
where did you
read as spontaneous
?
 [ ]
 hear
 this
 ?

said
heard
all (various)
duplicate, copy
 black ink (inkstone)
read as:
filiations of inscription, what is taken down, formulated, given form,
produced and disseminated: the articulation of learning, in the sense
of armature from origin or commencement (see sending). of hand-craft
as well the material which is passed on. duplicate: to assert.
 from child
 , duplicate
 black
ink
 from
 son
 heard
 obvious
 chant, recitation
read as: the chant or recitation is the first form, aurality not yet
codified. we're moving temporally in reverse; inscription is after
the fact.
 from

grandchild
 , obvious
 chant
 grandchild (son)
 heard
 it from

read as: the filiation son/grandson ends at this point; lineage begins
at this point, tendrils above. so that kinship is a matter/manner of
chanting and recitation, a manner of inking and inscription.
appearance (sight)
 bright
 , appearance
read as vision or impression (bright appearance)
read as sight or view
read as: the first enunciation of form, an appearance both particulate
and blinding.
 bright
 heard
 it from

whispered
 approval
read as hearing and listening
read as: the murmuring of the world, the mumbling or ululation within
the chora or receptacle - the seething or fractal liquidity of the
real. whispered approval tends to inundate bright appearance, the
gathering of materia dejecta into the beginnings of identity, form,
structure, culture, language.
 , whispered
 approval
 heard
 it from
 needing
 service
read as distinguish, express
read as confirm the practice of reality
read as approach the real, practice
 , needing
 service (military)
read as aid or help
read as: primordial intentionality, teleology, tropism, waiting.
 heard
 it from
 here

extolling
 , here
 extolling
read as chanting or singing together, in
read as: primordial sound, plasma, a1-supernova, universal chaos
tending towards coherency. we are approaching the bottom from
the top, tending towards incoherency, the mystery or existential
problematic.
 heard
 it from
 mysterious (occult)

darkness
read as gloomy, dim, sullen, murky, obscure
read as: darkness of darkness of no light no image, darkness of
darkness of no form of no form. of no formlessness of no
formlessness. darkness out of which nothing emerges, nothing
withdraws. the same which is close to but not identical to the
emissions from the bottom, the originary flux, the non-identical
flux, the flux of no-identity of no-identity. but also of gloom,
of universal dark energy expansion, of defuge, of exhaustion,
of catatonia, tending towards psychosis above.
 , mysterious
 darkness
 heard
 it from
 empty

read as emptiness, vacant, unoccupied
read as entering, taking part in
read as: taking part in emptiness, joining the unoccupied. darkness
above is already an occupation, here of absence, absenting here,
the writing or inscription, taking part in, not occupying, not
there, almost as if the symbol were in someone's mind. as if there
were someone.
 goings
 ,
empty
read as: we have to start somewhere.
 goings
 heard
 it from
 doubtful
read uncertain
 commencing (beginning)
read as beginning, origin, source
read as: we have to begin somewhere.
read as: read up through this sequence towards the symbol. for
the symbol emerges as culture emerges, defines and constructs
space. propositional logic is based on shaky foundation of flux
and obscurity; in the dark, identity and equivalence are identical
and equivalent. as one escapes, the origin disappears, becomes
problematic, is deferred. as one escapes, the origin is annihilated.
culture is entropic in its very foundation, noisy in its axiomatics,
asservations. what is gained is always on the back of chaos; what is
spoken, must be whispered; it is the murmur that is whispered.
nothing and everything is built within the murmur, speaking it
louder, crushing its voice. the throat of the world is its silencing.
.

From:         Pierre Joris <joris@ALBANY.EDU>
Subject:      Police Stop Collecting Data on Protesters' Politics
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304101823140.12025-100000@ganymede.pcglabs.mun.ca>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=WINDOWS-1252; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v551)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

New York Times
April 10, 2003

Police Stop Collecting Data on Protesters' Politics

By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

  hen a series of large antiwar protests began nearly eight weeks ago,=20=

the New York Police Department started questioning hundreds of people=20
arrested at the demonstrations about their prior political activity and=20=

recording the information in a database.



  But yesterday, after the practice came to light, the Police Department=20=

said it would destroy the database, created with a debriefing form, and=20=

largely abandon the initiative, which civil libertarians and=20
constitutional law experts said was deeply troubling.



  "After a review, the department has decided to eliminate the use of=20
the Demonstration Debriefing Form," Michael O'Looney, the department's=20=

chief spokesman, said in a statement. "Arrestees will no longer be=20
asked questions pertaining to prior demonstration history, or school=20
name. All information gathered since the form's inception on Feb. 15=20
has been destroyed."



  Several constitutional scholars and civil libertarians said that the=20=

practice raised grave questions about whether asking people about their=20=

political affiliations or activity would have a severe chilling effect=20=

on protest and speech that are protected by the First Amendment.



  Central to the practice was the debriefing form, which detectives used=20=

to record where the arrested protesters went to school, their=20
membership in any organizations and their involvement in past protests.



  Mr. O'Looney said Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and his deputy=20=

commissioner for intelligence, David Cohen, a former top Central=20
Intelligence Agency official, did not know the debriefing form was in=20
use. Mr. Cohen oversees the Intelligence Division detectives who=20
conducted the questioning sessions at 1 Police Plaza as the protesters=20=

waited for their arrests to be processed.



  "When it was brought to their attention," Mr. O'Looney said, "they=20
took a look at it, decided some of those questions were not critical to=20=

our needs and decided to end its use."



  He would not comment on the constitutional issues raised by the=20
questions or say who had developed the form. Mr. O'Looney said that no=20=

disciplinary action was being contemplated against those responsible=20
for developing the practice.



  The police practice came to light after the New York Civil Liberties=20=

Union, which had notified protest organizers that it was seeking=20
reports of possible police abuse or interference at the city's first=20
large antiwar protest on Feb. 15, received hundreds of e-mail messages,=20=

said Christopher Dunn, the group's associate legal director. More than=20=

a dozen of the messages included accounts of arrested demonstrators'=20
being questioned about their political activity, Mr. Dunn said.



  The group later obtained a copy of the debriefing form from lawyers=20
who had sought to represent some of the demonstrators taken to 1 Police=20=

Plaza for questioning after protests on Feb. 15 and March 22, Mr. Dunn=20=

said. Those lawyers were in most cases denied access to the arrested=20
protesters, raising additional concerns about the protesters' right to=20=

counsel, Mr. Dunn said.



  The Civil Liberties Union sent a letter to Mr. Kelly on Tuesday=20
complaining that the information sought during the questioning was=20
constitutionally protected, and called on him to halt the practice. The=20=

letter cited the group's concern that the department had "embarked upon=20=

a concerted campaign to collect information about lawful First=20
Amendment activity" and was "using the coercive environment of an=20
arrest interrogation to obtain that information outside the presence of=20=

counsel."



  Yesterday, after a reporter inquired about the questioning and the=20
commissioner's response to the letter, Mr. O'Looney said Mr. Kelly had=20=

halted the practice, but would not elaborate on how it had begun.



  Mr. O'Looney said that the department would continue to ask arrested=20=

protesters what groups they were affiliated with and would retain the=20
information in the form of a tally, but not with individuals' names. He=20=

said that knowing how many people had been arrested from particular=20
groups would help the department assign the right number of officers to=20=

future protests by the same groups.



  He also said that because the department viewed the questioning of the=20=

arrested demonstrators as "debriefings" rather than "interrogations,"=20
they were not entitled to a lawyer, a position with which Mr. Dunn and=20=

other civil liberties lawyers vehemently disagreed.



  Donna Lieberman, the Civil Liberties Union's executive director, said=20=

the group was pleased that the department had reversed what she called=20=

an ill-conceived policy. "This is a practice that never should have=20
happened and raised serious First Amendment concerns," she said. "But=20
the good news is that the city had second thoughts about it in response=20=

to our objections."



  The disclosure of the practice and the department's decision to halt=20=

it came just two weeks after a federal judge relaxed guidelines that=20
for nearly 20 years had limited police surveillance and investigation=20
of political groups. The guidelines, which are known as the Handschu=20
Agreement, were put in place as a result of a class action lawsuit=20
brought in 1971 on behalf of people who felt threatened by police=20
surveillance of political activities in the late 1960's and early=20
1970's. They required the department to seek approval of a special=20
panel to investigate political groups or activities.



  The judge, Charles S. Haight of Federal District Court in Manhattan,=20=

eased the limits after the police sought greater latitude to conduct=20
terrorism investigations. The lawsuit stemmed from the activities of=20
the Intelligence Division, the same unit responsible for the=20
questioning.



  Jethro M. Eisenstein, one of the lawyers who handled the case that led=20=

to the limits and recently argued before Judge Haight against their=20
loosening, contended yesterday that the questioning =97 some of which=20
occurred before the guidelines were changed on March 25 =97 violated the=20=

earlier limits and might also have violated the new guidelines. Mr.=20
O'Looney said the department took the position that questioning=20
violated neither set of guidelines.



  Intelligence gathering in all its forms, whether surveillance of=20
mosques or keeping track of homeless people, has become more widespread=20=

in American policing since Sept. 11, 2001. But the practice has raised=20=

new questions for a society founded on the principles of individual=20
freedoms.



  While such practices seem threatening to some people, others are more=20=

willing to cede some rights in the pursuit of greater security. But one=20=

of the protesters who was arrested on Feb. 15 and questioned about his=20=

political affiliations and past protesting felt otherwise.



  "I was very concerned," said Brendan Knowlton, 26, a computer=20
programmer who was arrested as he was trying to reach the protest that=20=

day on First Avenue. "I felt that the cops were on a fishing=20
expedition," he said. "The whole thing felt sketchy. It felt=20
inappropriate and irrelevant for why we were actually there."

From:         Jane Sprague <janesprague@CLARITYCONNECT.COM>

West  End Reading Series

KAZIM ALI
NADA GORDON
and GARY SULLIVAN

will read from their work @
Gimme! Coffee, 506 West State Street, Ithaca NY
Saturday, 4/19/03 at 7pm.
This event is free and open to everyone.


Gary Sullivan is the author of Dead Man, (Meow Press, 1996)
How to Proceed in the Arts, (Faux Press, 2001) and (with Nada Gordon)
Swoon, (Granary Books, 2001.) His poetry, plays, criticism and cartoons =
have
appeared in print and on the web in dozens of publications, including: =
Avec, Chain, City
Pages, Combo, Jacket, the L.A. Weekly, Publishers Weekly, Rain Taxi, the
S.F. Weekly, Shampoo, Talisman, and Vert. He edited the online zine =
Readme
(1999-2001) and currently co-edits the Poetry Project Newsletter with =
Nada
Gordon. In 2002 he co-curated the Segue Series at Bowery Poetry Club =
with
Brian Kim Stefans. His artwork appears in books by Nada Gordon and Susan
Landers.

Nada Gordon's latest book, V. IMP (Faux Press
2003), has been described as "mood-riddled hijinx and impudent lyric
protest" and "nonsense galore, as in a bathhouse." With Gary
Sullivan, she is the author of Swoon (Granary Books 2001), a
nonfiction e-pistolary multiform  novel.  She published two other
books in 2001:  Are Not Our Lowing Heifers Sleeker than Night Swollen
Mushrooms? (Spuyten Duyvil), and Foriegnn Bodie (Detour), a
collection of poems written during her eleven years in Tokyo. With
Gary Sullivan, she edits the Poetry Project Newsletter.  Ongoing
obsessions include song, odalisques, ornament, and all forms of life.
Her more-or-less daily musings on life and poetics can be found at
http://ululate.blogspot.com.


Kazim Ali is a poet, painter, and performance artist
living in the Hudson Valley. His recent work has
appeared in Quarter After Eight, Hayden's Ferry
Review, Washington Square, and Xcp. He is a member of
the Cocoon Theater Modern Dance Company, and on the
faculty of the Culinary Institute of America.

Amazing or not??!! I find this pretty(!) upsetting. S
___________

Student poets victimised for anti-war stance

NEW MEXICO, USA - On March 17, the day of US President George Bush's
televised announcement of the imminent US military attack on Iraq, Green
Left Weekly writer Bill Nevins was suspended from his teaching job at
Rio
Rancho New Mexico public high school. The student Poetry Slam Team/Write
Club, which Nevins organises and sponsors, was also barred from
performing
their outspoken words in public. This took place after an anti-war poem
written by a Rio Rancho New Mexico poetry team member read out a poem
over
the in-school closed circuit TV system. Following the reading, the
student's
parent (also a teacher at the school) was ordered by an assistant
principal
to go home and search the student's room for a print copy of the poem.
The
parent declined to do so. All members of the poetry team were
individually
interrogated by the school administration. The charge against Nevins is
that
he permitted students to perform at public poetry readings without
approved
``field trip'' forms being on file. Nevins is fighting the suspension
with
the strong support of the New Mexico teachers' union. The Slam
Team/Write
Club has achieved local fame for the courageous way that multicultural
youth
from the school and the community had put their words of anger and
protest
into fine-crafted poetry. They have delivered these bursts of truth on
local
television, in print and at frequent poetry open mikes throughout
central
New Mexico. The team was planning to appear at the Taos State Wide Youth
Poetry Slam on March 21 but was told by the Rio Rancho High School
administration on March 17 that they may be barred from going there by
the
school. Several students vowed to go to Taos anyway and to speak out
there
against repression in the USA, denial of free speech at their school and
the
suspension of Nevins. GLW readers are asked to send protest letters to
New
Mexico governor Bill Richardson from his web site at
http://www.governor.state.nm.us

Below is the poem that was read out:



Revolution X

Bush said no child would be left behind

And yet kids from inner-city schools

Work on Central Avenue

Jingling cans that read

Please sir, may I have some more?

They hand out diplomas like toilet paper

And lower school standards

Because

Underpaid, unrespected teachers

Are afraid of losing their jobs

Funded by the standardised tests

That shows our competency

When I'm in detox.

This is the Land of the Free ...

Where the statute of limitations for rape is only five damn years!

And immigrants can't run for President.

Where Muslims are hunted because

Some suicidal men decided they didn't like

Our arrogant bid for modern imperialism.

This is the Land of the Free ...

You drive by a car whose

Bumper screams

God bless America!

Well, you can scratch out the B

And make it Godless

Because God left this country a long time ago.

The founding fathers made this nation

On a dream and now

Freedom of Speech

Lets Nazis burn crosses, but

Calls police to

Gay pride parades.

We somehow

Can afford war with Iraq

But we can't afford to pay the teachers

Who educate the young who hold the guns

Against the "Axis of Evil"

Land of the Free ...

This is the land

If you're politically assertive

They call you a traitor and

Damn you to ostracism.

Say good-bye to Johnny Walker Lindh

And his family.

Bye Bye.

American Pie.

So maybe

My ideas about this nation

Don't resolve around perfection

But at least I know

Education is more important

Than money.

Land of the Free . . .

If this was utopia

We'd have to see each other naked

Before we got married

But instead, we see each other naked all the time

Because the government has my social security number

And the name of my dog!

And then we make babies,

But don't worry, they won't be left behind

And they grow up saying

God bless America!

But they don't know who Bush is

Because they never learned the Presidents.

And they will ride the ship Amistad

To our dreamland shores

Bearing the same shackles as us.

I'm here to say that

Generation X

Is pissed and we are taking over,

Ripping down the American illusion of perfection

We are the future generation

I have my qualifications

I know it looks like Angel Soft paper,

But don't worry

It's a diploma

Do I look qualified?

You can take our toilet paper,

But you can't take our Revolution.



>From Green Left Weekly, March 26, 2003.

Subject:      an optimistic perspective
Comments: To: oconn001@umn.edu, francobe@aol.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

  WAGING WAR OR PEACE?
>
Dr. Robert Muller, former assistant secretary general of the United
Nations, now Chancellor emeritus of the University of Peace in Costa
Rica was one of the people who witnessed the founding of the U.N. and
has worked in support of or inside the U.N. ever since.
>
Recently he was in San Francisco to be honored for his service to the
world through the U.N. and through his writings and teachings for
peace. At age eighty, Dr. Muller surprised, even stunned, many in the
audience that day with his most positive assessment of where the
world stands now regarding war and peace.

"I'm so honored to be here. I'm so honored to be alive at such a miraculous
time in history. I'm so moved by what's going on in our world today.
Never before in the history of the world has there been a global,
visible, public, viable, open dialogue and conversation about the
very legitimacy of war. The whole world is in now having this
critical and historic Dialogue -- listening to all kinds of points of
view and positions about going to war or not going to war. In a huge
global public conversation the world is asking -
>
>  'Is war legitimate?
>  Is it illegitimate?
>  Is there enough evidence to warrant an attack?
>  Is there not enough evidence to warrant an attack?
>  What will be the consequences?
>  The costs?
>  What will happen after a war?
>  How will this set off other conflicts?
>  What might be peaceful alternatives?
>  What kind of negotiations are we not thinking of?
>  What are the real intentions for declaring war?'
>
"We are not at war. We, the world community, are WAGING peace. We're in
peacetime. Yes, troops are being moved. Yes, warheads are being lined
up. Yes, the aggressor is angry and upset and spending a billion
dollars a day preparing to attack. In the process, he pointed out,
new alliances are being formed. Russia and China on the same side of
an issue is an unprecedented outcome. France and Germany working
together to wake up the world to a new way of seeing the situation.
The largest peace demonstrations in the history of the world are
taking place! Most peace demonstrations in recent history took place
when a war was already waging, sometimes for years, as in the case of
Vietnam.
>
"So this is a miracle. This is what 'waging peace' looks like."

Through these global peace-waging efforts, the leaders of that nation
are being engaged in further public dialogue, forcing them to
rethink, and allowing all nations to participate in the serious and
horrific decision to go to war or not.
>
Dr. Muller also made reference to a recent New York Times article
that pointed out that up until now there has been just one super -
power - the United States, and that that has created a kind of
blindness in the vision of the U.S. But now, Dr. Muller asserts,
there are two superpowers: the United States and the merging, surging
voice of the people of the world.

--

Date:         Fri, 11 Apr 2003 10:43:22 -0400

From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      dancing over reasons
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Andy Rathmann writes:  One contemporary poetic ideal -- with champions in
every camp -- seems to be a verbal dexterity so adroit and dazzling that
it can dance over all the embarrassing and banal reasons why people
actually read literature in the first place.  Academics have worked out a
professional discourse that avoids all these topics (while pretending to
explain everything).  It would be encouraging if poets weren't so eager to
follow suit.

I respond: It would be encouraging if critics actually read and attended
to the work they allege to discuss. Muldoon's work is rife, is infested in
fact, with elegy, astonishment, elation, and cool. I can't speak to
whether James Merrill or Heather McHugh are innocent of revealing their
feelings, but for god's sake, anybody who claims Ashbery wasted his gifts
in "stupid, narcissistic play" is ignorant of Ashbery's work from Rivers
and Mountains through Three Poems. David Shapiro is for me the ultimate
example of a poet whose continual insistence on pathos is mistaken for
playfulness; other examples might include Chris Stroffolino, Lee Ann
Brown, or Lisa Jarnot.

I admit I stop reading critics who use the word "stupid."
=========================================================================

From:         "K.Angelo Hehir" <khehir@CS.MUN.CA>
Subject:      A.Word.A.Day--concrete poetry
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

concrete poetry (KON-kreet PO-i-tree, kon-KREET -) noun

   Poetry that employs physical arrangement of words or letters on a page
   for visual effect to add to the meaning of the poem.

[From either Portuguese poesia concreta or German konkrete Dichtung.]

  "He (Bob Cobbing) was drawn to concrete poetry's ability to operate on the
   margins of language."
   Bob Cobbing (obituary); The Times (London, UK); Nov 7, 2002.

   "The main work is a series of three dozen extraordinary fabric collages,
   or miniquilts, stitched from clothing labels. Ms. (Berty) Skuber began
   by using labels from her own clothes, but most have been contributed by
   friends and strangers around the world who heard about her project. It
   is both an international collaboration and a labor-intensive species
   of concrete poetry, minutely composed but random, personal but
   unsentimental."
   Art Guide; The New York Times; Nov 1, 2002.

   Examples of concrete poetry:
   http://www.gardendigest.com/concrete/cvpindex.htm

failure...

hey, it's ok with me if you want to go 3rd party to alter the
democratic party landscape... i mean, if you're that clear about your
motives, that's well and fine...

but you and i will have substantive disagreement if you tell me that
it's more important to alter the aforesaid landscape regardless
whether the dems are elected or the repubs (unless of course it's a
foregone conclusion that the dems will most certainly lose)...

the next election, like the last, is shaping up, as i see it, to be a
Major Struggle twixt right-wingers and (at best, sadly) centrist
democrats... if these are our choices, i'm not about to put my vote
behind the right-wingers, if even by default, just to push the dems
left... i think my rationale for doing same is pretty clear (if
certainly not crystal clear)... seems to me another 4 years of bush &
co. will put this country, and the globe, more squarely behind the 8
ball than it already is...

and while i'm no prophet of doom, this will mean (at least) an
escalating chance that something even worse may happen to us (locally
and globally) than what's being experienced at present, esp. by the
have nots...

writing contest, "Women's Voices in War Zones"Dear friend,

We are writing to remind you of the May 1, 2003 deadline for our writing
contest, "Women's Voices in War Zones" (see announcement below) and to
ask you to spread the word, especially to people outside the United
States.  We are getting many more entries  from within the U.S. than
from other countries.

No doubt one reason for this is that we can only handle entries
submitted in English.  As a small, struggling, not-for-profit
organization, we simply do not have the resources to accept entries in
other languages, but will try to find a way to do so if we repeat the
contest in the future.

Another possible reason is that our mailing list is concentrated within
the U.S. If you have access to international e-lists, we specially
request you to circulate this notice widely, so that we can broaden the
scope of our conversations on war, terror, and security.

Some writers have misinterpreted our contest rules regarding copyright.
Please note: we will NOT retain exclusive copyright of any essay
submitted to us; entrants are free to use their essays in any form once
the contest is over. We do, however, need to have the right to reprint
these essays in our own media or use them for political or publicity
purposes, without having to contact an author each time. We do not
anticipate reproducing these essays for sale or in any other way
benefiting financially from them. As a writers' group, we are well
aware of the need to respect an author's ownership of her work and
reassure all those interested in the contest that we will not abuse the
copyright requirement.

Thank you for helping Women's WORLD publicize this important opportunity
for women the world over to express their opinions on living in war
zones.


Sincerely,


Meredith Tax



-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
-------

        ANNOUNCING A WRITING CONTEST: WOMEN'S VOICES IN WAR ZONES

Since Sept. 11, 2001 there has been constant public reference to  =
concepts of terror, war, and security, but little debate about their =
meaning, which differs from place to place and person to person.  And =
the voices of women and girls, both within the US and in the rest of the =
world, have been conspicuously absent from the discussion.

To bring forward women's ideas on this subject, and enable them to be =
heard in the public arena, Women's WORLD, a global free speech network =
of feminist writers,  is initiating a writing contest which will be =
co-sponsored by the The Nation Institute, whose mission is to defend =
freedom of expression and strengthen the independent media. The subject =
is Women's Voices in War Zones.

Eligibility:  All women are welcome to participate; age and citizenship =
are no barrier.  We are particularly interested in seeing work from =
writers, activists, students, and immigrants or refugees.

Rules:  Submissions must be previously unpublished personal essays of =
1000 words or less, in English, that address one or more of the =
following questions:

What does the term "war zone"  mean to you?  Do you live in a war zone =
or state of terror?  Is it personal or public?  Who is or are the =
aggressors?  How do you resist?  What keeps you going?  Where does your =
hope or security lie?  How do you imagine bringing this  terror to an =
end?  Does your government or society or family provide you with =
security or is it a source of  your unease?

We will read only one entry per person. =20

All entries must also include either a one page vita with contact =
information, or a short biographical statement with the writer's full =
name and contact information: mailing address, phone or fax numbers, and =
email address. =20
=20
Submissions can be sent by email to the following address: ratna =
@wworld.org; or by fax or post to Women' WORLD, 208 w. 30th St., #901, =
New York NY 10001.  fax 212-947-2973.  Email submissions are preferred.

Deadline:  Submissions must be received by 5 pm (Eastern Standard Time) =
on May 1, 2003.   Winners will be announced in early June.

Prizes:  Prizes will be given to women in three categories: 1) residents =
of the US; 2) residents of other countries; 3) immigrants or refugees in =
any country.

There will be three first prizes of $250, and three second prizes of =
$100.  Winning essays will be published on the The Nation website and =
the websites of Women's WORLD and its affiliates; announced to the =
press; and circulated to global email lists.

Copyright:  By sending us an essay, contestants automatically give =
Women's WORLD the right to publish it in any form and to license others =
to do so, whether or not the essay wins a prize.=20

Judges:  The judges will be Ammiel Alcalay, Paula Giddings and Katha =
Pollitt.


--
Meredith Tax, President
Women's WORLD
208 W. 30th St., #901
New York NY 10001
Tel. 212-947-2915
Fax: 212-947-2973
Email: wworld@igc.org or meredith.tax@verizon.net
http://www.wworld.org

and Nellie Sachs, "But Look":

But look
but look
man breaks out
in the middle of the marketplace
can you hear his pulses beating
and the great city
on rubber tires
girded about his body--
for fate
has muffled
the wheel of time--
lifts itself
on the rhythm of his breathing.

Glassy displays
broken raven-eyes
sparkle
the chimneys fly black flags
at the grave of air

But man
has said *Ah*
and climbs
a straight candle
into the night.

--translated by Matthew Mead and Ruth Mead

Dear List Members:

Apologies for "cross-posting," but in case anyone would like to stop by,
there will be a book launch for

All Poets Welcome: The Lower East Side Poetry Scene in the 1960s
(University of California Press, March 2003)

and

What is Poetry: Conversations with the American Avant-Garde
(Teachers & Writers Collaborative Press, April 2003)

"All Poets..." is a cultural/literary history of the poetry community in
NYC during the 1960s, and features sections on the coffee-house reading
culture (Le Metro, Les Deux Megots, the Poetry Project at St. Mark's
Church), magazines of the era (Ed Sanders' "Fuck You/a magazine of the
arts," Berrigan's "C," Lorenzo Thomas's and David Henderson's "Umbra,"
etc.) and so on. There's a CD with readings by Ceravolo, O'Hara, Notley,
Mayer, Waldman, Warsh, and more.  Books will be available for sale, and
I'll try and get discounted copies.

"What is Poetry" is a selection of interviews I've held with poets over
the years - Ashbery, Creeley, Mayer, Mullen, F. Howe, Jarnot, Lorenzo
Thomas, and more.

The launch is

Monday, April 28th at 7 PM at

5 Union Square West
(between 14th & 15th Streets, above Staples)
7th Floor
New York, NY  10003

as usual with T&W, lots of free grub and drink

From:         Jeffrey Jullich <jeffreyjullich@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      my Neo-Plasticist New York Times front page "war statement"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I've been perplexed lately about where I was and what
I was doing the last time we were bombing Iraq during
the '90-'91 Gulf War.  The only thing I can remember
is the Kuwaiti oil fields being set on fire.

And then, the other night, when I was in a "The
Russians are coming! The Russians are coming!" panic
and trying to photograph all the contents of my
Merzbau to preserve it from duct tape,...

...I came upon these artworks, photographed and
uploaded to

http://neoplasticistnyt.tripod.com/

Thirty-three New York Times front pages from that
period, painted over in Mondrian Neo-Plasticism, with
the gridwork and red/yellow/blue color rectangles
following the layout of the newspaper.

Some are in acrylic; some are in tempera; some of the
Neo-Plasticist white field is gesso.

http://neoplasticistnyt.tripod.com/

"Art is higher than reality, and has no direct
relation to reality. Between the physical sphere and
the ethereal sphere there is a frontier where our
senses stop functioning. Nevertheless, the ether
penetrates the physical sphere and acts upon it. Thus
the spiritual penetrates the real. But for our senses
these are two different things---the spiritual and the
material.  To approach the spiritual in art, one will
make as little use as possible of reality"

-- Piet Mondrian, 1914

http://neoplasticistnyt.tripod.com/

Date:         Fri, 11 Apr 2003 12:58:29 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: dancing over reasons
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.NEB.4.53.0304111035130.2305@panix1.panix.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I'm simply observing that there are poets who everyone agrees are great
talents, "geniuses" even, but who produce works that (everyone also agrees)
are pretty inconsequential.  Isn't that true?

I think this phenomenon of brilliance wedded to inconsequence reflects a
persistent uncertainty about what the ambitions of poets ought to be
(beyond having an academic career, it seems).

As a poet of the 1950s, Ashbery shares with many members of his generation
an extremely modest, self-limiting idea of literary ambition.  In
interviews, he is frank about the ephemerality of his productions.

For Muldoon, poetry writing seems primarily to be a means to demonstrate
skill.  As a formal innovator, I think he goes way beyond what usually
passes for "formal innovation."  Yet how often does he rise above being a
writer of exercises?  (Indeed, how could anyone rise above that level who
publishes as often as he does?)  I wish I could find on-line the
quasi-sestina he published in the New Yorker not long ago, the elegy called
"The Last Time I Saw Chris."  It illustrates what I think is his tendency
to use odd formal structures to compensate for a lack of clear emotional
necessity.

It is strange, this mixture of pretentiousness and happy triviality that
characterizes contemporary poetics, and also strange that one often seems
to open the door for the other: a happily inconsequential poet and
journalist like Ashbery opens the door for a school of academic Marxists
dedicated to smashing subjectivity, who in turn open the door for the next
group.  It's as if no one can find the right scale.

Andy

the first to call the cops if a homeless person camped out on
their doorstep.

Nader and ESPECIALLY La Duke never ever made such people comfortable,
mainly because they spoke quite freely about the unfair distribution
of wealth in this country, and about HOW to make it a little fairer.

Hell on Earth created by American corporate interests, made possible

scraping a living), and NOT for the vocal "left" Democrats.

"Radical young politicos from privileged backgrounds who had
sought to intervene on oppressive capitalism became adults who
were eager to find and keep their place in the existing
economic system.  And if this system was fast turning our
nation into a world of haves and have-nots with little in
between, they wanted to remain in the ranks of
the privileged."

From:         Nick LoLordo <lolordov@UNLV.EDU>
Subject:      Re: dancing over reasons
In-Reply-To:  <v04011700babca6b5a4bb@[63.187.193.2]>

Quoting Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>:



> It is strange, this mixture of pretentiousness and happy triviality that
> characterizes contemporary poetics, and also strange that one often seems
> to open the door for the other: a happily inconsequential poet and
> journalist like Ashbery opens the door for a school of academic Marxists
> dedicated to smashing subjectivity, who in turn open the door for the next
> group.  It's as if no one can find the right scale.


Many academics think subjectivity is complicated; they have theories about
something they (no doubt pretentiously) call "the subject": its self-presence,
coherence, or lack thereof.  Why is it strange that such accounts might be
applied to the poetry of Ashbery?  What you call his inconsequentiality is one
way of describing his poetic relation to his own subjectivity, the way being in
the world feels to him.  Would you rather he talked like an artist in a 'major
motion picture'?

--Nick

glyphs preferred the world the world they knew
pronouncement is a sound of desecrated tombs
enriched initials leak to the finish and,
nearby, begin anew – a musical temperature
each city lives through the script, presumption tears up
a miniature distribution of dead pity
language is pity, the vilest curse a blessing
a vocable pulses from breath to death, how many
are needed to outlive us as prayer?
marrow, which was formerly called soul, stands pat
what is first ails our memories, the top of my light
one person is already out of the frame
oppose what is within the Paracelsus of Paris
and the earth makes things worse
cadence as the sense of the impossible
before waste blesses me with continents
these savage lands are kindling for pyres
destroyed frost leaves the ground green
undivined grace kidnaps another language
self-tempted rumor lies unwashed in the flood

Date:         Fri, 11 Apr 2003 14:10:07 -0700

From:         David Hadbawnik <rova@ROVA.ORG>
Subject:      Re: Nader & LaDuke
In-Reply-To:  <3D027F7F.5177CCFD.01F36A84@aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

Hello

I'm glad that a discourse of some sort on this
issue is taking shape, because although it may
seem inconsequential and sour-grapesy now, it's
going to get a lot more important come election
time 2004. The way I see it, the kind of
soul-searching and consolidating the Reps. did so
well during the Clinton years, especially after
their meltdown in the 96 elections, still hasn't
even begun to happen on the other side of the
aisle.

As Frank pointed out, extremists like Ralph Reed
were able to significantly shape policy on the
right and fashion a platform far to the right of
anything Nixon/Reagan/Bush I had ever dreamed up.
How were they able to do it? At the grass-roots
level, with phone and mailing campaigns, winning
little battles with moderates over party
positions, infiltrating the power structure
without resorting to the buffoonery of actually
running for office (which had been their major
mistake in previous primary elections). (And while
we're on the subject, there was an excellent
article in a recent Harper's on "The Family" -- a
shadow organization of religious nuts who have
connections with corporations and corrupt
governments all over the world, and who exercise
enormous influence over select Reps. AND dems --
you can't make shit up this spooky.)

So although it's not as sexy as getting arrested
in a protest or submitting a poem to an anti-war
journal, it's absolutely essential to get out and
pound the pavement for candidates you can support
at the local level, make phone calls, write
letters, find out how you can be effective in
influencing policy, even if it has all the effect
of a rain drop on the hull of an aircraft carrier.

As I stated before, my vote for Nader in
California didn't mean much -- I don't know HOW I
would have voted if I'd lived in New Hampshire or
any of the other swing states. But my disgust for
Gore and the Democratic party is such that I can't
guarantee it would have outweighed my revulsion to
Bush et al. in any case, and forced me to vote for
the former. And to clarify -- I was never trying
to exonerate Nader from any culpability in the
election fiasco. I was only pointing out that
there are at least a dozen very good reasons Gore
"lost," and ten of those lay at no one's feet but
his own.

DH

Date:         Fri, 11 Apr 2003 16:07:24 -0600
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Joe Amato <joe.amato@COLORADO.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Nader & LaDuke
In-Reply-To:  <FJEBIAECHLLAMEPOJPGEMEIFCMAA.rova@rova.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

yes, i agree with david, important to have this conversation, or i
wouldn't be posting in as i get set to haul my ass off a thousand
miles east (in 3 months), in search of a steady academic paycheck...

for the record, and i don't think anyone said this about yours truly,
but i'm no nader hater... not by a long shot... i think he's done
some great public service, more so than most in politics... he pissed
me off during the last election, yes, but that doesn't mean i hate
the guy... i use that word "hate" when i express a sentiment like, "i
hate hussein"...

we don't know, of course, and will never know, how the u.s. might
have fared under gore instead of bush... that's something i wish i
could know, but in any case am happy (for a number of reasons) that
gore won't be running in 04... remember what dick morris (who hates
the clintons these days) once said about gore?... that he was a most
chameleon-like creature once the spotlight was on him, but that
one-on-one he was completely stable, likable, and committed... in
short, that he just didn't have a solid public persona, but that he
was ultimately a much more stand-up guy than william jefferson (not
that anyone ought to trust morris, but there's at least some truth
here i think... for some this will simply be splitting hairs, i know,
and in any case personalities are less the matter perhaps than are
the respective machines)...

surely the repubs have had an election strategy in place ever since
they started fiddling with districting in the south... i.e., they
didn't just up and mobilize the christian coalition (if that
too)---they played some pretty savvy politics (i'd write dirty
politics, but politics IS dirty)... and they did so, let's recall,
with tons o capital... now the right persistently tries to argue that
it doesn't have e.g. "union money," like the left... but the repubs
have far greater access to corporate funding than do the dems---we
all know this, or should know this... and money talks... real
campaign finance reform would be great, sure, but money talks, and
will in the next election, no way around that...

now if the next election begins to shape up like the last, what do we
do? ("we" used very deliberately here)... rerun that third party
scenario like we did last time 'round?...

i hope not...

i'm living in liberal land right now, perhaps the most liberal (and
wealthy) region in the intermountain west (boulder county,
colorado---along with several other listmates), and the past 4 years
have indeed been a nice lesson in the differences twixt being left
and being liberal... as i recall, nader was either at 9 or 11% of the
vote in the town of boulder---which is to say, from where i sit, a
fair number of liberals (along with some leftists, sure) went for
nader... just to set the record straight-er here... i don't have
access to hard data on this, but from where i sit, it was precisely
the crew that craig is railing against that went nader (not gore)...
to have gone gore would have been perceived, by many around here, as
an establishment vote...

you'll have to trust me on the latter, i suppose, b/c i'm
characterizing many of the nader votes as liberal, and not left...
but i had my debates at the time with many of these folks (incl.
students on my extremely well-heeled campus), about gore losing to
bush b/c of nader... in point of fact, most (though not all) of the
folks i'm referring too had enough disposable income so that it
wouldn't matter a damn if bush won---not a damn...

almost in fact the working definition of liberal, not left... nothing
to lose, and having nothing to lose makes you believe that you ought
to throw your vote where you think your principles lie (so to
speak)... remember:  money can insulate you from just about
anything... i really enjoy it, too, when someone 22 years old tells
me that they voted for nader, in between telling me that they're
planning to spend a year off after school "traveling around the
world"... or when the nader vote is coming from someone who lives in
a million dollar home...

this sorta thing really makes my day, as i say, even though i
appreciate the (is it?) idealism... but then again, i have my ideals
too...

don't take my word for it, come to think of it:  nader did poorly
last election among people of color, women, the formally uneducated
and the elderly (right?)... in boulder---a largely white educated
young-ish and green green town---he did real well, relatively
speaking... oh---boulder is extremely monied, too, did i say that?
(median housing just cracked the $400,000 mark)... now do we know
whether those with money, or who come from money, voted for ralph?...
no (i don't anyway)... is it likely that the general presence of
money around here was a factor... i think so... does the fact that
e.g. the uneducated didn't vote for nader mean that you shouldn't
have voted for nader?... certainly not...

but if you *did* vote for nader, and you are white, and educated, and
young, and male, you might want to think over what's at stake here...
maybe (i say maybe) you ought to think this over in terms of what
john g. gunnell used to talk about as political ontology... i know
i'll be thinking things over in such terms---and you know where i
stand... hell, if it looks like the dems are gonna get killed, i'll
probably throw my vote at nader (if he runs)... but if it's tight, i
don't think so...

so in my 2nd and last post of the day, i'd like only to insist that
(1) we follow the money and (2) we consider whether voting for a dem
comprises a lack of courage (which i think is nonsense, to be candid)
or whether it's possible that some of us who go dem are scared
shitless of the alternative---and not simply for ourselves, either...

best,

joe

            Beginning with an evening reading by Fred Wah hosted by =

poets and scholars discussing formally innovative and socially engaged =
practices. Topics will include Racing through Poetics, Engendering =

Quartermain.

Date:         Fri, 11 Apr 2003 19:11:38 -0400
Reply-To:     poetry@hypobololemaioi.com
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Kevin Magee <poetry@HYPOBOLOLEMAIOI.COM>
Subject:      Relics & phonemes
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

The full text of an address I'm giving Monday for a conference here in
Tomsk can be read at

http://hypobololemaioi.com/pages/bio5.html

and though there isn't much there for poetry, it's intended as a
response to the question, "The eyes of the world blink from nervous
exhaustion, while Benjamin's reading of the relics turns up more and
more burnt remains. Is this fate? Or can the bones be ground into
phonemes?"

Who can claim they speak or claim their speech when it is the space
which speaks through them, whether it is a discussion list or
conference auditorium? The title of Monday's conference is "Language
and the Multi-Cultural Space: Aspects of Theory and Practice." One of
the members on the organizing committee for this space is the English
Language Officer from the Public Affairs Section of the American
Embassy in Moscow. Another (American) speaker is from the Bureau of
Education and Cultural Affairs of the U.S. Dept. of State in
Vladivostok.

It is hardly likely that I'll read the Punctuation Exercise as obvious
and innocuous as it must sound in the space of this discussion list,
and I wonder whether the freedom of speech practiced on this list
depends at least partly on the single-language domination of English?
If there were other languages present here, would it change anyone's
language? Do American poets have an ethic imperative to communicate
internationally, if the language of protest were to reach beyond
itself?

Benjamin also wrote that English is the language of accountants.

When this English is removed from its native environment, even in the
institutional sphere of culture, the pressure becomes something like
the description of walking on layers of ice in the "Moscow" essay
published in a new translation by Harvard in 1999. (The Chaucer pages
at this university are comparatively general, even superficial,
compared to similar sites at philological departments in Europe).

A statue of Mandelstam was raised in Vladivostok last year. The story
appears for several minutes on the national news. "I alone in Russia
work with my voice." A cryptic utterance? When the voice is removed
from the environment which constructed it, how the simplest words
begin to disturb, for they are always heard in a condition of
difference. In the cross-cultural space (the translation area)
everything depends on communication. Translation may be that labor
which shows one language how to appropriate the other.

From the text of the address:

There is a linguistic question here about states and actions expressed
by verbs in English, not to mention the shifting functions between
verb and noun, which often leave the form of the word unchanged, so I
posed the problem to myself this way: How can the windows be said to
be anything except windows, since the action of painting them has not
made them anything except windows which have been painted out? The
action of painting them, in other words, has not changed the state of
the windows. They are still windows, painted or unpainted. As a native
speaker of English, and as a poet who uses this language, I was very
interested in my need for the passive to be expressed in the active
tense, as in, "Workers had painted out the windows," and it was this
need for an active subject which produced my incorrect use of the past
perfect, since I heard the action of the subject even when the subject
had been omitted, and so I gave priority to the action and not the
state. Native and non-native teachers of English know very well how
relentless the subject-verb-object relationship is in this language,
and for the native speaker sometimes, the domination of this structure
can interfere with using alternative, even theoretical,
constructions. The story of this sentence ended, if it can even be
said to have ended, in my growing fascination with the study of
English as an object, even though my subjectivity is immersed in the
habits and reflexes of my native language.

One of the greatest insights into the study of English has been given
to me this year by the opportunity of working with a Russian teacher
on the faculty of this university on a lecture course in the History
of English. Often I feel more like a student than a colleague, since
the discipline of Historical Linguistics, as any survey of the subject
will show, has suffered in Western and especially American
universities, partly in response to theories advanced by scholars
working in the related fields of socio-linguistics and applied
linguistics, and partly as an effect of the popularity of cultural
studies. Old English in many universities can be used to fulfill the
foreign language requirement for a PhD, since the synthetic structure
of this earlier English is all but foreign to the user of Modern
English. In the monographs used for the course at this university,
written by a Russian linguist from Tomsk, there are linguistic
practice exercises in the pronunciation of Old English as well as
Middle English, and analytical exercises in grammatical and lexical
features belonging to these periods. Sometimes I feel as though I am
watching the English language being preserved at the very moment in
history when internet technology is producing a rapid expansion and
transformation of this language in the continuous present of
electronic communications.

To end on a humorous note, I would like to read to you from page 121
the Longman Diagnostic and Editing Tests which is used with the
Longman 2003 English Handbooks by freshman composition students at
many universities in the United States. This particular Exercise is
for using End Punctuation, which reflects the priority given in
Anglo-American education to the visual use and appearance of the
language over the communicative paradigm of the speech act.

Instructions: Select the letter of the choice that correctly
punctuates the sentence.

1. Asked what word came to mind when he thought of the Internet, one
third-world subscriber responded, "Colonialism"

a. "Colonialism"!       b. "Colonialism!"       c. "Colonialism?"

2. Why would the Internet, a collection of more than 10 million
computers that moves data among almost 200 nations, be considered a
form of colonialism

a. colonialism.         b. colonialism!         c. colonialism?

3. The answer, according to some critics of the system, is that the
Internet exports the English language (carrying with it immense
cultural power)

a. language.            b. power.)              c. power).

4. Complaining that it is easier to download English translations of
Russian classics than Russian versions, Anatoly Voronov asks, "Why
shouldn't Pushkin or Lermontov be more available in Russian

a. Russian?"            b. Russian"?            c. Russian?".

5. Voronov argues that the need to use English over the Internet,
divides the world into new sorts of "haves and have-nots

a. have-nots".          b. have-nots."          c. have-nots"

6. But isn't Christian Huitema, a member of the board of the Internet
Society, correct when he says, "The effect of the Internet is to make
information available at a minimum cost and effort

a. effort."             b. effort"?             c. effort?"

7. The need to use English, according to this view, is a small price,
indeed, to pay for access to the major libraries of the world

a. world!               b. world.!              c. world?


--

http://hypobololemaioi.com

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      the pure drop
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

the pure drop


i am the pure drop, useless and living
off the muscle of those working to produce
electronics, homes, and clothes,
for me and my partner,
for which we will never give sufficient thanks
to the unknown women, men, and children
suffering in order that i have the freedom
to write, to film, to play useless music
that inspires no one, leads no one
towards better lives or healthier bodies,
doesn't for an instant correct injustice
or lead to equalization among nations
or individuals - instead i reside, not really
aloof, but alone and powerful,
with equipment not of my making,
and in relative warmth and comfort -
possessing the luxurious ability
to think in any direction i desire,
to write whatever i want on whatever subject,
and to continue this useless work
at my leisure - i am this pure drop -
such a very pure drop -


===

Jullich:I've been perplexed lately about where I was
and what
I was doing the last time we were bombing Iraq during
the '90-'91 Gulf War.  The only thing I can remember
is the Kuwaiti oil fields being set on fire.

And then, the other night, when I was in a "The
Russians are coming! The Russians are coming!" panic
and trying to photograph all the contents of my
Merzbau to preserve it from duct tape,...

...I came upon these artworks, photographed and
uploaded to

http://neoplasticistnyt.tripod.com/

Thirty-three New York Times front pages from that
period, painted over in Mondrian Neo-Plasticism, with
the gridwork and red/yellow/blue color rectangles
following the layout of the newspaper.

Some are in acrylic; some are in tempera; some of the
Neo-Plasticist white field is gesso.

http://neoplasticistnyt.tripod.com/

"Art is higher than reality, and has no direct
relation to reality. Between the physical sphere and
the ethereal sphere there is a frontier where our
senses stop functioning. Nevertheless, the ether
penetrates the physical sphere and acts upon it. Thus
the spiritual penetrates the real. But for our senses
these are two different things---the spiritual and the
material.  To approach the spiritual in art, one will
make as little use as possible of reality"

-- Piet Mondrian, 1914

http://neoplasticistnyt.tripod.com/
