Subject:      Perforations 26: Kismet, my love ...
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=X-UNKNOWN
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 11 Apr 2003 09:55:08 -0400
From: robert cheatham <zeug1@earthlink.net>
To: artnews@pd.org
Subject: Perforations 26: Kismet, my love ...

Kismet, my love=8A
Perforations 26

Guest editor - Charles Kriel <journal@kriel.tv>
Senior editor - Robert Cheatham <zeug@pd.org>
http://www.perforate.org/

Theme:
Kismet, my love=8A is concerned with the growing phenomena of the
mediation of personality and the marketing of the self via new tools
for communication: text and multimedia messaging; 3G video phones;
mobile and stationary email; web pages; web logs; networked software
agents and others. It is concerned with both the technical workings
of any new innovations with potential use in this context, as well as
the social implications and the theoretical issues surrounding them.
As Perforations is an e-journal with impact beyond the theoretical,
we are interested in works that express their ideas through a variety
of media, including sound, video, visual art, performance, etc., as
well as the written paper.

George Myerson's Heidegger, Habermas and the Mobile Phone, is a one
possible starting point in this exploration. To quote John Bird on
Myerson: [M]obile phone communication is, essentially, the provision
of information through a technology which does not really require a
person on the other end of the handset.

The MIT AI Lab robot, Kismet, built by Dr. Cynthia Breazeal, is
another source. Although Kismet speaks nonsense, it will engage you
in conversation. Through gesture and vocal inflection, it will make
clear that it understands that you have said something to it, it will
speak non-demanding nonsense back to you, and then indicate that it
is your turn to speak again. It insists only that you keep it at the
right level of stimulation, and that you keep a reasonable distance.

Finally, blogs play a role in this work. Certain Frankfurt School
theorists critiqued the wearing of one's personality externally and
materially, whether through fashion or some other inscription into
the corps of collective expression; the more democratic the language
of expression, the more banal. Blogs, which typically express
individual personality via a collection of links and a display of
friendships (I am what I reference), are ripe for evaluation within
this framework, whether pro-Adorno, anti-, or viewed within more
contemporary theoretical parameters.

This particular trend of expression of the individual via selection
from the collective belies a drift in culture in general: the
arrogation of the curator over the artist, the DJ over the musician,
the blogger over the journalist. Kismet, my love=8A privileges neither
voice, but seeks to evaluate this shift in culture.

Format:
There are no limits to media formats, other than that which can
(reasonably) be placed on the web. There are preferences, however:
PDF & Word files will be converted into HTML and be made available
for download in either format. Papers and artworks are equally
encouraged.

Submissions:
Submissions should be sent to Charles Kriel, at journal@kriel.tv
Deadline: 31 August 2003
Perforations is an affiliate of Public Domain, Inc, a 501-c-3
organization unaffiliated with any other organization.

--

Dear Joe, thanks for the lessons in Political Ontology and such, but i STILL don't see how you can justify asking ANYONE in a Democracy to vote ANY WAY but by their conscience.  it's really, in the end, up to the candidates to PROVE themselves.  it is very interesting how much Al Gore DIDN'T want those debates with Nader.  yeah, it was much easier to debate Dumbo mini Bush.  Nader wasn't even allowed into the audience while the debates were going on, even though he had a PAID ticket stub.  he was THE ONLY person forbidden into the televised debates who had a PAID ticket stub, made to watch from the fucking Green Room!

if you're SO interested in SAVING the Democrats why don't you go do a little Political Ontological missionary work on the Republicans.  how you vote is up to you, and i'm glad you shared with us your feelings about why and who and what comes where for you to make your decisions about who to vote for.  everybody has their own recipe, and that's what makes this country so fantastic in the end.  but me, i din't give two shits if they hoisted Gore up on the gallows and THREATENED to hang him if i voted for Nader, i'd STILL vote for Nader.

by the way, those demographics you shared, the ones about who voted for Nader, i suppose statistics can be grabbed out of thin air after all.  i know PLENTY of lesbians of color who voted for Nader, a bunch a drag queens, in FACT there's a WHOLE group of drag queens (what do they call their group?  GLAMERICANS?  something like that) and radical faeries, a VERY LARGE population of dykes and fags in their 50s who helped fill Madison Square Garden to support him.  in fact, Patti Smith MADE A POINT of saying on stage when singing at that benefit concert for Nader HOW MANY DIFFERENT KINDS OF PEOPLE were in the audience, as she said, "THESE are all the shapes and colors of the what American is about."  your attempt to NARROW the chute we're sliding through in support of FREEDOM from a (too old) 2 party system is really pointless.

go dem baby, knock your pretty self out,
ain't no one standing in your way Joe,
love, love, and yet more love,
CAConrad

> yes, i agree with david, important to have this conversation, or i

> some great public service, more so than most in politics... he pissed
> me off during the last election, yes, but that doesn't mean i hate
> the guy... i use that word "hate" when i express a sentiment like, "i
> hate hussein"...
>
> we don't know, of course, and will never know, how the u.s. might
> have fared under gore instead of bush... that's something i wish i
> could know, but in any case am happy (for a number of reasons) that
> gore won't be running in 04... remember what dick morris (who hates
> the clintons these days) once said about gore?... that he was a most
> chameleon-like creature once the spotlight was on him, but that
> one-on-one he was completely stable, likable, and committed... in
> short, that he just didn't have a solid public persona, but that he
> was ultimately a much more stand-up guy than william jefferson (not
> that anyone ought to trust morris, but there's at least some truth
> here i think... for some this will simply be splitting hairs, i know,
> and in any case personalities are less the matter perhaps than are
> the respective machines)...
>
> surely the repubs have had an election strategy in place ever since
> they started fiddling with districting in the south... i.e., they
> didn't just up and mobilize the christian coalition (if that
> too)---they played some pretty savvy politics (i'd write dirty
> politics, but politics IS dirty)... and they did so, let's recall,
> with tons o capital... now the right persistently tries to argue that
> it doesn't have e.g. "union money," like the left... but the repubs
> have far greater access to corporate funding than do the dems---we
> all know this, or should know this... and money talks... real
> campaign finance reform would be great, sure, but money talks, and
> will in the next election, no way around that...
>
> now if the next election begins to shape up like the last, what do we
> do? ("we" used very deliberately here)... rerun that third party
> scenario like we did last time 'round?...
>
> i hope not...
>
> i'm living in liberal land right now, perhaps the most liberal (and
> wealthy) region in the intermountain west (boulder county,
> colorado---along with several other listmates), and the past 4 years
> have indeed been a nice lesson in the differences twixt being left
> and being liberal... as i recall, nader was either at 9 or 11% of the
> vote in the town of boulder---which is to say, from where i sit, a
> fair number of liberals (along with some leftists, sure) went for
> nader... just to set the record straight-er here... i don't have
> access to hard data on this, but from where i sit, it was precisely
> the crew that craig is railing against that went nader (not gore)...
> to have gone gore would have been perceived, by many around here, as
> an establishment vote...
>
> you'll have to trust me on the latter, i suppose, b/c i'm
> characterizing many of the nader votes as liberal, and not left...
> but i had my debates at the time with many of these folks (incl.
> students on my extremely well-heeled campus), about gore losing to
> bush b/c of nader... in point of fact, most (though not all) of the
> folks i'm referring too had enough disposable income so that it
> wouldn't matter a damn if bush won---not a damn...
>
> almost in fact the working definition of liberal, not left... nothing
> to lose, and having nothing to lose makes you believe that you ought
> to throw your vote where you think your principles lie (so to
> speak)... remember:  money can insulate you from just about
> anything... i really enjoy it, too, when someone 22 years old tells
> me that they voted for nader, in between telling me that they're
> planning to spend a year off after school "traveling around the
> world"... or when the nader vote is coming from someone who lives in
> a million dollar home...
>
> this sorta thing really makes my day, as i say, even though i
> appreciate the (is it?) idealism... but then again, i have my ideals
> too...
>
> don't take my word for it, come to think of it:  nader did poorly
> last election among people of color, women, the formally uneducated
> and the elderly (right?)... in boulder---a largely white educated
> young-ish and green green town---he did real well, relatively
> speaking... oh---boulder is extremely monied, too, did i say that?
> (median housing just cracked the $400,000 mark)... now do we know
> whether those with money, or who come from money, voted for ralph?...
> no (i don't anyway)... is it likely that the general presence of
> money around here was a factor... i think so... does the fact that
> e.g. the uneducated didn't vote for nader mean that you shouldn't
> have voted for nader?... certainly not...
>
> but if you *did* vote for nader, and you are white, and educated, and
> young, and male, you might want to think over what's at stake here...
> maybe (i say maybe) you ought to think this over in terms of what
> john g. gunnell used to talk about as political ontology... i know
> i'll be thinking things over in such terms---and you know where i
> stand... hell, if it looks like the dems are gonna get killed, i'll
> probably throw my vote at nader (if he runs)... but if it's tight, i
> don't think so...
>
> so in my 2nd and last post of the day, i'd like only to insist that
> (1) we follow the money and (2) we consider whether voting for a dem
> comprises a lack of courage (which i think is nonsense, to be candid)
> or whether it's possible that some of us who go dem are scared
> shitless of the alternative---and not simply for ourselves,
> either...
>
> best,
>
> joe

From:         Halvard Johnson <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      "Firefight at Palestine Hotel"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Firefight at Palestine Hotel

31 minutes ago — No quagmire, but still some questions.
The censorship begins inside the heavily armored tank if it
is placed correctly. To err on the side of caution whenever
practical, classrooms were filled with hundreds of crates

of grenade launchers, hunkered down in their homes by a wife
and two children hoping that peace would prevail. Critical questions
a hundred flights up? Brides stripped bare by their bachelors?
Coalition forces sound sirens again in the Iraqi capital Baghdad.

Knew there were journalists there and ordered a return volley
anyway. Media march to war, and my very bones sweated.
Classrooms were filled with a lull following an evening
bombardment. Ourselves with ourselves. Told reporters that

after a lull following an evening bombardment. Rifles and rocket-
propelled grenades reduced to a line in a sonnet, if it is placed
correctly. Journalists warned of the danger that combat may lie
ahead, can injure or kill. The commander knew that journalists were

there, inside the heavily armed tank, amid hundreds of cartons
of leaflets, trying by any means to seize the offensive, win the peace.


Hal

Halvard Johnson

email: halvard@earthlink.net
website: http://home.earthlink.net/~halvard

Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Stephen Vincent <steph484@PACBELL.NET>
Subject:      On looting the National Museum of Iraq
Comments: cc: Brian Stefans <bstefans@arras.net>
In-Reply-To:  <004001c3011c$7e1b8270$0200000a@Unnamed>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

On looting the National Museum of Iraq: 50,000 artifacts from 7,000 years of
history lost in 48 hours.

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/12/international/worldspecial/12CND-BAGH.html

I find outrageous and unbelievable that U.S. troops would be allowed to
stand-by and permit this disaster to happen - to essentially permit the
destruction of one of the  prime repositories the world's earliest history.
At best one can pray that the objects are not destroyed and that vigilance
abounds at the borders for dealers in these artifacts.
Cultural terrorism is as old as the hills - including the burning of
libraries of which I suspect we will also soon have witness - a form of
cutting the tongue out of the enemy. Since these are Iraqis who are
performing this cultural self-destruction - and for what angry, desperate
and self-serving reasons we can probably imagine - yet, by permitting it to
openly happen, whether it be ransacking hospitals, museums, whatever  - the
United States Government has shown itself complicit and accountable for
contributing to these crimes.

Or as Secretary of War Donald Rumsfeld put out the Government's apparent
point of view yesterday:
Think what's happened in our cities when we've had riots and problems and
looting. Stuff happens! But in terms of what's going on in that country, it
is a fundamental misunderstanding to see those images over and over and over
again of some boy walking out with a vase and say, "Oh, my goodness, you
didn't have a plan." That's nonsense. They know what they're doing. And
they're doing a terrific job. And it's untidy. And freedom's untidy. And
free people are free to make mistakes and commit crimes and do bad things.
They're also free to live their lives and do wonderful things. And that's
what's going to happen here. . . .


I personally feel a deep shame - and I am sure I am far from alone - for
what has happened in our name under the watch of "Occupation." In this case
I hope the Museums in this country and around the world - as well as the
Galleries and dealers that they may stand to profit from these thefts - will
take the lead in condemning the U.S. failure to act against these crimes
and, most important now, take the lead in supporting Iraqi efforts to
recover and restore the stolen treasures of this Museum and possibly other
museums and libraries through out Iraq.

A very sad moment.

Stephen Vincent

On looting the National Museum of Iraq: 50,000 artifacts from 7,000
years of history lost in 48 hours.
=========================================================================
Date:         Sun, 13 Apr 2003 00:25:58 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         George Bowering <bowering@SFU.CA>
Subject:      Fwd: Americans Target & Kill Journalists from Al-Jazeera &
              Reuters, Again
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

>
>
>Reuters cameraman Taras Protsyuk, 35, was killed when an
>American tank fired a shell directly at the Reuters suite
>on the 15th floor at the Palestine hotel, where many
>journalists are staying.
>
>Jose Couso, 37, a cameraman for the Spanish television
>channel Tele 5, was wounded in the same attack and died
>later in hospital. Samia Nakhoul, the Gulf bureau chief of
>Reuters, was also injured, along with a British
>technician, Paul Pasquale, and an Iraqi photographer,
>Faleh Kheiber.
>
>Earlier, al-Jazeera cameraman Tarek Ayyoub, a 35-year-old
>Palestinian who lived in Jordan, was killed when two bombs
>dropped during a US air raid hit the satellite station's
>office in the Iraqi capital.
>
>American forces also opened fire on the offices of Abu
>Dhabi television, whose identity is spelled out in large
>blue letters on the roof.
>
>All the journalists were killed and injured in daylight at
>locations known to the Pentagon as media sites. The tank
>shell that hit the Palestine hotel slammed into the
>18-storey building at noon, shaking the tower and spewing
>rubble and dirt into hotel rooms at least six floors
>below.
>
>The attack brought pandemonium in the hotel which lies on
>the east side of the Tigris. It was adopted by all
>remaining western journalists in the city after advice
>from the Pentagon to evacuate from the western side of the
>river.
>
>Central command in Qatar said its troops had been
>responding in self-defence to enemy fire but witnesses
>dismissed that claim as false. According to a central
>command statement, "commanders on the ground reported that
>coalition forces received significant enemy fire from the
>hotel and consistent with the inherent right of
>self-defence, coalition forces returned fire".
>
>The statement added: "Sadly a Reuters and Tele 5
>journalist were killed in this exchange. These tragic
>incidents appear to be the latest example of the Iraqi
>regime's continued strategy of using civilian facilities
>for military purposes."
>
>But journalists in the hotel insisted there had been no
>Iraqi fire.
>
>Sky's correspondent, David Chater, said: "I never heard a
>single shot coming from the area around here, certainly
>not from the hotel," he said.
>
>BBC correspondent Rageh Omaar added that none of the other
>journalists in the hotel had heard any sniper fire.
>
>Chater said he saw a US tank pointing its gun at the hotel
>and turned away just before the blast. "I noticed one of
>the tanks had its barrel pointed up at the building. We
>went inside and there was an almighty crash. That tank
>shell, if it was an American tank shell, was aimed
>directly at this hotel and directly at journalists. This
>wasn't an accident. It seems to be a very accurate shot."
>
>Geert Linnebank, Reuters editor-in-chief, said the
>incident "raises questions about the judgment of the
>advancing US troops who have known all along that this
>hotel is the main base for almost all foreign journalists
>in Baghdad".
>
>Journalists, a watchdog group that defends press freedoms,
>demanded an invesigation in a letter to the US defence
>secretary, Donald Rumsfeld. "We believe these attacks
>violate the Geneva conventions," the letter said, adding
>that even if US forces had been fired on from the
>Palestine hotel "the evidence suggests that the response
>of US forces was disproportionate and therefore violated
>humanitarian law".
>
>During the Afghan war, two supposedly smart US bombs hit
>the Reuters office in Kabul and many suspect the attack
>was no accident. It happened at a strategic moment, two
>hours before the Northern Alliance took over the city.
>
>US military officials at central command said they were
>investigating and added that the casualties were
>"regrettable". "We know that we don't target journalists,"
>said Brigadier General Vince Brooks, deputy director of
>operations.
>
>Al-Jazeera correspondent Tarek Ayyoub was broadcasting
>live to the satellite station's 7am news bulletin when US
>aircraft fired two missiles at the bureau building,
>killing him and injuring a colleague. Two Iraqi staff are
>missing.
>
>Ibrahim Hilal, al-Jazeera's chief editor at its
>headquarters in Qatar, said a US warplane was seen above
>the building before the attack. "Witnesses saw the plane
>fly over twice before dropping the bombs. Our office is in
>a residential area and even the Pentagon knows its
>location," he said.
>
>Al-Jazeera correspondent Majed Abdul-Hadi said the
>bombardment was probably deliberate.
>
>In Doha last night al-Jazeera's chairman, Hamad bin
>Thamer, said the channel "could not ascertain" if its
>Baghdad bureau had been targeted by the US. But he
>dismissed American claims that there had been gunfire
>coming from the building at the time of the attack.
>
>"This was absolutely and categorically denied by other
>reporters and our reporters present on the ground," he
>said.
>
>Mr Ayyoub, 35, a Palestinian born in Kuwait, had not
>intended to go to Baghdad but as the war dragged on he
>felt he had to work there, and al-Jazeera agreed to let
>him work in Baghdad.
>
>His widow, Dima Ayyoub, launched a vitriolic attack on
>America: "My message to you is that hatred breeds hatred,"
>she said in a live telephone link-up from her home in
>Amman, Jordan. "I cannot see where is the cleanness in
>this war. All I see is blood, destruction and shattered
>hearts. The US said it was a war against terrorism. Who is
>committing terrorism now?"


--
George Bowering
Almost a Huguenot
Fax 604-266-9000

>
>  >SUNDAY HALIFAX-CHRONICLE HERALD COLUMN -- March 26, 2003 [HH0313]
>>
>>A DIPLOMATIC MEMO
>>by Silver Donald Cameron
>>
>>To: Ambassador Paul Cellucci
>>Embassy of the United States of America
>>490 Sussex Drive
>>Ottawa, Ontario
>>
>>Dear Mr. Ambassador:
>>Your recent remarks about Canada's policy with respect to Iraq were
>>inaccurate, inappropriate and offensive. Prime Minister Chretien is
>>maintaining a delicate balance between US pressure and Canadian opinion
>>- a familiar position for Canadian Prime Ministers - and he will not tell
>>you to go pound sand. But someone should.
>>
>>Fundamentally, you argue that the United States would instantly come to
>>the aid of Canada in an emergency, and Canada should therefore participate
>>in your ill-advised attack on Iraq.
>>
>>"There is no security threat to Canada that the United States would not
>>be ready, willing and able to help with," you are quoted as saying. "There
>>would be no debate. There would be no hesitation. We would be there for
>>Canada, part of our family."
>>
>>Codswallop. And that's diplomatic.
>>
>>The primary threat to Canadian security has always been the United
>>States.  A monument in Quebec honours my earliest Canadian ancestor for
>>repelling an invasion from your home state of Massachusetts in 1690. The
>>very first instance of military co-operation among the Thirteen Colonies
>>occurred in 1745 under the leadership of James Shirley, your predecessor as
>>Governor of Massachusetts, whose army invaded Nova Scotia and captured the
>>Fortress of Louisbourg. Thirty years later, during the American Revolution,
>>your privateers sacked our ports. We were at war once more in 1812-15. The
>>birth of Canada in 1867 was prompted by fears of a US invasion. That's why
>>our railroad runs along the Gulf of St. Lawrence, far from the US border.
>>Do you remember "manifest destiny," the 1840's US doctrine which held
>>that your country had a God-given mission to rule all of North America? Do
>>you remember "Fifty-four-forty or fight," the slogan which rallied
>>Americans to threaten an invasion in 1902 over the Alaska boundary? Yours is
>>the only country which has ever invaded ours, and it would do so again in a
>>wink if it thought its interests here were seriously threatened.
>  >
>  >And how does your sentimental mantra of perpetual willingness to spring
>  >to our assistance apply to the First World War, which we entered in
>  >1914, while you stayed out for three years? We went to war against Hitler in
>>1939, while you were moved to join your sister democracies only after
>>the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor two years later. A million Canadians
>>fought in World War II, and 45,000 died. We need no lectures from Americans
>>about the defence of liberty and democracy.
>>
>>Nevertheless, despite the strains of our history, we are probably as close
>>as any two nations in the world. Many Canadians -- I am one -- have
>>family members who are American citizens. Our two nations fought together
>>not only in two World Wars, but also to repel the invasions of South Korea
>>in 1949 and Kuwait in 1991. And when great catastrophe strikes without
>>warning, our people have indeed been there for each other. As Governor of
>>Massachusetts, you must have been present at the lighting of the Christmas
>>tree in Boston each year - an annual gift from Nova Scotia to commemorate
>>the immediate and massive assistance of Massachusetts after the Halifax
>>Explosion in 1917.
>>
>>Our chance to reciprocate came on September 11, 2001, when Canadian
>>communities took in, on an instant's notice, 40,000 passengers from US
>>planes forced down by the terrorist attacks. Halifax alone hosted 7,200. We
>>housed them in our homes and schools and churches, fed them and comforted
>>them and treated them as family. We probably gave more immediate and
>>practical assistance to Americans than any other country. Yet when your
>>President later thanked the nations for their help, he did not mention
>  >Canada.
>>
>>The Iraq conflict, however, is not an unforeseen disaster, but a deliberate
>>choice. Your President has squandered a worldwide outpouring of sympathy
>>and solidarity in less than two years -- an astounding diplomatic debacle.
>>Your own remarks, with their dark hints of economic revenge, are entirely
>>consistent with the Bush administration's policy of diplomacy by bullying,
>>bribing and threatening.
>>
>>A huge body of opinion -- even in the US and Britain -- judges this war
>>to be illegal, reckless and irrelevant to the fight against terrorism.
>>Your government appears to have forgotten Osama bin Laden, and not to have
>>noticed that the September 11 terrorists were mostly Saudi, not Iraqi.
>>They lived not in Baghdad but in Hamburg and San Diego. The Iraq campaign is
>>a sideshow, a grudge match, a distraction. It will breed more martyrs,
>>and more terrorists.
>>
>>Back in Massachusetts, in 1846, a young man was arrested and jailed for
>>refusing to pay taxes, to avoid supporting his government's deplorable
>>policies. He explained this in an essay, "On the Duty of Civil
>>Disobedience," which has ever since inspired people like Gandhi and
>>Martin Luther King. His name was Henry David Thoreau, and no doubt the
>>Governor of Massachusetts thought he was a pretty poor American. He was not;
>>like King, he was a voice for what is finest in American life and values.
>>And the issue on which he took his stand may sound a bit familiar. He was
>>opposed to an imperial war -- the unprovoked US invasion which stripped
>>Mexico of 40% of its territory.
>>
>>Good citizens - and good friends - oppose bad policies. By telling you the
>>truth, they strive to save you from folly. They may be mistaken, but they
>>are not your enemies. That is the message you should take back to the
>>White House, whether or not there is anyone there who will understand it.
>>Sincerely,
>>Silver Donald Cameron

From:         Herb Levy <herb@ESKIMO.COM>
Subject:      shadow language poetry
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

This was linked from Arts Journal <http://www.artsjournal.com> when I
checked it this morning:
<http://www.newcriterion.com/archive/21/apr03/ormsby.htm>

It's remarkable that someone writing in the New Criterion is willing
to admit there's anything he doesn't understand, but Eric Ormsby
makes much of the fact that he was inspired early on by listening to
an album of recordings of poetry in languages he didn't understand.
He doesn't, quite, say that he hates speech, though he comes close
once or twice.

Following a lede about an unnamed (and quite possibly conceptual)
Iraqi professor of English who 40 years ago posited that Shakespeare
was an Arabic mariner originally named Shaykh Zubayr, Ormsby ends up
far less unexpectedly (this is the New Criterion, after all) praising
Geoffrey Hill at great length.

craig, not giving anyone any "lessons," again, just to be clear... i
*am* trying to suggest ways to think about why we vote who we vote
for---and if what i suggest is old news, the better for that... the
nader demographics speak for themselves---they're not a matter of
what you may have seen at the voter booths personally, as i was
trying to drive home by saying "don't take my word for it"... i wish
in fact i had better, more accurate stats, and if anyone does, i'll
be happy to stand corrected...

again, i thought it was wrong not to let nader into the
debates---completely wrong... but this isn't a reason to vote for
him, again (or, to my way of thinking, to have voted against gore)...
and yeah, i like patti smith lots too, but i don't necessarily turn
to her for political advice...

and i suppose i can't hope to change anyone's mind, either... but
yeah, i AM asking that voters stop to consider what they think
they're accomplishing with their vote, and for whom... i find the
nader folks---and again, to be candid, your post is some
representative of this---err in their enthusiasms, which often strike
me as evangelicalisms... it's nice to be passionate about a
candidate, sure (i've been there occasionally), but i'm still
concerned e.g. about folks who are dirt poor (a few of whom are in my
family, no shit)... no condescension intended or implied (wrt these
folks) but they won't be voting nader, and not b/c they don't
understand his platform, either...

as i suggested at the beginning of this thread, i knew that talking
about this, on this list, would only generate a mild shitstorm---like
anything else worth talking about on this list... i suppose now we
have to say, unfortunately, what?---that we each haven't budged in
our perspectives?... well, listening to the pro-nader perspective,
again, *has* helped me to think more about the larger political
domain, the reasons why voters vote as they do... writing a few posts
of my own *has* given me the opportunity to find a better way to
articulate my thoughts about the 00 election... but no, i haven't
heard anything that's really changed my mind about my voting
strategy... and i can only assume the situation is much the same on
the other end of the string...

how to forge anything like a coalition on the left given the latter
reality is quite beyond me... so i'll sign off on this thread for
now, and leave that one for others to ponder, as i ponder it mself...

peace,

joe

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      On the Mysteriousness of Cats
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

On the Mysteriousness of Cats


The intermediary phenomenology of the cat. Consider the vector

rabbit <--> cat <--> dog .

There are three positions; rabbit/dog link by totality - the impervious
rabbit, and salivating dog. The dog responds more or less fully to human
communication; the rabbit, almost not at all. The rabbit exists in a world
dominated by muteness, inexpressivity; the dog, in a world of excessive
emotion. A 'happy' dog is almost always recognized as such. The dog is
cultivated by the male - "a dog is man's best friend." A dog accompanies
the man on the hunt for the rabbit. The man-dog is preyer; the rabbit is
prey. The dog eats; the rabbit is eaten. The rabbit is read as 0; the dog
as 1. The rabbit is fodder; the man-dog a double-prosthesis. The rabbit is
an idea; the dog, a psychology. The dog is an accompaniment within the
aegis of instrumental reason; the rabbit, consigned to both the natural
and inert. The rabbit is used by man; the man-dog, a function of totality.

The cat is intermediary. The cat is mute, but expressive; its expressivity
is by and large instinctual. The dog and rabbit are understood; the cat is
the locus of projections and introjections - the locus of jectivity. The
cat is feminine/feline; the rabbit pays no attention, the dog full, and
the cat partial. If the man-dog is an object for itself, and rabbit, an
object in-itself, the cat is a part-object, partial-object, recognizing
neither object nor others, rather recognizing in part objects and others.
A cat is the site of dreamwork, fantasm; it is necessarily incomprehensib-
le. The cat is feared as neither tool/function or food; it problematizes
human communication. A cat appears contented, but its purr is still not
understood; machines reproduce what might be considered the language of
dogs translated into human speech, and a rabbit is of limited vocality.
The cat, in the intermediary or problematic position of women in relation
to male ration/phallocracy, refuses interpretation, and worse, refuses
through its ignoring of human labors at translation.

The cat is the source of a continuous production of interpretive books;
the truth is that there is nothing to interpret, only a phenomenology in
relation to other mammals, within a field of trans-species communication.
It is the wavering position of the animal, its flux or fluid mechanics
near the point of turbulence, that breaks through the surface of classical
logic and negation (not-x = y, not-y = x), instead tending towards fuzzy
and dissipative negations, loopings without return, the sheffer stroke
dual of neither x nor y. (I've written at length on this in other
contexts.)  In short, the cat (in relation as well to transitional
objects) cannot be classified, classically-described, through no fault or
characteristic of its own - instead, it is our cultural field that fails
to accommodate what we perceive as murkiness, in relationship to what we
also tacitly accept as our own clarity and rationality.

From:         Halvard Johnson <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Five sentences by Pres. G.W.B.
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Five sentences by Pres. G.W.B., as quoted by Lewis H. Lapham
in "Shock and Awe" in *Harper's Magazine* May 2003.

1. "The liberty we prize is not America's gift to the world,
it is God's gift to humanity."

2. "We do not claim to know all the ways of Providence, yet we
can trust in them, placing our confidence in the loving God behind
all of life, and all of history."

3. "Events aren't moved by blind change and chance . . . [but] by
the hand of a just and faithful God."

4. "The crew of the shuttle *Columbia* did not return safely to
earth. Yet we can pray that all are safely home."

5. "We will export death and violence to the four corners of the
earth in defense of our great nation."

Hal                Serving the tri-state area.

Halvard Johnson

Date:         Sun, 13 Apr 2003 12:28:24 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Nader
In-Reply-To:  <7AA853D2.4459C654.0080AC7C@aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

If you want a leftist candidate who has a chance of winning try running one
and voting for her/him in the Democratic primaries. More than schoolboard
elections it was the organizing of conservative church groups to vote in
Republican primaries that pushed the party so far to the right. That's the
way the system works under a winner-take-all constitution as opposed to a
parliamentary government. It would be nice if there were an alternative,
but there isn't.

The first and last third party to take power in the US was the Republicans
in 1860. That was a consequence of the total disintegration of the existing
political system, and it didn't establish third-party politics, it simply
replaced one of the other parties.

Mark

Subject:      fwd - Greenboathouse News...

Greenboathouse Books is pleased to announce the release of our first title
for 2003:

*The Eye-Shift of Surface*
by Meredith Quartermain.

An astonishingly new collection of prose poems by Vancouver poet Meredith
Quartermain, Eye-Shift of Surface explores the permutations of the word "I"
(its abbreviations, roots, utterance and grammar) and its intimate
connection with the word "eye."

Here are the vocabularies of "I" including ways in which the letter is used
as more than linguistic container of self. Anti-confessional in tone these
playful associations challenge the transparent notion that "I" sees
everything.

Printed on acid-free 80lb Pastelle Text and wrapped in Fabriano Ingres
flyleaves
with 70lb Genesis Birch jacket; hand-stitched with French flaps.
This edition is limited to 52 numbered copies, all signed by the author.

    ISBN 1-894744-12-8
    Available now!
    $15.00

*

For more on Meredith's work, check out our second Exact Change dialogue
between Meredith Quartermin and Greenboathouse editor, Aaron Peck, now
on-site.

*

The first instalment of our Variant project is also up, with new poems by
Andy Weaver, Faro Sullivan, rob mclennan, Bonnie Nish and Brenda Schmidt.

Variant:
A new Greenboathouse initiative, Variant invites writers to respond in
poetic, lyric or narrative form to a "trigger"; a passage from a book, poem,
theoretical text (or billboard for that matter) will be posted on-line to
which writers are invited to respond in whatever direction they're drawn.

For more information or to check out the current batch of variants, visit
www.greenboathouse.com

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Rob McLennan <az421@FREENET.CARLETON.CA>
Subject:      greenhouse books project

check out http://www.greenboathouse.com/variant.htm to see the next
project for Victoria BC's Greenboathouse books "variant" series, run
by Jason Dewinetz & Aaron Peck.

their current trigger is:       "Sometimes a journey makes
                                    itself necessary."
                                                - Anne Carson,
                                                  Autobiography of Red
*

A new Greenboathouse initiative, Variant invites writers to respond in
poetic, lyric or narrative form to a "trigger"; a passage from a book,
poem, theoretical text (or billboard for that matter) will be posted
on-line to which writers are invited to respond in whatever direction
they're drawn.

We're looking for innovative and unconventional responses to these quotes,
and encourage contributors to develop their submissions as directly or
indirectly as they choose.

Submission Deadline:
June 30, 2003

Submission Guidelines:

Submissions to the Variant project can be of any genre, and we hope to get
a wide variety of styles and approaches.

The idea is simply to explore the theme provided as directly or indirectly
as you see fit. Take it in any direction it leads you, explore the
possibilities, then package your submisssion up inside the body of a
regular email and ship it off to us at variant@greenboathouse.com

From the Variants submitted we'll post somewhere around 5 pieces on-line.
The author of one of these will receive copies of the latest
Greenboathouse chapbooks and this piece will also be published as a
numbered and signed broadsheet with 10% of the print run going to the
author.

We also see this project as an invitation to reading and hope that
participants will not only submit their work but also send us passages
from their own readings, which may be used as future quotes to spur more
Variant writing by others.

www.greenboathouse.com

--

From:         "K.Angelo Hehir" <khehir@CS.MUN.CA>
Subject:      Who's next for global vigilante?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Who's next for global vigilante?

GWYNNE DYER
Apr. 11, 2003

A reader's letter published in the Los Angeles Times last week said it all:
"We have learned two things from the war in Iraq. We have learned that the
Tigris flows through Baghdad, and the Hubris flows through the White House."

Hubris -- the belief that you are so clever and so powerful that you can get
away with anything -- is certainly the prevailing state of mind in
Washington this week as the Iraqi regime collapses before the U.S.
onslaught. So where is the next war?

There was never any doubt that the United States would win this war: The
U.S. defence budget last year was 250 times bigger than Iraq's.

But the next phase of the drama is already taking shape offstage and is
likely to be more painful and difficult for the United States than simply
smashing up a Third World army.

In the north of Iraq, the Kurds want to control the mainly Kurdish cities of
Mosul and Kirkuk because the surrounding oil fields would place an
independent Kurdish state on a sound economic footing. Kurdish fighters have
already seized Kirkuk -- but Turkey, anxious about the influence of an
independent Kurdistan on their own huge and restive Kurdish minority, have
said that if the Kurds take Mosul and Kirkuk, they invade.

The United States is trying to limit the damage, promising that the Kurdish
fighters will be replaced by "coalition" troops in Kirkuk and inviting
Turkish army observers to the city. But it won't find it easy to get the
Kurds out.

This is their best chance for independence in the past 80 years, and they
would be mad not to try for it. They have been betrayed by the U.S. so many
times that they feel they owe it nothing, and they say they would resist a
Turkish invasion whether the U.S. helps them or not.

The situation down south is even more precarious, for the long-oppressed
Shia Arabs of the south are about two-thirds of the entire Iraqi population.

If Iraq really became a democracy, the Shiites would dominate the
government, and naturally turn to their fellow Shiites in Iran for advice
and support.

Since Iran is allegedly part of the "axis of evil," the retired U.S.
generals who will shortly be ruling Iraq are unlikely to turn the country
over to people with that sort of friends. If U.S. troops stay in Iraq and
the Shiites feel cheated out of their fair share of power yet again,
however, it won't be long before they start resisting U.S. rule.

It gets worse. Any Shia resistance movement in Iraq is bound to get support
from Iran, and there will soon be U.S. troops all along the Iran-Iraq
border, only a few hours' drive from Iran's main oil fields.

Even if the Bush administration isn't planning another war before the next
election, U.S. attempts to stop infiltration across the border from Iran
could easily lead to a U.S.-Iran war much sooner than that -- and Iran has a
relatively united population three times bigger than Iraq's.

Above all, there is the fact that the United States, abetted by Britain and
Australia, has launched an unprovoked attack on a sovereign state.

That is why most other governments are deeply worried: The American attack
on Iraq could be used as a precedent, using exactly the same arguments as
President George Bush, to justify an Indian attack on Pakistan or a North
Korean attack on South Korea. The U.S. action in Iraq has fundamentally
challenged the rule of law in the world, which is a problem no matter how
happy most Iraqis are at the moment -- and Washington clearly meant to do
just that.

Consider the remarks of former CIA chief James Woolsey, a Bush
administration insider who was recently mentioned in a leaked Pentagon
document as one of the possible administrators of post-war Iraq.

Last week in Los Angeles, Woolsey described the war in Iraq as the start of
the fourth world war (the Cold War being the third), and warned his audience
that, "This fourth world war, I think, will last considerably longer than
either the first or aecond world wars did for us."

The real enemies this time, he explained, were the religious rulers of Iran,
the "fascists" of Iraq and Syria, and the Islamic extremists of Al Qaeda. He
made no distinctions between them (though in real life they have very little
in common), and he promised a long crusade against them.

There was no suggestion the U.S. would bother to get legal authority from
the United Nations before attacking the sovereign states on his list.

"As we move towards a new Middle East over the years and the decades to
come," he said, "we will make a lot of people very nervous. Our response
should be, 'Good! We want you nervous. We want you to realize now, for the
fourth time in a hundred years, this country and its allies are on the
march'."

Eventually, the American public is likely to rebel against the continual
flow of casualties and the higher taxes that come with this new role of
global vigilante, but in the meantime it is going to be a wild ride.

. . . . . . .

Gwynne Dyer is a Newfoundland journalist based in London whose articles are
published in 45 countries.

How weird to see the cover of the NY Times Book Review!

Cassius Marcellus Coolidge, 1844-1934, lived in Antwerp, NY, and worked as
a druggist and sign painter, even founded a bank and a newspaper. Then he
moved to Rochester and started painting his dog pictures (not just poker,
but playing baseball, riding trains, more). Cigar companies made prints of
them to use as publicity, and Coolidge turned out copies for
advertisements, calendars, and prints -- and they're still popular, just by
the measure of the amount of places you can buy them listed on Google.
Kitsch surrealism pop, something weird and amusing, about these paintings,
and they gave comfort to many working and middle class families. Now, I
would like to find his letters, his papers, his archive, and get to the
source of his inspiration, the core of his doggy heart. Is there a poetry
equivalent?  Would I feel better if Bush's cabinet were replaced entirely
with dogs?

Hilton Obenzinger

                       given the audacity
                         they contented
                             two years

              erratic intervals for four years

                     foyers

             coiled loop
                        sprang
                            back into darkness

                   stayed put a short while

                         pretty low form

                          them pleasing

                        approaching a yelp

                the ground, or at least each other


                    inflamed guards
                         without abate

                         round his cell
                     round and round his cell

                           intend to do

                        complicated gestures
               long series of complicated gestures

                           park alongside
                           time to collect

              Bishop’s convention
                           tasted much better
              something howled across
                           the graveyard of his ship

                      this was the death-pill

                slow-motion display
                    open contempt

                 detested the kings

                 how can you return?


                      provided accompaniment
                              top to bottom

             they haven’t replied

                 unscrambled and rescrambled
                           scramble
                           scumble
                           stumbles after me

              on my flight
                     given conditions

                     glowered at the signals
                              by proxy
                              taking the box

                       try to calm yourself

              Keats, like the criminal classes, drags
      his loathsome length along the ooze to make children good

                     amble around that huge number

                          the wrong details

                        hunger, fed up


                              they got it
                                  we haven’t

Date:         Sun, 13 Apr 2003 15:22:39 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: dancing over reasons
In-Reply-To:  <1050092803.3e972503859be@webmail.scsv.nevada.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I don't find it strange that academics want to talk about "subjectivity" when discussing Ashbery.  They need to invoke such categories in order to be taken seriously within a profession that has little interest in poetry as such.  What would be strange would be if an academic wrote a book about Ashbery and _didn't_ mention "subjectivity."

I think one could go further, and claim that most academics are only able to write about poems that seem to fit pre-existing professional categories.  That's why Susan Howe is so often written about in learned journals, and Robert Pinsky is not.  So long as "subjectivity" or the "material signifier" or "women writers" are dominant categories within the profession, Howe will attract many commentators; should "democracy" or the "city" (sorry, "urban spatiality") become dominant, the academics will begin publishing on Pinsky.

But I don't think that most readers of Howe, Pinsky, and Ashbery conceptualize the poetry in this way.  Their abstractions are likely to be more commonplace: for them, the poetry is about happiness, regret, fear, etc.  And, indeed, fear and regret matter to most of us; "subjectivity" does not.  An academic critic might be able to have insights that would interest most readers, but he or she would not be able to articulate them in the authoritative tones of the professional.  There would be no footnotes, no theorists to cite (at least no recent theorists).  There would be no means of answering an interview committee when they ask what "your work is about."

I've just re-read "The System," Ashbery's long Wordsworthian meditation on, among other things, the changing seasons and the nature of human happiness.  I don't recall the word "subjectivity" coming into my thoughts once, and I can't imagine he would use the term either.  Nor, when I try to think like a professionally accredited young scholar, can I call to mind a period of literary history in which "subjectivity" hasn't seemed "complicated."  So what does that say about the usefulness of the category?

Andy


>
>Many academics think subjectivity is complicated; they have theories about
>something they (no doubt pretentiously) call "the subject": its self-presence,
>coherence, or lack thereof.  Why is it strange that such accounts might be
>applied to the poetry of Ashbery?  What you call his inconsequentiality is one
>way of describing his poetic relation to his own subjectivity, the way being in
>the world feels to him.  Would you rather he talked like an artist in a 'major
>motion picture'?
>
>--Nick

was something one day!!!!!! He must have kids (they r men now or ladies)

there feeling about it when they faced dead?????? what they were thinking
about???? Maybe there kids or there fathers or mothers am sure they were sad

moment.

that my life is for the others not for me ……….  I gave all my power and all

Subjectivity is not the opposite of objectivity. Without the subject there
is no object, without the object there is no subject. So why address it? "O
a lot / Blooms, get squashed on the tongue: / Where are you going? Why do
you think you are? / Crushed leaves, berries, the stars / Continually
falling, / streaking the sky: / Can it be a climate? No, it is old and /
Sometimes the agog spectator wrenches a cry / From his own house. He thought
he heard."
John Ashbery. From, "But Not That One."

Joel W.

Date:         Sun, 13 Apr 2003 20:07:39 -0600
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark DuCharme <markducharme@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Nader & LaDuke
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

>how to forge anything like a coalition on the left given the latter
>reality is quite beyond me... so i'll sign off on this thread for
>now, and leave that one for others to ponder, as i ponder it mself...
>
>peace,
>
>joe


I don't really have time-- no offence to anyone-- to get involved in what
Joe memorably calls elsewhere in his post the "shitstorm" of back & forth on
this, but I do want to throw in a few thoughts.  The need to build a
coalition of resistance to the very effective political strategies of the
right is ~exactly~ what's necessary at a time like this, & exactly what the
left has been unable to pull off.  Our inability to do that, plus the
apparent ease with which the left has been coopted (by Dem politicians,
e.g.) is one of the things that has allowed the political discourse in the
U.S. to be steadily shifted to the right in the years since Reagan was first
elected.  Part of the problem is our disunity (which can also be put in a
positive way: our diversity-- & this IS also a strength).  Another problem
is our lack of coherent tactics.  There ARE things about which we should not
compromise, but to never compromise is a great way to be unable to build
consensus, to be unable to negotiate past obstacles, & ultimately to be
unable to to work with anyone but the highly like-minded.  This would be a
fine strategy if people who thought as we do about politics (at least)
numbered something like 70 to 80 percent.  In the present circumstances, it
is self-defeating.

One thing that has always struck me about the right-wing Republicans is
that, like them or not (& let me be very clear that I loathe them), they
have great party discipline.  They work very hard (including, I'm sure, a
lot of arm twisting & coercion & backroom tactics which I disapprove of) to
get senators & representatives, etc., to support their program.  They're a
political machine, & working at their most efficient (the current
administration, & Reagan's first one) they can ram a lot of ambitious (read:
scary) legislation through.  The Democrats haven't been as effective in
getting their programs through, much less in opposing the other side's,
really, since LBJ's Great Society, & before that, Roosevelt.  I think that
until a left or left-liberal party builds that degree of discipline &
effectiveness, then we are going to be unable to turn back much of what
Reagan & Shrub have done.

Which is to say, it comes down to grassroots organizing (which I certainly
am not doing at present, I'll admit).  It also comes down to realizing that
we have to work together, make what alliances we can, & recognize that we
may not easily achieve all of what we want, but with effort & common sense
we can achieve some victories against our real enemies.  & Let's be clear:
wealthy born-again christian zealots who want to wage wars of imperialism
while rolling back civil rights at home are our ENEMIES.  We need to do what
we can, & think clearly about what we are doing, be persistent, & be very
focused on our ultimate aims, or else some day there may not be much
democracy left to fight for.  And that, friends, is what really scares me.

Preachin' to the choir, s'cuse me....

Mark DuCharme

on 4/13/03 3:22 PM, Andrew Rathmann at andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET wrote:

> I don't find it strange that academics want to talk about "subjectivity" when
> discussing Ashbery.  They need to invoke such categories in order to be taken
> seriously within a profession that has little interest in poetry as such.
> What would be strange would be if an academic wrote a book about Ashbery and
> _didn't_ mention "subjectivity."


Adding -ivity to the ends of words seems to be the latest academic fad right
now: Subjectivity, performativity, etc. Less trite than the usual -ism, I
guess, but no less suitably stuffy and obfuscational. It's only a matter of
time before we see:

Phallotivity
Vaginativity
Barakativity
Canadativity


Make up your own!


-m

At 12/04/03 20:06:52, Stephen Vincent <steph484@PACBELL.NET> wrote:
#  On looting the National Museum of Iraq: 50,000 artifacts from 7,000 years of
#  history lost in 48 hours.
#
#  http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/12/international/worldspecial/12CND-BAGH.html
#
#  I find outrageous and unbelievable that U.S. troops would be allowed to
#  stand-by and permit this disaster to happen - to essentially permit the
#  destruction of one of the  prime repositories the world's earliest history.
#  At best one can pray that the objects are not destroyed and that vigilance
#  abounds at the borders for dealers in these artifacts.
#  Cultural terrorism is as old as the hills - including the burning of
#  libraries of which I suspect we will also soon have witness - a form of
#  cutting the tongue out of the enemy. Since these are Iraqis who are
#  performing this cultural self-destruction - and for what angry, desperate
#  and self-serving reasons we can probably imagine - yet, by permitting it to
#  openly happen, whether it be ransacking hospitals, museums, whatever  - the
#  United States Government has shown itself complicit and accountable for
#  contributing to these crimes.
#
#  Or as Secretary of War Donald Rumsfeld put out the Government's apparent
#  point of view yesterday:
#  Think what's happened in our cities when we've had riots and problems and
#  looting. Stuff happens! But in terms of what's going on in that country, it
#  is a fundamental misunderstanding to see those images over and over and over
#  again of some boy walking out with a vase and say, "Oh, my goodness, you
#  didn't have a plan." That's nonsense. They know what they're doing. And
#  they're doing a terrific job. And it's untidy. And freedom's untidy. And
#  free people are free to make mistakes and commit crimes and do bad things.
#  They're also free to live their lives and do wonderful things. And that's
#  what's going to happen here. . . .
#
#
#  I personally feel a deep shame - and I am sure I am far from alone - for
#  what has happened in our name under the watch of "Occupation." In this case
#  I hope the Museums in this country and around the world - as well as the
#  Galleries and dealers that they may stand to profit from these thefts - will
#  take the lead in condemning the U.S. failure to act against these crimes
#  and, most important now, take the lead in supporting Iraqi efforts to
#  recover and restore the stolen treasures of this Museum and possibly other
#  museums and libraries through out Iraq.
#
#  A very sad moment.
#
#  Stephen Vincent
#
Roger

Date:         Mon, 14 Apr 2003 05:03:20 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Lewis LaCook <llacook@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      three more from Dirty Milk
Comments: cc: "arc.hive" <_arc.hive_@lm.va.com.au>,
          software and culture <softwareandculture@listserv.cddc.vt.edu>,
          cyberculture <cyberculture@zacha.org>,
          cupcake kaleidoscope <CupcakeKleidoscope@yahoogroups.com>,
          Renee <curry333@hotmail.com>, rhizome <list@rhizome.org>,
          thingist <thingist@bbs.thing.net>, webartery <webartery@egroups.com>,
          wryting <WRYTING-L@LISTSERV.UTORONTO.CA>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I was standing in the feedback of hours, untouched by
any of the changes coursing through your skin, with
all the white falsity of digital networking caching
dead musics in my face. I was thinking kinship levels
of everything overslept; the birds hadn't gotten up
yet, the sun in her wraparound sunglasses and
tanningBooth smile still had to lend her cool sweet
body to the banks of sky's rhetoric suffused with
surgery; the hands moved within me, plucking from my
veins these intrinsic equations: mind: time shadows;
the slopes of tone. I was messing myself up with her
downsizing in those slick tunnels of usage. When I
woke that day, still coping with fatal latitudes, the
trees and their anatomies had separated for good.




Her voice notches birdsong to delicious flute. Lulls
in use have tamped all cursive stalks into noisy dirt.
Earnings hoisted , soon blond stir panned fruit until
full. Tools numbed by broods of tasks curl genre
around toys on alert.





As dumb luck would have it,  trees are budding beyond
her control in the segment before sleep, as I dream
rows of alphabets frosted with silk. Am I awake, or do
all these hours shiver to pin-size, soliloquoy? True,
you do seem saddened by them, or is it the injection
you fear, slipshod membrane scored with razor snoring
but staring white-eyed at the ceiling of her dreams
until the canon wears off? I weather night thinly,
like a copse of braille.


=====

From:         Charles Bernstein <bernstei@BWAY.NET>
Subject:      Re: On looting the National Museum of Iraq
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed

I want to extend Steve Vincent's comments about the looting of the National=
=20
Museum of Art in Baghdad. Many of us echoed the news during this weekend's=
=20
poetry festival in New York, The People's Poetry Gathering: it was a theme,=
=20
a cry, a lament through much of the proceedings. Abdellatif Laabi called=20
it, quite rightly, it a "crime against culture." Adding insult to injury=20
are the unbelievably callous remarks of Donald Rumsfeld, quoted by Steve --=
=20
I say unbelievably even though my threshold for what I believe the Bush=20
regime will say is constantly being reset to the south side of decency, in=
=20
the direction of, indeed, crimes against culture. A friend at the=20
proceedings mentioned to me that she planned to do a performance in which=20
she stamped on the American flag. But I would say otherwise: Donald=20
Rumsfeld and George Bush are the ones trampling the flag. If we condemn=20
this totally predictable and preventable, can we say with some literal=20
accuracy barbaric?, act, which occurred as a direct result of U.S.=20
government actions and policy, we condemn it, also, in the spirit of an=20
America, our America, that we must now struggle all the harder to reclaim=20
from those who have cut out its heart and sold it in noncompetitive bids to=
=20
Halliburton and the other members of the hooded brotherhood of the Axis of=
=20
Unilateralism.

"Now is the time for your tears."

Charles Bernstein
[http://epc.buffalo.edu/authors/bernstein/new.html]


This is the report from the today's Chronicle of Higher Education:

Looting of Antiquities in Iraq Outrages Scholars

By DANIEL DEL CASTILLO

The looting and destruction of priceless artifacts in Iraq's premier museum=
=20
over the weekend outraged scholars worldwide. They said that the loss or=20
damage of tens of thousands of objects in the National Museum of Iraq could=
=20
forever hurt the understanding of Babylonian, Sumerian, and Assyrian=20
civilizations.

Many of the museum's staff members wept upon seeing the devastation. Nabhal=
=20
Amin, the deputy director, told reporters, "They have looted or destroyed=20
170,000 items of antiquity dating back thousands of years. ... They were=20
worth billions of dollars."

Ms. Amin and other scholars blamed the U.S. military for not protecting the=
=20
museum.

"It was completely avoidable," said McGuire Gibson, one of the world's=20
leading scholars on Mesopotamia and a professor at the University of=20
Chicago's Oriental Institute. "I thought I had gotten assurances that the=20
building would be safeguarded. I have been talking to the military since=20
January 24th, and we supplied them with a list of more than 5,000=20
archaeological sites, which they've been putting on their maps. They know=20
where those locations are."

A spokesman for the U.S. Department of Defense declined to comment on=20
Sunday on how individual sites would be protected. "The mission of the=20
forces has not changed over all since this operation began," the spokesman=
=20
said. "Where those locations that are safe and secure to conduct noncombat=
=20
operations exist, we are making the transition. But I can't talk to any=20
specific location -- it's impossible to know the situation on the ground=20
except for the commanders that are there, who have to make that call."

The loss at the National Museum was particularly devastating since it=20
contained not only its own collections but artifacts from smaller museums=20
around the country in a deliberate effort to centralize and protect the=20
objects from the onslaught of war.

"It's nothing short of a total disaster. It's certainly the worst thing=20
that has ever happened to a museum in the Middle East," said Eckhart Frahm,=
=20
a professor of Assyriology at Yale University. Mr. Frahm, who has worked in=
=20
Iraq, said the losses for scholarship were incalculable, especially given=20
that tens of thousands of cuneiform tablets were stolen or destroyed before=
=20
they had been cataloged or deciphered.

"It wasn't just what was in the showcases, but everything in the basement,=
=20
very little of which had been published or properly examined," he said.

A livid Mr. Gibson, who has spent 34 years working in Iraq and heads the=20
American Association for Research in Baghdad, was frustrated and perplexed=
=20
at how a tragedy of such a cultural magnitude could unfold, especially when=
=20
other archaeological sites have been relatively protected.

"It's the equivalent of if the U.S. Army had been sitting outside the Cairo=
=20
Museum and let it be looted by a mob, or if they had been in Athens and let=
=20
a mob loot the Athens Archaeological Museum," he said.

In an effort to focus international attention on the crisis, a group of=20
scholars of Mesopotamia and the Near East has written a petition to the=20
United Nations, urging measures for the safeguarding of Iraqi cultural=20
heritage now and after the war. The petition, which had more than 260=20
signatures as of Sunday night, is scheduled to be presented to the United=20
Nations today.

"'Mesopotamia' designates the land where human beings first built cities,=20
organized complex states, formulated elaborate religious beliefs, invented=
=20
writing, developed sophisticated visual and literary expression,=20
articulated measures for maintaining law and justice," the petition reads.=
=20
"Destruction of Iraqi cultural heritage will result in devastating and=20
irrecoverable losses to human civilization, and to participate in or allow=
=20
such destruction may inflame resentment and anger throughout the world,=20
particularly in the Middle East. We believe, as is also recognized by the=20
people and government of Iraq, that the ancient cultural heritage of the=20
Iraqi people is at least as vital to their future as oil reserves are to=20
their country's economic survival."

Ko=EFchiro Matsuura, the director general of the United Nations Educational,=
=20
Scientific and Cultural Organization, or Unesco, issued a rare emergency=20
statement on Saturday emphasizing "the urgent need to preserve collections=
=20
and a heritage considered to be one of the richest in the world."

Mr. Matsuura contacted the American and British authorities in Iraq and=20
urged them to take immediate measures to assure military protection for the=
=20
National Museum in Baghdad and another important museum in the northern=20
city of Mosul, as well as other Iraqi cultural institutions and=20
archaeological sites.

Unesco has also alerted Interpol and countries bordering Iraq, requesting=20
that they respect and enforce the 1970 Unesco Convention prohibiting the=20
illicit import, export, and transfer of ownership of cultural property. Mr.=
=20
Matsuura has called upon a variety of cultural, academic, and commercial=20
institutions to join forces with Unesco "in a comprehensive mobilization so=
=20
that stolen objects should not find their way to acquirers."

Outside of Baghdad, other collections important to scholars have also been=
=20
damaged. The University of Mosul last week had its rare-books collection=20
stolen, along with hundreds of ancient Arabic manuscripts, as the city fell=
=20
into chaos. To no avail, clerics used the loudspeakers of the city's=20
mosques, urging looters to respect the religious and cultural heritage of=20
the documents.

details before the after



this is not about what I know

                have had though inevitable

                        at cement floors

         coughing sleep
                is no nissan future present

         just grasping description



this is not about what I know

        surface tension  lays and waits

                as things rule
        or rules about them


    even out of words

                the dark walls, my skin and francis

        wait

Date:         Mon, 14 Apr 2003 08:53:31 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jeffrey Jullich <jeffreyjullich@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Re: On looting the National Museum of Iraq
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

The disappearance of Sumerian-Babylonian artefacts
already started in the '90s, under Hussein's rule (not
that that in any way lessens the enormity of this loss
[and not that any of this lessens the uncomfortable
situation of mourning the disappearance of objects at
a time when loss of life, casualties, would seem to
mean so much more]):

http://iraqaction.org/oldsite/babylon.html

http://www.newint.org/issue316/rivers.htm

The Babylon Museum was filled with empty cases even
before April changed everything.  It's
reported/claimed that Hussein moved artefacts into
safekeeping to protect them from air raids,... but
that was understood to mean they had been permanently
moved into underground circulation.  Other monuments
(the winged bull in the above article) were mutilated
with chainsaws in an attempt to transport them away;
archaeological sites were showing up empty.

(Meanwhile, the Iraqi government had been appealing to
Berlin for the return of the Ishtar Gate, removed
during European imperalist campaigns.)


I studied cuneiform for about two or three years.
(The process of studying cuneiform is remarkably like
Armand Schwerner's ~The Tablets,~ which is much more
faithful to the internal experience of
studying/reading cuneiform than anyone would possibly
imagine from Schwerner's slapstick: the strains
cuneiform places upon the memory require florid
mnemonic devices of, all my fellow students reported
to me, extremely personal and idiosyncratic
connections and inventions: pet's names, relatives...
all mixed in with ancient Babylonia.)

The irony of cuneiform "literature" is that it's
extremely dry and consists almost entirely of receipts
and financial accounting.  Rarities like Gilgamesh are
embraced so fervently by Westerners because they're
one of the few instances of a picaresque, colorful
narrative along Occidental sensibilities.

There are millions, probably tens of millions, of
cuneiform documents, meticulously recording debts,
loans, and payments, mainly.  Their abundance, and
their bureaucratese, makes them more than anyone knows
what to do with.  The vast majority of them are left
untranslated, simply because the thousands that ~have~
been translated have largely been passed over as
unutilizable (cuneiform translators are also, of
course, in diminishing numbers).

My studies centered around a "palaeo-economics"
project, plotting the price fluctuations in six
commodities over a 600 year period . . . barley, cress
. . . wool . . . darn, I can't remember the
commodities any more (a friend who'd invited over for
dinner once tried to put together a meal out of the
food involved!).  Unfortunately for me, a Ph.D. up at
Yale was awarded her dissertation just as we were put
in touch with each other, our research completely
duplicating each other's.  Her name is Alice and, as
far as we knew, there was only one other person, in
Hungary, who was involved with the same material.  (It
was all just waiting to happen and, in a sense,
latently self-evident: the 800-page tome of Abraham
Sachs' edition of the Babylonian Astronomers' Diaries
gave the price changes on a monthly basis for those
years, [along with the rise and the fall of the river
level] so, sort of, it was "simply" a matter of
collating the data.)

Financial records were so extensive and detailed that
my teacher, a Sumerologist, was able to reconstruct,
street by street, house by house, family by family,
the interrelationships of residents in one
city/village in Ur, based on who owed whom how much
money when.


(There's a theory of Denise Schmandt-Besserat's,
incidentally, which is quite persuasive although hotly
contested [Schmandt-Besserat's academic credentials
weren't entirely ~pro forma~], that writing and
cuneiform pictographs originated out of ~counting~ and
numbers, rather than out of language.  The Middle East
is scattered with these odd little Hershey's
Kiss-shaped blobs [the forms vary, actually], billions
of them, of previously unknown purpose.
Schmandt-Besserat established a time line and
genealogy that traced the most archaic cuneiforms
pictographs out of the blob tokens.  [The tokens look
like Yves Tanguy shapes.]  The radicalism of that
possibility is a sort of ~de facto~ grammatology,
where writing would, at least in origin, indeed no
longer be a pale echo of speech.)


Cuneiform is interesting, though, in a "The Subject
Does Not Exist" sort of way: it chronicles a time
~before~ the subject showed any inklings of ever
~beginning~ to exist.  I recall, specifically, the
surprise when, in a particular dynastic history of the
reign of such-and-such a king, out of nowhere the
prose veers and it says something like "And he sat on
a rock..."!  That shift to a more descriptive,
personified concept of person represented a paradigm
shift in depiction.

. . . Similarly, talking about it reminds me, there
were startling moments in the Babylonian Astronomers'
Diaries, which otherwise read like almanacs, where "A
dog appeared inside the city gates" . . .  When Alice
and I first spoke, reminiscing about those few,
bizarre alphabestiary cameo appearances was
heart-warming. ("And remember when the locusts...!")


I'll see if I can't pull some of my pages, graphs and
records from those days together to scan 'n' show.

(Actually, once I learned that Alice had scooped the
commodity information and there was no point in going
further with it [everything except a prose elucidation
was completed, regardless], I went back and plotted
the ~rainfall~ and weather for that same, 600-year
period.  Those graphs I haven't shown anyone yet.)

a new narrative



war data
         claims
        a strong lower reverse
                 of personalities
         absent of perfect hysteria

        calvinated in dead songs rod rrose
        slightly dubious
        reduced to a selavy

a negative sneeze

  then chronology becomes the recently placed not zoo rhetoric

simple servos or
        any group dialectics of
        body caresses
        identity there in the
        deep conquered
        become a scene
        with a pastoral new

Date:         Mon, 14 Apr 2003 12:23:45 -0400
