From:         Steve Tills <STills@GWLISK.COM>
Subject:      in Middle Class Land
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

Out here in Middle Class Land, an aunt and uncle come over to visit.  My
brother and I are watching the conclusion of the Master's Tournament.  My
father has just let my aunt (mother's sister) and uncle in and then gone to
the kitchen, where they will have coffee, cake, etc.

The uncle, nice enough man, makes his usual feeble attempts at social
contact.  He shares his latest "office email Iraq War jokes":
"Why do Iraqi pilots cost less to train?"  "Because they don't have to learn
to land." Etcetera Etcetera Etcetera

My brother, a stock broker and country club golfer, does his best to
politely smile (accept the uncle's feeble attempt at social contact) but not
"reinforce" and encourage the uncle to go on and on.  Yes, he's a stock
broker, but that in no way means he's a redneck or a Republican; he's not,
period.  In fact, his clients have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars on
the Bush Administration stock market, and No, my brother is not even
remotely fond of the pillaging or the pillagers.

I take a slightly more direct and "aggressive" tact.  I know that my uncle
is simply an average Joe, a regular upstate New York, Catholic, TV watching,
family "man" who would be telling jokes from the Anti-Bush side if he were
only intelligent and sophisticated enough to imagine that neither my brother
nor I sympathize with his stupid, pedestrian "humour."  When next he starts
"defending" Hootie Johnson and the legal "right" for the Augusta "National"
Golf Course to restrict their membership to women, I know darn well that
here again, Uncle Middle Class has again incorrectly assumed that my brother
and I are all for the Augusta Neanderthal's rejection of Ms. Burke's efforts
to get women into Augusta as members.  I point out that, Yes, of course
Hootie and the old guard are "not legally obligated" to change their private
club's membership restrictions, but "it's coming, anyway--women will be in
the club within a few years (and rightfully so), so Johnson is just an
idiot-jerk."  End of discussion, essentially, without ruffling his feathers
or even hurting any feelings, and he merely gets a little more reality as to
broaching topics and views that will "impress" his nephews, something he's
tried to do in his same old same old tired, naive manner for 30 years.

After my uncle leaves the room and goes out to the kitchen to join my aunt
and my father and mother, my brother and I keep watching the little
post-tournament ceremony and we start cracking up with jokes about Hootie
Johnson, the racists and chauvinists of Augusta/Georgia, about Tiger Woods
(whom we "dislike" for his "arrogance" and his single-minded approach to
being the greatest golfer, though it makes him less a human).  We laugh at
Hootie Johnson especially, though, for right at this very moment he has a
black golfer (Tiger, the previous year's Master's champ) and a Canadian
golfer (Mike Weir, this years Master's winner, and a left-hander, too) in
the same "sacred, secret Master's Champ Room" at Augusta.  We joke that if
they let Tiger's mother in (she's female, obviously, and she's also Asian),
why then Hootie's head will probably blow up, etc.

What's my point? I don't know, exactly.  To some degree, I'm just sharing
some feelings and thoughts and experience.  I want to say, though, that this
is the same scenario throughout Middle Class Land (at my workplace, for
example, which is a manufacturing plant, or "factory," actually).  I firmly
believe that it's not just western or "upstate" New York, only.  This is
Middle Class Land all over the country.

Steve Tills



Microcomputer/Software Specialist
MIS Dept.- G.W. Lisk Company, Inc.
315-462-4309
Stills@gwlisk.com

Subject:      Meditations - 10

Meditations in a Time of Delusions and Lies - 10

[I write these "meditations" from time to time in an attempt to stay
sane. If you find them tedious, apply the magic of "delete." If you want
to share them with others, feel free to do so.]


April 13, 2003

"Stuff happens," Donald Rumsfeld explains.

Artifacts from thousands of years of civilization smashed and stolen:
"Stuff happens."  How many urns and statues will circulate through the vast
antiquities black market and end up in the vaults of London bankers and
Texas oilmen?

The crowds cheer as the statue of the dictator, another artifact, is pulled
to the ground.  An aerial photo shows that the square is surrounded by
tanks with the crowd barely filling a tenth of it.  These are the
multitudes of Iraqis cheering their liberation.  Most Iraqis are cowering
at home.

Man-on-the-street TV interview with a Baghdad grocer: "We are happy.  We
want freedom from Saddam, yes?  And we want freedom from America.  You
understand?  Both."

Even before Baghdad fell, even before the blood stopped flowing, Syria
became the next target.

North Korea made an important concession: to open talks about their nuclear
program in any format (instead of the bilateral talks with the US they had
demanded).  But, as one expert on Korea comments in The New York Times
(April 13, 2003), "the problem is that, given the mood of the moment, can
the Bush administration take yes for an answer?"

Weapons of mass destruction have yet to be found.  No matter.  The Bush
gang falls upon its crudest, most opportunist rhetorical device: it appeals
to Americans' sense of justice and fair-play, that we are liberating a
people, and that we are acting in the interests of freedom.

My 85-year-old aunt who survived the Nazi murders through her wits and
sheer luck knows something about war.  We have many differences of opinion,
but we share a deep revulsion, and she too is suspicious of the great
arrogance of America.  She is sure disaster awaits America, and then "They
will blame the Jews."

My aunt's paranoia is borne of years of experience, since the Nazis and
other anti-Semites did blame everything on the Jews, from socialism to
socialites.  But she may be on to something in this case too: there is such
a complete identification between the US and Israel, even the same
personnel  Wolfowitz, Perle, and about two dozen other high-placed Jewish
advisors who have promoted the neo-con Likudnik line.  The reactionary
evangelists also promote the same line, but it'll be the Jews who will get
the shaft.

Congressman Moran, on the eve of the war, argued that the US was being
pushed to war by the Jews  an excessive comment, since American Jews were
no different in their opinions than the rest of the country, and if
anything they tilted against the war.  But his remark was accurate in the
sense that these ultra-Zionist demagogues are in the driver's seat.  The
distinctions between the US and Israel are smaller and smaller, the
distinctions between Jews as Jews and Zionist ideologues are growing more
confused day by day.

Once upon a time we Jews fought against the Roman Empire  now we ARE the
Roman Empire.

Jessica Lynch, a wounded POW, is rescued by soldiers, a daring
operation.  She is from Palestine, West Virginia.  Her good buddy, a Hopi
Indian, is killed.  Ironies and absurdities abound in images that violently
crisscross history: the women warriors, the settler and the Indian, the
echoes of Biblical obsession.

A former CIA director gleefully declares that this is the beginning of
World War IV (it turns out that World War III was the Cold War, but the
fact that we did actually avoid nuclear catastrophe deludes us into
thinking that it wasn't a war).

The TV has become so completely subservient, has become such an overt
propaganda operation, that I can barely watch anymore.  I flip on the news
channels, pick up the latest ejaculation, and turn to Comedy Central.  But
even there, stand-up comics entertain the troops.

Demonstrators for peace at the docks in Oakland are shot at with rubber
bullets and other "non-lethal" weapons.  Longshoremen standing by the sides
are also shot and arrested.  After the lockout, was there a reason to
target the ILWU?

"Stuff happens": a few harsh examples of state coercion, just a few
arrests, just some sweeps of immigrants, some civilian "watchdog" groups
like "Campus Watch," just the weight of the media cheering, and perhaps
people will shut up, acquiesce, defend the American way of life.  The fact
of the matter is that the bulk of Americans, at least for the moment,
accept the slide into fascism.  Didn't the Germans?

I do not think that "Peace is Patriotic."  I am not a patriot of the New
Roman Empire.  Peace is a universal.  I do not defend the "American way of
life."  I believe freedom and democracy is a development of humanity and
not a special creature of the United States.  I do not believe that the
two-party system is the highest form of democracy.

I am a traitor.

I hereby declare that my brain is a weapon of mass destruction.  I await
the invasion.

Founded in Chicago in 2001, Flood Editions is an independent press

Subject:      Zimbardo on War and Peace
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

From Zimbardo's (former president of the APA) recent speech which in part
addresses the Surgeon General's recommendations on national stress:
"War is one of the intense stressors  we are
dealing with as a nation. The mature, tough solution is not to look away
from the cause but to deal with the stressor at its origin. To me, that
means to look longer and deeper at this war machine, this prime time,
death-dealing video war game, contrived by the current administration in
the name of "national security."

One of the things that caught my interest here was that in this analysis
which is based in part on contemporary psychological research on
emotion-focused and solution-focused coping strategies
he felt the need to pair 'tough' with 'mature'.  As background here consider
that loosely and stereotypically speaking these strategies can be equated
with sex roles.  Also as background consider that while in general more
productive of solutions, solution-focused coping strategies can lead to
exacerbation of stress when no solution is in fact possible.

that female golfer wanting to play with the Big Boys

Indifference as a form of emotiona; vitality"

From:         Christine Murray <cmurray@UTA.EDU>
Subject:      a/loud little history machine: Yannis Ritsos & "our papers and bo
              oks are burned"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

and Yannis Ritsos, March 21, 1968, "After the Defeat":

After the heavy losses that the Athenians suffered at Aegospotami,
     a little later,
after our final defeat, free talk is dead, so too the Periclean glory,
the flowering of Art, the Gymnasia and the Symposia of our learned
     men.  Now
deep silence and gloom in the Agora, and the Thirty Tyrants
     unaccountable.
Everything, even what is most ours, becomes ours by default, without
     the possibility of any appeal, any defense or vindication,
any formal protest even.  Our papers and books are burned,
our country's honor thrown out in the garbage.  And if we might ever
    be allowed
to bring an old friend as a witness, he would refuse to to come
     for fear of finding himself in our situation--and rightly so.
That's why it's really alright to be here: maybe we can establish a new
     relationship with nature,
gazing out, beyond the barbed wire, at a bit of sea, the stones,
     the grass,
or maybe a cloud at sunset, heavy, violet, touching.  And maybe
     someday we'll find a new Kimon, secretly guided
by the same eagle, to dig down and uncover the iron point
     of our spear,
rusted, that too eaten away, so that he can carry it officially through
     Athens
in a funeral procession or victory celebration, with music and wreaths.

**Translated by Edmund Keeley**

From:         Steve Evans <Steven.Evans@MAINE.EDU>
Subject:      Third Factory
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I've been meaning to mention the following URL for some time

        http://www.thirdfactory.net

A little background, for those interested:

The site, Third Factory/Notes to Poetry, continues an experiment in
criticism that I began in e-mail format back in 1998/99 (now archived as a
.pdf document on Brian Kim Stefans's ARRAS site at
http://www.arras.net/pdfs.htm).

After a longish pause in 1999/2000 and the stormily collective debates
about market-driven poetics in early 2001, I began the transition from
email bulletins to a web format in the summer of 2001. Once the site was
constructed, I tended it off-line for about a year and a half, finally
loading it to a server provided by Jerrold Shiroma/Duration Press just this
past January. Since then it has been quietly logging about forty unique
visits a day--a steady handful of which originate, happily, from outside
the US.

Conceived as an attempt to document one reader's passage through the
teeming field of contemporary poetry, the site is articulated into several
components:

* daybooks - reading, listening to, and looking at contemporary poetry
* constellations - eleven titles that together conspire to look like "the
present" to me
* the lipstick of noise - columns, talks, articles
* notes to poetry - capsule reviews of recent publications
* links - to blogs, poetry sites, a few political resources
* works received - pub info for everything that comes into the house as
gift or purchase

There is also a page that pulls most of these elements together for easy
bookmarking and browsing (http://www.thirdfactory.net/ensemble.html).

Fan of blogs though I am (a current favorite: Stephanie Young's
"Well-Nourished Moon" on blogspot at http://stephanieyoung.blogspot.com/),
I don't update Third Factory frequently enough to have it qualify as a
blog. It's more in the nature of site to be glanced at every now and again:
which is what this e-mail invites you to do.

Steve Evans


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Assistant Professor of English
Coordinator, UMaine New Writing Series
Co-editor, Sagetrieb: Poetry and Poetics after Modernism
1-207-581-3809 | Steven.Evans@umit.maine.edu
www.thirdfactory.net

i've heard it said that "most" or "many" Americans are stupid, and that's simply
not true.  some are more informed than others (for various reasons), and the more
aware everyone becomes--REALLY SEEING what it is our consumption of goods,
services and other resources is doing to the people of this planet, and to the
planet, the better choices we'll finally begin to make together.  Big Mouths
like me have our work to do, patiently studying the affects of alarm clocks,
sitting beside them eating or speaking different things until the giant alarm
is perfected for running into the streets with our poems or bull horns.

in Philadelphia there is a 92-year-old poet named Herschel Barron who about
lost his head to Joseph McCarthy when he was younger.  i ran into Herschel
a couple of weeks ago to hear him promise me that Homeland Security will
prove to be far more ominous than the witch-hunts he and others were
subjected to when he was his own kind of walking alarm clock.

i first met Herschel when i was a teenager, and i've never heard or seen
him so agitated about the political climate within our borders.  i DO RECALL
him giving a speech about ten years ago at a union rally, and saying that
if the bourgeois poets of his day had gotten off their asses and lent
him and others a hand that things might not have become so grim.

more and more i believe that Americans will involve themselves in the
reparations of labor and land if they can really GLIMPSE the daily
battlefield our consumption creates.  this is a country of AMAZING
people, millions and millions of amazing people who are good, and
want to do good by the world, but maybe they don't always get to
see how certain things they do in their lives affect the world.

more later,
CAConrad

From:         Steve Tills <STills@GWLISK.COM>
Subject:      Re: Zimbardo on War and Peace
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

Re: Tom Bell's post on the Subject of "Zimbardo on War and Peace," some of
which I copied in below:
"From Zimbardo's (former president of the APA) recent speech which in part
addresses the Surgeon General's recommendations on national stress: "War is
one of the intense stressors we are dealing with as a nation. The mature,
tough solution is not to look away from the cause but to deal with the
stressor at its origin. To me, that means to look longer and deeper at this
war machine, this prime time, death-dealing video war game, contrived by the
current administration in the name of 'national security.'
One of the things that caught my interest here was that in this analysis
which is based in part on contemporary psychological research on
emotion-focused and solution-focused coping strategies he felt the need to
pair 'tough' with 'mature'. As background here consider that loosely and
stereotypically speaking these strategies can be equated with sex roles.
Also as background consider that while in general more productive of
solutions, solution-focused coping strategies can lead to exacerbation of
stress when no solution is in fact possible."
I am reminded of undergraduate school class (25+ years go, and I recall
studying Zimbardo, too--Phillip?), "Group Process," for which Prof Borkk had
the class elect "a process" leader (to facilitate, and/or attend to,
emotional processes) and "a project" leader (to facilitate task
organization).  No, he wasn't trying to show us how splitting up leadership
into those two roles would make each work better, i.e., you can get more
done if you cut off the emotions?
I am reminded of undergraduate classes (also years ago) in Humanistic
Psychology with Prof November and many times getting the difference between
"doing" and "being" (Perls' Gestalt drew on Heidegger and we got plenty of
both in November classes).  I frequently understood that those into "doing"
(including my "over-achiever" self(serf?) at the time) were often cutting
off "the being" parts of themselves, parts that are considerably more
"reflective," "patient," "meditative," "still," in tune with greater depth
(and ambivalence and ambiguity) of emotions and range of emotion.
I am reminded of the distinctions between mental health and mental
not-health: the former observes and nourishes through life an increasing
capacity for experiencing "tolerance of ambivalence"; the latter shuns and
avoids ambivalence and remains rigidly resistant to this mind/body state
inside.  Hey, both of these are all of us, in varying degrees, on numerous
levels.
I am reminded of poets here in the Experimental venues and elsewhere in
Mainstream venues, all cherishing and revering "ambiguity," indeed generally
equating it with the term poetry altogether.
Back to Zimbardo, and Tom Bell's take: I have a strong hunch that "mature
and tough" refers to approaching problem solving with the immense and adult
courage it takes to look inside, maturely take responsibility for one's own
emotions (like, for example, I'm sure that Bush never looked deeply inside
and thought to himself, Geez, Clinton got that great economy and stuff
through his 8 years, and here I am in Robert Reich's aftermath, I'll bet
they planned it this way, the economy crapping out and balancing itself and
then I got this 9/11 thing, too, why have they been so damn hard on my Pappy
and me, why can't they just let me have a really cool presidency,
too--ooops, that's the C-student in me spoiled by Pappy's riches and
thinking I deserve everything without ever having to really work for it;
I'll show them, I'll start some wars, How dare they make me take a hard look
at my inadequacies and my father's imperfect fathering!).  The
neoconservatives and facists in general come from an entirely difference
emotional/psychological orientation.  They want to kill off "being" and
perfect "doing."  For them, "hard work" is never a matter of facing inner
demons, ambivalence, and ambiguity inside in order to better "understand"
what it means "to be," much less respecting "others"'conception of same.
For them, "hard work" is strictly external "action" that achieves goals,
especially political goals, that statistically perfect an apparently static
and entirely preplanned world, a product idealized in their minds and
American Enterprise Institute programs, etc.
I wonder, of course, if a lot of us must also exercise our so-called
advantage for accepting/understanding being, and for living with
ambiguity--but in ways we are not considering.  Are we being too intolerant
of our own more "forceful" abilities, not, smile, throwing maletov cocktails
at the Whitehouse, but, ummm, well, who knows what our greater ingenuity
could come up with.  (Personally, I'd love to be able to organize Buffett
(who says there will be a special place reserved in hell for Gary Winnick of
Global Crossing), George Soros (staunchly opposed to the war and Bush
actions), and Bill Gates, and a few others; together, a few of these parties
could bring Bush-egonomics down to its knees in a week or two via focused
and pinpointed "shorting" of the defense industries and the investment banks
that have stolen so much from retail investors.  I'm sure there is a fair
amount of money in Hollywood that would agree to collectively castrate the
neoconservatives' money machines as well.)
I don't know.  Just some thoughts here.

Steve Tkills, Tills  :)





Microcomputer/Software Specialist
MIS Dept.- G.W. Lisk Company, Inc.
315-462-4309
Stills@gwlisk.com

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      A Tyrant in Noose
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

A Tyrant in Noose


Philo, Questions and Answers on Genesis, translated Marcus:

57. (Gen. xix. 37) Why did the elder (daughter) on bearing a son call him
Moab, proclaiming aloud what ought to have been concealed, (namely) "he is
from my father"?

The literal meaning is (an occasion of) exultation and glorification for
those who think rightly. For she did not cease (talking) and remain quiet
as if (it were) a reproach but prided herself in thought as if on a great
achievement, and with delight said, "I have a deserved honour, which the
father, who is the mind in me, sowed. And having been sown, he did not
disintegrate and pass away but having been born perfect, he was found
worthy of birth and nurture." And what should be the irreprehensible and
irreproachable progeny of the mind and counsel if not good and excellent
counsel. Wherefore (the child) who was born was a male.

Genesis xix. 36-37:

36 Thus the two daughters of Lot became pregnant by their father.
37 And the firstborn bare a son, and called his name Moab; the same is the
father of Moab unto this day.

Now please note that "Moab" is m'av, from the father. Thus Moab carries
the name of the father in the son produced from an incestuous union. Of
course this has been repeatedly re/marked.

Therefore there is the father and the son whose sister is his mother; the
genes strangle and turn to salt. Now out of this union MOAB, the Mother Of
All Bombs, appears, the Mother who is the also the Son of the Father, in
order that the Father complete His work, which become the work of the Son.

Such is the work and the noose of the work that tightens on zero, on null,
on total annihilation, MOAB; thus the Absolute appears even within this
family circle, that of the tyrant itself.

Genesis xix. 30-35:

30 And Lot went up out of Zoar, and abode in the mountain, and his two
daughters with him; for he feared to abide in Zoar: and he abode in a
cave, he and his two daughters.
31 And the firstborn said unto the younger, Our father is old, and there
is not a man in the earth to come unto us after the way of all of the
earth:
32 Come, let us make our father drink wine, and we will lie with him, that
we may keep alive seed from our father.
33 And they made their father drink wine that night: and the firstborn
came and lay with her father; and he knew now when she lay down, nor when
she arose.
34 And it came to pass on the morrow, that the firstborn said unto the
younger, Behold, I lay yesternight with my father; let us make him drink
wine this night also; and come thou, and lie with him, that we may keep
alive seed from out father.
35 And they made their father drink wine that night also; and the younger
arose, and lay with him; and he knew not when he lay down, nor when she
arose.

Rashi: ...whereas in reference to Moab it (Scripture) only forbade waging
war against them but permitted them (the Israelites) to vex them.

(Rosenbaum/Silbermann translation.)

be careful when delving into the past, as poetry often does, for some
prisoners there is nothing back there they care to remember.

also to protect yourself be sure that they know you are only available to
them during the workshops, don't encourage them to send you stuff or keep
contact with you after the workshops. try not to get involved in the
personal dramas of their lives, clearly define your role as a literary
mentor so that they don't get too dependent on you personally.

but, apart from this, i have found such workshops can be fun and rewarding
for you and the incacerated.

a fellow called charles remington first introduced me to prison workshops
and he'd go in with a pocket full of lollies and a packet of cigarettes,
even though he didn't smoke himself, but i found my presence at workshops
was usually a treat in itself, they don't get much contact with people from
'the outside'.

cheers
komninos

From:         Philip Nikolayev <philn@KANDASOFT.COM>
Subject:      POET KATIA KAPOVICH IN THE BOSTON GLOBE
Comments: To: Poetryetc provides a venue for a dialogue relating to poetry and

POETRY IN MOTION

Author:    David Mehegan, Globe Staff Date: March 29, 2003 Page: E1 =
Section: Living / Arts

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - Force of nature. There must be a more original =
descriptor for Katia Kapovich, Russian poet, but no milder one will do. =
With her flaming hair, ever-present cigarette, and intense voice =
punctuated with darting or sweeping gestures, she resembles some =
universal physical force, such as gravity or magnetism. By turns ironic, =
pensive, droll, and passionate in telling her life story in a low and =
lilting voice, this force is fueled by poetry.

Like other writers who came of age in the old Soviet Union, Kapovich =
battled crushing pressure to conform. In one 1980 melee in St. =
Petersburg, she slugged a cop while resisting arrest. She's been =
confined in a psychiatric hospital, harassed and ostracized, yet endured =
to become a known artist in her native country. Since she settled in =
Cambridge 11 years ago, life has been much quieter. Now 42, she is =
married to Russian poet and medievalist Philip Nikolayev, and they have =
a daughter, Sonia, 4 1/2. Kapovich and Nikolayev are editors of Fulcrum, =
a new literary review, and Kapovich works at Schoenhof's, the Cambridge =
foreign-language bookstore near Harvard Square.

Yet Kapovich's artistic life now has a different kind of excitement. In =
recent years, she has begun a metamorphosis into an American poet. She =
hasn't abandoned her native tongue - Kapovich has published four books =
of poetry in Russian. But English has given her a new voice.

The only child of Jewish parents in Kishinev, in southern Russia, =
Kapovich began writing poems when she was 7. Because of anti-Semitism - =
and because her father had antagonized Soviet authorities - Kapovich was =
barred from colleges in Kishinev, so in 1977 she enrolled in a college =
in Nizhnii Tagil, a gritty industrial town near the Ural Mountains =
surrounded by prison camps.

In her two years there, she studied literature, but the atmosphere was =
as grim as the surroundings: "I was beaten and ostracized. You had to =
subscribe to Izvestia and Pravda, but I objected - `I don't want these =
papers. I never read any Soviet paper.' "

Sick and depressed, she "escaped" to Kishinev and found another sort of =
trouble brewing. Her father, organizer of an architects collaborative to =
bypass the government and build rural housing, was imprisoned for crimes =
against the state. Kapovich's mother insisted her only daughter continue =
her studies, and Kapovich got into a Kishinev institute, studying world =
and Russian literature. There, she found a circle of like-minded young =
poets - a connection that became a lifeline.

The poets became part of an underground network, trundling clunky =
typewriters to other cities to find and secretly copy forbidden books - =
writings of Joseph Brodsky, Alexei Tsvetkov, Vladimir Nabokov.

"We met every day," Kapovich says. "We were on the phone, we would =
laugh, recite poems, and type them out."

Though the 1980s were the waning years of the Soviet Union, "the KGB =
made us famous," Kapovich says. "They would come to the university and =
say, `Beware of certain people who try to entice young intellectuals =
into their so-called literary movement.' They would give out our names =
and make us visible. People would immediately become interested in us. =
We were like forbidden fruit."

In August 1980, Kapovich's fiance, poet Eugene Horvat, frantically =
buried borrowed manuscripts in a Leningrad flower bed as she distracted =
a suspicious police officer. Another time, her typewriter and poems she =
carried were confiscated. Police later jailed the couple and their =
friends for issuing leaflets at Leningrad universities, demanding =
intellectual freedom. Despite her slender build, Kapovich fought back, =
and her glasses were smashed.

Thinking back, she dismisses the idea she was a hero or martyr: "I am =
actually not very brave. I was just obstreperous and hard to control. I =
wasn't afraid, because I was in love, and we were poets, and that is =
what mattered."

Ultimately, the young poets were returned to their hometowns for KGB =
interrogations. "My father was in prison, and they strongly recommended =
I undergo treatment in a madhouse," Kapovich says. "They said, `We know =
how close you are to your father, and you don't want anything to happen =
to him.' "

Her confinement lasted a few weeks at first, then she was discharged on =
a kind of probation, required to get a job and check in with the =
hospital from time to time. She was given counseling and medicated. =
"They found me very inadequate and manic-depressive because I would cry =
and say `I want to go right now,' and they would stop me and say `Don't =
you realize you need help?' " This continued intermittently for years, =
even as she worked during the day and studied at night. But she lost =
each job when she was caught writing poems.

Horvat's hometown, a suburb of Leningrad, had an especially brutal KGB =
office. Kapovich says her fiance openly admitted his activities to the =
agents. "I did it. These are my papers," she recalls him saying. Agents =
beat him, threatened to rape his sister, and forced him into exile in =
1981. Kapovich visited him in Berlin in 1989, but by then "he was mad," =
she says, sadly. Two years later, he killed himself. As she speaks, =
Kapovich takes a framed photograph of Horvat from the wall, gently =
placing it on the table.

"You had to get out of that world in order to see what was really =
there," Kapovich says. The state control was so pervasive that "they =
didn't need to kill thousands of people. A poet makes the evil visible. =
The way you breathe, the way you look at people is different, and they =
sense it. They would say, `We don't like the look on your face. You look =
like a foreigner.' "

In 1983, Kapovich received a master's degree in literature, with honors. =
She stayed in Kishinev for the next seven years but struggled to find =
teaching work, getting and losing menial jobs. She once smuggled =
sheepskins to make ends meet. She married a member of her circle, and =
when the Soviet Union fell apart in 1990, she moved to Israel with her =
husband and mother.

When her marriage dissolved, Kapovich moved to Cambridge in 1992, to =
marry another poet from her Kishinev group who lived in Boston, but that =
marriage didn't last, either. Philip Nikolayev, whom she had known in =
Russia, was a student at Harvard, and they eventually wed. She then =
enrolled in Boston College, receiving a degree in Russian literature in =
1995.

Though she had always loved poetry written in English - Dylan Thomas, =
Robert Frost - she wrote her first poem in English unexpectedly. "Paper =
Plane to Nowhere," written in 1997, was about the Kishinev psychiatric =
hospital, a subject that stymied her when writing in Russian.

"It was amazing," she says. "It was so simple, flowing through my mind, =
as if I were telling somebody, what [Osip] Mandelstam calls `the =
providential reader.' I was jumping up and down, like Pushkin jumped =
after finishing a poem, jumping for joy because I had tried to tell this =
story many times. But English made it possible."

Many of her English poems have appeared in literary journals and in a =
just-published anthology from Random House, though her manuscript of 55 =
poems, "Gogol in Rome," has yet to be published.

The importance of poetry in her life can't be exaggerated. "My =
[previous] husband was a nice guy," she says, "but I basically divorced =
him because of poetry. The last straw was when he said about my favorite =
poet, Timur Kibirov, `It's not even poetry.' I adore Kibirov. I said, =
`We cannot live together, you don't like Kibirov.' "

Last January, after a reading in Washington, the audience received =
copies of a poem, and a woman approached her - a poet from Kurdistan. =
"She said her husband was sick, and this poem could cure him," Kapovich =
recalls. "I looked in her eyes, because you can tell if a person is mad. =
It is a dream to write poetry in such a way that it can cure people."

Kapovich picked up the poem, signed her name, then added a Hebrew phrase =
from the Bible: "Talita ve kumi."

Get up and walk.

Good Day

People change in phenomenally small ways.  But the news changes =
instantly.  And it isn't obvious.  Today.  The televisions at work were =
showing some sort of bohnspiel and motor racing.  These are realities =
that I might have seen on the news:  I have a happy face pen that is =
black and yello; I am white; the sky is falling or else it is rain and =
then snow after the sun sets.  Doomed to always make sense, pistachio =
roses, logs, and strong coffee.  As well as those good grey days.  While =
it rains, the phone rang so close to Easter, news about a Toronto =
reading series filter through my only channels.

Good Day

Soulcrush.  Regime change.  These are our fits that were not always.  Of =

being in 2003.  Instead of on 2003.  To be tied.  Don't tread on me.  I =
have a crush on your soul.  Let's change regimes.  Check Yes or Not-no.  =
And I washed the light blue sheets again.  Tonight I'll switch them with =
the dark blue ones, but only if the rain stops.  And you'll never know.

Good Day

Shrapnel and azaleas hurtle over the radio, a commercial each for =
different products.  That it could happen, that it did.  Operation Iraqi =
Freedom means metal in the head and breast.  Shot through windows, =
explosions in the sky.  Rahed Hakem remembers "the voice of explosions" =
and saw from her door "the sky raining fire".  Bomblets.  Let's bomb.  =
In the name of freedom.  We can't say french.  Some remain unexploded =
right before the television screen in the living room.  Register your =
firearms.  I wonder if these little bombs have warning labels for =
children that say:  "if you can read this."  Cluster fuck.  What now.  =
What next?  That question leads Us.  Will that be our answer ad =
infinitum?

Good Day

I woke up late today and there still weren't tanks or the sounds of =
gunfire=20
outside on 19th Ave NW.  The ground wasn't violently heaving.  Tho the=20
carpet was thick with dust.  After eight hard days at work it was nice =
to=20
wake slowly.  My girlfriend made coffee early and by the time I got out =
of=20
bed it was thick, full, steeped.  So I put on another pot, but not =
because=20
of that.  She let her cup go cold.  I finished mine.  War stats and star =

wars.  Wonder how far along the film is along now?  Sunny Baghdad.  The =
airport seems to be the last site of open warfare.  From now on it =
becomes an urban mission.  Maybe that's when we'll feel the tread of the =
tanks shake my basement apartment walls, maybe then we won't be able to =
go down the street to the A & A deli for baklawa.  And maybe not.  Maybe =
while buildings are rocked with mortar fire over there, I'll still want =
to sleep in, be tired from work, and upset that I don't have time to =
read the books I want to read.  Maybe absolutely nothing on the surface =
will be disrupted here in Calgary.  Good for business, I guess.

Good Day

Queen Victoria's. Secrets and do you like that. Do you want a tarot =
reading? Ere the crows fly the colours of their home. They fly the cross =
of the blue factory flame. Magnetic poetry company. They ain't true =
colours, but they're real colours of their flame. Paralyzed by the =
emptiness. Chalice. Blog. Thinfragilair.blogspot.com. Blix. Choose the =
dominoes to spread a street centric system for spray paint. It is =
uncanny. That this could be newsworthy. Cluster bombs. Post fact. Every =
mile for ten thousand mile. Every year for a thousand year. Every night =
for a thousand nights. Thank you jason molina. It gets blurry and =
continentally important. Biased. Space. Woman's voice. Paralyzed. Wounds =
funny, shrapnel record, go ahead. Who knows?  ' </jason> <!--4:25 AM-->

Good Day

It moves left and right. Responsible person can't lie. It is a =
hierophant=20
and a middle idel for land mines. Glenn says post your own page. Good =
Day. It shines and world flights one of one, and oreo and a beer. With =
the takeover of CPU. It happens and slices into islands or peninsulas =
and=20
spelling mistakes, a rise in the drama. More results for search engines. =

Socks up, chemical weapons masks on. Functional alcoholism makes me =
reasonable. The raindrops. Shades.

Good Day

Resigned.  That ignition.  Or ignoble nation.  Don't underline that.  =
The=20
prisoners buy French fries and make the mental switch, from fast food to =

freedom and maybe back again.  I target.  That you've linked your =
website to my arm.  My army.  The weather has been warm today, at least =
plus 6.  Over bells and coffee, at work read.  Sentences dip and swerve, =
meld, monitor just behind conversation.  Do you want breakfast?  Where =
is this?  Calgary local 499.  As though my feet weren't as cold.  Number =
please, area calls only at this phone box, she said, clipped British.  =
Tony divides the house and offers US half.  That it can't always rain.  =
And French fries were never a problem there, at least not as much as in =
Boyse.  International assemblies, places, Poland, that a page is so =
cosmopolitan.  Resigned.  We laud and attack Bush's attributes with the =
same breath.  There are experts about this war.  I've seen them on TV.  =
There the ones that don't have shrapnel all over them.  And they look so =
proud with their new suits, new haircuts.  Finally, after years of =
study, their specialities are wanted.  Vindication!  Not only a boost to =
the economy, but they finally have something to say and something to say =
it about.  I finally hit the stride, eh?  Fingering freedom, these black =
little buttons, that it may as well be informed.  Maybe I should ask CNN =
for an opinion column and then open myself up for expert media analysis. =
 What was his name?  Scharf?  Shrafe?  Shade? =20
If it isn't well written then we don't give a damn.  Don't you care =
enough=20
to write properly, with passion, and attention to the minutest detail? =20
Don't you care?  Don't you care at all?  The experts on CNN care a great =
deal, look how plainly they spell it out, look, admire their =
transparency,=20
eh?  Got to get it right in the end.


Good Day

All the towels smell like you today.  Even as Saddam's head topples in =
the center of Baghdad, somehow the day is a balmy plus ten in Calgary.

Good Day

First an American flag was placed over his head, just rested against the =

chain noosed around his neck, and then the flag of Iraq was draped =
across his mouth.  Things will be different, I guess.  Not better maybe, =
but different at least.  Iraq has been liberated into freedom.  America =
is given diplomatic immunity from foreign policy virus.  And like that =
it never existed.  Should the coverage now shift SARS-ward?  The media =
has a field day on their hands, what with a war and an epidemic at the =
same time.  Our years shouldn't be marked anymore.  Not with numbers.  =
And our days, only a tally of the events.  Even as they are sufficiently =
violent.

Good Day

What it means, what it meant, what will it, wills it, that apple pie, =
our=20
debt.  Shackled forever, ensnared by the chains of liberty, eh?  The =
charms are ours.  Pizza, hamburgers, and shoestring fries.  Not French.  =
Operation Iraqi Freethum.  Rolls off the tongue and over the citizens, =
down into the center of Baghdad.  Infinite Justice.  Good, pray for =
infinite justice.

From:         "Lipman, Joel A." <JLipman@UTNET.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject:      Re: prison workshops
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Komninos's advice is consistent with my experience, both with women's =
and men's floors in prisons, jails & work farms. Work closely with the =
inmate services staff -- they know the prisoners, meds & problems, and =
the inside culture. Try to publish something including their work [our =
program did a collection called FROM INSIDE OUT, a chap called STAINLESS =
STEAL] -- there's a lot of prison literature that's been gathered over =
the years. Read, if you haven't already, the poems of Etheridge Knight, =
Michael Hogan and some of the work gathered in the past by Joe Napora. =
If anyone on this list knows how to contact Diane Kendig get her =
address, as she did workshops at the state prisons in Lima, Ohio for =
years. Be adept at transcribing the words of participants who lack =
writing skills or find an inmate participant who can assist them outside =
of the workshop. Bring in guest writers insofar as the program and joint =
allows you to. Don't delve into their personal histories, but work with =
the writers to explore themselves either with or without creative =
masking. Desire is a theme that our workshops constantly had great =
success with. Iterative forms work well as patterned repetition tends to =
be loosely connected and quick. Prison and jail workshops are wonderful =
environments for teaching poetry & writing -- the folks really need what =
you have to offer. Enjoy & good luck. [a postal address will get you a =
copy of INSIDE OUT].  JL

New College Emerging Artists Series

Thursday, May 1st, 7.30pm -- free

New College Cultural Center, 766 Valencia (between
18th & 19th Sts., San Francisco)
http://www.newcollegenews.net/index.html

Duncan McNaughton has published several books,
including Valparaiso, Kicking the Feather, and a
translation of Italian poet Dario Villa’s works
entitled Venus Ill-treated by the Odd Ones. In
addition, his long poem “The Quarry” was chosen by
Robert Creeley for Best American Poetry 2002.

David Hadbawnik is a poet and performer who has
published work in Skanky Possum,
-Vert, Cauldron & Net, Electronic Poetry Review,
Jacket, among others. He has collaborated with
several movement, performance, and music-based
artists, and also publishes Habenicht Press.

Noam Birnbaum is a student of poetics at New
College.

Also performing is the East Bay new music ensemble
Married Couple. Married Couple (Rob Ewing,
trombone; Lisa Mezzacappa, double bass; Jason
Levis, drums) performs a hybridized blend of
avant-jazz, soul, pop, and classic New Orleans
rag, swinging effortlessly through interpretations
of everything from Björk to Shostakovitch to
Coltrane, with original compositions that draw
from every musical genre. The band celebrates the
release of their new album Looks Like a Pie to Me;
for more information, visit
http://www.marriedcoupletheband.com.

The Germ and the Poetic Research Bloc present:

Abdellatif La=E2bi

Sunday, April 20 at 4pm at Dawson's Book Shop!

***
Poet, novelist, playwright, and essayist, Abdellatif La=E2bi is one of =
the
most prolific and critically acclaimed of contemporary North African
writers.  He was born in 1942 in F=E8s (Morocco). In 1966 he founded =
the
magazine Souffles =
<http://clicnet.swarthmore.edu/souffles/sommaire.html>
which would play an important role in the renewal of Moroccan cultural =
life.
He created the publishing house Atlantes and also the Association de
Recherche Culturelle - the activities of which did not please the =
Moroccan
government. Abdellatif Laabi was arrested and spent eight years in jail =
from
1972 to 1980. He settled in France in 1985. He has published Le Soleil =
se
meurt in 1992, L'Etreinte du monde in 1993 and Le Spleen de casablanca =
in
1996. His novel, Rue du retour, has been translated into English and
published by Readers International. In 1999 he was awarded the Fonlon
Nichols Prize by the African Literature Association and the
Wallonie-Bruxelles poetry prize. The World's Embrace: The Selected =
Poems of
Abdellatif La=E2bi (City Lights Books, 2003) consists of poems selected =
by
La=E2bi from three books published in French over the past ten years. A =
novel,
Le Fond de la jarre, was published by Gallimard in 2002.

The World's Embrace <http://www.citylights.com/CLpub4th.html>, from =
City
Lights, is his latest book in English.=20

For more on Laabi,. see his Swarthmore entry:
<http://clicnet.swarthmore.edu/litterature/moderne/laabi/presentation.ht=
ml>=20

Read some of his poetry (in French):
<http://clicnet.swarthmore.edu/litterature/moderne/laabi/heure.html>=20

***

Doors open at 4. Readings at 4:30.

Dawson's Book Shop is located at 535 N. Larchmont Blvd between Beverly =
Blvd
and Melrose Blvd in the Larchmont district south of Hollywood, CA.
Bookstore Tel: 323-469-2186

Readings are open to all. $3 donation requested for poets/venue.

Call Andrew at 310.460.4035 for more info.

From: Steve Tills <STills@GWLISK.COM>
To: POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Date: Monday, April 14, 2003 9:34 AM
Subject: in Middle Class Land


>Out here in Middle Class Land, an aunt and uncle come over to visit.  My
>brother and I are watching the conclusion of the Master's Tournament.  My
>father has just let my aunt (mother's sister) and uncle in and then gone to
>the kitchen, where they will have coffee, cake, etc.
>
>The uncle, nice enough man, makes his usual feeble attempts at social
>contact.  He shares his latest "office email Iraq War jokes":
>"Why do Iraqi pilots cost less to train?"  "Because they don't have to
learn
>to land." Etcetera Etcetera Etcetera
>
>My brother, a stock broker and country club golfer, does his best to
>politely smile (accept the uncle's feeble attempt at social contact) but
not
>"reinforce" and encourage the uncle to go on and on.  Yes, he's a stock
>broker, but that in no way means he's a redneck or a Republican; he's not,
>period.  In fact, his clients have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars on
>the Bush Administration stock market, and No, my brother is not even
>remotely fond of the pillaging or the pillagers.
>
>I take a slightly more direct and "aggressive" tact.  I know that my uncle
>is simply an average Joe, a regular upstate New York, Catholic, TV
watching,
>family "man" who would be telling jokes from the Anti-Bush side if he were
>only intelligent and sophisticated enough to imagine that neither my
brother
>nor I sympathize with his stupid, pedestrian "humour."  When next he starts
>"defending" Hootie Johnson and the legal "right" for the Augusta "National"
>Golf Course to restrict their membership to women, I know darn well that
>here again, Uncle Middle Class has again incorrectly assumed that my
brother
>and I are all for the Augusta Neanderthal's rejection of Ms. Burke's
efforts
>to get women into Augusta as members.  I point out that, Yes, of course
>Hootie and the old guard are "not legally obligated" to change their
private
>club's membership restrictions, but "it's coming, anyway--women will be in
>the club within a few years (and rightfully so), so Johnson is just an
>idiot-jerk."  End of discussion, essentially, without ruffling his feathers
>or even hurting any feelings, and he merely gets a little more reality as
to
>broaching topics and views that will "impress" his nephews, something he's
>tried to do in his same old same old tired, naive manner for 30 years.
>
>After my uncle leaves the room and goes out to the kitchen to join my aunt
>and my father and mother, my brother and I keep watching the little
>post-tournament ceremony and we start cracking up with jokes about Hootie
>Johnson, the racists and chauvinists of Augusta/Georgia, about Tiger Woods
>(whom we "dislike" for his "arrogance" and his single-minded approach to
>being the greatest golfer, though it makes him less a human).  We laugh at
>Hootie Johnson especially, though, for right at this very moment he has a
>black golfer (Tiger, the previous year's Master's champ) and a Canadian
>golfer (Mike Weir, this years Master's winner, and a left-hander, too) in
>the same "sacred, secret Master's Champ Room" at Augusta.  We joke that if
>they let Tiger's mother in (she's female, obviously, and she's also Asian),
>why then Hootie's head will probably blow up, etc.
>
>What's my point? I don't know, exactly.  To some degree, I'm just sharing
>some feelings and thoughts and experience.  I want to say, though, that
this
>is the same scenario throughout Middle Class Land (at my workplace, for
>example, which is a manufacturing plant, or "factory," actually).  I firmly
>believe that it's not just western or "upstate" New York, only.  This is
>Middle Class Land all over the country.
>
>Steve Tills
>
>
>
>Microcomputer/Software Specialist
>MIS Dept.- G.W. Lisk Company, Inc.
>315-462-4309
>Stills@gwlisk.com
>

Date:         Mon, 14 Apr 2003 22:21:31 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Kevin Killian <kevinkillian@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Enthusiastic
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

Enthusiastic about the new issue of "House Organ" which came to me
over the weekend and which I opened somewhat warily.  But yeepee,
wait till you read this issue, I can heartily recommend it.  it's
composed of just two poems, "Adamant" and "From Inform to
Information," both of them by William Sylvester.  While I was reading
"Adamant" I had that strange feeling of the hair sticking up on the
back of my neck that I associate wrongly or rightly with Emily
Dickinson!!!  Maybe she said it somewhere or something.  Anyhow, if
William Sylvester is on this list, congratulations on having written
a really great poem.  I don't know how you did it!  Were you a
soldier during World War II?  If so, how old are you?  If not, how
did you make this material so convincing, and yet so
all-encompassing, a funnel or tunnel through which we see all of 20th
century history actually reassemble and come alive, animated and so
life-like?  And what a time to write this poem, during US wartime
once again, so everything rings so clearly and soundly across the
thin air.  Or did you write it a long time ago and the editor of
"House Organ" has just printed it now?  I don't pretend to be able to
understand the Greek tags which are sprinkled throughout the second
column of the poem, but I think I understand their function-- but
what is it, it's hard to paraphrase.

The rest of you might have seen this poem before, or perhaps you too
get "House Organ" in the mail?  If not, maybe you could write to the
editor

House Organ
c/o Kenneth Warren
1250 Belle Avenue
Lakewood, Ohio   44107

and get a copy yourself.

Gee, this is the kind of thing I should write in a blog, but I don't
have one, so I'll put in here in hopes that some of you will pick up
on this really remarkable serial poem "Adamant."  Thanks everyone--

Kevin K.

MERIT

for Hilton Obenzinger


how can I call this a poem? words may gush as if from a faucet
in the allegory of this mythological background the charge against me
I have been false I have been untrue and I am a traitor
even to myself if I would live without my life but I withhold my pen
for vain were the fancy by treatise or sermon or poem or tale
that writes for autumn and grass the poem of dust

I'm ecstatic I have passed my days uselessly I am a traitor to my own self
I am committing suicide a million soldiers face
because I do not wish for myself ugliness beyond
I sell my life to the satanic path seeking in blind eyes a last plume
and when my blood spills crimson on the sand in defense of those dark people
no red-blooded American will cry national military law no doubt
will point out that I am a "traitor wimp and homo"

prisoner next door: "you don't want to talk to me
I am not only a sinner but I am a traitor a treacherous man"
then said the fox "who sayeth that I am a traitor
you do not know my duty because I am a Leanbh na stor
I am a traitor but I am perfectly ok with that"

oh Krsna you have everything you're my freakin' idol
the way you wrote that poem and all and the way all the chicks go after you
I love you more than the stars can shine but to you I am a time bomb
waiting to EXPLODE! be careful you are hinting that I am a traitor
that I am a traitor not fit to sit in parliament
my vows my prayers they were all meaningless recitations
I am a traitor every page
one does not acquire merit merely by singing the verses of the Gita
if I am a traitor heaven will turn me into a pearl

another masterpiece was a feminist poem
in the number of verses in a stanza of stanzas
Ptolemy sat on a rough blanket spread over the ground
"oh but I am a traitor Betty I am a traitor to the military government
so first and foremost make your heart pure
color in coloring books hold a stuffed animal write a poem
SLEEP WITH A MYSTERY TO SOLVE
spilling coffee on yourself can make you a millionaire"
one might say that I am a traitor but in reality I am not I

From:         Kevin Killian <kevinkillian@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Enough about Sylvester now  more about me
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

Hooray, my book Argento Series is the featured book on the website of
the Dublin book store Anthology Books

http://www.anthologystore.com/

Check it out, apparently my appeal has spread even to the land of
Paul Muldoon, but maybe it's because I'm Irish too.

Also here's another website with a recent interview with me.  It's
called "Solanas Online," a website devoted to devotees of Valerie
Solanas.  You'll find their new issue quite illuminating and besides
this interview with me there's a video clip of me riding a carousel
all done through animation.  Warning, don't try to open this site
while you're at work, why, because a) it's very heavy with Flash and
other special effects b) it opens up with a loud musical
Blaxploitation-disco theme and c) the site is X rated and who knows
who's monitoring your web usage while at work especially if you live
in the US and the attorney general is trying to cut down on porn
images, etc.  You might jot down the website address and remember to
try to dial it up while at a friend's house.  PS, the editors also
sent a reporter to the recent Acker conference at NYU and she has
written it up in a jaundiced, spiteful, irreverent way I sort of
like, though I'm glad I wasn't among her "victims."  Anyway, if you
have your pen the URL is

http://www.solanasonline.com/

That's all for me, for now.

-- Thanks everyone -- Kevin K.

Said Anti-American Reflex Syndrome

Def: an acute infection pandemic
in the academic community, passed
along thru word or mouth, symptoms
include severe sycophantic anti-
semitiism, self-serving self-
righteousness, tendentious
footnitis, & fatal inflammatory
rhetoric...na na na....leading
to the death of language..See
also SCARS or Chomskitis, an
abstract but deadlier form
of the same infection but ac-
comanied by the stink of self-
loathing....

Small Press Traffic presents
Friday, April 18, 2003 at 7:30 PM
Cassie Lewis & Brydie McPherson
Join us as we listen to two of our most ardent, sassy younger (prose) poets.
Cassie Lewis is the author of High Country (Little Esther, 2001) and Winter
District (Potes and Poets, 2002). Originally from Melbourne, Australia, she
moved to the Bay Area in 2000. Her poetry has been widely published in
Australia, as well as in England, New Zealand and the U.S. -- most recently in
Tinfish, Overland, Shampoo, Famous Reporter, Jacket and Southerly. Brydie
McPherson is the author of Abandon's Garden (EtherDome, 2000). McPherson is a
local -- a graduate of the MFA program at San Francisco State, her work has
appeared in Inscape, lyric&, Fourteen Hills, Outlet and New American Writing.
"Crossed over into spaciousness this nourishment neglects me: being company of
others in vicinity... A plan left me unbending in its binding."




All events are $5-10, sliding scale, and begin at 7:30, unless otherwise
noted.
Unless otherwise noted, our events are free to SPT members, youth under 18,
and CCAC faculty, staff, and students.
Unless otherwise noted, our events are presented in
Timken Lecture Hall
California College of Arts and Crafts
1111 Eighth Street, San Francisco (just off the intersection of 16th &
Wisconsin)




Elizabeth Treadwell Jackson, Executive Director
Small Press Traffic
Literary Arts Center at CCAC
1111 - 8th Street
San Francisco, California 94107

From:         tombell <trbell@COMCAST.NET>
Subject:      Just some thoughts and a chalenge
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Steve Tills did some cleaning up of the thoughts he posted yesterday and I'm
reposting them below today not because they contain any answers but because
the entirety raises some questions which merit discussion here and on a
psychologists' listserv and on psyart as well as other venues.  This is an
experiment in the sense that I'm curious about whether it is discussable
without degenerating into polarization and ego wars.

"Dear Tom,

Yes, indeed, if it can add to their dialogue, share it with them.  Below, I
cleaned up the paragraphs a bit, as they were rather sloppily copied/posted
on the list.

Re: Tom Bell's post on the Subject of "Zimbardo on War and Peace," some of
which I copied in below: "From Zimbardo's (former president of the APA)
recent speech which in part addresses the Surgeon General's recommendations
on national stress:

"War is one of the intense stressors we are dealing with as a nation. The
mature, tough solution is not to look away from the cause but to deal with
the stressor at its origin. To me, that means to look longer and deeper at
this war machine, this prime time, death-dealing video war game, contrived
by the current administration in the name of 'national security.' One of the
things that caught my interest here was that in this analysis which is based
in part on contemporary psychological research on emotion-focused and
solution-focused coping strategies he felt the need to pair 'tough' with
'mature'. As background here consider that loosely and stereotypically
speaking these strategies can be equated with sex roles. Also as background
consider that while in general more productive of solutions,
solution-focused coping strategies can lead to exacerbation of stress when
no solution is in fact possible."

I am reminded of an undergraduate school class (25+ years go, and I recall
studying Zimbardo, too--Phillip?), "Group Process," for which Prof Borkk had
the class elect a "process" leader" (to facilitate, and/or attend to,
emotional processes) and a "project leader" (to facilitate task
organization). No, he wasn't trying to show us how splitting up leadership
into those two roles would make each work better, i.e., you can get more
done if you cut off the emotions? I am reminded of several other
undergraduate classes (also years ago) in Humanistic Psychology with Prof
November and many times getting the difference between "doing" and "being"
(Perls' Gestalt drew on Heidegger and we got plenty of both in November
classes).  I frequently understood that those into "doing" (including my
"over-achiever" self(serf?) at the time) were often cutting off "the being
parts" of themselves, parts that are considerably more "reflective,"
"patient," "meditative," "still," in tune with greater depth (and
ambivalence and ambiguity) of emotions and range of emotion. I am reminded
of the distinctions between mental health and mental not-health: the former
observes and nourishes through life an increasing capacity for experiencing
"tolerance of ambivalence"; the latter shuns and avoids ambivalence and
remains rigidly resistant to this mind/body state inside. Hey, both of these
are all of us, in varying degrees, on numerous levels.

I am reminded of poets here in the Experimental venues and elsewhere in
Mainstream venues, all cherishing and revering "ambiguity," indeed generally
equating it with the term poetry altogether. Back to Zimbardo, and Tom
Bell's take: I have a strong hunch that "mature and tough" refers to
approaching problem solving with the immense and adult courage it takes to
look inside, maturely take responsibility for one's own emotions (like, for
example, I'm sure that Bush never looked deeply inside and thought to
himself, 'Geez, Clinton got that great economy and stuff through his 8
years, and here I am in Robert Reich's aftermath, I'll bet they planned it
this way, the economy crapping out and balancing itself and then I got this
9/11 thing, too, why have they been so damn hard on my Pappy and me, why
can't they just let me have a really cool presidency, too--ooops, that's the
C-student in me spoiled by Pappy's riches, thinking I deserve everything
without ever having to really work for it; I'll show them, I'll start some
wars, How dare they make me take a hard look at my inadequacies and my
father's imperfect fathering!).

The neoconservatives and facists in general come from an entirely difference
emotional/psychological orientation. They want to kill off "being" and
perfect "doing." For them, "hard work" is never a matter of facing inner
demons, ambivalence, and ambiguity inside in order to better "understand"
what it means "to be," much less respecting "others"'conception of same. For
them, "hard work" is strictly external "action" that achieves goals,
especially political goals, that statistically perfect an apparently static
and entirely preplanned world, a product idealized in their minds and
American Enterprise Institute programs, etc. I wonder, of course, if a lot
of us must also exercise our so-called advantage for accepting/understanding
being, and for living with ambiguity--but in ways we are not considering.
Are we being too intolerant of our own more "forceful" abilities, not,
smile, throwing maletov cocktails at the Whitehouse, but, ummm, well, who
knows what our greater ingenuity could devise. (Personally, I'd love to be
able to organize Buffett (who says there will be a special place reserved in
hell for Gary Winnick of Global Crossing), George Soros (yes, and old
financier once convicted of insider trading, but today staunchly opposed to
the war and Bush's actions), and Bill Gates, and a few others; together, a
mere handful of these parties could bring Bush-egonomics down to its knees
in a week or two via focused and pinpointed "shorting" of the defense
industries and the investment banks that have stolen so much from retail
investors. I'm sure there is a fair amount of money in Hollywood that would
agree to collectively castrate the neoconservatives' money machines as
well.) I don't know. Just some thoughts here.

Steve Tkills, Tills :)"

tom bell
not yet a crazy old man
hard but not yet hardening of the
art

the Dublin book store Anthology Books

Check it out, apparently my appeal has spread even to the land of
Paul Muldoon, but maybe it's because I'm Irish too.

Also here's another website with a recent interview with me.  It's
called "Solanas Online," a website devoted to devotees of Valerie
Solanas.  You'll find their new issue quite illuminating and besides
this interview with me there's a video clip of me riding a carousel
all done through animation.  Warning, don't try to open this site
while you're at work, why, because a) it's very heavy with Flash and
other special effects b) it opens up with a loud musical
Blaxploitation-disco theme and c) the site is X rated and who knows
who's monitoring your web usage while at work especially if you live
in the US and the attorney general is trying to cut down on porn
images, etc.  You might jot down the website address and remember to
try to dial it up while at a friend's house.  PS, the editors also
sent a reporter to the recent Acker conference at NYU and she has
written it up in a jaundiced, spiteful, irreverent way I sort of
like, though I'm glad I wasn't among her "victims."  Anyway, if you
have your pen the URL is

http://www.solanasonline.com/

That's all for me, for now.

Meanwhile back at home, the Baseball Hall of Fame has canceled a tribute to
the baseball film Bull Durham because of Tim Robbins' anti-war views.  The
Canadian production company Alliance Atlantis has fired one of their veteran
executives for remarks he made in a TV Guide interview about an upcoming
movie about Hitler where he compared the mood in Germany circa 1939 to the
one in the U.S. now.

This is frightening stuff and chilling for free speech.  Mangling a Japanese
aphorism I'm sure, it doesn't take much to see that if the dandelion that
rises above the other dandelions gets its blossom whacked off you're going to
have a field of some pretty compliant and submissive flowers.

IRW

Subject:      this is the beginning
In-Reply-To:  <a0510030dbac107986f63@[192.168.1.9]>

this is the beginning










                                        it ended again

                                        not there now

it started in the outside of the outside of the outside
out beyond         an indifferent organization that had its own party
line
divisible by    units
                cells
                individuals
                functions
                operations
                & details

        each limited in option or purpose

eye of the needle - thread - coin drop - eye lash

no border lands
no city limits

the escape hatch never existed

say nothing and hear everything
say that or that is the same is saying that

call it this
        paint it
                cast into a permeant flow chart

                        from here to eternity

                                and still it is - that


        pulsating

        simmering

        delicate

        indestructible


flash to quick

                its gone to the next and next and next

        incoherent whisper


jump cut


this is the beginning

                it ended again

        found again and again and again

now with purpose and intention


                                        follow the bouncing ball


                                         yellow dotted lines


                                                flashing red lights


hear the sirens       every where


                this is the beginning that will never end
                this is the door that will remain open after it is closed

Today, I get this from email passed along the company network where I work:

"Later, at dinner, Richard was very quiet. When I asked if he'd like to
talk about it, my big strong husband broke down in tears. "That's the
first time anyone ever thanked me for my time in the Army", he said.

Richard, like many others, came home to people who spit on him and
shouted ugly things at him. That night was a turning point for him. He
walked a little straighter and, for the first time in years, was proud
to have been a Vet. I'll never forget Ann Margaret for her
graciousness and how much that small act of kindness meant to my
husband."

At the same time, there's this from the Yahoo war news:

"At least 10 people were shot dead and scores wounded in the northern Iraqi
town of Mosul,
a hospital doctor said, with witnesses claiming US troops had opened fire on
a crowd after
it turned against an American-installed local governor.
Those charges were denied by a US military spokesman here, who said troops
had come
under fire from at least two gunmen and fired back, without aiming at the
crowd."
http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/afp/20030415/wl_mideast_afp/i
raq_war_us_mosul_030415151253
And from another article, this:
"Meanwhile, demonstrators marched to the center of the predominantly Shiite
southern city of Nasiriyah,
chanting 'Yes to freedom ... Yes to Islam ... No to America, No to Saddam.'"
http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story2&cid=1514&e=1&u=/afp/20030415/wl
_mideast_afp/iraq_war_rebuild_030415152748


The real bad guys, as everybody here knows, are the Bush/Rumsfeld/Kissinger
and Hussein/binLaden types, of course.
More particularly, though, this "spitting" thing, and to some extent
historically true, is IMO definitely the Numero Uno image and "symbol" that
sticks in the caw of at least half of the folks giving Bush and his war 70%
approval ratings.  Surely, there were "young" and upset kids during Vietnam
protesting in mass numbers, something unigue for the U.S.  And everything
was new and newer and sometimes dumb and dumber and crazy and crazier.
Ultimately, the "spitting" was wrong in most cases, references to it now are
both right AND wrong, and there were many anti-war protesters who dearly
grieved for their brothers and friends being forced to go over there.
Some of these young kids who have shot into the crowd today and killed and
maimed the presumably and basically relatively defenseless Iraqi protesters
will probably have the emotional scars come back to cause them X-amount of
pain one day.  "More" tragically, there are the deaths and maimings.  Ughhh,
sigh...
Spitting...  (The professional ball players do it all the time...)
I'll start again.  Spitting...  This is one of the main symbols (being used
by?) the propagandists to persuade a good portion of the 70% Bush war
approvers and equally by a fair number of good people who don't respect Bush
at all but had husbands in Vietnam (my cousin N., for example) to remind all
of us that the front line soldiers are almost all neighbors from small town
U.S.A. who have no other monies for going to college or gaining job skills.
It is ALSO rightfully (rightfully?  Yes, probably) an appropriate symbol
registering appropriate and righteous resentment for those (not "knowing any
better") who were so cruel to those others (soldiers, also "not knowing any
better") who went over to Vietnam and lost limbs, minds, buddies, and lives.
Everybody here knows that a whole lot of "classism" goes into this recurring
mess, that "we" are also much more advanced from even 30 years ago...
Bush and his cohorts and his masters and their small band of elites (10,
000, 000?  more?  not significantly more?) are also of a lower class.
Everybody here knows that "they" are ONLY of "the Upper Class" in reference
to material wealth and political/military power/control.  Otherwise, their
intellectual, their spiritual, and (most importantly, IMO)  their
"psychological awareness" levels are far below average, and in some cases
severely impaired, abnormal/pathological, as it were.
Spitting...  Sometimes ya can't solve a problem directly or by focusing on
it directly.  It'd be more "romantic," of course, to stop "Bush" (he's just
a puppet for his father's Carlyle Group and the mini-puds at the American
Enterprise Institute, actually, IMO) by storming the White House with "acid
rain" and 60 foot walls of bibles or something.
However, the ends may be more realistically achieved by directly (not
confronting but) dialoguing with the 35% who remember the spitting.  They've
got quite ample "psychological awareness" and in some cases considerably
more than a lot of the spitters who tore their loved ones' hearts out.  We
heal our differences with these folks and I'll bet the last 35% of deeply
co-dependent and severely disabled (that is, psychologically disabled) sots
who so desperately require handholding with their anthropomorphic parent
surrogates will come aboard the human race in an instant.
Thinking...  Not a lot of poetics here, but I know most consider it okay.
Steve Tills

    comes to the point
cubes     about response
       started down
a little differently

lightning-set went on
    swift search
            watertight

          towrope

liberty, resentment, function

       huddled masses
     (peak discontinue)
     process themselves

        halted near

     the peril murmured
         "take steps
     merciless playmates,
      they are restless
     expect a better one"

    Heaven specially created
        angle of
                 throw

       framework shuttered

           "...little consequence"

From:         Harrison Jeff <worksonpaper01@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Third Missive From Virginia
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

  I tried hard to keep my self away from the whispered fence, from the
crawled grieve, from the savored decisions... Believe me I did try... And I
should be rewarded for this dead efforts?

   Picturing my self like that reflect a huge humiliation for my
punishment...

   Tell me dear have u ever climbed Ur compassion? Have u ever hit Ur
miserable sorrow with a sharp sour? Have u ever thought to destroy ur
humanity response to disappear? HAVE U?  Tell me if u asked the ghost of ur
determination to go away? tell me that every one of us needs the chance to
relax from her beating life, and her disturbing dreams?

   My life was being swallowed up more and more each day by this strange
feeling... Felling of refusing to transfer my desire to a need

   I have been forced to rehearsing to bend over to my ridiculous commitment
to the silent stone inside me... Every time I whisper to my thoughts to hang
up there and that am coming to let u go free... but my whispers disappear
behind the hidden breath...

   Every night I listen to my youth chewing my dreams and barely swallow it
with my cursed proud...

   I kept hitting the life waves... I knew nothing about the other Virginia
in me... she is living with me, eating, breathing, feeling, and
suffering.... u introduce me to her politely, and in a friendly way...I
liked her and I felt sorry for her, cuz she was there, since she was a kid
,and I ignored her, I didn't see her grow up, I didn't see her first step, I
didn't hear her first word... She was there, straggling for me, trying to
tell me something...

    Now u know why I am bending over to the SILENT STONE.

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      ABNU
MIME-Version: 1.0
