From:         Christine Murray <cmurray@UTA.EDU>
Subject:      History as populated "red" & "from the blue waves"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

and Oscar Hahn, "Gladiolos junto al mar" (Gladioli by the Sea):

Gladiolos rojos de sangrantes plumas,
lenguas del campo, llamas olorosas,
de las olas azules, amorosas,
cartas os llegan, palidas espumas.

Flotan sobre las alas de las brumas
epistolas de polen numerosas,
donde a las aguas pidan pos esposas
gladiolos rojos de sangrantes plumas.

Movidas son las olas por el viento
y el pie de los gladiolos van besando,
al son de un suave y blando movimiento.

Y en cada dulce flor de sangre inerte
la muerte va con piel de sal entrando,
y entrando van las flores en la muerte.


(as translated by Isabel Bize:

Red gladioli of bleeding feathers
field tongues, fragrant flames,
from the blue waves, loving
epistles to you arrive, pallid foams.

Over the wings of the mist float
numerous letters of pollen
where the waters are asked to be wed
by red gladioli of bleeding feathers.

The waves are rocked by the wind
and the foot [sic] of the gladioli go on kissing
to the rhythm of a smooth and supple movement.

And in every sweet flower of stagnant blood
with a salty foot, death goes on entering
and the flowers go on entering their death.)

  Friends,

As you can see from the note below from the author of the petition on
Iraq's heritage, all of us are invited to sign it.  Some colleagues of
mine felt it addressed itself solely to archeologists and scholars in
Mesopotamian studies.  I am glad this isn't the case.  PLEASE
disseminate this petition far and wide.  Thanks.

Here's the URL again:
The petition and list of signatories can be found at:

          http://users.ox.ac.uk/~wolf0126/petition.html

  It is linked to a larger web site, The Threat to World Heritage in
  Iraq maintained by scholars of the ancient Near East at Oxford and
  Cambridge Universities:

          (http://users.ox.ac.uk/~wolf0126/index.html).

Salwa

-------- Original Message --------
Subject: Re: petition
Date: Fri, 18 Apr 2003 15:22:43 -0400
From: "Kathryn E. Slanski" <kathryn.slanski@yale.edu>
To: Salwa Ghaly <sghaly@sharjah.ac.ae>
References: <85B564565395D51180D500D0B7C85CA094EC6D@nwebmail.sharjah.ac.ae>



Dear Salwa,

Thank you for your kind words regarding the wording of the petition;
because this was a US-based initiative, great efforts were made to give
the Iraqi scholars their due authority in deciding what should be done
next.

In response to your and similar requests, we have opened up the
petition to academics from other fields. I've forwarded your name to be
added to the petition (although it probably will not appear until
Monday). I am very pleased to be able to add another scholar from the
Arabic-speaking world.

Sincerely,
Kathryn

--- All because ... (25.)

Abbe T*** had given me
Black line at the top
Complete with a washable long sleeve
Domestic concerns." Do you retain
Except the incident of the
For burdens, but benefits. "Don't
Government and private capital, have
Her husband is a jurist
In various handcrafts, trades and
"Jeune premiere," at one point
Kind of cleavage we are
Left margin, using all capital
Molded with the same techniques
Not be thrown into that
Off classes, universities terminate research
Problem solving, American history, English
Quite a fraud, but it
Removable from a hardwood stand
So represented doth consent to
The degree of its energy
Until they are invited into
Virtuous and beautiful as she
Which left me no doubt
"Xoanephores" of Sophocles; Byron's "Sardanapalus"
Years. The room utilized for
Zero airspeed and zero altitude

From:         Gabriel Gudding <gmguddi@ILSTU.EDU>
Subject:      Kalayaan ay Buang -- by Hilton Obenzinger
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Kalayaan* ay Buang


Kalayaan flops on my belly
in a 4-year-old version of
sky-diving.
         Kalayaan ay
buang! She is crazy
with joy to snuggle with Mom
& me. Me? Who is this hairy
pink Pollack anyway?
Will he hit Mom or will he
caress her in the same world
as he does Kalayaan?

"What is this ring?" she queries
in girlie squeek voice
pinching my finger.
"See, it says Vietnam" I reply
"Vietnam people shot down
American bomber plane
& they took metal of the plane
to melt it into a ring
with their name on it."

"Gimme that!" she coyly demands.

"No, Kalayann. I was on
the island of Cuba & there a comrade
from Vietnam gave me this ring
even as bombs flung down on his people.
As we toasted plum wine I vowed
'Imperialists will have to cut my
finger off to get this ring'
that was how deep my feeling ran.
Now I'm giving this ring to your Mom.
Kalayaan, I hope you understand.
Love is solid & hard in revolution.

"The imperialists will have to cut
her finger off to get this ring
yet still I maintain my vow
to the kasama from Vietnam.
The finger of the Philippines
will be the same as my own.
Isulong ang Pakikibaka.
As the struggle advances
thru strenghts & weaknesses
thru virtues & failings,
with both our hands
we'll place the stones
of the foundations of the world."

"You silly," she shouts
& smiles a future as broad
as her name,
the Kalayaan of my freedom
as well as her own.


  * Kalayaan ay buang means "Freedom is crazy" in Tagalog

                 -- Hilton Obenzinger

fr. _Omens from the Flight of Birds: The First 101 Days of Jimmy Carter_
(San Francisco: Momo's Press.1977)

From:         Halvard Johnson <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Poems by others: Guillaume Apollinaire, "The Pretty Redhead"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The Pretty Redhead

I stand here in the sight of everyone a man full of sense
Knowing life and knowing of death what a living man can know
Having gone through the griefs and happinesses of love
Having known sometimes how to impose his ideas
Knowing several languages
Having travelled more than a little
Having seen war in the artillery and the infantry
Wounded in the head trepanned under chloroform
Having lost his best friends in the horror of battle

I know as much as one man alone can know
Of the ancient and the new
And without troubling myself about this war today
Between us and for us my friends
I judge this long quarrel between tradition and imagination
Between order and adventure

You whose mouth is made in the image of God's mouth
Mouth which is order itself
Judge kindly when you compare us
With those who were the very perfection of order
We who are seeking everywhere for adventure

We are not your enemies
Who want to give ourselves vast strange domains
Where mystery flowers into any hands that long for it
Where there are new fires colors never seen
A thousand fantasies difficult to make sense out of
They must be made real
All we want is to explore kindness the enormous country where
     everything is silent
And there is time which somebody can banish or welcome home
Pity for us who fight always on the frontiers
Of the illimitable and the future
Pity our mistakes pity our sins

Here summer is coming the violent season
And so my youth is as dead as spring
Oh Sun it is the time of reason grown passionate
And I am still waiting
To follow the forms she takes noble and gentle
So I may love her alone

She comes and draws me as a magnet draws filaments of iron
She has the lovely appearance
Of an adorable redhead
Her hair turns golden you would say
A beautiful lightning flash that goes on and on
Or the flames that spread out their feathers
In wilting tea roses

But laugh laugh at me
Men everywhere especially people from here
For there are so many things that I don't dare to tell you
So many things that you would not let me say
Have pity on me

--Guillaume Apollinaire, tr. James Wright

fr. *Calligrammes* (1925)

in *The Random House Book of Twentieth-Century French Poetry*
ed., Paul Auster [New York: Random House,1982]

and in James Wright, *Collected Poems* [Wesleyan Univ. Press, 1971]


Hal

Halvard Johnson

email: halvard@earthlink.net
website: http://home.earthlink.net/~halvard

From:         ian davidson <zyborski3@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      On Wales
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

On Wales is a 32 page booklet featuring work either about Wales or within a
Welsh context by poets not resident in Wales. It includes both new and
previously published work by Peter Riley, Tom Raworth, Douglas Oliver, Lee
Harwood,  Alan Halsey, Ralph Hawkins, Wendy Mulford, John James and Andrew
Duncan.

Copies are available at two pounds and fifty pence sterling, five euros or 6
US dollars post free from:

Zoe Skoulding, 2 Greenfield Terrace, Hill Street, Porthaethwy, Ynys Mon,
Cymru/Wales LL59 5AY

zoe@skald.omnia.co.uk


On Wales is a special issue of Skald magazine. Skald appears twice a year
and publishes poetry and prose in Welsh and English with visual artworks. It
aims to publish a broad range of writing, including the innovative and
experimental, and is interested in the connections and differences between
the local and the international and the visual and the verbal. Each issue
also features reviews and notices of books received. Unsolicited manuscripts
are welcome.

A section of the next issue of Skald will be given over to a special feature
on cultural identity. We are seeking contributions of verbal and visual art
work  (poems, prose, drawings photographs etc) which explore tensions within
ideas of cultural identity, cross perceived cultural boundaries or bring
elements of different cultures together.  These explorations could be
through the content of the work, or through the use of particular forms.

Skald is based in Wales, in a community where two languages, Welsh and
English, are part of everyday life. We would be particularly interested in
artworks which reflect and interrogate this situation. Work which reflects
cultural or linguistic connections  between cultures in other geographical
areas, and in ways other than through language,  is equally welcome.

The closing date for submissions is May 30.

From:         Anastasios Kozaitis <anastasios@HELL.COM>
Subject:      THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

April 19, 2003

The Latest Theory Is That Theory Doesn't Matter
By EMILY EAKIN
http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/19/arts/19CRIT.html
=0A
These are uncertain times for literary scholars. The era of big theory is=20
over. The grand paradigms that swept through humanities departments in the=
=20
20th century =97 psychoanalysis, structuralism, Marxism, deconstruction,=20
post-colonialism =97 have lost favor or been abandoned. Money is tight. And=
=20
the leftist politics with which literary theorists have traditionally been=
=20
associated have taken a beating.

In the latest sign of mounting crisis, on April 11 the editors of Critical=
=20
Inquiry, academe's most prestigious theory journal, convened the scholarly=
=20
equivalent of an Afghan-style loya jirga. They invited more than two dozen=
=20
of America's professorial elite, including Henry Louis Gates Jr., Homi=20
Bhabha, Stanley Fish and Fredric Jameson, to the University of Chicago for=
=20
what they called "an unprecedented meeting of the minds," an unusual=20
two-hour public symposium on the future of theory.

Understandably, expectations were high. More than 500 people, mostly=20
students and faculty, squeezed into a lecture hall to hear what the=20
mandarins had to say, while latecomers made do with a live video feed set=20
up in the lobby.

In his opening remarks, W. J. T. Mitchell, the journal's editor and a=20
professor of English and art history at Chicago, set an upbeat tone for the=
=20
proceedings. "We want to be the Starship Enterprise of criticism and=20
theory," he told the audience.

But any thought that this would be a gleeful strategy session with an eye=20
toward extending theory's global reach, or an impassioned debate over the=20
merits of, say, Derrida and Lacan, was quickly dispelled.

When John Comaroff, a professor of anthropology and sociology at Chicago=20
who was serving as the event's moderator, turned the floor over to the=20
panelists, for several moments no one said a word.

Then a student in the audience spoke up. What good is criticism and theory,=
=20
he asked, if "we concede in fact how much more important the actions of=20
Noam Chomsky are in the world than all the writings of critical theorists=20
combined?"

After all, he said, Mr. Fish had recently published an essay in Critical=20
Inquiry arguing that philosophy didn't matter at all.

Behind a table at the front of the room, Mr. Fish shook his head. "I think=
=20
I'll let someone else answer the question," he said.

So Sander L. Gilman, a professor of liberal arts and sciences at the=20
University of Illinois at Chicago, replied instead. "I would make the=20
argument that most criticism =97 and I would include Noam Chomsky in this =
=97=20
is a poison pill," he said. "I think one must be careful in assuming that=20
intellectuals have some kind of insight. In fact, if the track record of=20
intellectuals is any indication, not only have intellectuals been wrong=20
almost all of the time, but they have been wrong in corrosive and=20
destructive ways."

Mr. Fish nodded approvingly. "I like what that man said," he said. "I wish=
=20
to deny the effectiveness of intellectual work. And especially, I always=20
wish to counsel people against the decision to go into the academy because=
=20
they hope to be effective beyond it."

During the remainder of the session, the only panelist to venture a defense=
=20
of theory =97 or mention a literary genre =97 was Mr. Bhabha. "There are a=
=20
number of people around the table here and a number of people in the=20
audience, in fact most of you here are evidence that intellectual work has=
=20
its place and its uses," he insisted. "Even a poem in its own oblique way=20
is deeply telling of the lives of the world we exist in. You can have poems=
=20
that are intimately linked with political oppositional movements, poems=20
that actually draw together people in acts of resistance."

But no one spoke up to endorse this claim. In fact, for a conference=20
officially devoted to theory, theory itself got very little airtime. For=20
more than an hour, the panelists bemoaned the war in Iraq, the Bush=20
administration, the ascendancy of the right-wing press and the impotence of=
=20
the left. Afterward, Mr. Gates, who arrived late because he had been=20
attending a conference in Wisconsin, said: "For a moment, I thought I was=20
in the wrong room. I thought we would be talking about academic jargon.=20
Instead, it was Al Qaeda and Iraq =97 not that there's anything wrong with=
 that."

Finally, a young man with dreadlocks who said he was a graduate student=20
from Jamaica asked, "So is theory simply just a nice, simple intellectual=20
exercise, or something that should be transformative?"

Several speakers weighed in before Mr. Gates stood up. As far as he could=20
tell, he said, theory had never directly liberated anyone. "Maybe I'm too=20
young," he said. "I really didn't see it: the liberation of people of color=
=20
because of deconstruction or poststructuralism."

If theory's political utility is this dubious, why did the theorists spend=
=20
so much time talking about current events? Catharine R. Stimpson, a=20
panelist and dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Science at New York=20
University, offered one, well, theory. "This particular group of=20
intellectuals," she said, "has a terror of being politically irrelevant."
=========================================================================

From:         Steven Shoemaker <shoemak@FAS.HARVARD.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <a05100305bac72a902e28@[128.138.86.168]>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Well, would Paul Wolfowitz count as a "theorist"?  I mean this question
seriously.  People are talking about intellectuals being irrelevant, but
it's also true that Bush, brainless though he is, is under the spell of a
group of what Newsweek recently referred to as "big-think neocons."
It's as if his very vacuousness has create a, well, vacuum for the
ideas of conservative "thinkers" to come rushing in.  So maybe
it's only the theorists of the left who are irrelevant these days?  But of
course theorists of the left *have* caused an awful lot of damage of their
own over the course of the last century.

So is the big problem that theorists are irrelevant, or that when they do
have influence they fuck things up?  These two views are
different, but they seem to overlap in some weird way in
accounts of the current intellectual malaise.  Personally, I find myself
more and
more struck by the extent to which so much of history and politics *is*
driven by ideas, ideologies (include religion here), as opposed to, say,
economics alone (tho of course economics is important--we do want the
oil--but it plays out in dialectic with driving ideologies...

But now, the article was really not about theory per se but about literary
theory, which has been in the odd position in recent decades of channeling
all sorts of thinking about power and politics through the medium of
literary texts...

Steve

Dear All,
My first thought on this--and it may be unfair and based on an
incomplete report--is "how convenient."  How convenient, in this time
where speaking out is necessary and has acquired some risk, that these
academics neuter themselves and in the process protect
their many assets.  My second thought--and this *is* considered--is that
these people have little idea what it is not to matter.  Any bunch of
inmates in United States prisons knows what it is to not matter.
Even I, who have only some contact with prisoners--and the heroic
struggle of one individual prisoner to
*do good* beyond the walls, capacities, and reach of his situation--have
an inkling of what not mattering means.  Plunge into poverty and you
also find what it is not to matter.  These academics have all the
privileges of education, financial security, mobility, articulacy,
offices, computers, phones, fax machines, cars, houses even, and they
have the nerve to say what they write doesn't matter.  If the report is
incomplete, Anastasios, and if the session actually included grief at
failure to exercise privilege in a way which *does* matter, and a
determination to do so henceforth, then I would like to hear more.
Education, what happens in a classroom, thinking and
writing about literature and culture *do* matter, and *do* change how we
approach, understand, behave, and take action in our world.  It's true
that if I think what writers influenced me most while at graduate
school, George Lakoff would probably be number one.
I consider him a theorist, and often a literary theorist at that.  His
ideas about language have direct relevance to my understanding of my
world.  I will close with the words of Paul Celan who said when he
received the Bremen Prize for German literature: "Only one thing
remained reachable, close and secure amid all losses: language.  Yes,
language.  In spite of everything, it remained secure against loss.  But
it had to go through its own lack of answers, through terrifying
silence, through the thousand darknesses of murderous speech.  It went
through."
Mairead

Mair*ad Byrne
Assistant Professor of English
Rhode Island School of Design
Providence, RI 02903
www.wildhoneypress.com
www.maireadbyrne.blogspot.com
>>> anastasios@HELL.COM 04/19/03 11:21 AM >>>
April 19, 2003

The Latest Theory Is That Theory Doesn't Matter
By EMILY EAKIN
http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/19/arts/19CRIT.html


These are uncertain times for literary scholars. The era of big theory
is
over. The grand paradigms that swept through humanities departments in
the
20th century — psychoanalysis, structuralism, Marxism, deconstruction,
post-colonialism — have lost favor or been abandoned. Money is tight.
And
the leftist politics with which literary theorists have traditionally
been
associated have taken a beating.

In the latest sign of mounting crisis, on April 11 the editors of
Critical
Inquiry, academe's most prestigious theory journal, convened the
scholarly
equivalent of an Afghan-style loya jirga. They invited more than two
dozen
of America's professorial elite, including Henry Louis Gates Jr., Homi
Bhabha, Stanley Fish and Fredric Jameson, to the University of Chicago
for
what they called "an unprecedented meeting of the minds," an unusual
two-hour public symposium on the future of theory.

Understandably, expectations were high. More than 500 people, mostly
students and faculty, squeezed into a lecture hall to hear what the
mandarins had to say, while latecomers made do with a live video feed
set
up in the lobby.

In his opening remarks, W. J. T. Mitchell, the journal's editor and a
professor of English and art history at Chicago, set an upbeat tone for
the
proceedings. "We want to be the Starship Enterprise of criticism and
theory," he told the audience.

But any thought that this would be a gleeful strategy session with an
eye
toward extending theory's global reach, or an impassioned debate over
the
merits of, say, Derrida and Lacan, was quickly dispelled.

When John Comaroff, a professor of anthropology and sociology at Chicago

who was serving as the event's moderator, turned the floor over to the
panelists, for several moments no one said a word.

Then a student in the audience spoke up. What good is criticism and
theory,
he asked, if "we concede in fact how much more important the actions of
Noam Chomsky are in the world than all the writings of critical
theorists
combined?"

After all, he said, Mr. Fish had recently published an essay in Critical

Inquiry arguing that philosophy didn't matter at all.

Behind a table at the front of the room, Mr. Fish shook his head. "I
think
I'll let someone else answer the question," he said.

So Sander L. Gilman, a professor of liberal arts and sciences at the
University of Illinois at Chicago, replied instead. "I would make the
argument that most criticism — and I would include Noam Chomsky in this —

is a poison pill," he said. "I think one must be careful in assuming
that
intellectuals have some kind of insight. In fact, if the track record of

intellectuals is any indication, not only have intellectuals been wrong
almost all of the time, but they have been wrong in corrosive and
destructive ways."

Mr. Fish nodded approvingly. "I like what that man said," he said. "I
wish
to deny the effectiveness of intellectual work. And especially, I always

wish to counsel people against the decision to go into the academy
because
they hope to be effective beyond it."

During the remainder of the session, the only panelist to venture a
defense
of theory — or mention a literary genre — was Mr. Bhabha. "There are a
number of people around the table here and a number of people in the
audience, in fact most of you here are evidence that intellectual work
has
its place and its uses," he insisted. "Even a poem in its own oblique
way
is deeply telling of the lives of the world we exist in. You can have
poems
that are intimately linked with political oppositional movements, poems
that actually draw together people in acts of resistance."

But no one spoke up to endorse this claim. In fact, for a conference
officially devoted to theory, theory itself got very little airtime. For

more than an hour, the panelists bemoaned the war in Iraq, the Bush
administration, the ascendancy of the right-wing press and the impotence
of
the left. Afterward, Mr. Gates, who arrived late because he had been
attending a conference in Wisconsin, said: "For a moment, I thought I
was
in the wrong room. I thought we would be talking about academic jargon.
Instead, it was Al Qaeda and Iraq — not that there's anything wrong with
that."

Finally, a young man with dreadlocks who said he was a graduate student
from Jamaica asked, "So is theory simply just a nice, simple
intellectual
exercise, or something that should be transformative?"

Several speakers weighed in before Mr. Gates stood up. As far as he
could
tell, he said, theory had never directly liberated anyone. "Maybe I'm
too
young," he said. "I really didn't see it: the liberation of people of
color
because of deconstruction or poststructuralism."

If theory's political utility is this dubious, why did the theorists
spend
so much time talking about current events? Catharine R. Stimpson, a
panelist and dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Science at New York

University, offered one, well, theory. "This particular group of
intellectuals," she said, "has a terror of being politically
irrelevant."

steve, others, yeah---but lit theory wasn't ever really just lit
theory, as we know... its contemporary origins come from everywhere
on the intellectual map... philosophy (if you count derrida as a
philosopher, which some philosophers of course don't), anthropology
(from levi-strauss forward), history, linguistics, political science
(eventually), sociology, feminism, LITERATURE etc etc etc---part of
the emergence of theory as such has been its (sometimes tacit,
sometimes blunt) attempt to move away from that old time religion
(lit criticism)...  sure, many of the folks sucked into the theory
enterprise were disciplinary renegades...

which multidisciplinarity has always made its knowledge claims
problematic, which is not to say invalid, when it comes to issues of
social transformation (as the grad student "with dreadlocks ... from
jamaica" suggests)... i mean, hovering behind any theory is, to echo
geertz, the relationship of thought to social action... but the point
of theory was, in part, to examine this relationship...

so when theorists en masse (largely of the left, yes, most of whom
are academics) begin to talk as if their activity is an intellectual
parlor game (and again---that article points correctly, i think, to a
reality that i've seen developing mself), what's happening has
perhaps less to do with theory (and anti-theory) as such than with
the way said theorists (and anti-theorists) have come to understand
their public and professional (incl. writerly and, often, teacherly)
selves...

to understand this latter reality might require another view of
theory, yes, or at least, another view of discourse (ok?), and the
spheres in which one's discourse takes effect, which means of course
a wider appreciation for other kinds of discourses, and for other
kinds of effects (from the generative to the reception side)... as a
poet on a poetry/poetics list, i don't expect my saying this will be
esp. controversial, but i would say, to the theory set and in so many
words, that they need to work harder to make their practice more
meaningful (as writers, teachers, etc.) to more diverse audiences
(ok?)... instead of combatting complacency, say, instead of striving
to make their points ring true in the face e.g. of neocon theorists
(or thinkers, if you prefer), they're now going to cop a noncommittal
public pose?... that's a very convenient subject position, yknow,
esp. when you're taking in, what, six figures annually (as everyone
mentioned in that piece is taking in, and then some---and ditto for
the neocons)... i mean, whenever i've taught theory, i've examined
its liabilities---but i haven't dismissed its efficacy outright, and
not b/c i'm being paid to teach theory, but b/c to act, we have to
believe in something, yes?... some working conception of, what, not
just contingencies of value, but of, what, awareness?...

don't we?... i mean, even with the wholesale critique of agency and
enlightenment and the rest, isn't it implicit in the very pursuit of
thought (along with, uhm, tenure) that such striving, however
fraught, can amount to something, finally?... i'm speaking as a
teacher now, i know, but how else could i walk into the classroom
(which is not to say that i tell my students what to believe in,
either)... i suppose this would require something like faith (try not
to well up, now), faith in----... damn, even watching ~the crying
game~ again last night i got the distinct impression that some
positive cultural work had come of a few million souls viewing that
flick... am i just a deluded optimist, or what?...

anyway, fish et al. piss me off, and i'll be sure to find a way to
let them know that i'm pissed off...

out for the day, i guess...

best,

joe

Steven Shoemaker writes:

>So is the big problem that theorists are irrelevant, or that when they do
>have influence they fuck things up?

I don't know that they mean to "fuck things up."  Perhaps *they know not
what they do,* as it were...

As you say, this is really not about theory, literary or no, then.  Isn't it
more about power relations, authority, privilege, hegemony: who speaks, who
listens, who can say what, who can name what? Dialectical, then, as you say,
but very limited-outrageously so, across the spectrum, neolib or neocon--but
now perhaps these authoritative messengers are realizing how limited their
thinking is in terms of materiality. Perhaps what we're seeing/hearing here
is a form of humility, given all the 20th c.'s whack intellectual hubris.

Then, too, this seems only a little *As the World Turns* flap between main
theatricals, with the NYTimes attempting to beg off as a semi-recording
angel.  None of it to much effect, as Mairead says, on real lives, except in
trickle-down through the various real-life sites both real and symbolic, of
Ghetto, in its underscored *first world* capital G.  Why *do* graduate
students get so wrapped up in/about theory, anyway?

Chris Murray

From: "Halvard Johnson" <halvard@EARTHLINK.NET>

Sent: Saturday, April 19, 2003 10:22 AM
Subject: Poems by others: Guillaume Apollinaire, "The Pretty Redhead"


> The Pretty Redhead
>
> I stand here in the sight of everyone a man full of sense
> Knowing life and knowing of death what a living man can know
> Having gone through the griefs and happinesses of love
> Having known sometimes how to impose his ideas
> Knowing several languages
> Having travelled more than a little
> Having seen war in the artillery and the infantry
> Wounded in the head trepanned under chloroform
> Having lost his best friends in the horror of battle
>
> I know as much as one man alone can know
> Of the ancient and the new
> And without troubling myself about this war today
> Between us and for us my friends
> I judge this long quarrel between tradition and imagination
> Between order and adventure
>
> You whose mouth is made in the image of God's mouth
> Mouth which is order itself
> Judge kindly when you compare us
> With those who were the very perfection of order
> We who are seeking everywhere for adventure
>
> We are not your enemies
> Who want to give ourselves vast strange domains
> Where mystery flowers into any hands that long for it
> Where there are new fires colors never seen
> A thousand fantasies difficult to make sense out of
> They must be made real
> All we want is to explore kindness the enormous country where
>      everything is silent
> And there is time which somebody can banish or welcome home
> Pity for us who fight always on the frontiers
> Of the illimitable and the future
> Pity our mistakes pity our sins
>
> Here summer is coming the violent season
> And so my youth is as dead as spring
> Oh Sun it is the time of reason grown passionate
> And I am still waiting
> To follow the forms she takes noble and gentle
> So I may love her alone
>
> She comes and draws me as a magnet draws filaments of iron
> She has the lovely appearance
> Of an adorable redhead
> Her hair turns golden you would say
> A beautiful lightning flash that goes on and on
> Or the flames that spread out their feathers
> In wilting tea roses
>
> But laugh laugh at me
> Men everywhere especially people from here
> For there are so many things that I don't dare to tell you
> So many things that you would not let me say
> Have pity on me
>
> --Guillaume Apollinaire, tr. James Wright
>
> fr. *Calligrammes* (1925)
>
> in *The Random House Book of Twentieth-Century French Poetry*
> ed., Paul Auster [New York: Random House,1982]
>
> and in James Wright, *Collected Poems* [Wesleyan Univ. Press, 1971]
>
>
> Hal
>
> Halvard Johnson
> ===============
> email: halvard@earthlink.net
> website: http://home.earthlink.net/~halvard

"Dear All,
My first thought on this--and it may be unfair and
based on an
incomplete report--is "how convenient."  How
convenient, in this time
where speaking out is necessary and has acquired some
risk, that these
academics neuter themselves and in the process protect
their many assets.  My second thought--and this *is*
considered--is that
these people have little idea what it is not to
matter.  Any bunch of
inmates in United States prisons knows what it is to
not matter.
Even I, who have only some contact with prisoners--and
the heroic
struggle of one individual prisoner to
*do good* beyond the walls, capacities, and reach of
his situation--have
an inkling of what not mattering means.  Plunge into
poverty and you
also find what it is not to matter.  These academics
have all the
privileges of education, financial security, mobility,
articulacy,
offices, computers, phones, fax machines, cars, houses
even, and they
have the nerve to say what they write doesn't matter.
If the report is
incomplete, Anastasios, and if the session actually
included grief at
failure to exercise privilege in a way which *does*
matter, and a
determination to do so henceforth, then I would like
to hear more.
Education, what happens in a classroom, thinking and
writing about literature and culture *do* matter, and
*do* change how we
approach, understand, behave, and take action in our
world.  It's true
that if I think what writers influenced me most while
at graduate
school, George Lakoff would probably be number one.
I consider him a theorist, and often a literary
theorist at that.  His
ideas about language have direct relevance to my
understanding of my
world.  I will close with the words of Paul Celan who
said when he
received the Bremen Prize for German literature: "Only
one thing
remained reachable, close and secure amid all losses:
language.  Yes,
language.  In spite of everything, it remained secure
against loss.  But
it had to go through its own lack of answers, through
terrifying
silence, through the thousand darknesses of murderous
speech.  It went
through."
Mairead

Mair*ad Byrne
Assistant Professor of English
Rhode Island School of Design
Providence, RI 02903
www.wildhoneypress.com
www.maireadbyrne.blogspot.com
>>> anastasios@HELL.COM 04/19/03 11:21 AM >>>
April 19, 2003"

exhibitors), at the Glebe Community Center, Main Hall, 690 Lyon Street (at
2nd Avenue), Ottawa.

admission free to the public. tables are $15 for exhibitors (payable to
rob mclennan). full tables only. for catalog, exhibitors should send (on
paper, not email) name of press, address, email, web address, contact
person, type of publications, list of publications (with price), if
submissions are being looked at, & any other pertinent info, including
upcoming ottawa-area events (if any).

the fair usually contains exhibitors with poetry books, novels, cookbooks,
posters, t-shirts, graphic novels, comic books, magazines, scraps of
paper, gum-ball machines with poems, 2x4s with text, etc. happens twice a
year, started in 1994 by rob mclennan & James Spyker. now run by rob
mclennan thru span-o.

Just available:

a first collection of poems, ANARCHY, by Mark Scroggins (Spuyten
Duyvil, $10)

"Like a kaleidoscope ('a pretty seeing') that offers a new snowflake
symmetry with every jiggle, these poems of Mark Scroggins teach us that
chaos is a restless order livelier than order itself.  These poems are
annotations about the insults, both spiritual and physical, that have
terrorized history from Sodom to the Twin Towers."
        --Guy Davenport

"What does the London punk rock scene of the 1970s have to do with the
bloody religious turmoil of seventeenth-century England? And why do
'the occult connections between Muenster antinomianism / and Johnny
Rotten' so concern a young American poet and cittern player) originally
from Tennessee) who also happens to be one of the world's leading
authorities on Louis Zukofsky? In Mark Scroggins' *Anarchy* (cf.
*Paradise Lost* II. 959-967 *and* the Sex Pistols), 'Baalim / and
Peorim smash a thousand / Telecasters and Marshall amps.' Scroggins
ransacks British history to give us 'words for a t-shirt / traced white
/ on black' --and so much more."
        --Norman Finkelstein

Procurable (with charming discounts) from the fat cats at B&N and
amazon.com.

Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Mairead Byrne <mbyrne@RISD.EDU>

Dear Andy,
This is a good question.  Would you care to elaborate?  Are you thinking
of specific poets?
Does "poetics" imply an association with academia/academic theory?  I
assign some value to poetics--in fact poets' statements/explorations of
poetics are often exhilarating (I think I like prose
inordinately), and I'm suspicious of poets who are suspicious of
poetics.  All of which indicates that I'd be interested in a discussion
about this if you would be more precise: which poets, what merger, and
the connection between poetics and academic theory.
Mairead

From:         Nick LoLordo <lolordov@UNLV.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Quoting Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>:

> What does this say about poets who have advocated a closer relationship to
> academic theory (that is, advocated the merger of poetry and "poetics")?
>
> Andy
>

To answer:  "this", insofar as this is a NYTimes article about "theory", says
virtually nothing about "poets who have advocated the merger of poetry and
poetics".  (To equate "poetics" with "academic theory" is exceedingly
reductive:  did nobody ever speculate about poetry before 1968?)  It says much
more about how the media views the academy.

This article shouldn't be taken any more seriously by members of this list than
they'd take a similar Times piece on non-mainstream poetry; if we read it as
any kind of serious account of theory or theorists, we'll just share in the
Times' own lofty amusement--"aren't the eggheads silly?"--a tone I'm sure some
of us recognize....

Take the article's last paragraph:

"If theory's political utility is this dubious, why did the theorists spend
so much time talking about current events? Catharine R. Stimpson, a
panelist and dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Science at New York
University, offered one, well, theory. "This particular group of
intellectuals," she said, "has a terror of being politically irrelevant.""

The seeming inconsistency that the author glibly locates is of course anything
but:  the _difference_ between the enterprise of literary theory as practiced
in journals and a large panel discussion involving a different audience might
be precisely the _reason_ the theorists ended up talking about current events.

Moreover:  since the de Man affair "theory" has come to stand for the fact that
departments of literature are no longer doing what they're supposed--in the
eyes of conservative cultural commentators--to be doing.  When literature
scholars are talking about politics, rather than literature, their activity is
seen as suspect (note, eg, the article's reference to the lack of discussion of
literary genres...).  Given this, one might suspect that an article chiding
literary academics for their lack of belief in political efficacy needs to be
read with a certain irony: political efficacy is exactly what literature
scholars aren't supposed to have.

Some academics have long since acknowledged the mediatedness of any theoretical
"intervention":  the fact that left politics when practiced within the context
of writing in academic journals dosen't simply magically make its way into the
public sphere.  Such an admission isn't a disavowal of one's own agency, can't
necessarily be blamed on elitism or the corrupting influence of cushy academic
jobs--it might also be an admission that the politics of the academy have to do
with the _entirety_ of one's relation to the institution...

Nick
----------

V. Nicholas LoLordo
Assistant Professor

University of Nevada-Las Vegas
Department of English
4504 Maryland Parkway
Las Vegas, NV 89154-5011

(702) 895-3623

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      The Higher Pantheism in a Nutshell
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

The Higher Pantheism in a Nutshell


One, who is not, we see: but one, whom we see not, this:
Surely this is not that: but that is assuredly is.

What, and wherefore, and whence? for under is over and thunder:
If thunder could be without lightning, lightning could be without under.

Doubt is faith in the main: but faith on the whole is without:
We cannot believe by proof: but could we believe doubt?

Why, and whither, and how? for barley and rye are not over:
Neither are straight lines curves: yet over is under and clover.

Two and two may be four: but four and four are not fate:
Fate and God may be twain: but God is the same thing as eight.

Ask a man what he thinks, and get from a man what he heels:
God, once caught in the fact, shows you a fair pair of feels.

Body and spirit are twins: God only knows which is ditch:
The soul squats down in the flesh, like a tinker drunk in a which.

More is the whole than a part: but half is more than the soul:
Clearly, the soul is the body: but is not the body the whole?

One and two are not one: but one and nothing is true:
Truth can hardly be false, if falsehood cannot be two.

Once the mastodon was: pterodactyls were common as ox:
Then the mammoth was God: now is He a prize cocks.

Parallels all things are: yet many of these are you:
You are certainly I: but certain I am not askew.

Springs the rock from the plain, shoots the stream from the cock:
Cocks exist for the hen: but hens exist for the rock.

God, whom we see not, is: and God, who is not, we dee:
Fiddle, we know, is didle: and diddle, we take it, is see.


__

ENJOY
BELLADONNA**

with

Elaine Equi

and

Maggie Nelson

*

Friday, April 25,

6:30 p.m. (PROMPT!!!)

at Zinc Bar

90 W. Houston Street, NYC

(between LaGuardia Place/Thompson, below Zamir fur shop)

A $4 donation is suggested.

Bring in the spring, celebrate national poetry month, and share reports from
the anti-war.

Elaine Equi s latest book is The Cloud of Knowable Things (Coffee House
Press). She is also the author of many books including Surface Tension,
Decoy and Voice-Over which won the 1998 San Francisco State Poetry Award.
Widely anthologized, her poems have been included in Postmodern American
Poetry: A Norton Anthology and The Best American Poetry for the years 1989,
1995 and 2002. She teaches creative writing in The New School s MFA Program
and in the graduate department at City College of New York.

Maggie Nelson originally comes from California. Her books of poems include
Not Sisters, with Cynthia Nelson (Soft Skull Press, 1996), Shiner (Hanging
Loose, 2001) and a collection just out this spring, The Latest Winter (also
from Hanging Loose). With three other ladies, she runs the literary magazine
Fort Necessity, a purse-sized volume of fabulous writing published annually.
She has taught poetry at Wesleyan University and the New School and is about
ten minutes away from recieving her Ph.D. from CUNY. She's glad to be here.


***

Belladonna* is a feminist/innovative reading and publication series that
promotes the work of women writers who are adventurous, experimental,
politically involved, multi-form, multicultural, multi-gendered, delicious
to talk about, unpredictable, dangerous with language.  BELLADONNA* has
featured such writers as Erica Hunt, Fanny Howe, Mei-mei Berssenbrugge,
Cecilia VicuC1a, Lisa Jarnot, Camille Roy, Nicole Brossard, Abigail Child
and Chris Tysh, among many other experimental and hybrid women writers.
Beyond being a platform for women writers, the curators promote work that is
experimental in form, connects with other art forms, and is
socially/politically active in content.  Alongside the readings, BELLADONNA*
supports its artists by publishing commemorative pamphlets of their work on
the night of the event.  Please contact us (Rachel Levitsky and Erica
Kaufman) at belladonnaseries@yahoo.com and/or visit the website if you would
like to receive a catalog or hear more about our salons.
http://www.durationpress.com/belladonna



**deadly nightshade, a cardiac and respiratory stimulant, having
purplish-red flowers and black berries



Belladonna* readings happen monthly between September and June.

Please backchannel if you would like to be taken off this list or if you
receive multiple announcements.

and PS come after to a second reading on the 25th at CERES Gallery 306
B'way, Poets for Choice with Rachel Levitsky, Nick Piombino and Jerome Sala

From:         Scott Pound <pounds@BILKENT.EDU.TR>
Organization: Bilkent University
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I would say, to modify a Wittgensteinism, that the meaning of a theory is
its use in the world.

And that theory is not one thing.

And that theory itself is meaningless outside the question of agency, of its
use by people.

And that the people who use theory the most have no real use for it.

And that the people who use theory exclusively to make sense of the world
are deep down very sad about something they cannot change but wish they
could.

And that the use of theory in literature departments is often a reductive
and distorting heuristic device that obscures as much as it reveals.

And that the use of theory in other contexts such as art practice and
activism and teaching can lead to new discoveries about perception,
ideology, and meaning.

And that theory tells us nothing of how poems are made, distributed, and
used, and next to nothing about how art might best be understood in terms of
something other than theory.
=========================================================================

Rhizome ArtBase as a linked object.

http://rhizome.org/object.rhiz?14970

Creation Date: Jan 01 1995
Type: Text, Audio, Animation
Genre: Participatory, Narrative, Conceptual, Anti-Art
Technology: VRML, QuickTime, MP3, JavaScript, Java, HTML, Flash
Keywords: Language, Internet, Community, Audio, Animation

Statement

komninos zervos:
description of the site:

"cyberpoetry" is the name i gave to the poetry created on my macintosh
lc630avcd, my goal was to create a poetry that was computer generated, that
was moving, that was two and three dimensional and that incorporated voice
and sound.

it was a poetry that could not be published as a traditional print
publication. whilst it resembled film-making the text created the images
and evoked moods and was always the principle object of every animation and
movie.

cyberpoetry:
poetry that can not be published in the traditional print media,
poetry that moves in time and space,
poetry that requires new ways of reading,
poetry that allows interaction,
poetry that is moving digital, aural, visual, and animated.


in 1996,  i established a web presence, developing cyberpoetry for the net
and a gallery of cyberpoetry from around the globe.  since then the site
has received 100,000 visitors. i want the site to be as active as possible,
a celebration of words/text/sounds, entertaining, informative and
fun.  hope you enjoy it.

other sites which i have contributed to:
cyberpoet@slv:  http://www.experimedia.vic.gov.au/
weak blood:   http://netartefact.de/weakblood/

Text on-line journal:
http://www.gu.edu.au/school/art/text/speciss/issue2

my own sites:
http://users.bigpond.net.au/mangolegs
http://spokenword.blog-city.com
http://www.gu.edu.au/ppages/K_Zervos



Bio

komninos zervos:biographical details

komninos, performance poet, poeted from 1985 professionally, taking his
poetry to schools, community groups, hotels, music venues, prisons, coffee
lounges and universities, radio and television and now the internet.

komninos the published poet has two adult collections of poetry with the
university of queensland press, 'komninos', 1991, and 'komninos by the
kupful', 1994, a collection of poetry for children illustrated by peter
viska and published by oxford university press, 'the baby rap and other
poems', 1992, and a hard cover illustrated children's picture
book  published by harper/collins, 'high street, kew east', 1991.

komninos has had three plays performed by professional theatre companies in
sydney and brisbane.

in 1992 komninos received the australian human rights award for literature
and in 1993 was awarded the australia council's ros bower award for
outstanding achievement in community arts.

in 1995 komninos completed a masters of arts in creative writing at the
university of queensland, he authored a cd-rom of 'cyberpoetry' for his
dissertation.

in 1997 komninos travelled to london to be writer in residence at artec, a
multimedia training and resource centre in islington where he authored a
cd-rom, 'cyberpoetry underground'.

komninos teaches full-time and convenes the CyberStudies major, at the
School of Arts, Griffith University, Gold Coast Campus, Australia.


komninos zervos
lecturer, convenor of CyberStudies major
School of Arts

Surrealist's art collection fetches =A332m

                                            Paul Webster in Paris
Saturday  April     19, 2003
The Guardian

                               After two weeks of turbulent auctions -=20=

inevitably described as surrealist - the sale of Andr=E9 Breton's=20
personal art collection has fetched =8046m (=A331.8m), twice the =
pre-sale=20
estimate.

The auctions, which went on late into the night to accommodate=20
telephone bidders from the US, were disturbed by opponents of the=20
state's refusal to buy Breton's rented flat near Pigalle, in the north=20=

of Paris, where the surrealist manifesto was drawn up in 1924.

Since the poet's death in 1966, at the age of 70, the flat has been=20
preserved along with thousands of artworks, photographs, a collection=20
of primitive art and personal souvenirs.

Led by intellectuals including the philosopher Jacques Derrida,=20
protesters disturbed some of the sales to campaign for state=20
intervention. Even without their presence the event was often chaotic.

More than 50,000 people viewed the 6,249 lots while hundreds of=20
spectators packed the saleroom during the 21 sessions. Bidding was=20
often wild, with records set for paintings by Magritte, Miro and Arp=20
and several others when state museums stepped in to outbid private=20
buyers.

The most contested part of the sale was a collection of photographs by=20=

Man Ray and lesser known photographers.

One specialist collector, Jean-Claude Vrain, was outbid 100 times by=20
museums which spent nearly =8012m to cream off the best items.

Mr Vrain said: "I am angry because the state ignored objects connected=20=

with Breton's political activities as a faithful, anti-Stalinist=20
Trotskyist."

The biggest official buyers were the Jacques Doucet Museum in Paris,=20
where Breton left his personal letters, and the National Museum of=20
Modern Art at the Pompidou centre, which had previously acquired some=20
of Breton's artefacts as part of death duties.

Marcel Fleiss, the leading dealer in Breton mem orabilia, said the=20
auction had resurrected interest in the surrealist movement and given=20
long-delayed recognition to neglected artists.

He said: "Breton's magic has done what I haven't been able to do in 30=20=

years.

"I have been selling 90% of these artists all that time and even in my=20=

dreams I could never sell them at these prices."

The star of the sale was a portrait of Breton by Victor Brauner which,=20=

at =80180,000, fetched five times its reserve price. The painting will =
be=20
exhibited at the City of Paris Modern Art Museum.

Breton's daughter, Aube Ell=E9o=FCet-Breton, decided to sell her =
father's=20
collection two years after the death of his widow, Elisa.

From:         Joe Amato <joe.amato@COLORADO.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <1050790154.3ea1c90af317e@webmail.scsv.nevada.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

i appreciate what nick lolordo is saying, given the standard media
relationship to highbrow academics... but i don't think eakin's
article constitutes merely a failed public relations gambit for the
theory wing (as it were)...

have a look at what skip gates is actually quoted as saying... or
stanley fish... these folks btw are *used to* being quoted in
newspapers... i.e., they know how to handle journalists... heck, i
saw fish e.g. on o'reilly some months back...

besides which, as i say (again, my anecdotal contribution to this
thread), i saw this coming... e.g., i had a conversation back at mla
in nyc (the day prior to our hanging out over beer and chicken wings,
nick!) in which i told a buddy of mine that this was the prevailing
attitude toward theory by the theorists i'd been bumping into...
viz., not simply that we ought to be skeptical of the conceptual
purchase we obtain through theory (fine, ok), but that theory itself
was something one can be paid to do (write) and to teach (well,
sorta!) w/o in any sense committing to its provocations... read that
latter clause over...

in short, that theory is just a game... the top-ranked theorists
might not cop to this, quite, but those who don't share the limelight
may... in fact, the more extreme version of this attitude---and i'm
suggesting that this attitude is chic right now, in many of the more
well-heeled english depts. anyway---is that teaching too is something
of a game (and if this isn't said outright, it's implied through any
number of institutional gestures, esp. when it comes time e.g. to
ensure that one's course makes enrollment minimums)... in fact, i
think the failure here is that many of these folks have long since
been insulated from the classroom in any real sense, or at least,
from students who really need to learn (as mairead has argued)...

now i don't wish to pick a fight with christine murray either (hi
christine!) but when she writes that this is a matter of "power
relations, authority, privilege, hegemony: who speaks, who listens,
who can say what, who can name what?" i can't help but observe that
she's talking theory... these are the terms that theory gave us...
these are the terms (let's say) with which many of us hope to crank
open discourse in our undergrad and even grad classrooms (by fiat,
btw---theory courses are now prereqs in most undergrad english
curricula)... if the terms feel a bit musty, perhaps we need new
terms, ok... but from where i sit, these terms have proved mighty
useful...

most of us who learned that discourse sweated through it, sure (as
grad students, and as faculty---in my case, btw, as a former
practicing engineer)... but it's not just a matter of learning now
that we've been sold a bad bill of goods---for me, theory has worked,
both as a means of furthering my own thinking and in the classroom,
and whatever my misgivings about it, or about its
quasi-commodification... and how many times have i had to defend
(this is what it amounts to) my using "theory" in the classroom? (i
have to use quotes now)... how many times, as a creative writing
instructor, have i bumped up against, not just anti-theoretical-ism,
but anti-intellectualism?... check that:  not "bumped up against,"
but crashed into...

here's a little tidbit from p. 5 of my recent tenure committee
report, the document chiefly responsible for what has turned out to
be my 2nd tenure denial (and ain't nobody on this list can say, join
*that* club):

"Deconstruction theories, for better or worse, have so thoroughly and
skeptically interrogated traditional values, assumptions, standards
and canons of work that there is no longer a cohesive epistemology
available in the humanities."

you can hear, in this somewhat awkwardly writ micro-narrative, a
resistance to theory that many theorists have yet to entirely
appreciate... remember---this is a tenure committee report, not a
~pmla~ article... by associating yours truly with "deconstruction
theories"---a kind of red-baiting, if you will---the creative writing
faculty who penned this gem position me for any number of the zany
allegations that follow in its wake...

and now, these selfsame faculty will no doubt be the first to pick up
that ~ny times~ piece and feel even more justified in not having
bothered to really learn what it is they've tried so hard to
ignore... if fish, gates and the rest had imagined that the reporter
they were talking to wielded this kind of institutional power (a
testament to the efficacy of journalism?)---which is to say, if they
understood just how fraught the situation is in so many quarters of
academe, for so many of us---maybe they would have paused to consider
the ramifications of their pronouncements...

but i doubt they think that far ahead these days, for as christine
indicates, this is about power relations, authority, privilege,
hegemony: who speaks, who listens, who can say what, who can name
what...

best,

joe

                       Pater Noster

            Our Father who art in heaven
                          Stay there
              And we'll stay here on earth
             Which is sometimes so pretty
           With its mysteries of New York
                 And its mysteries of Paris
       At least as good as that of the Trinity
               With its little canal at Ourcq
                    Its great wall of China
                      Its river at Morlaix
                        Its candy canes
                   With its Pacific Ocean
           And its two basins in the Tuileries
       With its good children and bad people
           With all the wonders of the world
                        Which are here
                     Simply on the earth
                    Offered to everyone
                         Strewn about
        Wondering at the wonder of themselves
                   And daring not avow it
       As a naked pretty girl dares not show herself
          With the world's outrageous misfortunes
                       Which are legion
                        With legionaries
                          With torturers
                With the masters of this world
The masters with their priests their traitors and their troops
                        With the seasons
                          With the years
        With the pretty girls and with the old bastards
          With the straw of misery rotting in the steel
                             of cannons.

--Jacques Prévert, tr. Lawrence Ferlinghetti

fr. *Paroles* 1946
and City Lights Books, 1958

also in *The Random House Book of Twentieth-Century French Poetry*
ed., Paul Auster [New York: Random House,1982]



Lines read at Alix-Cléo Blanchette's and Jacques Roubaud's Bridal

Alix-Cléo is joined to Jacques
and Jacques is joined to Alix-Cléo

This is a delicious coincidence
and so at this hour
both are allied and united
as are bird and branch
Aucassin and Nicolette
table and chair
science and doubt
desert and oasis
*tilia* and *quercus*
quill and tale
sunrise and sunset
absence and trace
bee and linden

It's a nice hour in June
the sun shines on Ile de la Cité
on their transistor radios dealers in used literature listen to Alessandro Scarlatti's *Sonate a quattro*
harassed tourists ascend the stairs to Sacré-Coeur
on Rue de la Huchette blue-jeaned Dutch lasses sound their banjos and binious

The entire earth stretches out around us
its unsounded oceans
its lochs, its tablelands, its channels
its hills and its tundras
its sand dune, its hidden treasures, its islands, its roadsteads,
its crude oil and its turbines
its bauxites and rare soils
its basilicas, its haunted castles, its ruined bastions
its adult scouts in hot-red raincoats that chant carols at the hours close to the sacred birth
its crescent-lensed notaries that read the late editions under old burners
its retired colonels in council at the *tabac* on Rue Saint-Louis-en-l'Ile
its carousers that exit antiquated discos and then scatter
its slant-lidded Siberians that ride across the Tuba in birch canoes
its beret-clad excursionists that assault the Ballon d'Alsace
its austere Jansenists that recite Exodus and Isaiah
its circus ballerinas balanced on their obedient steeds
its D.Litt.'s that discuss Judeo-Christian structures in Hölderlin's discourse
its obese Irish chars that collect salted dills and beer (in cans) in a Bronx delicatessen

Here blue surrounds the sun, or soon shall
Let's abandon the era's raucousness
     tornadoes and clouds
Let's listen to the linnet's tune
to the cat stretched out in the den next to Bescherelle's *Dictionnaire*
quiet quotidian sounds
the heart's beat

These occasional lines
that do not concern
either carious teeth
or roots that clutch
or the author etherised on a table
or the *Coccinella cardinalis*
or the 1848 Constitution
are here inscribed to usher in this betrothal

Let decades rich in elation and delectation
bless Alix-Cléo and Jacques
those here saluted
and let there arise in the east
     a sable jet salute: childhood
and in the south
     a turquoise blue salute: adulthood
and next
     non-existence's ochre abalone salute
     that cannot be calculated or uttered
and in the north
     an alabaster seashell salute: the Resurrection

and let the Southern Cross salute Alix-Cléo and Jacques
and the star that heralds the sunset
and all the constellations
and all the nebulae

and that as sunrise starts
at the hour that bleaches the surround
both stride quite around the earth's bounds and the stars.

George Perec, tr. Harry Matthews

fr. *Épithalames*, 1982
in *Oulipo Compendium*, eds. Harry Matthews and Alastair Brotchie
[London: Atlas Press, 1998]


Hal

From:         Mairead Byrne <mbyrne@RISD.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
Mime-Version: 1.0

Stanley Fish, in any case, has been quite clear about his view that the
role of the academy is to *teach*, not to form or express political
opinion (I'd love to hear his definition of teaching; well, on second
thoughts I wouldn't; and I don't think it would actually be possible to
engage in dialogue with him, I tried once).  In his columns in the
Chronicle of Higher Education, he makes no bones about the close
relationship between the academy and *money* though he
resists the implications of this: the academy must do anything necessary
(including exploiting workers) to continue to offer the gifts of the
academy to those who can afford it.  It's the sort of self-perpetuating
nonsense that prevails in the academy and in America, too often: you can
have tenure as long as you're too exhausted, played out, and implicated
to invoke its protection, we have free speech as long as we don't use
it, we must desist from free speech in order to show solidarity with our
soldiers fighting for the rights of others to have free speech...  Well,
the academy is not some bleeping R2D2 stuffed with money dribbling what
Stanley Fish calls academic virtues all round its manic circuitry.  It's
an organic, albeit sometimes arthritic, component of our economy,
saturating/soaking (and silencing?)a sizeable proportion of "American
youth": it *matters*.
And forgive me all, I'm not an American citizen, though my grandparents
were and I am dependent on its economy and alive in its cultures.
Mairead

Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER

Before we get too much further into the muck of abstractionism and the
gnarly minutiae of academia and its endless discontents, can somebody tell
me on a basic level what is theory, and how does it differ from, say,
thinking? Isn't theory merely all that which hasn't yet become fully a form
of practice? It seems to me that to talk of an end to theory is as silly as
to talk of an end to thinking itself. I suppose some conservatives would
like this to happen very much, making America into a nation of docile
assembly line drones and compliant cannon fodder, which is why the idea
appeals to them, now that they are within striking distance of taking the
world by fist and fury. But theory and thinking and politics and imagination
are all one and the same, it seems to me. What makes it go off the track is
when theory is divorced from practice and action, which, so I hear, is a
common academic affliction. But theorizing poets and practicing theorists
should know better than this, much better.

m

Sorry to hear about your second tenure denial, Joe.  Academia remains one of
the few places in the U.S. where chicken fights are legal.

RE:  this theory, yay or nay, quibble.  There is no escape from theory.  When
exactly have we been free of it?  Whatever mode of inscription we practice,
the scribble opens itself to one theory or another.  Seems the resistance is
to explanatory systems and methodologies that involve indeterminacy, not to
theory per se.  When it was Aristotle to Coleridge there was barely a peep.
Indeterminacy, however, interrogates hierarchies (values), and that ain't
good for business (the corporate model now dominates the university system).
Much as the uncertainty principle threatens the intelligibility of the
universe, deconstruction et al undermines the unfettered transmission of
certain values within the humanities.  That many of these theories come from
France--well, given the current state of affairs . . .

Anyway, such resistance is of course political, and nothing new.  Anti-int
ellectualism?  Most certainly.  I have a physicist friend whose work involves
subatomic particle/waves--you know, the atomic geography where the rational
world breaks down.  A few years ago he was fully funded via government
grants.  Now the well has dried up.  Seems the work just isn't "practical"
enough.  What, after all, is produced?  So it goes.  Best, Bill



WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
bn.com

Some of the resistance is as you say, but a lot is more to the=20
impenetrability of the jargon. Much academic literary criticism has become=
=20
I think for the first time unreadable to the otherwise literate, even when=
=20
what's being said would be easily expressed without jargon.

It seems to me that there's a problem when any group of critics become=20
canonical to the point that other critics simply assume familiarity with=20
their systems to the extent that the lack of that familiarity bars others=20
from the discussion. The work of literature at hand is effectively held=20
hostage.

Among the older professoriate there is also the memory of the=20
condescension, utter arrogance and raw ambition of the first couple of=20
generations of decnstructophiles. I saw it happen when Ren=E9 Girard took=20
over the Hopkins French dept. It wasn't pretty. None of the opposition were=
=20
hostile to France or the French.

Mark

Date:         Sun, 20 Apr 2003 11:54:10 -0600
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Joe Amato <joe.amato@COLORADO.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <5.1.0.14.1.20030420095701.01e38b88@mail.earthlink.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

mark, i *do* think that theory can be impenetrable, esp. in the hands
(reading or writing) of lesser mortals (like me)... at the same time,
theory is there for theoretically inclined minds, whether the theory
is for physicists or for litcritters... i don't have a problem with
the latter, in itself, and i'm not sure why anyone would... i also
don't have a problem with undergrads in english learning this
discourse, phoneme by phoneme... i might have a problem with the idea
that, as a poet, i have nothing necessarily to do with theory...
there's just too much work out there at this point, under the theory
rubric, for any self-respecting writer to dismiss it out of hand...

or so i would aver...

but first, to repeat what bill austin just wrote, in so many words:
theory and thought don't, can't end... but as mairead was arguing,
they can certainly be curtailed... in short, and to answer mwp, there
are institutional repercussions to the sort of publicity that ~times~
piece generates... it adds fuel to certain fires, and extinguishes
others... of course the immediate effect is felt at the institution
of origin---academe... "theory" in academe, in english depts., can
mean something very specific, in instutional terms---it does not
equate with thought... not that it couldn't---but the problem is,
again, that many of those who would claim the anti-theory posture
will insist that they're still thinking, when in reality and upon
closer examination their capacity for critical reflection kicked it a
long, long time ago...

you'll just have to trust me on this...

naturally, most of what happens in academe eventually leeches out
into the wider culture (much as today we deconstruct tom, dick, and
harry)...

now the anti-jargon argument has some legitimacy, in that we've all
witnessed theoretical devices deployed (ha), whether consciously or
less so, so as to inhibit understanding... there are poor writers, in
any mode... but lurking here, too, may perhaps be the question of
outlets for such writing---i for one would favor more of the kind of
in-between journals umberto eco once talked about as all but absent
on the u.s. scene (see his ~travels in hyperreality~)... i.e.,
journals that aren't for specialists, but aren't for ~ny times~
readers, either... the web has answered to this demand, but not
entirely...

but let me return to this question of jargon:  when foucault's work
started gaining in popularity, much was made by some of how
"difficult" he was to understand (in translation, mind you)...
personally, i find foucault easier to follow these days than, say,
plato... specifically, an essay like "what is an author?" strikes me
as the epitome of lucidity (i also find that essay endlessly
valuable)... some theorists, like derrida, continue to be tough reads
(for me anyway), but i've a much better sense of what they're about
if only b/c i've danced with their ideas, and diluted versions of
their ideas, for so long, much as the sex pistols sound rather
melodious to my ears these days...

which is another way of saying, that we ought at least to allow that
some things take some getting used to, and that even if we have a
responsibility (i say if) to articulate ourselves at times so that
most all literate beings can understand us, we probably ought to
forgo the dream of a common language, or lingo... as i address this
sentiment to poets, i can't imagine that anyone would strenuously
disagree, for if there's a set of word-practices that habitually
inhabit the non-communicative regions of language, or threaten to do
so, it's poetry... in fact, in this sense, poetry certainly trumps
theory...

out for the day///

best,

joe

From the forthcoming Donald Rumsfeld anthology:


The Unknown

As we know,
There are known knowns.
There are things we know we know.
We also know
There are known unknowns.
That is to say
We know there are some things
We do not know.
But there are also unknown unknowns,
The ones we don't know
We don't know.

-Feb. 12, 2002, Department of Defense news briefing


Happenings


You're going to be told lots of things.
You get told things every day that don't happen.

It doesn't seem to bother people, they don't-
It's printed in the press.
The world thinks all these things happen.
They never happened.

Everyone's so eager to get the story
Before in fact the story's there
That the world is constantly being fed
Things that haven't happened.

All I can tell you is,
It hasn't happened.
It's going to happen.

-Feb. 28, 2003, Department of Defense briefing

The Situation

Things will not be necessarily continuous.
The fact that they are something other than perfectly continuous
Ought not to be characterized as a pause.
There will be some things that people will see.
There will be some things that people won't see.
And life goes on.

-Oct. 12, 2001, Department of Defense news briefing

Hey, Joe, I understood that the Times piece had a political content, but I
also know--I think I was talking about--ways in which some academic
theorists have made themselves vulnerable.

And I'll add that many of those who would claim a theory posture will
insist that they're still thinking, when in reality and upon
closer examination their capacity for critical reflection kicked it a long,
long time ago...you'll just have to trust me on this.

The ideas, as far as I've understood them, are often elegant but not
particularly difficult (and some terms, like deconstruction, merely name
activities that have been common forever). I suspect that there are
political motivations in the difficulty of the lingo--a clerical language.

The analogy with physics simply doesn't work--physics uses a different
language because the common tongue can't handle the concepts. Very little
critical theory is so burdened.

As to politics, it's good to remember that a lot of academics were openly,
without the shield of jargon--before the current jargon existed--marxists
when it was far more dangerous to be so, and paid the price.

Jargon is of course to a degree inevitable. Using it wholesale when there
are alternatives is just lazy. I'm proposing a sort of Occam's razor
applied to language.

Mark
