Date:         Sun, 20 Apr 2003 15:07:58 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Christine Murray <cmurray@UTA.EDU>
Subject:      THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T...
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

matter...

"Litcritters"--

Of course theory matters, is wed to the material practices and aspects of
life and is essential to material being. Reason to be grateful for irony in
this is that even theory in all its guises of arrogance can't take away the
everyday relation of theory to practice.  To be shamelessly reductionist:
when the cat keeps track of the mouse from the window, or for that matter,
keeps rack of another cat, then the cat is strategizing, thus employing a
form of theorizing: thinking about how to deploy or act before (or after
works too) acting. The mouse reciprocates in its way, too.  The problem with
that analogy, as theory also reminds us, is that hierarchical animal
relationships--food chains and all that--are far more limited than what
humans can make available for human community (to cast it in a shamelessly
optimistic perspective)by recognizing and rethinking the relation between
theory and practice.  In that sense, it is outrageous that the NYTimes and
Skip Gates or St.Fish pass theory off as immaterial (literally + figurally),
but it's part of the theater that theory also is: play, as well as work, and
all that.

Thanks, Joe Amato: no fight here.  Yes, there are "useful" bits of language
phrasing from theory all over my ways of speaking and positions of
enunciation. One cannot escape this, as someone has pointed out, and
especially not after immersion in academics.  But more telling and
symptomatic is immersion in high literacy, I think, which can occur without
the formal academic kinds.  Reading and writing are radical actions in all
ways.  That's why poetry matters so much.

My point is that one reason the stream of theory-speak--who speaks?-who
listens?-who cares? & etc--is "useful" is that it is easily recognized and
accessible phrasing. It has a kind of currency akin to street-cred. If you
come to theory at college level from discourse areas where theory is seen as
mystifying and useless, then you can understand it's utility and economies
immediately if you identify through that line of questioning. It's a matter
of translating, radically, from one discourse to another.  There's a certain
agency in that, though its use, too, is contentious. From that perspective,
the idea of theory as related to practice can *really* matter to you, make
you want to find out what the academics doing theory are up to.  That's how
it happened to me, anyway.

"Poor writers" may be misleading.  More like "poor writing," literally,
impoverished due to lack of input. To my mind this would be lack of enough
commonality and plain old bear grease to keep the translation effective.
This, I'm sure you know, in literacy theory would be a writer in need of
reciprocal relationships with other thinkers/writers, and the varieties of
available discourses.  There is a long standing hierarchy of reference to
writers/writing, I want to point out, that draws a line between "high" and
"low" rhetorics: street vs hoi poloi ways of saying stuff.  This, too, has
to do with power relations and how reciprocity occurs as translation--more
accurately, transaction though without the capitalistic connotation if we
can imagine such (we may not be able to)--between differing folks and
communities.

This is way too long.  Thanks.  One more thing: Mark Weiss, on "jargon"
yeah, what a pain jargon is when we read student work, sure.  But there is a
certain kind of allure there, one poets can work in easier than can any
other functionary of writing (ugh! what awful phrasing that is).  In
theory's jargon is music and poetics mixed, heady, ripe as future peaches.
Play, to overturn each hegemonic arrogance, then.

keep on, all.

chris murray

(Gothic News Service, 04/20) Easter Morning at the SUV, Solar and Oak Grove
Ranch Near Crawford

Easter morning, drivers along Highway 185 in Texas  - the one that leads
right by the President=B9s White House in Crawford =AD found themselves treated
to a brand new roadside attraction.  Five SUVs =AD each one from a different
manufacturer - are spaced 10 feet apart and stuck nose first at 65-degree
angles into the earth. Only the back side doors, windows and rear ends
remain revealed, each of the vehicle=B9s alternatively royal blue,
butterscotch gold, white, and cherry red colors oddly glowing like fresh
spring growth in the face of the rising sun..

More curiously, on a small northern pathway from the SUV vista stop =AD on
what is normally an arid, some say Biblical landscape =AD is the emergence of
a large, circular Oak Grove that includes picnic tables at the open center
and several winding paths into private alcoves with small benches under the
awnings of the robust trees. Perhaps equally spectacular, extending out for
several acres behind the SUV spectacle, are the parallel, reflective solar
energy panels that rotate at different angles to best catch the sun=B9s rays
at different points of the day. Visitors are welcome to pedal the site=B9s
free bicycles up and down paths that extend in several directions across th=
e
horizon.

In the roadside parking area =AD on a stand shaped out of SUV hood =AD a small
brochure printed on recycled paper provides some information about the site=
:
=85 The solar panels steel rotational supports are one hundred per cent
constructed from shredded SUV metal. Granulated glass and shredded syntheti=
c
upholstery units constitute the reflective material and chemical agents
required to produce solar energy.
=85 Bicycle frames, wheels and gears are also created from recycled SUVs. One
SUV will create 1000 bicycle frames and parts.
=85 Individuals and families are welcome to donate their SUVs to the Ranch
Recycling Center located at Crawford town limits. Free van transportation t=
o
your destination and back home is provided to donors.
=85 Under the auspices of Solar Utility Vendor Inc. (SUV Inc.) the company
provides energy through out Texas and adjoining states for community
electrical, fuel and heating systems.
Easter Morning featured an egg hunt in the Grove with both adults and
children fanning out across the paths to find blue, red, gold, and green
eggs in and around the trees. Each egg also bore a stencil printed "RECYCLE=
"
message. Egg shell waste cans were set up at the exit with fresh painted
advice,  "Partake of  the egg and recycle as you wish.  Shells hells conver=
t
to biodegradable plastic for practical use."
Houston art critics have been quick to claim the new site=B9s significance.
"This is a great contemporary re-interpretation of the both practical and
sublime use of the traditional religious shrine," one said.  "It=B9s a magica=
l
combination of high-tech modern materials used to produce both illumination
and power co-leveraged with the Oak;s healing, restive and regenerative
power. Joseph Beuys, the German artist who planted trees, and the Texas Ant
Farm=B9s Cadillac Ranch are influences here =AD but SUV Inc.=B9s commitment to
recycling, non-fossil fuel commitment, and implicit reverence for nature as
a human partner is a clear artistic step forward to community, national and
world health."

The Crawford White House refused to publicly comment on the value of the
site other than to express its concerns about either pagan religious and/or
terrorist uses. It is also not known whether the President=B9s ranch will buy
into SUV Inc.=B9s solar power unit. At last look, on Easter morning, families
were stopping =AD many in SUVS - to join in the egg hunt, picnic and quietly
contemplate on Grove benches while man took advantage of bikes to pedal
towards the horizon on the special paths between the illuminated panels.

From:         Hilton Obenzinger <hobnzngr@STANFORD.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <5.1.0.14.2.20030419111727.00ba3738@incoming.verizon.net>

The day before the article appeared in the NY Times there was the review of
"Empire" -- and another appeared the next day in the Sunday Book Review --
a book which argues that the British empire did much good, and the US
should learn from it.  Paul Berman received major reviews for his version
of liberal imperialism in the guise of anti-totalitarianism just days
before.  About 10 years ago, soon after the Somalia debacle, articles and
books began to appear which sought to restore the good name of colonialism
and empire; now "empire" and "imperialism" and "colonialism" are no longer
terms considered to be "leftist rhetoric" but part of general discourse.

I am not sure about the intellectuals at the meeting reported on in the
article -- and what really transpired -- but the reporting itself seems to
be in line with certain trends in the NY Times and other media:
oppositional intellectuals, particularly academic ones, are ridiculous
simply for attempting to be oppositional (while theorists who reinforce
current power assumptions are praised, such as Bernard Lewis or Harold
Bloom).  Now, there have been excesses in certain circles: jargon;
arrogance associated with cushy jobs; fadishness; presumption that literary
analysis is identical to social analysis or that theory itself is
praxis.  But I do not think that is what is at the root of NY Times'
disparagement.  In addition to typical American anti-intellectual
attitudes, I would suggest that there are also many people that would like
to discredit "theory" if it is oppositional and to pass off "theories" as
non theories (or as merely pragmatic realism) if they support imperial
interests or the status quo.  In response, I have a few thoughts:

We need theory more than ever, particularly social and economic theories
that can help explain the operations of globalization and world
empire.  Such theories will have a component that affects the way we think
about producing literature, analyzing literature, and examining all kinds
of cultural phenomenon.

Whoever may have thought that theory was the exclusive province of
universities was deluded -- but anyone who thinks that theory is not
produced in universities is also deluded.

Anyone with a critical sensibility can see that the world is in a lot of
trouble.

Get to work.

Hilton Obenzinger

it widely known within the FAA and the military that four planes have been
simultaneously hijacked and taken off course, no one notifies the President
of the United States. It is not until 9:30 that any Air Force planes are
scrambled to intercept, but by then it is too late. This means that the
National Command Authority waited for 75 minutes before scrambling
aircraft, even though it was known that four simultaneous hijackings had
occurred. [Source: CNN; ABC; MSNBC; Los Angeles Times; The New York Times;

Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER

Yes, it seems the rise of the Theory Contras!
It seems a bit of piling on of humiliation after the "successful liberation
of Iraq."  The liberation "from what" is easily persuasive, no matter how
pursued, if the focus remains on Hussein; the "for liberation what" agendas
and the theories and folks that drive those theories into practice are the
ones that I think are driving many of us crazy. "Retro-colonial Romancing
the Mideast" - replete with  Pilgrim Progress novels - appear to prefigure
this Administration's public imagination of the immediate future while, at
the same time, an Occupation reality that will feature - when threatened by
religious, ethnic or political opposition - Israeli military style controls
as in Palestine, only this time it is the US Military. Simultaneously,
offering more US military protection, will be the creation of entirely
insular Oil well and Refinery communities, similar to those of Chevron and
Shell in the Nigeria Delta region "to protect the flow of oil".   Bleak.
Bleak.

I think what I am experiencing - and perhaps this is shared by others(?) -
is the desire of this Administration not only to re-enforce the humiliation
of the Arabs - making all the nation's and peoples line up and behave "or
else" - but to extend that same momentum to the Peace Movement. They are
trying to take full advantage right now to neuter, silence (i.e. terrorize
and humiliate) the world and domestic opposition.

As I believe Hilton suggests, much to do, including thinking in a reactiony
time that appears to already have fateful consequences on our daily lives.
And not lose, but to reconstitute the aims and momentum of opposition so
strong before this invasion.

Happy Rabbit Day, pull a leg hard, etc.,
Stephen V

Date:         Sun, 20 Apr 2003 22:03:37 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Aaron Vidaver <vid@RUNCIBLE.ORG>
Subject:      Canada Harbours American Poetry Haters
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"; format="flowed"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

This review is by Robin Mathews--"Canada's leading
political poet."

> > Charles Watts and Edward Byrne (eds.), THE RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC
> > WORLD, ESSAYS ON POETICS IN HONOUR OF ROBIN BLASER, Vancouver,
> > Talonbooks, 1999, 464 pages.
> >
> > Ian Angus (ed.), ANARCHO-MODERNISM: TOWARD A NEW CRITICAL THEORY, IN
> > HONOUR OF JERRY ZASLOVE, Vancouver, Talonbooks, 2001, 384 pages.
> >
> > Miriam Nichols (ed.), EVEN ON SUNDAY, ESSAYS, READINGS, AND ARCHIVAL
> > MATERIAL ON THE POETRY AND POETICS OF ROBIN BLASER, Orono, Maine,
> > U.S.A., The National Poetry Foundation, 2002, 396 pages.
> >
> > "The imperial RAISON D'ETRE is to erase the other."
> > (anonymous)
> >
> > The three books named above are produced as celebrations for two U.S.
> > immigrants to British Columbia, Robin Blaser and Jerry Zaslove. The
> > men are friends who worked in the same SFU English Department, they
> > are stamped with the same imperiocentricity, and each has contributed
> > to the celebration volume of the other. In addition, they belong to
> > the band of U.S. immigrants involved in the task of demeaning
> > Canadian legitimacy, denigrating Canadian uniqueness and potential,
> > recruiting young Canadians into their view of things, and - generally
> > - erasing Canadian culture and history.
> >
> > Why are the two U.S. immigrants here? What brought them? What
> > establishes them as motivation for the production of three quite
> > large books - with, apparently, more to come? In the 1960s the
> > Canadian university and college system was expanding. Money was
> > available to hire new faculty. Many Canadians were demanding more
> > attention to and respect for Canadian institutions, achievements,
> > historical complexity, and contemporary population. That drive was
> > connected both to the spreading effect of the 1951 Massey Report on
> > the Arts, Letters, and Sciences, and to the push by people like
> > cabinet minister Walter Gordon, from the late 1950s on, to have the
> > colonized Canadian economy returned to Canadian ownership and control.
> >
> > Against those demands the forces of colonialism, of denigration, were
> > pushing strongly. Our historic internationalism was being re-read by
> > many as inevitable and desirable subservience to the U.S.A. If the
> > Massey commissioners wanted to limit U.S. influence, liberal
> > continentalists like Frank Underhill shouted that Canada couldn't get
> > enough of it. When the drive came to hire Canadians for cultural
> > positions, Frank Underhill - then not far from the grave - publicly
> > scoffed at the idea as did the host of his liberal continentalist
> > allies. U.S. government, as always, pushed for North American
> > integration.
> >
> > U.S. academics flooded into Canada's expanding higher education
> > institutions because Canadian intellectual and cultural
> > administrators believed Canadians inferior to others - especially
> > U.S. people. Secondly, U.S. government wanted excess U.S. graduate
> > school products to be lodged in Canadian universities and colleges.
> > Finally, individual U.S. academics could get (a) better pay (b)
> > better working conditions (c) and wider experience in their first
> > years in Canada than in the U.S.A. In short, most came for economic
> > reasons. Canada was a TERRA INCOGNITA to most of them, but a buck is
> > a buck ... anywhere.
> >
> > Hugh MacLennan noted that the best minds of a country "think with"
> > all the accumulated cultural furniture that has given them peculiar
> > being, and they don't usually forsake that density to live partial
> > intellectual lives elsewhere. George Orwell said something similar
> > in his 1940 essay, "Inside the Whale". Writing of (U.S.) Henry
> > Miller's TROPIC OF CANCER, set in Paris, Orwell wrote: "Miller is
> > writing about the man in the street, and it is incidentally a pity
> > that it should be a street full of brothels. That is the penalty of
> > leaving your native land. It means transferring your roots into
> > shallower soil".
> >
> > In that shallower, because impenetrable, cultural soil imperial
> > English speakers in Canada very often think they face no language
> > barrier. They often refuse to grant that cultural difference exists
> > and declare that difference in the host people is a sign of
> > inferiority. And they work - often audaciously - to build a
> > self-defensive and self-perpetuating community of like-minded
> > imperials and subservient local followers. They live, in short,
> > imperiocentric lives - lives, that is, that have their being in
> > imperial consciousness, that "think with" the intellectual products
> > of the imperial country, that proselytize for its universal
> > centrality, and - especially - that ignore, deprecate, deny, erase
> > the culture and intellectual products of their host country. "The
> > imperial RAISON D'ETRE is to erase the other."
> >
> > In both universities and colleges a long, nasty battle had to be
> > fought to prevent (especially) U.S. academics from using
> > institutional money to bring in, as guests, only people from the
> > U.S.A. Warren Tallman, U.S. immigrant, friend, and contemporary of
> > Blaser and Zaslove, brought to the 1961 B.C. Festival of the
> > Contemporary Arts and the 1963 Vancouver Poetry Conference, for
> > instance, the following: Robert Duncan, Charles Olson, Allen
> > Ginsberg, Denise Levertov, Jack Spicer, Robin Blaser, and Margaret
> > Avison. Only the last named was Canadian. All the rest were from
> > the U.S. That pattern was repeated almost as policy. Subsequently,
> > Blaser was hired at SFU. Miriam Nichols records those things in EVEN
> > ON SUNDAY, where she quotes Margaret Avison being called an AVANT
> > GARDE writer; and she, herself, calls George Woodcock a prolific
> > "nationalist" critic. Woodcock was a spirited anti-nationalist
> > anarchist all his life. One need only read Avison's work to know she
> > was a poetically conservative, deeply religious poet.
> >
> > A few years later, (partly to conserve national grant money) I tried
> > to get UBC to share a few of the Canadian guests I was bringing to
> > the University of Alberta in trade for an equal number of UBC's U.S.
> > guests. The UBC English Dept. guest programmer (a U.S. immigrant)
> > was plainly not interested. Helen Zontoff - Phyllis Webb assured me
> > - disliked the Canadian writers I suggested to her in a letter she
> > did not even condescend to answer. Zontoff obviously wanted to keep
> > Canadian students from being contaminated by contact with major
> > Canadian writers. Little wonder Vancouver bred a group of young
> > Canadians devoted to U.S. ideas and personalities and contemptuous of
> > Canadian traditions.
> >
> > When I was proposed in the mid-1980s for a one year exchange at SFU,
> > English Dept. Chairman was Jerry Zaslove, praised in
> > ANARCHO-MODERNISM for deep concern about human rights. He forcefully
> > supported - if he did not lead - the completely illegitimate attempt
> > to keep me out of SFU. (Warmly supported, I was told, by Robin
> > Blaser.) The case attracted wide attention, being editorialized in
> > the GLOBE AND MAIL and the VANCOUVER SUN, for instance. It was then
> > Chairman Zaslove wrote to the GLOBE AND MAIL to protest. He asserted
> > that I was an "undesirable" and if I would only realize I was
> > "undesirable" I would not be making trouble. After months of dispute
> > the Canadian Association of University Teachers (Canada's national
> > faculty union) visited SFU for three days of investigation and
> > publicly declared SFU in violation of academic freedom for its
> > Zaslove-fronted attempt to suppress freedom of speech and the free
> > exchange of ideas by keeping out a Canadian known for insisting that
> > Canadian culture and ideas be taken seriously in Canadian educational
> > institutions.
> >
> > What can be said abut the three celebratory volumes in praise of
> > Robin Blaser and Jerry Zaslove? Apart from the kind of fundamental
> > error made by editor Miriam Nichols, already mentioned, the books
> > are, more generally, textually inadequate. None possesses an index.
> > THE RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC WORLD, moreover, has almost fifty
> > contributors, none of whom is identified for the reader. Generally,
> > too, there is a state of alienation present in the volumes which is
> > pervasive, and which will become obvious.
> >
> > With Blaser, Jerry Zaslove dwells in an anarcho-modernist world
> > nibbling at Arendtian phantasms of beautiful, consensual society.
> > With Arendt, Zaslove and Blaser are anti-nationalist,
> > 'anti-political', and almost totally absorbed as U.S. people in U.S.
> > life and its dictates (imperiocentrism). Like her, they act as if
> > U.S. imperialism is somehow the whole human condition and so
> > something to be lived, not resisted. The U.S.-inspired anarchist
> > position permits the rejection of responsibility to a difficult
> > vision of a whole, structured, decent, politically articulate
> > society. The rejection is easy because the U.S.-inspired anarchist
> > position is profoundly individualistic, and, finally, solipsistic.
> >
> > Zaslove's investigation into the politics of culture and human rights
> > has been, quite simply, imperiocentric. From time to time I examined
> > the offerings of the Institute of the Humanities which he created and
> > headed. I became convinced that the treatment of Canada and of
> > thinkers in Canada was not merely 'tokenism' but insult. The reading
> > lists were indeed 'international': U.S. writers and writers
> > everywhere who could fit the imperiocentric view of reality. But no
> > John Clark Murray, Norman Bethune, John Watson, Susanna Moodie,
> > Charles de Koninck, John Richardson, F.-X Garneau, Stanley Ryerson,
> > Lionel Groulx, W.L. Morton, Milton Acorn, Hubert Aquin, Sara Jeanette
> > Duncan, Donald Creighton, Hugh MacLennan, Edmond de Nevers, W.D.
> > Lighthall, Jacques Godbout, etc. etc. etc. In short, there never
> > seems to have been the slightest attempt to have Canadian students
> > think seriously about and use the works of Canadians to 'think with'.
> >
> > What about the Institute for the Humanities courses taught in jail
> > and the Downtown East Side (Carnegie Centre)? ("A Dangerous
> > Business: Teaching the Humanities on the Street and in the Gaol",
> > Stephen Duguid and Jane Harris, ANARCHO-MODERNISM, pp. 185-193.).
> > The following writers are named: Carl Sagan, the Romantics, Rousseau,
> > Tolstoy, Socrates, Steinbeck, Cervantes, Burgess, Orwell, Thoreau,
> > Marcuse, Conrad, Dostoevesky, Kropotkin, Kierkegaard, Plato, Freud,
> > Skinner, Fromm, E.H. Carr, V. Serge, the Brontes, Kate Millett. They
> > all swirl around - the authors tell us - "the overall circular theme
> > of 'Human Nature and the Human Condition'".
> >
> > Strange. Notice. Not a single Canadian work mentioned in the
> > article. Though just outside the windows of the Carnegie Centre much
> > of Irene Baird's novel WASTE HERITAGE is set, a novel about
> > unemployment, repressive police, governments that avoid issues, men
> > and women who struggle for solidarity, attempts to organize the
> > destitute, the desperation of the young to gain some meaning and
> > freedom in their lives. But why go on...? When Harold Innis -
> > writing of the imposition of intellectual control by empires - coined
> > the phrase "monopolies of knowledge", he might have been referring to
> > the offerings of the SFU Institute for the Humanities.
> >
> > A few pieces on Walter Benjamin, Aldous Huxley, and human rights in
> > ANARCHO-MODERNISM are interesting. The claim that the book moves
> > "Toward a New Critical Theory", however, is empty. In addition,
> > nothing in the text opens up or deals in a fresh, informative, way
> > with any important aspect of Canadian life, society, history,
> > sociology, belief - or anything else. Even Alan Whitehorn's article
> > "From Alienation to Community...,"( pp. 261-266) based, apparently,
> > upon Canadian experience - is so careful, so correct, so distant, so
> > anaesthetized to U.S. imperial presence in Canada, it could never (as
> > Norman Bethune did) catch septicaemia from getting into close contact
> > with the patient it wishes to treat. If this book provides us with a
> > look at the force of Anarcho-Modernism, we can turn over and go back
> > to sleep.
> >
> > Robin Blaser is invariably referred to as a U.S. poet, having been
> > published in THE NEW AMERICAN POETRY in 1960, being treated as a U.S.
> > poet in such publications since, and figuring as the subject of the
> > 2002, EVEN ON SUNDAY. It is produced by the U.S. National Poetry
> > Foundation which obviously considers him a U.S. 'national' poet. His
> > primary political reality (besides sexual orientation) is the U.S.A.
> > He rarely makes reference to any Canadian in a way that uses him or
> > her for "thinking with". He rarely makes reference to Canadian
> > politics. As late as the middle of the 1990s, fantasizing in
> > conversation, he talks about what is being done to "our political and
> > economic structures"; and then he says, "when I become President...."
> > (p. 429, THE RECOVERY...) Shortly after coming to Canada, he began a
> > periodical called PACIFIC NATION. The name provides a perfect
> > example of the imperial intellectual merging his host country into
> > the imperial country from which he has come. His verse work,
> > IMAGE-NATIONS, is titled, Rachel Blau DuPlessis tells us -
> > predictably - as an anti-nationalist pun. "The imperial RAISON
> > D'ETRE is to erase the other."
> >
> > At one point he refused to go to the U.S.A., not because he was
> > offended by its rapacious foreign policy, nor because he disliked its
> > bullying of his adopted country. Perish the thought. He refused to
> > go to a short term teaching job in the U.S. in 1993 because a law
> > restricting homosexuals was going to be passed in Colorado.
> >
> > The 1995 conference in honour of Blaser in Vancouver (from which THE
> > RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC WORLD is drawn) was astonishing. Canadian
> > funding was poured out in a flood to consider various states of U.S.
> > being, and then to publish the transactions. At a time when the
> > community of writers should have held a conference in honour of
> > Dorothy Livesay, an intricate part of social, political, cultural,
> > and creative life in Canada for more than 60 years, a poet of
> > irreplaceable importance, and living in Victoria - that community
> > ignored her. When a conference in honour of Al Purdy , a major poet,
> > a part of B.C., a significant figure in the Canadian poetic
> > tradition, living in Sidney, should have been held - no conference
> > was held. Instead, U.S. speakers were flushed into Vancouver, and
> > some Canadians were summoned, to celebrate the success of U.S.
> > cultural imperialism in a conference called, "The Recovery of the
> > Public World", a conference in honour of Robin Blaser. "The imperial
> > RAISON D'ETRE is to erase the other." But nothing will erase the
> > insult delivered to Canadians by the neglect of Dorothy Livesay and
> > Al Purdy in B.C. by the U.S. anarchist imperialists and their
> > Canadian clones.
> >
> > If homosexuality is a chief political centre for him, a form of U.S.
> > poetic process is Robin Blaser's philosophical and social centre.
> > THE RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC WORLD huffs and puffs the platitudinously
> > obvious about poetics until the subject becomes a huge, gray
> > dirigible blocking out the sun. Language becomes Blaser's
> > God-replacement, and so the act of making poetry is enquired into
> > with tireless, tedious repetition. Blaser's concept of his
> > God-replacement, however, accords perfectly with anarchist liberalism
> > and, interestingly, with U.S. imperialism which reinterprets any
> > truth to suit imperialist intentions and proclaims the contingency of
> > truth and language. When Blaser, moreover, wrote in the 1960s about
> > Vietnam, Andre Klobucar ("The Decline of the American Margins...."
> > pp. 331-338) says he did not provide "intellectually informed
> > judgement" but "dissolution". Klubucar says Blaser wishes to "place
> > the poem within the social arena rather than vice versa." That may
> > well be pointing to coded assent to or, at best, protective ambiguity
> > about the war - both very specific kinds of politics.
> >
> > The peculiar characteristic of - especially Blaser's but - almost all
> > of the argument stuffed into the two books is its cult-solipsism.
> > From the statement that the poetic line is shaped by the
> > individual(istic) breath, that the"closed" poem is authoritarian and
> > exclusive, that real poetry is paratactic, that beauty and great
> > statement are aristocratic, to the delusion that the "open"
> > (unpunctuated, un-terminated, un-capitalized, free-flow) statement is
> > "democratic", reader-created, ironic, and pluralist, the writers
> > engage in a kind of cult-solipsitic, anarchist manifesto-making.
> >
> > George Bowering ("Robin Blaser at Lake Parodox", EVEN ON SUNDAY)
> > gives us a glimpse of their cult exclusivity. He is a Canadian taken
> > over by U.S. explanations of being. Such a person must imitate, and
> > the imitator always gives away unstated (awkward) assumptions of the
> > original. Bowering separates himself and his audience from ordinary
> > people, the others: "the grammar teacher", "the old grammar teacher's
> > definition of a sentence", "regular Canadian literature critics", and
> > "Canadian literature critics who like the untroubled sentences and
> > straight-ahead similies they can purchase in the lyrics of
> > autobiographical Canadian poets". He dismisses (snottily) readers of
> > a poetry that is not poetry of the cult group because (he says) "they
> > do not want difficulty, either of allusion or lexical presentation"
> > (p. 81). And he dismisses poetry that is "simply descriptive of the
> > world or little autobiographical bits of it" (pp. 88-89), as if any
> > utterance that is poetry could be "simply" either of those two
> > things. But Bowering is shutting out the CANAILLE, the non-members.
> > Having done that, he turns to address the other cult members....
> >
> > That brings us to conclusions. Two things. First: neither Blaser
> > nor Zaslove ever touches the culture which is the living, being,
> > shaping, aspiring, and creating activity of Canadians in their
> > community, here, now.
> >
> > Secondly: almost all the utterance reproduced in the three volumes
> > under the name 'poetry' is disappointing. "All this talk," one says,
> > "all this exclusivity, all this special pleading, all this
> > intricification of the platitudinous, all this labyrinthine
> > theorizing - about a heap of accumulated mediocrity."
> >
> > George Bowering is useful here, again. Assuming the morally
> > querulous position of those who have mastered his creative soul, he
> > gives away in his imitations "unstated (awkward) assumptions of the
> > original". In a sense, he may be said to speak for them all (and to
> > sum them up) in a little poem he wrote (in 1974) before the three
> > volumes were begun:
> >
> > 1944 I loved
> > the beautiful American army helmet
> >
> > Naked, shining, drab, olive green
> > or painted with wide white stripes, maybe MP
> > or covered with netting, maybe leaves stuck all over
> > or a star on front for a pistolero general in fatigues
> > or dark blue in the battleship gun turret
> > or lying alone on the island beach sand in LIFE magazine
> >
> > There is no more LIFE magazine
> > But the American army helmet lying alone
> > on the jungle floor is beautiful
=========================================================================

From:         Christine Murray <cmurray@UTA.EDU>
Subject:      History as "trying to clear.."
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

and Nina Cassian, "Vowel":

A clean vowel
is my morning,
Latin pronunciation
in the murmur of confused time.
With rational syllables
I'm trying to clear the occult mind
and promiscuous violence.
My linguistic protest
has no power.
The enemy is illiterate.

Translated by Brenda Walker and Andrea Deletant

-----Original Message-----
From: UB Poetics discussion group [mailto:POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU]
On Behalf Of Aaron Vidaver
Sent: April 20, 2003 10:04 PM
To: POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU
Subject: Canada Harbours American Poetry Haters

This review is by Robin Mathews--"Canada's leading
political poet."

> > Charles Watts and Edward Byrne (eds.), THE RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC
> > WORLD, ESSAYS ON POETICS IN HONOUR OF ROBIN BLASER, Vancouver,
> > Talonbooks, 1999, 464 pages.
> >
> > Ian Angus (ed.), ANARCHO-MODERNISM: TOWARD A NEW CRITICAL THEORY, IN
> > HONOUR OF JERRY ZASLOVE, Vancouver, Talonbooks, 2001, 384 pages.
> >
> > Miriam Nichols (ed.), EVEN ON SUNDAY, ESSAYS, READINGS, AND ARCHIVAL
> > MATERIAL ON THE POETRY AND POETICS OF ROBIN BLASER, Orono, Maine,
> > U.S.A., The National Poetry Foundation, 2002, 396 pages.
> >
> > "The imperial RAISON D'ETRE is to erase the other."
> > (anonymous)
> >
> > The three books named above are produced as celebrations for two
U.S.
> > immigrants to British Columbia, Robin Blaser and Jerry Zaslove. The
> > men are friends who worked in the same SFU English Department, they
> > are stamped with the same imperiocentricity, and each has
contributed
> > to the celebration volume of the other. In addition, they belong to
> > the band of U.S. immigrants involved in the task of demeaning
> > Canadian legitimacy, denigrating Canadian uniqueness and potential,
> > recruiting young Canadians into their view of things, and -
generally
> > - erasing Canadian culture and history.
> >
> > Why are the two U.S. immigrants here? What brought them? What
> > establishes them as motivation for the production of three quite
> > large books - with, apparently, more to come? In the 1960s the
> > Canadian university and college system was expanding. Money was
> > available to hire new faculty. Many Canadians were demanding more
> > attention to and respect for Canadian institutions, achievements,
> > historical complexity, and contemporary population. That drive was
> > connected both to the spreading effect of the 1951 Massey Report on
> > the Arts, Letters, and Sciences, and to the push by people like
> > cabinet minister Walter Gordon, from the late 1950s on, to have the
> > colonized Canadian economy returned to Canadian ownership and
control.
> >
> > Against those demands the forces of colonialism, of denigration,
were
> > pushing strongly. Our historic internationalism was being re-read by
> > many as inevitable and desirable subservience to the U.S.A. If the
> > Massey commissioners wanted to limit U.S. influence, liberal
> > continentalists like Frank Underhill shouted that Canada couldn't
get
> > enough of it. When the drive came to hire Canadians for cultural
> > positions, Frank Underhill - then not far from the grave - publicly
> > scoffed at the idea as did the host of his liberal continentalist
> > allies. U.S. government, as always, pushed for North American
> > integration.
> >
> > U.S. academics flooded into Canada's expanding higher education
> > institutions because Canadian intellectual and cultural
> > administrators believed Canadians inferior to others - especially
> > U.S. people. Secondly, U.S. government wanted excess U.S. graduate
> > school products to be lodged in Canadian universities and colleges.
> > Finally, individual U.S. academics could get (a) better pay (b)
> > better working conditions (c) and wider experience in their first
> > years in Canada than in the U.S.A. In short, most came for economic
> > reasons. Canada was a TERRA INCOGNITA to most of them, but a buck is
> > a buck ... anywhere.
> >
> > Hugh MacLennan noted that the best minds of a country "think with"
> > all the accumulated cultural furniture that has given them peculiar
> > being, and they don't usually forsake that density to live partial
> > intellectual lives elsewhere. George Orwell said something similar
> > in his 1940 essay, "Inside the Whale". Writing of (U.S.) Henry
> > Miller's TROPIC OF CANCER, set in Paris, Orwell wrote: "Miller is
> > writing about the man in the street, and it is incidentally a pity
> > that it should be a street full of brothels. That is the penalty of
> > leaving your native land. It means transferring your roots into
> > shallower soil".
> >
> > In that shallower, because impenetrable, cultural soil imperial
> > English speakers in Canada very often think they face no language
> > barrier. They often refuse to grant that cultural difference exists
> > and declare that difference in the host people is a sign of
> > inferiority. And they work - often audaciously - to build a
> > self-defensive and self-perpetuating community of like-minded
> > imperials and subservient local followers. They live, in short,
> > imperiocentric lives - lives, that is, that have their being in
> > imperial consciousness, that "think with" the intellectual products
> > of the imperial country, that proselytize for its universal
> > centrality, and - especially - that ignore, deprecate, deny, erase
> > the culture and intellectual products of their host country. "The
> > imperial RAISON D'ETRE is to erase the other."
> >
> > In both universities and colleges a long, nasty battle had to be
> > fought to prevent (especially) U.S. academics from using
> > institutional money to bring in, as guests, only people from the
> > U.S.A. Warren Tallman, U.S. immigrant, friend, and contemporary of
> > Blaser and Zaslove, brought to the 1961 B.C. Festival of the
> > Contemporary Arts and the 1963 Vancouver Poetry Conference, for
> > instance, the following: Robert Duncan, Charles Olson, Allen
> > Ginsberg, Denise Levertov, Jack Spicer, Robin Blaser, and Margaret
> > Avison. Only the last named was Canadian. All the rest were from
> > the U.S. That pattern was repeated almost as policy. Subsequently,
> > Blaser was hired at SFU. Miriam Nichols records those things in EVEN
> > ON SUNDAY, where she quotes Margaret Avison being called an AVANT
> > GARDE writer; and she, herself, calls George Woodcock a prolific
> > "nationalist" critic. Woodcock was a spirited anti-nationalist
> > anarchist all his life. One need only read Avison's work to know she
> > was a poetically conservative, deeply religious poet.
> >
> > A few years later, (partly to conserve national grant money) I tried
> > to get UBC to share a few of the Canadian guests I was bringing to
> > the University of Alberta in trade for an equal number of UBC's U.S.
> > guests. The UBC English Dept. guest programmer (a U.S. immigrant)
> > was plainly not interested. Helen Zontoff - Phyllis Webb assured me
> > - disliked the Canadian writers I suggested to her in a letter she
> > did not even condescend to answer. Zontoff obviously wanted to keep
> > Canadian students from being contaminated by contact with major
> > Canadian writers. Little wonder Vancouver bred a group of young
> > Canadians devoted to U.S. ideas and personalities and contemptuous
of
> > Canadian traditions.
> >
> > When I was proposed in the mid-1980s for a one year exchange at SFU,
> > English Dept. Chairman was Jerry Zaslove, praised in
> > ANARCHO-MODERNISM for deep concern about human rights. He forcefully
> > supported - if he did not lead - the completely illegitimate attempt
> > to keep me out of SFU. (Warmly supported, I was told, by Robin
> > Blaser.) The case attracted wide attention, being editorialized in
> > the GLOBE AND MAIL and the VANCOUVER SUN, for instance. It was then
> > Chairman Zaslove wrote to the GLOBE AND MAIL to protest. He asserted
> > that I was an "undesirable" and if I would only realize I was
> > "undesirable" I would not be making trouble. After months of dispute
> > the Canadian Association of University Teachers (Canada's national
> > faculty union) visited SFU for three days of investigation and
> > publicly declared SFU in violation of academic freedom for its
> > Zaslove-fronted attempt to suppress freedom of speech and the free
> > exchange of ideas by keeping out a Canadian known for insisting that
> > Canadian culture and ideas be taken seriously in Canadian
educational
> > institutions.

> > Robin Blaser and Jerry Zaslove? Apart from the kind of fundamental
> > error made by editor Miriam Nichols, already mentioned, the books
> > are, more generally, textually inadequate. None possesses an index.
> > THE RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC WORLD, moreover, has almost fifty
> > contributors, none of whom is identified for the reader. Generally,
> > too, there is a state of alienation present in the volumes which is

> >
> > With Blaser, Jerry Zaslove dwells in an anarcho-modernist world
> > nibbling at Arendtian phantasms of beautiful, consensual society.
> > With Arendt, Zaslove and Blaser are anti-nationalist,
> > 'anti-political', and almost totally absorbed as U.S. people in U.S.
> > life and its dictates (imperiocentrism). Like her, they act as if
> > U.S. imperialism is somehow the whole human condition and so
> > something to be lived, not resisted. The U.S.-inspired anarchist
> > position permits the rejection of responsibility to a difficult

rights

and
> > headed. I became convinced that the treatment of Canada and of
> > thinkers in Canada was not merely 'tokenism' but insult. The reading
> > lists were indeed 'international': U.S. writers and writers
> > everywhere who could fit the imperiocentric view of reality. But no
> > John Clark Murray, Norman Bethune, John Watson, Susanna Moodie,
> > Charles de Koninck, John Richardson, F.-X Garneau, Stanley Ryerson,
> > Lionel Groulx, W.L. Morton, Milton Acorn, Hubert Aquin, Sara
Jeanette
> > Duncan, Donald Creighton, Hugh MacLennan, Edmond de Nevers, W.D.
> > Lighthall, Jacques Godbout, etc. etc. etc. In short, there never
> > seems to have been the slightest attempt to have Canadian students
> > think seriously about and use the works of Canadians to 'think
with'.
> >
> > What about the Institute for the Humanities courses taught in jail
> > and the Downtown East Side (Carnegie Centre)? ("A Dangerous
> > Business: Teaching the Humanities on the Street and in the Gaol",
> > Stephen Duguid and Jane Harris, ANARCHO-MODERNISM, pp. 185-193.).
> > The following writers are named: Carl Sagan, the Romantics,
Rousseau,
> > Tolstoy, Socrates, Steinbeck, Cervantes, Burgess, Orwell, Thoreau,
> > Marcuse, Conrad, Dostoevesky, Kropotkin, Kierkegaard, Plato, Freud,
> > Skinner, Fromm, E.H. Carr, V. Serge, the Brontes, Kate Millett. They
> > all swirl around - the authors tell us - "the overall circular theme
> > of 'Human Nature and the Human Condition'".
> >
> > Strange. Notice. Not a single Canadian work mentioned in the
> > article. Though just outside the windows of the Carnegie Centre much
> > of Irene Baird's novel WASTE HERITAGE is set, a novel about
> > unemployment, repressive police, governments that avoid issues, men
> > and women who struggle for solidarity, attempts to organize the
> > destitute, the desperation of the young to gain some meaning and
> > freedom in their lives. But why go on...? When Harold Innis -
> > writing of the imposition of intellectual control by empires -
coined
> > the phrase "monopolies of knowledge", he might have been referring
to
> > the offerings of the SFU Institute for the Humanities.
> >
> > A few pieces on Walter Benjamin, Aldous Huxley, and human rights in
> > ANARCHO-MODERNISM are interesting. The claim that the book moves
> > "Toward a New Critical Theory", however, is empty. In addition,
> > nothing in the text opens up or deals in a fresh, informative, way
> > with any important aspect of Canadian life, society, history,
> > sociology, belief - or anything else. Even Alan Whitehorn's article
> > "From Alienation to Community...,"( pp. 261-266) based, apparently,
> > upon Canadian experience - is so careful, so correct, so distant, so
> > anaesthetized to U.S. imperial presence in Canada, it could never
(as
> > Norman Bethune did) catch septicaemia from getting into close
contact
> > with the patient it wishes to treat. If this book provides us with a
> > look at the force of Anarcho-Modernism, we can turn over and go back
> > to sleep.
> >
> > Robin Blaser is invariably referred to as a U.S. poet, having been
> > published in THE NEW AMERICAN POETRY in 1960, being treated as a
U.S.
> > poet in such publications since, and figuring as the subject of the
> > 2002, EVEN ON SUNDAY. It is produced by the U.S. National Poetry
> > Foundation which obviously considers him a U.S. 'national' poet. His
> > primary political reality (besides sexual orientation) is the U.S.A.
> > He rarely makes reference to any Canadian in a way that uses him or
> > her for "thinking with". He rarely makes reference to Canadian
> > politics. As late as the middle of the 1990s, fantasizing in
> > conversation, he talks about what is being done to "our political
and
> > economic structures"; and then he says, "when I become
President...."
> > (p. 429, THE RECOVERY...) Shortly after coming to Canada, he began a
> > periodical called PACIFIC NATION. The name provides a perfect
> > example of the imperial intellectual merging his host country into
> > the imperial country from which he has come. His verse work,
> > IMAGE-NATIONS, is titled, Rachel Blau DuPlessis tells us -
> > predictably - as an anti-nationalist pun. "The imperial RAISON
> > D'ETRE is to erase the other."
> >
> > At one point he refused to go to the U.S.A., not because he was
> > offended by its rapacious foreign policy, nor because he disliked
its
> > bullying of his adopted country. Perish the thought. He refused to
> > go to a short term teaching job in the U.S. in 1993 because a law
> > restricting homosexuals was going to be passed in Colorado.
> >
> > The 1995 conference in honour of Blaser in Vancouver (from which THE
> > RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC WORLD is drawn) was astonishing. Canadian
> > funding was poured out in a flood to consider various states of U.S.
> > being, and then to publish the transactions. At a time when the
> > community of writers should have held a conference in honour of
> > Dorothy Livesay, an intricate part of social, political, cultural,
> > and creative life in Canada for more than 60 years, a poet of
> > irreplaceable importance, and living in Victoria - that community
> > ignored her. When a conference in honour of Al Purdy , a major poet,
> > a part of B.C., a significant figure in the Canadian poetic
> > tradition, living in Sidney, should have been held - no conference
> > was held. Instead, U.S. speakers were flushed into Vancouver, and
> > some Canadians were summoned, to celebrate the success of U.S.
> > cultural imperialism in a conference called, "The Recovery of the
> > Public World", a conference in honour of Robin Blaser. "The imperial
> > RAISON D'ETRE is to erase the other." But nothing will erase the
> > insult delivered to Canadians by the neglect of Dorothy Livesay and
> > Al Purdy in B.C. by the U.S. anarchist imperialists and their
> > Canadian clones.
> >
> > If homosexuality is a chief political centre for him, a form of U.S.
> > poetic process is Robin Blaser's philosophical and social centre.
> > THE RECOVERY OF THE PUBLIC WORLD huffs and puffs the platitudinously
> > obvious about poetics until the subject becomes a huge, gray
> > dirigible blocking out the sun. Language becomes Blaser's
> > God-replacement, and so the act of making poetry is enquired into
> > with tireless, tedious repetition. Blaser's concept of his
> > God-replacement, however, accords perfectly with anarchist
liberalism
> > and, interestingly, with U.S. imperialism which reinterprets any
> > truth to suit imperialist intentions and proclaims the contingency
of
> > truth and language. When Blaser, moreover, wrote in the 1960s about
> > Vietnam, Andre Klobucar ("The Decline of the American Margins...."
> > pp. 331-338) says he did not provide "intellectually informed
> > judgement" but "dissolution". Klubucar says Blaser wishes to "place
> > the poem within the social arena rather than vice versa." That may
> > well be pointing to coded assent to or, at best, protective
ambiguity
> > about the war - both very specific kinds of politics.
> >
> > The peculiar characteristic of - especially Blaser's but - almost
all
> > of the argument stuffed into the two books is its cult-solipsism.
> > From the statement that the poetic line is shaped by the
> > individual(istic) breath, that the"closed" poem is authoritarian and
> > exclusive, that real poetry is paratactic, that beauty and great
> > statement are aristocratic, to the delusion that the "open"
> > (unpunctuated, un-terminated, un-capitalized, free-flow) statement
is
> > "democratic", reader-created, ironic, and pluralist, the writers
> > engage in a kind of cult-solipsitic, anarchist manifesto-making.
> >
> > George Bowering ("Robin Blaser at Lake Parodox", EVEN ON SUNDAY)
> > gives us a glimpse of their cult exclusivity. He is a Canadian taken
> > over by U.S. explanations of being. Such a person must imitate, and
> > the imitator always gives away unstated (awkward) assumptions of the
> > original. Bowering separates himself and his audience from ordinary
> > people, the others: "the grammar teacher", "the old grammar
teacher's
> > definition of a sentence", "regular Canadian literature critics",
and
> > "Canadian literature critics who like the untroubled sentences and
> > straight-ahead similies they can purchase in the lyrics of
> > autobiographical Canadian poets". He dismisses (snottily) readers of
> > a poetry that is not poetry of the cult group because (he says)
"they
> > do not want difficulty, either of allusion or lexical presentation"
> > (p. 81). And he dismisses poetry that is "simply descriptive of the
> > world or little autobiographical bits of it" (pp. 88-89), as if any
> > utterance that is poetry could be "simply" either of those two
> > things. But Bowering is shutting out the CANAILLE, the non-members.
> > Having done that, he turns to address the other cult members....
> >
> > That brings us to conclusions. Two things. First: neither Blaser
> > nor Zaslove ever touches the culture which is the living, being,
> > shaping, aspiring, and creating activity of Canadians in their
> > community, here, now.
> >
> > Secondly: almost all the utterance reproduced in the three volumes
> > under the name 'poetry' is disappointing. "All this talk," one says,
> > "all this exclusivity, all this special pleading, all this
> > intricification of the platitudinous, all this labyrinthine
> > theorizing - about a heap of accumulated mediocrity."
> >
> > George Bowering is useful here, again. Assuming the morally
> > querulous position of those who have mastered his creative soul, he
> > gives away in his imitations "unstated (awkward) assumptions of the
> > original". In a sense, he may be said to speak for them all (and to
> > sum them up) in a little poem he wrote (in 1974) before the three
> > volumes were begun:
> >
> > 1944 I loved
> > the beautiful American army helmet
> >
> > Naked, shining, drab, olive green
> > or painted with wide white stripes, maybe MP
> > or covered with netting, maybe leaves stuck all over
> > or a star on front for a pistolero general in fatigues
> > or dark blue in the battleship gun turret
> > or lying alone on the island beach sand in LIFE magazine
> >
> > There is no more LIFE magazine
> > But the American army helmet lying alone
> > on the jungle floor is beautiful

From:         Steve Tills <STills@GWLISK.COM>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

Of course, theories don't kill people; people smack pupils with Kristol and
Bennett and Adelman texts; then pistils and patriots kill people.

Yes indeed, in response to Mairead's post, especially  "second thought--and
this *is* considered--is that these people have little idea what it is not
to matter. Any bunch of inmates in United States prisons knows what it is to
not matter. Even I, who have only some contact with prisoners--and the
heroic struggle of one individual prisoner to *do good* beyond the walls,
capacities, and reach of his situation--have an inkling of what not
mattering means. Plunge into poverty and you also find what it is not to
matter."  I can personally attest to what it feels like to lose one's entire
life savings in the stock market, largely (if not completely) from a stock
Bush's pappy cashed in for $14 million (on shares given to him for a couple
of half-day speaking engagements), DNC chair Terry McAuliffe cashed in for
$18 million (from same, speaking engagements, as I recall), and the average
investor and pension holder (in the case of employees, locked out of selling
their shares), sans any winks from insiders about a good time to sell, were
left holding the bag.

Or maybe: "Theories don't matter; people do."  Smiles.  But seriously, they
do indeed matter.  That's why the Right uses might to foreground their own
pathetic tomes and elevate their weak buffoons to "authors" and "think tank
experts."  Same as trying to supplant "evolution theory" with so-called
"Creationist science."   And then, say you're an Adjunct someplace, at a
community college, say, and you engage students there with No, not quite
Benjamin and Adorno, but just plain Darwin, and the students are not
terribly sophisticated, ditto the administrator who calls you in one day
cause Christian Kid X or Christian Kid Y complained, and you have no job
security, 'cause you got no tenure, so maybe you can stick some Foucault or
Fish or Jameson, Frederick up the administrator's, umm, nose, and ask
politely, "Wanna catch a whiff of this," and the administrator's a former
Dept. Head in that department of Impossibility...  Okay, I'll stop...

OT: Petroskey, the Baseball Hall of Fame dork, (had to) come out and give
Robbins and Sarandon and Baseball an apology, today.  Well, that's cool.
Ultimately, the whole lot of them are going to go down in Shame.  Well,
that's my prediction.  Or maybe it's a mission.  Anyways...  :))



Steve Tills


Microcomputer/Software Specialist/
MIS Dept.- G.W. Lisk Company, Inc.
315-462-4309
Stills@gwlisk.com

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Humanity Belief in Goodness
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Humanity Belief in Goodness


Humanity Belief in Goodness will bring all of us into an untimely end as
no one will agree with one what Goodness is or even Belief. I think
Goodness is not hurting but what if one in Humanity is hurting me. I think
we are all in Humanity. Everyone will want to be Good but sometime we
forget we want to be Good and then there are problems. What do we do then.
I think I agree that Mr. Hussein forgot to do Good but when he would think
he would laugh but sometime he would think about being Good. Mr. Bush
thinks all the time I am doing Good and has his Belief. Mr. Hitler from
long ago thinks all the time I am doing Good but he would not eat meat.
Mr. Bush will eat meat. I do not think it is Good to eat meat because I do
not Believe an animal will want that. We cannot ask the animal. If I could
ask the animal I would know.


___

From:         Charles Bernstein <bernstei@BWAY.NET>
Subject:      Barbara Guest's Forces of Imagination
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Forces of Imagination: Writing on Writing
by Barbara Guest

Cover and interior images by Laurie Reid.

Kelsey St. Press, Berkeley, California, 2003. 108 pages, $14

Order from Small Press Distribution (http://www.spdbooks.org/)
or from Bridge Street Books <AERIALEDGE@aol.com>

And on Weds., April 30, a rare NYC appearance by Barbara Guest, who will be=
=20
reading with Elaine Equi at 8pm at the Poetry Project of St. Mark's Church.

Equi also has a new book: The Cloud of Knowable Things, from Coffee House=20
Press <http://coffeehousepress.org/cloudofknowablethings.asp>

For more information on Barbara Guest, go to her EPC home page:=20
http://epc.buffalo.edu/authors/guest

Commens on Guest's Forces of Imagination:

We expect poets to give a first-hand account of what poetry is. But some=20
poets, when they write criticism, produce a kind of prose that is itself on=
=20
the verge of being poetry. Val=E9ry, Stevens and Marianne Moore belong to=20
this "visionary company." And so does Barbara Guest, whose writings on=20
poetry, collected here, are among the most inspiring works of their kind.=20
It is a deep pleasure to know that such writing can still exist.  --John=20
Ashbery

Guest has earned her formidable reputation through dedication to modern=20
lyric's difficult double-project of making song think and making thought=20
sing, of stretching the very medium of conceptual thought language all the=
=20
way toward music and affect, but without relinquishing any of the rigor of=
=20
conceptual intellection. The essays, talks and addresses, and prose and=20
verse meditations now gathered in Forces of Imagination offer welcome=20
points of entry into Guest's challenging aesthetic.  --Robert Kaufman,=20
Stanford University

Writing about thinkers, poets and writers as diverse as Baudelaire,=20
Mallarm=E9, Plato, Walter Benjamin, Kant, Pasternak, Machado de Assis, H.D.,=
=20
Horace, Wallace Stevens and Pound; about radical and conservative poetics,=
=20
modernism, postmodernism, the relationship between art and poetry; about=20
the importance of imagination and surprise in poetry, Barbara Guest=20
situates herself in a multi-faceted literary landscape spanning centuries=20
and continents, at the same time providing brilliant insights into the=20
roots and workings of contemporary poetry. This is an evocative collection=
=20
of essays and poems on writing that might be quite provocative to a certain=
=20
audience steeped in the poetics of academia. Fascinating reading for anyone=
=20
interested in the possibilities of modern writing. --Johannes Beilharz
 =20

Date:         Mon, 21 Apr 2003 14:20:37 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <5.1.0.14.2.20030419111727.00ba3738@incoming.verizon.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Does anyone think that academic theory has been good for contemporary poetry?  Has theory helped poets to write originally and well?  If so, what has theory made available to poets that was not already present in the tradition?  Examples, please.

I think academic theory has been good for contemporary poetry only to the extent that theorists' patronizing attitude toward literary value has challenged poets to try to articulate why their art matters.  Unfortunately, poetry's importance is not something that poets are able to explain very convincingly in conceptual terms, is it?

Andy

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The winner of the "Banner-Strike" contest was "Peace of Cake"
by Pau Waelder.

Honorable mentions go to KRN and Michael Szpakowski.

"Banner-Strike" was a joint contest held by the Banner Art Colelctive
and Opensorcery.net's Velvet Strike project.  It was a contest for
digital graffiti and net.art that was created under specific
limitations and which critically examined the war in Iraq. As the
winner, Pau will receive a copy of Counter-Strike: Condition Zero when
it is released in October. His banner will be featured at the top
of bannerart.org for one month. The 34 entries for the contest will be
turned into sprays for Counter-Strike and added to the Velvet-Strike
collection.

We would like to thank all the artists that participated in the contest.
Additionally, special thanks goes to Joan Leandre for helping judge the
competition.

Best,
Brandon Barr and Garrett Lynch
Banner Art Collective

Hi y'all,

A couple of months ago I wrote to the list that we were culling a lot
of recordings, books, etc. that we've had in storage for years. We've
finally gotten through some of the poetry and prose boxes and I'm
starting to list some things on ebay.

Right now, there's a full set of Temblor 1-10; This 1-12, , Montemora
1-8, The O'blek double issue Writing from the New Coast, five special
issues of Boundary 2 (Baraka, Creeley, Olson, Spicer & the Oral
Impulse (Antin/Rothenberg et al), recordings by Basil Bunting and
John Taggart, and a long mesostic poem by John Cage (I-VI).

In coming weeks we'll be listing a complete set of L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E,
VORT, lots of other issues of poetry and related critical magazines,
many anthologies, & eventually some books by individual writers.
Judging from how long it took to get through most of the new music
material we decided to sell off (we still have a month or so of that
stuff to go), I think the poetry-related auctions will be going on
through most of the summer months.

If you're interested, please check out this page:

http://cgi6.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewSellersOtherItems&userid=hrebll

If this link doesn't work for you, search ebay for SELLER <hrebll>.

Please tell other folks who may be interested.

Thanks a lot.

Bests,

Herb

Date:         Mon, 21 Apr 2003 16:42:58 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Christine Murray <cmurray@UTA.EDU>
Subject:      THE LATEST THEORY  IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

The insularity of continental US poetry has been a problem in terms of what
theory does for poets and poetry.  So maybe it's better to clarify
relations: where, who, what theory and what poetry?

Example: Latin American poets from all over that continental "America"
created lively,influential poetries based on input and animated thought from
what are considered--even by St.Fish?--to be schools of theory: surrealist &
ect. That's only one major example from the 20th century.

Historically there are many more of course, but mostly not coming out of the
continental US, where the nationalizing drive in poetry circles of late
nineteeth throughout the twentieth century became so focused to canon
formations--as an ultimate and highly economical act of exclusivity--as to
forget that there are many influences that go into the creation and
reception of poetic arts.  I'm thinking here of Tim Morris's *Becoming
Canonical in American Poetry*, for one explanation, though there are many
others.

chris murray

(graphic designer) ~vas:  an opera in flatland~, just out on station

me, as it's one of THE narrative + image texts of the early 21st
century... just incredible...

(2) if you folks can get a hold of same, see ~new media:  theories
and practices of digitextuality~, ed. anna everett & john t.
caldwell, just out on routledge... yours truly has an essay therein,
in which a few listmates pop up (jeffrey jullich, brian kim stefans,
alan sondheim), but my scribblings aside, there's some asskicking
work in this volume...

best,

My (probably inarticulate) two cents on Guest book:

It is so lovely and brilliant; and in a tradition of
"generosity" it *feeds*. And enables: finally at the
end Guest privileges "imagination" over any other
consideration in poetry. The woman's completely
inviolate, uncorruptible. She's light, she's
lantern-bearer, she would have no idea why I am saying
the things I say about her if she should read
this...Read, read, read,

Kazim.

Every library should have it.
All the poets should read it.
All the teachers should use it.
All the students should eat it.

Date:         Mon, 21 Apr 2003 16:25:53 -0600
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Joe Amato <joe.amato@COLORADO.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY  IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <BB48F73042D29D41A033A684D5FBB984011B2A22@exchange.uta.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

to pick up quickly on what chris m just said, and to answer andrew:
i'm tight with steve tomasula (see ~vas~ in my prior post)... he and
i and my partner kass fleisher talk theory all the time, have for
years now... he calls himself a prose writer, not a poet, and i don't
claim any special influence on or insight into his work... but it's
clear to me how, specifically, theory has influenced ~vas~ (see
kass's review in an upcoming ~abr~)... ~vas~ is certainly a work
informed by any number of scientific theories and contemporary body
technologies (let's say)... but in terms of a poetic, sure---you
simply can't compose a work like that and not bump up against theory
and theories, from everyplace and anyplace, the academic variety
included... it's a fully theorized item, and even to say this in such
terms is to acknowledge a debt to academic theory in particular...

i want to say something like, prove academic theory is NOT at work in
helping contemporary poets to write "originally and "well"... but
this would be to prove a negative, in effect, so it's an unfair
request... so let's look at it anecdotally:  as a poet (some will
say, academic poet, sure), i can say with complete certainty that the
conversations i have on this list, about theory (etc.), help me to
write originally and well... which is why at times i simply have to
say, you'll just have to trust me... if you don't, and we disagree
(which amounts to someone telling me i'm self-deceived, of course),
there's not much either side can do but move it along, right?...

best,

joe

From: "martin blume" <blume@aps.org>
To: <daniel.amit@roma1.infn.it>; <damita@green.fiz.huji.ac.il>
Subject: your email to the American Physical Society
Date: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 10:31 PM

Dear Dr. Amit,

We have received your email with your decision not to review a paper for us
in light of American actions in the middle east. We recognize that reviewing
manuscripts is a voluntary activity, one that you perform as a service to
the physics community, and we thank you for your efforts.

Given the voluntary nature of your participation we of course respect your
decision to cease, and have made an indication in our database so that no
further papers will be sent to you for review until you inform us otherwise.

We ask, however, that you consider the following in hopes that in the not
too distant future you will decide to review for us again. We regard science
as an international enterprise and we do our best to put aside political
disagreements in the interest of furthering the pursuit of scientific
matters. We have never used other than scientific criteria in judging the
acceptability of a paper for publication, without regard to the country of
origin of the author. We have done this even in cases where some of us have
disagreed strongly with the policies of that country, and we will continue
this practice. We believe it is essential that all parties involved make
every effort to separate social and political differences from their
participation in scientific research and publication. The pursuit of
scientific knowledge needs to transcend such issues.

Sincerely,

Martin Blume
Editor-in-Chief

===

Dear Dr Blume, Editor in Chief American Physical Society

09.04.2003

Thank you for you letter of April 8. I would have liked to be able to share
the honorable sentiments you express in your letter as well as your optimism
in the future role of science and the scientific community. To be frank, and
with much sadness and pain, after 40 years of activity and collaboration, I
find very little reason for such optimism.

What we are watching today, I believe, is a culmination of 10-15 years of
mounting barbarism of the American culture the world over, crowned by the
achievements of science and technology as a major weapon of mass
destruction. We are witnessing man hunt and wanton killing of the type and
scale not seen since the raids on American Indian populations, by a superior
technological power of inferior culture and values. We see no corrective
force to restore the insanity, the self-righteousness and the lack of
respect for human life (civilian and military) of another race.

Science cannot stay neutral, especially after it has been so cynically used
in the hands of the inspectors to disarm a country and prepare it for
decimation by laser guided cluster bombs. No, science of the American
variety has no recourse. I, personally, cannot see myself anymore sharing a
common human community with American science.

Unfortunately, I also belong to a culture of a similar spiritual deviation
(Israel), and which seems to be equally incorrigible. In desperation I
cannot but turn my attention to other tragic periods in which major
societies, some with claims to fundamental contributions to culture and
science, have deviated so far as to be relegated to ostracism and
quarantine. At this point I think American society should be considered in
this category. I have no illusions of power, as to the scope and prospect of
my attitude. But, the minor role of my act and statement is a simple way of
affirming that in the face of a growing enormity which I consider
intolerable, I will exercise my own tiny act of disobedience to be able to
look straight into the eyes of my grandchildren and my students and say that
I did know.

With regard,

Daniel Amit

PS I intend to distribute our exchange as much as possible. I authorize and
pray that you do the same.


----- End forwarded message -----
