2.

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/18/international/worldspecial/18RESE.html?pag
ewanted=print&position=


New York Times
April 18, 2003

Islamic World Less Welcoming to American Scholars


By SAM DILLON

Elizabeth C. Stone, a professor of anthropology, had planned to spend the
summer excavating a 2,600-year-old city surrounding an ancient citadel in
eastern Turkey. But like scores of other American professors, she was forced
to cancel her trip as American tanks rumbled toward Baghdad.

The war in Iraq, and the angry reactions it has aroused across the Islamic
world, have disrupted work by American scholars from Tunisia to Pakistan.

In some cases, academic institutions or researchers themselves have canceled
trips in response to State Department warnings of danger. In other cases,
host countries have denied them study permits.

Experts say the war has caused the greatest interruption of overseas study
since World War II, forcing the cancellation or postponement of hundreds of
expeditions researching everything from Islamic law to the bone knives used
by ancient butchers.

"I can't remember when research has been disrupted across such a wide
region," said Dr. Stone, who teaches at the State University of New York at
Stony Brook. "The war has left a very wide footprint."

Many professors with long experience in the region fear it could be years
before hostilities subside enough to allow researchers from the United
States to operate overseas as they have in the past.

"Only in the best case will conditions for research ever be as good as in
the past," said Philip D. Gingerich, a University of Michigan paleontologist
who has dug for ancient whale skeletons in Pakistan since the early 1970's.
"Anti-American feelings have grown so strong in these populations that
unquestionably it will now be more dangerous to work in many areas."

This year Professor Gingerich could not get a work permit from Pakistan, and
he suspects that was because officials were unable to guarantee his safety.

In recent weeks, anger among Islamic populations has affected American
research 1,900 miles to the west of Baghdad and 1,500 miles to the east. In
Tunis and Cairo, American scholarly institutions and libraries temporarily
closed their doors; in Yemen researchers abandoned rural sites for the
safety of the capital; and in Pakistan, American scholars have been denied
research permits that were freely extended in the past.

The regional crisis has unsettled the lives of hundreds of American
academics. Some professors had sublet apartments in preparation for
expeditions that are now suspended, and graduate students expecting those
trips to yield crucial data are now having to rethink years of planning for
their dissertations.

Still, many people were reluctant to dwell on their personal misfortunes.

"We can't be too concerned about our own problems - think of the people in
Iraq who are facing catastrophes," said Tony J. Wilkinson, an associate
professor at the University of Chicago's Oriental Institute who has worked
across the region studying the canals and roads of ancient civilizations.

Included in those catastrophes were the April 11 pillaging of Iraq's
National Museum and its main library. Those events horrified many scholars,
who were more keenly aware than the general public of the priceless
artifacts lost. Professor Stone and other academics now hope to enlist
graduate students whose expeditions were canceled to work on a cataloging of
items stolen from the museum to help with their recovery.

In the weeks leading to the Iraq war, the State Department warned Americans
to leave or to avoid travel to 17 countries across North Africa, the Mideast
and South Asia. The warnings cover all but three countries in the region:
Morocco, Tunisia and Egypt.

At the same time, the State Department suspended the Fulbright Program in
Kuwait, Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and Israel, which border Iraq or are within
500 miles, causing about 40 American Fulbright scholars to abandon those
countries. Last month the private group that organizes research in Jordan
for American and Canadian universities shuttered its office in Amman because
of security concerns and moved its staff to Cyprus, throwing into disarray
the plans of some 500 scholars who work in Jordan each summer.

Several professors with decades of experience in the Islamic world said that
at no time in memory, including the periods of turmoil surrounding the 1967
Six-Day War, the 1979 Iranian Revolution and the 1991 Persian Gulf war, had
so many travel warnings been in effect for so many countries in the region.
Kelly Shannon, a State Department spokesman, said she could neither confirm
nor contradict that assertion.

Although the department has issued no travel warning for Egypt,
anti-American protests outside the United States Embassy in Cairo and the
adjoining American Research Center in Egypt forced the center's closure on
March 20 and 23. The University of Pennsylvania ordered one graduate student
to return from its archaeological site at Abydos, in southern Egypt; she was
just weeks away from completing her research. Stephen P. Harvey, an
assistant professor of archaeology at the University of Chicago, canceled
his plans to spend this spring in Egypt with 10 students and colleagues
excavating monuments erected by the Pharoah Ahmose in 1500 B.C.

"In the Arab world there is a negative feeling about the U.S. that is
different than anything we felt even two years ago," Professor Harvey said.

Perhaps the most sweeping effects on American research have come in Jordan,
which until recently had offered one of the friendliest work environments.
But on Feb. 7, the State Department urged its diplomats to leave the
country, and 15 Fulbright scholars were ordered to leave as well. Pierre M.
Bikai, the Berkeley-trained director of the American Center of Oriental
Research in Amman, shut his office and moved his staff to Cyprus.

Mr. Bikai said he hoped to reopen the office but has set no date. Although
in a normal summer about 500 American scientists carry out research in
Jordan, this year he expects only a handful, he said.

Gary O. Rollefson, a professor emeritus of anthropology at Whitman College
in Washington, had planned to leave in May to begin work with colleagues at
two sites in Jordan, but he canceled plans for one site. He still hopes to
visit the second, a 13,000-year-old settlement of hunter-gatherers he
discovered last year, but he is not certain that his colleagues will
consider work in Jordan to be safe.

Most Jordanians "realize there's a difference between the Bush
administration and individual Americans who come over there," Professor
Rollefson said. "But you can't control emotions, and sometimes people just
fly off the handle."

Archaeologists from several American universities have canceled expeditions
to Syria, including Michael D. Danti, a University of Pennsylvania
researcher who in April and May was to direct excavations of 4,000-year-old
Mesopotamian structures at Tell Sweyhat, an eight-hour drive north of
Damascus.

The rise of anti-American sentiments across the region has left scholars
with sharply limited options for field research, Mr. Danti said. Recently
hopes had been rising that Iran, long closed, was opening to American
researchers, but the Iraq war has dashed them, he said.

"Turkey is touch-and-go, and Jordan is becoming more anti-American," Mr.
Danti said. "For people specializing in Near Eastern cultures, the places
where you can study are getting few and far between.

Subject:      Mr. Hole Sits Astride My Staring
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

splits unchipped, chips unsplit
counting threw beauty, followed night beauty
stitch gutter mountains, glossy proof of days' injuries

corpses' thief winds up in the fallen minute moors
wrong our bright, voluptuously open heads
new me is the shine, you're my night

Virginia prefers birds,
lakes, and observations to
the spiteful riddles of my tongue

back it back, slash what steps feet don't like
rats bit subtle, grace gladly reports
careful lest Wormswork sewer the stars, lakes, & round roses

Freud and Jung invented clerical languages for their cults. Both wrote=20
science fiction. Good for the dungeons and dragons set. Einstein used the=20
only available language (and a well-established one, at that) capable of=20
describing the phenomena, and used it with extraordinary economy..

What's involved in the present case is very different, I think, frfom a=20
philosopher limiting the meaning of a common word (and being very clear=20
about what he means by the term) so that he can discuss a limited concept=20
without confusion. In the case at hand very few of the concepts are new or=
=20
particularly difficult to grasp.

When Riffaterre was teaching explication de texte at Columbia my reaction=20
was, "so what else is new?" At least he was crystal clear. When he went on=
=20
to posit that any one passage contained the entire book I thought he might=
=20
get away with it better in an invented language, because it was on the face=
=20
of it an absurd idea.

>What's so difficult about learning a few words/concepts?


Why don't we all learn latin?

But I don't want to get too far off track. What I'm really saying is a=20
paraphrase of Olson: critics have to write as well as poets. Resorting to a=
=20
clerical language is more often than not an evasion of that piece of hard=
 work.

Oh, and by the way, Girard came into a sympathetic department as a full=20
professor--not much fight to get in.  I can't speak about the academic=20
world of the early 60s at large because I wasn't in the academic world at=20
large.


Mark

Date:         Mon, 21 Apr 2003 22:11:57 EDT
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Gloria Frym <GloriaFrym@CS.COM>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

In a very generalized sense, theory and thinking and philosophy and
linguistics has educated a generation of poets to the histories and
genealogies of international poetic and literary expression. Thinking has
rescued American (poetry) from its amnesia and ignorance of other poetries.
As keepers of language, it seems to me that thinking with an historical
context has restored poets and poetry (and there are exceptions) to makers
and keepers and archivists of poetic expression.  Not just of the
contemporary surfaces but of the surfaces and depths of expression over time.
 One could not,  for instance, study history without studying  the history of
history (historiography).   One needn't make poetry with the history of
poetry crowding the mind (and thus potentially quieting every phoneme--one
writes and one's mind and body might disappear for the moment.  Yet, as
Spicer says, poetry is a conversation between the dead and the living.
       There is no mandate, and what the NY Times reports is not very
relevant to writers, only professional readers of literature who are confused
now, especially perplexed as to what to think next.  As confused as the rest
of us. Perhaps this reflects our current political situation.   But we find
our balance more easily because of imaginative possibilities.   Real
academics, on the other hand, have to singularize themselves, and these are
difficult times for professional readers, when what is being produced seems
inexorably unclassifiable.  Particularly post-Language poets and writers who
curiously enough have little interest in killing off their "elders."  They
largely seem free of  Bloom's anxiety of influence.  They take and make and
try to find their own space, rather less anxiously than past generations.
       The real conundrum is the professionalization of poetry, I think, not
theory.  Even this has historical precedent.  Think of Longfellow!  Scholar
extraordinaire.  Best selling poet in America.   While Whitman was breaking
ground.  His theories were not particularly coherent, but he did have them,
and was completely aware of the history of literature.  And then he joined
the fray of the new.  But he wrote with and against theory, and became an
internationalist.

Best, Gloria Frym

I for one wasn't questioning theory in general--theory is inevitable. I was
questioning the language of  a certain kind of theory.

As to a supposed change in poetry away from Bloom's Oedipal model, when
Bloom came out with that stuff the folks I know thought it was pretty
silly. Bloom is, after all, something of a clown.

It's easy to confuse the history of poetry with the history
of  professional ideas about the history of poetry, I guess.

When do you think  that thinking rescued American poetry? I've been around
a long time, and I don't remember the pre-thought days. If what you mean is
that certain segments of the American poetry world don't appear to think
much, I'm with you, but that's a rather different proposition.

It's useful to remember that history didn't begin with one's own consciousness.

Mark

>  One could not,  for instance, study history without studying  the history of
>history (historiography).   One needn't make poetry with the history of
>poetry crowding the mind (and thus potentially quieting every phoneme--one
>writes and one's mind and body might disappear for the moment.  Yet, as
>Spicer says, poetry is a conversation between the dead and the living.
>        There is no mandate, and what the NY Times reports is not very
>relevant to writers, only professional readers of literature who are confused
>now, especially perplexed as to what to think next.  As confused as the rest
>of us. Perhaps this reflects our current political situation.   But we find
>our balance more easily because of imaginative possibilities.   Real
>academics, on the other hand, have to singularize themselves, and these are
>difficult times for professional readers, when what is being produced seems
>inexorably unclassifiable.  Particularly post-Language poets and writers who
>curiously enough have little interest in killing off their "elders."  They
>largely seem free of  Bloom's anxiety of influence.  They take and make and
>try to find their own space, rather less anxiously than past generations.
>        The real conundrum is the professionalization of poetry, I think, not
>theory.  Even this has historical precedent.  Think of Longfellow!  Scholar
>extraordinaire.  Best selling poet in America.   While Whitman was breaking
>ground.  His theories were not particularly coherent, but he did have them,
>and was completely aware of the history of literature.  And then he joined
>the fray of the new.  But he wrote with and against theory, and became an
>internationalist.
>
>Best, Gloria Frym

The language of which theory?  I don't think of Bloom as a clown--just an all
too earnest, heavily weighted reader.  A bear, almost, unwilling to be
anything else.  Yet his Freudian model was of its time, and quite relevant to
its time.

> I for one wasn't questioning theory in general--theory is inevitable. I was
> questioning the language of  a certain kind of theory.
>

> Bloom came out with that stuff the folks I know thought it was pretty
> silly. Bloom is, after all, something of a clown.

> of  professional ideas about the history of poetry, I guess.

i don't mean to singe you out here, Mark, but by the "American poetry world"
don't you perhaps mean the US of A poetry world?  For quite some time the US
hegemony has extended beyond weaponry to brand names, the media, and the
academy.

For example, I couldn't get either the public library of university library
here to accept _Across the Line _ as a gift and the high schools wouldn't
take it as there are no relevant questions on the annual tests.  I did
however auction it a an off-the-mall-and-interstate Mexican restaurant with
possibly some illegals in attendance, though, so you can cash the check.

perhaps the subject line here should be THE LATEST USUNIVERSITY THEORY...?

I think your close is quite apt:

> It's useful to remember that history didn't begin with
> one's own consciousness.

but perhaps the one's own here refers to the listserv's membership as a
body?

tom bell

Prize-winning poet and hypertext poetry pioneer
STEPHANIE STRICKLAND will present a combination oral/electronic reading,
with CYNTHIA LAWSON, new media technologist and educator, at Rhode
Island School of Design (Tap Room,2nd floor, Memorial Hall, between RISD
Museum and RISD Library on Benefit Street, Thursday April 24, 7pm) from
V: WaveSon.nets/Losing L'Una as published by the Penguin Poets series in
September 2002.

V is an invertible book with two beginnings.  In it, words slip and pour
across numbers that have their own lives.  At the book's opened center,
where Losing L'Una turns over into WaveSon.nets and vice-versa, one
jumps via a pointer(http://vniverse.com) to the book's third section.

the stele of unforgiving truth

of syzygy burrowing
i want it to be understood that
from one moment to another
carrying with them emotional and apocalyptic import
should never be in doubt, as well as
you will certainly find enlightenment
not just every now and then but constantly
and if there are laws they are broken
and if there are rocks they are dusts and radiations
both pure and impure
a form of cultural strengthening
into true comprehension
that purity and impurity are one

the stele of unforgiving truth
through textual armageddons
i want to be completely understood
into inconceivable philosophies and psychologies
so that the style is based on sememes transforming
carrying with them emotional and apocalyptic import
further and beyond this my originality
to now among all the literatures of the world
if you read me assiduously
you will certainly find enlightenment
not just every now and then but constantly
and if there are laws they are broken
and if there are rocks they are dusts and radiations
swallowed whole you will comprehend
both pure and impure
carrying you forward through emotional love

the stele of unforgiving truth
our energies diminish whom
into inconceivable philosophies and psychologies
so that the style is based on sememes transforming
carrying with them emotional and apocalyptic import
further and beyond this my originality
should never be in doubt, as well as
if you read me assiduously
you will certainly find enlightenment
not just every now and then but constantly
and if there are laws they are broken
and if there are rocks they are dusts and radiations
both pure and impure
a form of cultural strengthening

the stele of unforgiving truth
just as we quickly drown what
i want to be completely understood
my writings are transformed daily
into inconceivable philosophies and psychologies
so that the style is based on sememes transforming
further and beyond this my originality
should never be in doubt, as well as
a contestation of the golden apples of the brilliant
awarded almost no one from classical times
to now among all the literatures of the world
you will certainly find enlightenment
not just every now and then but constantly
but read the stele of AB.BA.HI.A.sondheim
and if there are laws they are broken
and if there are rocks they are dusts and radiations
swallowed whole you will comprehend
both pure and impure
a form of cultural strengthening
into true comprehension

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 00:21:53 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "Walter K. Lew" <Lew@HUMNET.UCLA.EDU>
Subject:      Karatani Kojin's Latest Theory
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1" ; format="flowed"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Mi ricevis permeson el Karatani Kojin e-po^sti la malsuprajn
paragrafojn el lia venonta libro _Transcritique: From Kant to Marx_,
trad. Sabu Kohso (MIT Press, in press). Prof. Karatani estas la
a^utoro de _Architecture as Metaphor_, _The Origins of Modern
Japanese Literature_ kaj multaj aliaj libroj. Lia edzino ne estas
Nikuko.
--^Gis, Valtero

'Marx spoke very little of communism, except for the rare occasions
on which he criticized others' discourses on the subject. He even
said somewhere that speaking of the future was itself reactionary. Up
until the climate change of 1989, I also despised all ideas of
possible futures. I believed that the struggle against capitalism and
the state would be possible without ideas of a future, and that we
should only sustain the struggle endlessly in response to each
contradiction arising from a real situation. The collapse of the
socialist bloc in 1989 compelled me to change my stance. Until then,
I, as many others, had been rebuking Marxist states and communist
parties; that criticism had unwittingly taken for granted their solid
existence and the appearance that they would endure forever. As long
as they survived, we could feel we had done something just by
negating them. When they collapsed, I realized that my critical
stance had been paradoxically relying on their being. I came to feel
that I had to state something positive.
[...]
'Marxism has been accused of being rationalist and teleological in
its attempt to realize the grand narrative. Stalinism was indeed a
consequence of this tendency: the party of intellectuals led the
populace by reason embodying the law of history, and thus the
infamous tragedy. In opposition to this, the power of reason has been
questioned, the superiority of intellectuals has been denied, and the
teleology of history negated. The reexamination of Marxism has
involved public consensus and negotiation among multiple language
games as opposed to the central control of reason, and heterogeneity
of experience or complexity of causality as opposed to a rationalist
(metaphysical) view of history; on the other hand, the present, which
has hitherto been sacrificed by telos, is reaffirmed in its
qualitative heterogeneity (or in the sense of Bergsonian duration).
I, too, was part of this vast tendency--called deconstruction, or the
archaeology of knowledge, and so on--which I realized later could
have critical impact only while Marxism actually ruled the people of
many nation-states. In the 1990s, this tendency lost its impact,
having become mostly a mere agent of the real deconstructive movement
of capitalism. Skeptical relativism, multiple language games (or
public consensus), aesthetic affirmation of the present, empirical
historicism, appreciation of subcultures (or cultural studies), etc.,
lost their most subversive potencies and hence became the dominant,
ruling thought. Today, these have become official doctrine in the
most conservative institutions in economically advanced
nation-states. All in all, this tendency can be summarized as the
appreciation of empiricism (including aestheticism) against
rationalism. In this sense, it has become increasingly clear that the
return to Kant in recent years has actually been a return to Hume.

'Meanwhile, it was in the effort of going beyond the empiricist
tendency--as a critique of Hume--that I began to read Kant. This, to
state it outright, is a project to reconstruct the metaphysics called
communism. It was Kant who provided the most lucid insight into
metaphysics' proper role and the inseparable and inevitable tie
between faith and reason. "Thus I had to deny knowledge in order to
make room for faith; and the dogmatism of metaphysics, i.e., the
prejudice that without criticism reason can make progress in
metaphysics, is the true source of all unbelief conflicting with
morality, which unbelief is always very dogmatic."  With this
statement, it is not that Kant sought to recover religion per se;
what he affirmed was the aspect of religion that tends toward
morality, encouraging us to be moral.

'In contradistinction from mainstream Marxists, Marx persistently
refused to consider communism as "constitutive idea (or constitutive
use of reason)" in Kant's sense, and he rarely spoke of the future.
Thus in The German Ideology, Marx made an addition to the text
written by Engels: "Communism for us is not a state of affairs which
is to be established, an ideal to which reality [will] have to adjust
itself. We call communism the real movement which abolishes the
present state of things. The conditions of this movement result from
the now existing premise."  Therefore, the dogmatization of communism
as a "scientific socialism" was much the kind of metaphysics Marx
refuted. But this is not contradictory to the fact that he nurtured
communism as "regulative idea (regulative use of reason)." So the
young Marx stressed the categorical imperative: "The criticism of
religion ends with the teaching that man is the highest being for
man, hence with the categorical imperative to overthrow all relations
in which man is a debased, enslaved, forsaken, despicable being."
For him, communism was a Kantian categorical imperative, that is,
practical and moral par excellence. He maintained this stance his
whole life, though later he concentrated his efforts on the
theoretical search for the historico-material conditions that would
enable the categorical imperative to be realized. Meanwhile, the
mainstream Marxists, having derided morality and advocated
"historical necessity" and "scientific socialism," ended up
constituting a new type of slave society. This was nothing short of
what Kant called "all pretensions of reason in general [aller
Anmaþungen der Vernunft ¸berhaupt]." Distrust of communism has
spread, and the responsibility for "the true source of all unbelief"
lies with dogmatic Marxism. We cannot and should not forget the
miseries of the 20th century caused by communism, and neither should
we take this mistake simply as misfortune. From that juncture onward
we have not been allowed to advocate "Idea" of any kind--not even of
the New Left, which came into existence by negating Stalinism--with a
naive positivity. That is why "in accordance with the fashion of the
age, [communism] proves despised on all ideas." Yet at the same time,
other kinds of dogmatism are flourishing in various costumes.
Furthermore, while intellectuals of advanced nations have been
expressing their distrust of morality, various kinds of religious
fundamentalism have begun to gain strength all over the world, and
the intellectuals cannot simply scorn them.

'For these reasons, beginning in the 1990s, my stance, if not my
thinking itself, changed fundamentally. I came to believe that theory
should not remain in the critical scrutiny of the status quo, but
should propose something positive to change the reality. At the same
time, I reconfirmed the difficult of doing so. Social democracy to me
would not offer any promising prospect, and it was finally around the
turn of the new century that I began to see a ray of hope that led me
to organize the New Associationist Movement (NAM) in Japan. Certainly
innumerable real movements that seek to abolish the status quo are
occurring in all corners of the world, inevitably, under the
procession of the globalization of world capitalism. But, in order to
avoid the repetition of bygone mistakes, I insist that a
transcritical recognition is necessary.'
=========================================================================

"Making Video, Being Political: Russian Art in an International Context"
Eleanor Hartney, Larry Litt, Nina Zaretskaya, Aaron Levy

April 23, 2003; 6:00 pm - 7:30 pm

http://slought.org/toc/calendar/display.php?id=1156

The second in a two-part series of lectures and public conversations
engaging contemporary Russian art and society. In conjunction with the
Slought Foundation exhibition "Détente: Russian Contemporary Art in Video
Format," featuring recent work by noted Russian artists Oleg Kulik,
Leonid Tishkov, AES, and Olga Stolpovskaya, and curated by Nina
Zaretskaya, TV Gallery, Moscow. On view through May 26, 2003. Détente"
invites a reconsideration of Russian contemporary art being viewed as
esoteric or subservient to the West.  This event sponsored by Slavic
Languages and Literatures at the University of Pennsylvania. Exhibition
information online:
http://slought.org/toc/calendar/display.php?id=1140

Janet Zweig, Jena Osman

April 24, 2003; 6:30 pm - 8:30 pm

http://slought.org/toc/calendar/display.php?id=1141

The second in a three-part series on dimensional texts and
interdisciplinary practice. "Dimensional Text" is an event series
collaboration between Chain Arts and Slought Foundation. The dimensional
text series is an investigation into the ways that language can be
presented off the page. It presents language work that steps away from
the book, the podium, or the conventional reading. Jena Osman will
lecture on Janet Zweig, followed by a presentation by Janet Zweig.

April 23, 2003 Event Biographies:

Eleanor Heartney is a New York based art writer and cultural critic. She
is Contributing Editor to Art in America and Artpress and has written
extensively on contemporary art issues for such other magazines as
Artnews, Art and Auction, The New Art Examiner, the Washington Post and
the New York Times. A collection of Heartney’s essays was published in
1997 by Cambridge University Press under the title “Critical Condition:
American Culture at the Crossroads”. Her “Movements in Modern Art:
Postmodernism” was published in 2001 by the Tate Gallery Publishers in
conjunction with Cambridge University Press. Heartney was the 1992
recipient of the College Art Association’s Frank Jewett Mather Award for
distinction in art criticism and has also received grants from the New
York Foundation for the Arts and the Asian Cultural Council.

Larry Litt is a writer, performer and filmmaker whose work has appeared
at the Venice Biennale, the Queens Museum of Art, the Cleveland Center
for Contemporary Art, the Apokalypsa Festival in the Czech Republic, and
the Seoul Media Fluxus Festival. He is currently at work on a series of
films under the series title The Blame Show, the most recent of which has
been commissioned by the Palm Beach Institute of Contemporary Art.

Nina Zaretskaya lives and works in Moscow and New York. She is a
documentary producer and founding director of Art Media Center “TV
Gallery” (1991), a Moscow institution responsible for the appearance and
development of video art and the art of new technologies in Russia. Nina
Zaretskaya has curated and organized numerous exhibitions including
“Total Recall” (dedicated to Phillip K. Dick), “This Other World of Ours”
(video installations by Young British Artists), and “Medium is the
Message” (presentation of work by Nam June Paik), introducing
contemporary foreign art to Russian audiences. Her recent show
“Femininity’s Redress,” held at Angel Orensanz Foundation Center for the
Arts, New York, initiates a multi-phase project presenting progressive
Russian women artists to the Western public.

Aaron Levy is Curator and Executive Director of Slought Foundation, an
arts organization, gallery, and archival resource engaging contemporary
life through critical theories about art. His curatorial projects include
ongoing lecture series, conferences, exhibitions, publications and
recordings featuring artists and theorists, also online.


------------

April 24, 2003 Event Biographies:

Janet Zweig is an artist who makes sculpture, books, and public art. In
her sculpture, she uses computers to permute text, connecting the results
to mechanical and kinetic elements. Her public art is often participatory
and generative. Zweig's sculpture and books have been exhibited widely in
such places as the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Exit Art, PS1 Museum, and
Cooper Union. She has installed public artworks at the University of
Minnesota, at Santa Fe Community College for New Mexico Arts, and at
Walton High School in the Bronx for New York's Percent for Art. She is
currently working on several other public projects including a frieze at
the Prince Street subway station for New York's Arts for Transit, an
open-air library in South Philadelphia for the Fairmount Park Art
Association, and a system-wide interactive project for the new Light Rail
Line in Minneapolis. She has received numerous awards including the Rome
Prize Fellowship and two NEA fellowships, as well as residencie
s at PS1 Museum and the MacDowell Colony. She has taught at the Rhode
Island School of Design since 1982 and at Yale University from 1991 to
2000. She lives in Brooklyn, New York.

Jena Osman is a poet and a professor of English and Creative Writing at
Temple University. Her book, The Character, won the Barnard New Women
Poets prize in 1998 and was published by Beacon Press. She is co-editor
of the award-winning interdisciplinary arts journal, Chain, with Juliana
Spahr. She has received grants from the National Endowment for the Arts,
the New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Fund for Poetry, and has
been a writing fellow at the MacDowell Colony, The Blue Mountain Center,
and the Djerassi Foundation. She received her Ph.D. from the Poetics
Program at SUNY-Buffalo and a Masters in Creative Writing from Brown
University.

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 10:36:21 EDT

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Austinwja@AOL.COM
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

In a message dated 4/21/03 5:22:13 PM, andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET writes:

<< Does anyone think that academic theory has been good for contemporary
poetry?  Has theory helped poets to write originally and well?  If so, what
has theory made available to poets that was not already present in the
tradition?  Examples, please.

I think academic theory has been good for contemporary poetry only to the
extent that theorists' patronizing attitude toward literary value has
challenged poets to try to articulate why their art matters.  Unfortunately,
poetry's importance is not something that poets are able to explain very
convincingly in conceptual terms, is it?

Andy >>

Hi Andy.  Your question is just a tad loaded--e.g., "patronizing attitude."
Where's the evidence for this?  Perhaps you are referring to the various
camps within the pobiz and the conflicts between them.  In that case, "All
are punished."

But that aside, whether or not this or that theory is good for poetry is,
well, "academic."
There always has, and always be theory.  (What, by the way, differentiates
academic from nonacademic theory?)  Coleridge was an academic.  His theory
seems to have done well by 19th century poetry, and beyond.  Various
theories--literary, scientific, psychological--have influenced the writing of
poetry and prose, painting, film.  Consider what the 20th century novel owes
to Freud, as just one example.  T.S. Eliot's poetry owes an enormous debt to
the philosophy of F.H. Bradley.  All of these "theories" were polished within
academia.  The simplest lyric poem is rooted in Romantic theory.

Most, if not all, contemporary theories which attach themselves to art found
their inspiration in Continental language philosophy.  Those academics did
nothing with language that quantum physicists (academics all) hadn't already
done with the "material" universe, i.e., expose the uncertainty which haunts
the core of things.  Maybe we should blame Heisenberg.  All I'm saying is
that all this is inevitable.  New poetic methodologies give rise to new
theory, and vice versa.  It has always been thus.  New discoveries influence
a range of activities.  One has a choice:  accept or deny, expose or censure.

One may argue that if a different system dominated the theoretical landscape,
a more accessible poetry would result.  One may also argue that if more
people read poetry, theory would be more accommodating to the masses.  Like
any circle, the end point is also the starting point.  No escape from this
conundrum.

As for poets not well explaining the importance of their craft--I don't think
that's true.  Romanticism from Blake to Williams has always held that poetry
is the original language, rather than an affectation.  It exercises modes of
thinking and feeling that some argue have been slowly lost in the industrial
and technological ages.  Do poets and poetry convince?  Convince whom?
Perhaps it merely has to be there to exercise an influence.  Perhaps--much as
any "primitive" culture steeped in mystery, or any non-rational activity on
the fringe, it infects our values, repels all efforts to completely banish
it, by virtue of its irreconcilable foreignness, otherness.  Sounds to me a
serious resistance that's both conceptual (theoretical) and practical.

Anyway, we all know our tastes.  Perhaps that's as far as we can go with
this.  Spoken word is popular.  It sells tickets.  Language poetry finds most
of its audience in the academy.  And the conventional lyric poem remains an
important player.  It's all there.  Contemporary poetry is a fucking
supermarket of forms.

Has theory been good for contemporary poetry?  Well, it hasn't killed
anything.  How bad can it be?  Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
bn.com

There was also an anthology of short fiction by Michigan writers entitled The Third Coast published by Wayne State Press in 1982.

Jim Harrison and Charles Baxter had a stories in it. My dad had a story in it, and I went to the reception for it, with my dad, when I was 13 years old.

I'll never forget, Jim Harrison looked about 10 feet tall to me; he was wearing jodphers (sp?); smoking a cigar; and laughing from deep in his belly. That image of him has made me smile for years.

S.

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 08:40:59 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Joel Weishaus <weishaus@PDX.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

> In a message dated 4/21/03 5:22:13 PM, andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET writes:
>
> << Does anyone think that academic theory has been good for contemporary
> poetry?  Has theory helped poets to write originally and well?  If so,
what
> has theory made available to poets that was not already present in the
> tradition?  Examples, please.
>
> I think academic theory has been good for contemporary poetry only to the
> extent that theorists' patronizing attitude toward literary value has
> challenged poets to try to articulate why their art matters.
Unfortunately,
> poetry's importance is not something that poets are able to explain very
> convincingly in conceptual terms, is it?
>
> Andy >>

Theory has been crucial to my work for at least the past twenty years. It
was Barthes, Derrida, Deleuze, Ulmer, and a host of others that made writing
inventive, thus possible, to me again, after I had given up on the Literary
World and returned to sculpting. I still look to theorists to help me
negotiate the shallows; and, like bodhisattvas, they still appear, if you
look for them. Theorists like Alan Bourassa, for example, suddenly pop up.

As for poetry's importance. As long as language is important, poetry will
naturally be at the helm.

-Joel

Joel Weishaus
Visiting Faculty
Center for Excellence in Writing
Portland State University
Portland, Oregon

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 09:03:56 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>
Subject:      THE END OF THEORY AND THE BEGINNING OF SCIENCE
In-Reply-To:  <00d801c308f3$d7172800$f2113444@rthfrd01.tn.comcast.net>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Perhaps what is meant by the "end" of theory is that science is finally
encroaching into the realm of the humanities and taking over, just as it
took over religion decades ago and basically made God irrelevant to any but
the holdouts (admittedly still in the billions) who still need faith to
govern their lives. For me, the innovations of brain science, for instance,
and what it reveals about how language works are far more interesting and
useful than anybody's literary "theory" of language. There is still a long,
long way to go with brain science, of course, but I think more new ideas of
how to make cutting-edge poetry will emerge from what we learn about the
biological functioning of the brain than from somebody revising Derrida or
Bloom.

(You may take this as a provocation if you like, as I am not sure how
willing I am to support such claims. It came to me more a "toss it out there
and see what sticks" kind of view.)


-mwp

From:         kari edwards <terra1@SONIC.NET>
Subject:      upper right hand coroner
In-Reply-To:  <00f301c308e4$e0c52cd0$1cfdba89@housepress>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v552)

upper right hand coroner


pray if you stop
        I will appear

-or-


         open sewers paved in intel


  a pound of heartless turbines


                adhere to my hydrogen and oxygen


                 knows no difference

        from the logic of Decapitation

        minimal expense for migration production


         and dogma retro-grade

all questions of credit card round up  (as)


        matter contained

                                        raised to the principle

                                        jump up response

when I call a question

         the band plays
                                Johnny marches to

                                        incomplete
mule resolution
                an ache

                        proceeds to idiom

         belched bone
  recreation center

                        this is call waiting

on abstract idealism


                        I am ok)-
                                next

                project complete

                        the body obsolete

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 12:23:40 EDT
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Austinwja@AOL.COM
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T. . .
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

In a message dated 4/21/03 7:28:49 PM, junction@EARTHLINK.NET writes:

<< Freud and Jung invented clerical languages for their cults. Both wrote

science fiction. Good for the dungeons and dragons set. Einstein used the

only available language (and a well-established one, at that) capable of

describing the phenomena, and used it with extraordinary economy..>>

Isn't poetry cultish?  Seems it's always been so.  Much of the language that
language philosophers use was either well established, or in the process of
becoming well established since referential (correspondent) linguistics began
its nosedive in the late 19th century.  Certainly Saussure provided much of
the lexicon long before structuralists/poststructuralists got their feet wet,
even if it found open air only a little at a time.  The same might be said of
Freud and Einstein, though here we may end up quibbling over degrees of
belatedness.  I'll leave alone "science fiction" and "extraordinary."  Can't
argue with reductions or adjectives.


<<What's involved in the present case is very different, I think, frfom a

philosopher limiting the meaning of a common word (and being very clear

about what he means by the term) so that he can discuss a limited concept

without confusion. In the case at hand very few of the concepts are new or

particularly difficult to grasp.>>

Yes, I do see your point.  There are no new ideas.  The Greeks had it
covered, one way or another.  Perhaps all we can say is that it's becoming so
much more difficult, and maximalist, and non-rational.  "Economy" is
certainly lost at the quantum level.  More generally we seem fated to contend
with the uncertainly of subject/object, of formulae, of language, of cultural
definition--this is where the intellect has taken us.  Of course, we can
refuse to go.  Language is surely capable of providing all the provisionals
we like.


<<Why don't we all learn latin?>>

Good idea.  Very good idea.  And let's add to the list Spanish, Italian,
French, Russian, Arabic, Hebrew et al so we Americans can at least understand
what the rest of the world is, and was, saying.

<<But I don't want to get too far off track. What I'm really saying is a

paraphrase of Olson: critics have to write as well as poets. Resorting to a

clerical language is more often than not an evasion of that piece of hard
work.>>

I like Olson.  A lot.  His fudging of the line between form and content is
worthy theoretical support for many postmodern poets and theorists (try
Baudrillard).  Olson did it himself in Maximus, though it was all in the
early stages then:  fragmentation's assault on linearity and the unified
subject; his reminding us of the Otherness of natural/pre-historic objects
(e.g., the breath) over the abstractions of "high culture."  And, of course,
some critics do  write as well as some poets; some better.  If there are no
new ideas, then how a critic or poet transmits ideas becomes the most
interesting aspect of the work, right?  That's the art part.  No?  Maybe.  I
guess.  Anyway, I enjoy the challenge.

The criticism you reference may at times amount to an evasion, at times not.
One kind of writing assumes an object without it, one that can be
represented, analyzed; another kind doesn't.  The latter flies off the
principle that all objects (for us) are linguistic, i.e., all knowledge is.
Beyond language lies only the irreconcilable, incomprehensible Other.  And
even that remark is meaningful only as a linguistic event.


<<Oh, and by the way, Girard came into a sympathetic department as a full

professor--not much fight to get in.  I can't speak about the academic

world of the early 60s at large because I wasn't in the academic world at

large.>>

You're aware, I'm sure, that Girard is more in the phenomenological mode than
the deconstructive.  He had his problems also with Derrida and company.  But
I believe you.  Believe me that in the 80s there was plenty of resistance to
those deconstruction guys.  Note the battles between Searle, Derrida and
between their respective followers.  I was just starting my academic career
in the 80s, and I got an earful.  Later, at SUNY, there was resistance to my
joining the faculty precisely because of my writing in the deconstructive
"vein" (imagine that!).  Can't speak for your experience, of course.


This was fun!  Many thanks, Mark!  Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
bn.com

For me, the innovations of brain science, for instance,and what it reveals about how language works are far more interesting anduseful than anybody's literary "theory" of language. From:         Aldon Nielsen <aln10@PSU.EDU>
Subject:      Re: THE END OF THEORY AND THE BEGINNING OF SCIENCE
In-Reply-To:  <BACAB5FC.DCAB%mpalmer@jps.net>

At 09:03 AM 4/22/2003 -0700, you wrote:
>Perhaps what is meant by the "end" of theory is that science is finally
>encroaching into the realm of the humanities and taking over, just as it
>took over religion decades ago


This sounds to me much more like the debates at mid-century and occasional
explanations of the New Criticism -- and I certainly don't see how science
and theory are here opposed -- there is, after all, the philosophy of
science, which takes as a part of its task the anatomizing of scientific
theorizing --

the NYT article certainly had less to do with any actual death or
diminution of theory than with on-going battles for dominance within the
humanities -- as any number have here pointed out, it's not as if those
pronouncing the death of theory don't advance as forcefully as they can any
number of theories of their own --

as for what theory may have done for make literary art "better," -- I can't
speak for others, but I remain grateful to Whitman for his essay on
American slang --

                 --Emily Dickinson

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 12:35:15 -0400
Reply-To:     poetry@hypobololemaioi.com
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Kevin Magee <poetry@HYPOBOLOLEMAIOI.COM>
Subject:      Negri's Leopardi
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

My translation-appropriation (use) of Toni Negri's article on Leopardi
can be read at  http://hypobololemaioi.com/hyoeides/harm.html
The French translation from the Italian can be read at
http://multitudes.samizdat.net

What Negri might be writing in this article is a text to shade out
Benjamin's Baudelaire, that contradictory figure, a prototype for
which appears at the end of WB's essay on Kracauer, "And if we wish to
gain a clear picture of him in the isolation of his trade, what we
will see is a ragpicker, at daybreak, picking up rags of speech and
verbal scraps with his stick and tossing them, grumbling and growling,
a little drunk, into his cart, not without letting one or another of
those faded cotton remnants--"humanity," "inwardness," or
"absorption"--flutter derisively in the wind. A ragpicker, early on,
at the dawn of the day of the revolution." (The essay was published in
1930 in two versions for Die Gesellschaft and Die literarische Welt.)
Though Benjamin is fascinated in the Passagen with the pencil-sketch
(or was it charcoal?) Baudelaire had made of Blanqui found among his
papers, he never tries to make Baudelaire into a revolutionary, after
the political sense. It seems strange that the 19th century still
lacks a revolutionary figure among its pleiade of poets. Negri's
Leopardi is trying to suggest such a figure, one more substantial than
Marti. The paragraphs on Whitman that were cut in the edit of Empire
read like Lunacharsky. There are many other Whitmans, but the authors
weren't able to do the philology. Could it be that philosophy,
political philosophy, needs such a figure as Leopardi, to help it to
remember to dream and boldly--if it is still possible for philosophy
to remember 1848?

The Mandelstam I write about has a relation to international modernism
much in the same way that Negri writes about Leopardi's relation to
the mid nineteenth-century revolutionary milieu in Europe. Benjamin's
Baudelaire leaves literary history with a central figure whose
manifold contradictions prevent the full dimension of dignity being
according to the labor of language that is poetry. This dignity is to
be found only in the approach of the poetic to the conceptual terrain
of philosophy and temporary, or temporal, habitations of its
theoretical language, since it is only from this direction that an
approach to revolutionary politics by way of the poetic can be
attempted without the overlapping spheres of the language-work
belonging to either poetry or philosophy surrendering to the purely
formal, static, abstract condition of political language
proper. Approach, not adaptation. It is not an issue of language being
appropriated for the purposes of propaganda, using works of art for
political ends. My work is opposed to this. Mandelstam even writes
that poetry may fall outside the sphere of culture altogether in the
ceaseless work of evading interpretation and definition, a place in
the world.

Especially interesting to me is the function of the poetry of
O.M. translated into English during the Cold War period to construct a
myth of the Western Poet destroyed by the totalitarian state, when the
very notion of the 'West' is a problem for Mandelstam, and his
position towards the 1917 revolution was among the most understanding
of the poets of his generation. "Classicism is revolutionary," he
writes, and the record of his critical writings discloses sharp and
prescient disagreements with the restoration that begins in the late
1920s. His essay on Dante gives to the history of poetry an
uncompromising figure in the bringing near to the State the Poetic,
the critique by the Poetic of the State and its operations of absolute
violence.  Mandelstam's Dante is a devastating chronicler of the
abuses of State power.  Negri's Leopardi is also trying to evoke a
figure whose writings never depart from the demands of the poetic,
which are never topical nor opportunistic, and it is in this sense
that both poets also offer counter-figures to the kind of use to which
Slavoj Zizek puts Brecht in the essay-postscript following his recent
selection of political writings by Lenin.  The equally uncompromising
critique by Walter Benjamin of the class relations which exert such a
determinative influence in the sphere of cultural production appear
especially relevant at the contemporary moment when the digitalization
of knowledge anticipated in the  "Passagen" and the corresponding
pressure on language-works and art-works to bear knowledge are being
posed.

Perhaps it is impossible for philosophy, or even cultural criticism,
to impose on the past in the search for a future a revolutionary
figure arriving from the poetic, and yet what's at stake may be the
multidimensionality of the language-work, freeing philosophy from
ontology, freeing poetry from the abyss of its limitless interiorities
and just as limitless surfaces, and freeing politics from the State
and returning the sphere of the political to the Society where the
language of politics has a chance of signifying. No one has really
heard what that language sounds like since no one has heard this kind
of coming into being of a class, despite all the work trying to find
the Parisian proletariat in the Passagen. In the age of strict
divisions and hierarchies at the beginning of the 20th century, both
Malevich and Mandelstam write about how their contemporaries outdid
each other in their will to annihilate one another, what Malevich
referred to as the 'Golden Age.' He said it was a race to send one
another's works to the cemetery. Mandelstam said of his generation
that it was an unprecedented enmity that made the hatreds of the
Classicists and the Romanticists look like child's play (and it wasn't
child's play in mid-19th century in France, nor in the France of the
Surrealists, both right and left wings). In comparison, 19th century
American poetry feels blithely other to all this, and is it possible
to speak of some sort of inheritance? Tradition? Whatever it is that
is orthodoxy? One such doxa might be the strict separation of the
spheres of language activity.

The false empiricism of watching events as they happen and stopping
and feeling bad about them.

http://hypobololemaioi.com
menya tolka ravni ubyoat

From:         kari edwards <terra1@SONIC.NET>
Subject:      packed in the narrows
In-Reply-To:  <00f301c308e4$e0c52cd0$1cfdba89@housepress>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v552)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

packed in the narrows


change has been dismantled

                roots and storms
        wrapped
                swelling in rotted triumph

a shrub trimmed of appetite

        yoked clean

all moments desoiled

for more then a thousand years

calm snakes crawl over
                the waking child

                times becomes estranged
as preemptive

        the cry of the too rational
                ends with a mythology of names


burnt and just a kernel remembered


  becomes a headboard

        cold paraffin rolled around
                        echoes

dull-headed  pale postmarks

mend any rips in the fabric
                         praises the new object

as a lesser evil


                but this is just a little piece
                        to nerves traded on open markets


                a shadow
one day

        at a distance

                        cramped in a dark tug

        wounded on the battlefield
=========================================================================

Segue Series at

Bowery Poetry Club



Presents . . .



EDDIE BERRIGAN and ERICA HUNT



April 26 from 4:00  -- 6:00



308 BOWERY, JUST NORTH OF HOUSTON



Eddie Berrigan is a part of the New York School of poetry in that he is a
product of the NYC public schools, and the former SUNY at Purchase (name
changed in protest of state education cuts). For the past four years he's
lived back in New York, experiencing the multiple vicissitudes and personal
consequences of the blithe gentrification. His book of poems, Disarming
Matter, is available from Owl Press.

Erica Hunt is the author of Local History (Roof) and the collaborative book
Arcade with sculptor Alison Saar (Kelsey Street). Hunt has worked as a
poetry teacher, housing organizer, labor news writer, and radio producer.
She is the author of the essay, "Notes for an Oppositional Poetics," which
first appeared in the anthology The Politics of Poetic Form (Roof).


http://www.bowerypoetry.com/

$4 admission goes to support the readers

Funding is made possible by the continuing support of the Segue Foundation
and the Literature Program of the New York State Council on the Arts.



(hosted by Renee Gladman and Rachel Levitsky)

From:         Stephen Vincent <steph484@PACBELL.NET>
Subject:      Negri's Leopardi
In-Reply-To:  <BACAC5DC.40B9%steph484@pacbell.net>

I find Negri's critique fascinating, rewarding, etc. However, I am a bit
mystified or not totally prepared by the piece to interpret the last
portion:

"The false empiricism of watching events as they happen and stopping
and feeling bad about them."

What would be "true empiricism" and what empiric factors make it possible to
transcend the momentary character of witness and feeling (good or bad) to
create - I assume - either an art with a more sustainable set of feelings or
a higher realm of art that dismisses the temporality of momentary witness
and feeling as a requirement at all.

Kevin, can you take us beyond speculation  here? I guess I am witnessing and
feeling events (interpreting, thinking, as well) as much as I can and I am
curious how Negri may consider empirical passion as off course!

Stephen V

> writes, and the record of his critical writings discloses sharp and
> prescient disagreements with the restoration that begins in the late
> 1920s. His essay on Dante gives to the history of poetry an
> uncompromising figure in the bringing near to the State the Poetic,
> the critique by the Poetic of the State and its operations of absolute
> violence.  Mandelstam's Dante is a devastating chronicler of the
> abuses of State power.  Negri's Leopardi is also trying to evoke a
> figure whose writings never depart from the demands of the poetic,
> which are never topical nor opportunistic, and it is in this sense
> that both poets also offer counter-figures to the kind of use to which
> Slavoj Zizek puts Brecht in the essay-postscript following his recent
> selection of political writings by Lenin.  The equally uncompromising
> critique by Walter Benjamin of the class relations which exert such a
> determinative influence in the sphere of cultural production appear
> especially relevant at the contemporary moment when the digitalization
> of knowledge anticipated in the  "Passagen" and the corresponding
> pressure on language-works and art-works to bear knowledge are being
> posed.
>
> Perhaps it is impossible for philosophy, or even cultural criticism,
> to impose on the past in the search for a future a revolutionary
> figure arriving from the poetic, and yet what's at stake may be the
> multidimensionality of the language-work, freeing philosophy from
> ontology, freeing poetry from the abyss of its limitless interiorities
> and just as limitless surfaces, and freeing politics from the State
> and returning the sphere of the political to the Society where the
> language of politics has a chance of signifying. No one has really
> heard what that language sounds like since no one has heard this kind
> of coming into being of a class, despite all the work trying to find
> the Parisian proletariat in the Passagen. In the age of strict
> divisions and hierarchies at the beginning of the 20th century, both
> Malevich and Mandelstam write about how their contemporaries outdid
> each other in their will to annihilate one another, what Malevich
> referred to as the 'Golden Age.' He said it was a race to send one
> another's works to the cemetery. Mandelstam said of his generation
> that it was an unprecedented enmity that made the hatreds of the
> Classicists and the Romanticists look like child's play (and it wasn't
> child's play in mid-19th century in France, nor in the France of the
> Surrealists, both right and left wings). In comparison, 19th century
> American poetry feels blithely other to all this, and is it possible
> to speak of some sort of inheritance? Tradition? Whatever it is that
> is orthodoxy? One such doxa might be the strict separation of the
> spheres of language activity.
>
> The false empiricism of watching events as they happen and stopping
> and feeling bad about them.
>
> http://hypobololemaioi.com
> menya tolka ravni ubyoat

From:         Tenney Nathanson <nathanso@U.ARIZONA.EDU>
Subject:      POG this Saturday evening: poet Anselm Hollo,
              painter Michael Cajero; plus Hollo talk Friday afternoon
Comments: To: Tenney Nathanson <tenney@dakotacom.net>

POG

presents
poet Anselm Hollo and painter Michael Cajero
Saturday, April 26, 7pm
Dinnerware Gallery, 135 East Congress
Admission: $5; Students $3

Additional Event: “Innovative Poetry: Life Outside the Box,” a talk by
Anselm Hollo followed by discussion: Friday, April 25, 2pm, UA English
Department, Modern Languages Building 451; this event is free and open to
the public.  (For directions, or advice about parking, phone POG at 615-7803
or email pog@gopog.org.)  Co-sponsored by Arizona Quarterly and the UA
Poetry Center.

Anselm Hollo was born in Helsinki, Finland, and was educated there and in
the U.S. In his early twenties, he left Finland to live and work as a writer
and translator, first in Germany and Austria, then in London, where he was
employed by the BBC's European Services in their Finnish Program from 1958
to 1967. Translations into Finnish from that time include Allen Ginsberg's
Howl and John Lennon's In His Own Write.
For the last thirty years, Hollo has lived in the United States, teaching
creative writing and literary translation at numerous colleges and
universities, including SUNY Buffalo, The University of Iowa, and The
University of Colorado. He is now Associate Professor in the Graduate
Writing and Poetics Department at The Naropa Institute.
Hollo has published more than thirty-five books and chapbooks, most recently
Corvus (Coffee House Press, 1995) and AHOE (Smokeproof Press, 1997). He has
also translated many contemporary Finnish poets, among them Paavo Haavikko
and Pentti Saarikoski, as well as fiction, plays, and poetry from the
German, French, Swedish, and Finnish.
Hollo's honors and awards include the New York State Creative Artists'
Public Service Award (1976), a National Endowment for the Arts Poet's
Fellowship (1979), the P.E.N./American-Scandinavian Foundation Award for
Poetry in Translation (1981), the American-Scandinavian Foundation Award for
Poetry in Translation (1989), Fund for Poetry Awards for Contributions to
Contemporary Poetry (1989, 1991), The Finnish Government Prize for
Translation of Finnish Literature (1996), and a Gertrude Stein Award in
Innovative American Poetry 1995-1996 (1996).
(excerpted from http://www.cyberpoems.com/abtans-h.html)

Michael Cajero. It was back in grad school, at Kent State University,
thatCajero first came under the spell of the ephemeral. He had been doing
regular two-dimensional paintings, applying pigment to the flat surfaces of
cloth or paper, when he started hearing about process art and arte povera.
These two schools emphasized what Cajero calls the "physicality of
materials" and "raw forms," giving equal value to such highly prized media
as oils and marble and mass-marketed goods. Cajero started experimenting
with junk materials designed not to last--masking tape and cheap wrapping
paper and newsprint. He twisted them into sculptural forms and spattered
them with paint.

After picking up a master's in painting, sculpture and art history, Cajero
came back home to his native Tucson. Immersed once again in the folkloric
imagery of the Hispanic Southwest, he began to see that the materials of
arte povera would make a perfect marriage with the icons of Mexican folk
art. Mexican artists of necessity have long used cheap, transitory materials
for their works--bread, sugar, clay--and Cajero mimicked this practice by
using paper and tape to make Mexicanesque skeletons and dancers and
musicians. Over the years Cajero, who teaches regularly at Pima College, the
Tucson Museum of Art and the UA, has taken these folkloric figures into new
territory. In 1992, the 500th-year anniversary of Columbus' arrival in the
New World, Cajero filled an entire room in the University of Arizona Museum
of Art with giant "light altars" chronicling the disasters of the Spanish
Conquest.
(excerpted from http://www.tucsonweekly.com/tw/1999-09-09/review.html)

POG events are sponsored in part by grants from the Tucson/Pima Arts
Council, the Arizona Commission on the Arts, and the National Endowment for
the Arts.  POG also benefits from the continuing support of The University
of Arizona Poetry Center, the Arizona Quarterly, Chax Press, and The
University of Arizona Department of English.  We also thank the following
POG donors: Patrons Roberta Howard, Tenney Nathanson, Liisa Phillips, Austin
Publicover, and Frances Sjoberg; Sponsors Barbara Allen, Chax Press, Alison
Deming, Elizabeth Landry, Stefanie Marlis, Stuart and Nancy Mellan, Sheila
Murphy Associates, and Tim Peterson.

for further information contact POG: 615-7803; mailto:pog@gopog.org;
www.gopog.org

From:         Ravi Shankar <drunkenboat@GRAFFITI.NET>
Subject:      Re: THE END OF THEORY AND THE BEGINNING OF SCIENCE
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
MIME-Version: 1.0

From my experience working at an agency that represented leading cognitive scientists, the animus that characterized lit theory in the seventies is de rigeur in the brain
sciences today, for the very reason that the field still has more speculation than consensus; for example, Stephen Pinker's occasionally histrionic embrace of genetic
determinism is more marketing ploy than description of reality, and the recent vogue of computational models for consciousness is yet another theory, no more able to
reveal impetus than certain acts of faith.  I'd argue that cutting-edge poetry is no more (or less) likely to find forms in electroencephalography than in afro picks.

Ravi Shankar
ed, http://www.drunkenboat.com

> Perhaps what is meant by the "end" of theory is that science is finally
> encroaching into the realm of the humanities and taking over, just as it
> took over religion decades ago and basically made God irrelevant to any but
> the holdouts (admittedly still in the billions) who still need faith to
> govern their lives.

From:         Brennen Lukas <blukas@COX.NET>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

These thoughts should be printed on posters. I'm tacking a copy onto the second wall of my cubicle/cage.

> I would say, to modify a Wittgensteinism, that the meaning of a theory is
> its use in the world.
>
> And that theory is not one thing.
>
> And that theory itself is meaningless outside the question of agency, of its
> use by people.
>
> And that the people who use theory the most have no real use for it.
>
> And that the people who use theory exclusively to make sense of the world
> are deep down very sad about something they cannot change but wish they
> could.
>
> And that the use of theory in literature departments is often a reductive
> and distorting heuristic device that obscures as much as it reveals.
>
> And that the use of theory in other contexts such as art practice and
> activism and teaching can lead to new discoveries about perception,
> ideology, and meaning.
>
> And that theory tells us nothing of how poems are made, distributed, and
> used, and next to nothing about how art might best be understood in terms of
> something other than theory.
>

Wow.  I know this may sound a bit sappy, but I must say, I'm really
appreciative all of the great posts here, the list, the participants...

The post about the webzine Vert, for example, turned me onto poems that
"give me permission" to write pretty direct poems and not worry so much
about their formal la-di-da etc.  Thanks editor Andrew Felsinger, for
example, for pieces by old pals I've always looked up to, like S.R. from
Bolinas, S.S. from S.F., to name but a few.  Really like the zine, Andrew
Felsinger.  And Thanks http://www.litvert.com/ !

From Diner poem/thing I wrote at 5 a.m. this morning, up early 'cause...

Chatter, like a porm addict
O'Reilly, say,
say, say,

as opposed to true thrill, still
this morning, Carly Simon's
trill in "You're so vain"

Over thirty years ago
before the world went away
and propaganda filled

every dream with Sports
stars who never really attended
college classes and

beautiful Madonna,
who cannot kill the material girl
who will not offend the troops

and it's all eye candy,
of course, including cluster bombs
blowing arms off, on FIX Networks

so what's body
and soul got to do
with it

anymore, after all
others live and
die and there's nothing

in between 'cept
the chatter and
the radio playing

Date:         Tue, 22 Apr 2003 17:46:30 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: THE LATEST THEORY IS THAT THEORY DOESN'T MATTER
In-Reply-To:  <v04011701bac9e4af1d4a@[63.187.224.217]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I was hoping someone could be more specific.  What specific styles, techniques, methods, forms, diction, whatever, has theory contributed to contemporary poetry?  Are these good?  Why?

Let me indulge my skepticism for a sec (as if I ever do anything else).  Take a book such as _My Life_.  Now, I find this work punishingly boring.  Others don't.  Fine.  But, based on my recollection, which may not be accurate, correct me if I'm wrong, it seems to me that one *might* say that Hejinian owes just about everything to Stein and other modernist poets, and that her debt to theory is not really visible on the page.  And perhaps, risking another possibly insipid assertion, one could say that what is usually taken to be "experimental" writing today likewise owes 99% of its styles, techniques, mannerisms, etc., to modernist models.  (Re-read Kenner's chapter on "Words Set Free" in _The Pound Era_ if you need to remind yourself just how little difference there is, formally, between what Williams was doing in _Spring And All_ and what scads of young poets are doing today.  And how much better Williams was, too, of course.)

So, if all theory has done is to encourage poets to think that imitating Stein or some other traditional poet will give their work philosophical or political bite, then theory has not done much more for poetry than re-certify (within the academy at least) certain models for literary imitation.  OR?

Andy

Ravi, that's so funny!  I got halfway through your sentence and was
wondering if anyone was going to bring up Pinker, and then you had...
Does this mean that poets possess the anima that can counterbalance today's
animus?  After all, poet's have more connections (neurons) between the
hemispreres of the corpus collossum, just as women have more compared to
what men are generally genetically predisposed to get.  (Yes, it's only a
theory of mine that poets and other artists, both male and female) have more
of these than their peers on the planet, and hence they greater
sophistication of emotion; they can "experience" MORE emotions and they can
articulate the nuances of those emotions in greater depth and quality.
They're favored (or plagued, the neanderthals would perhaps say) by this
actual physical difference between the male and female, and artist/nonartist
brain wiring).
Pinker's worth and merits...  Yes, it debatable whether he's just a groovy
guy marketeer or his theories in that first book (the green one, smile) are
really any good.  I'm referring to the book in which he argues that humans
have an innate predisposition to develop speech and communication, that even
a wildboy brought up by wolves will develop a language or something like
that.  Sorry, but it's been a long time since I (mis)read him, and I'm being
lazy at the moment.
Still, imagine something like that being true and, then, other
ramifications: Namely, do we not have innate tendencies to develop forms of
thought and human emotion that would prevail even if the Bush wacks "took
over" for 20-30 years (something I fear, though I know I should look at this
with some time-perspective)?  Is it guaranteed, somehow, that even if they
eliminated everybody but themselves and their types, their deeper genetic
codes would produce great-grandchildren one day who would figure out how to
reverse their devastation and return the species to sanity (or our
definition of same)?  I.e., even if they started a centuries long repression
of ambiguity tolerance, genetics would guarantee that ambiguity tolerance
will survive no matter how destructive they are?
Or are there no guarantees in evolution theory truly that "humans" are
getting wiser, kinder, more honest, more cooperative vs. competive (Riane
Eisler)?  Evolution only says that certain ones survive; only human
rationality and optimism prone thinkers would argue that "THE STRONG are the
wise, good, and poetic ones."  "The Strong" could be those who would kill
off emotion, sensitivity, compassion, altruism, cooperation--who can deaden
themselves to all but the most selfish and "inhuman" impulses and instincts
and compulsions and personlity traits.  Or there could be mutation that
would similarly favor the ambiguity murderers.  (This scares me, naturally.)
I would prefer to be comforted by some science that says "strong" means all
the kind of culture, ambiguity tolerance, etcetera, that has generally
prevailed for thousands of years, that it's all coded in already, that
"they," the neoconservatives and their spawn CANNOT outlast anybody.  But
these are biases of a rational and compassion sort of person; science and
evolution do not necessarily say or prove that this is the case...

>>From my experience working at an agency that represented leading cognitive
scientists, the animus that characterized lit theory in the seventies is de
rigeur in the brain sciences today, for the very reason that the field still
has more speculation than consensus; for example, Stephen Pinker's
occasionally histrionic embrace of genetic determinism is more marketing
ploy than description of reality, and the recent vogue of computational
models for consciousness is yet another theory, no more able to reveal
impetus than certain acts of faith. I'd argue that cutting-edge poetry is no
more (or less) likely to find forms in electroencephalography than in afro
picks.
Ravi Shankar ed, <http://www.drunkenboat.com>
> Perhaps what is meant by the "end" of theory is that science is finally >
encroaching into the realm of the humanities and taking over, just as it >
took over religion decades ago and basically made God irrelevant to any but
> the holdouts (admittedly still in the billions) who still need faith to >
govern their lives.<<
