this may be of interest to some:
k


Dear fellow peace activist/artist,

My name is Jim Mann, I am an American graphic designer living in
Barcelona, Spain.

Here in Barcelona, the anti-war movement is very strong and
demonstrations against the war in Iraq are being held daily.

This war is different in many ways. Beside the fact that virtually the
whole world community is against it, there has been an overwhelming
display by the people in the streets holding various anti-war posters.
Some of the posters have images and messages that are serious, others
use humor and satire to get their points across.

My goal is to put together some of the best posters from around the
world. Even if the book is published after the war ends, the messages
from these posters will live on into history, and that is one of the
goals of producing this book.

I am aware that many of you are very busy with organizing events and
recruiting people, but I ask for a few minutes of your time to send me
artwork either through email or by post.

Names of artists and organizations will be credited appropriately

The book will be printed at A3 (european tabloid size) and shall include
130 to 150 images color or black and white.

A portion of the Profits from the sale of the book will go to those
peace organizations who submit artwork, or to organizations which the
artists themselves choose.

Also organizations will be able to sell the book on their web sites or
at peace rallies or meetings. All images in the book will be copyright
free and available for individual use by the purchaser of the book.

Submissions can be in the form of printed paper or on cd-rom or floppy
diskette.
digital format: .eps, .jpeg, .pdf  adobe illustrator, photoshop, quark
express etc.
size: at least 11x17 or A3
resolution: 150 to 300 dpi

Deadline for submissions is June 1st 2003

Please mail submissions to:

Jim Mann
c/Duana 3,  1-1
08003 Barcelona
Spain

or email artwork to mann@opus5.info

Thankyou very much for your time, I look forward to receiving artwork
from you very soon. Please pass this email along to other interested
parties.

Peace,

Jim Mann

Astonishing Art Work Stops Traffic at Piccadilly Circus

(Gothic News Service, 5/23/03) This morning  - at the busy rush-hour
crossroad traffic around Piccadilly Circus - foot, bus and commercial
traffic were brought to a stand still by the sight of four coffin sized
aquarium tanks, each elevated on metal stands directly below the famous
roundabout=B9s statue of Eros. Carefully spaced and diagonally situated to
face each other, the aquariums at first appeared to be another
sensationalist sculptural work by Damian Hirst. However, instead of a lamb,
a shark, or a cow=B9s head suspended in formaldehyde, a much different sight
hypnotically stopped pedestrians and vehicles alike.  Naked mannequins of
President George Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair lay face up, suspended
in pale green liquid, both figures centered between the aquarium=B9s
transparent glass walls. Ironically, what appeared to be anatomical hearts
were floated suspended towards the top of the tank, each held by a single
thick artery attached to the cavity inside of each of the men=B9s chests, bot=
h
of which appeared to have been surgically opened.

In the other two aquariums =AD each at adjoining angles to those of the
President and the Prime Minister =AD the contents were quite dissimilar. Also
similarly suspended and frozen in pale green liquid, one contained another
figure apparently tilted to face the street. It appeared to be an adult
male, however one made difficult to identify because of the absence of a
head, its neck area tightly covered over with a dark scarf. The rest of the
body lay dressed in a loose blue tank-top, light gray, black oil smeared
trousers and black flip-flops. Sharp red flesh wounds haphazardly appeared
over exposed areas of the figure=B9s shoulders, arms and feet.

Curiously the other aquarium did not contain a body, but the model of an
upright, golden harp, one with nine vertical strings, similar to those
played in the courts of ancient Sumeria. In the angle of the morning sun =AD
even through the density of the formaldehyde - the singular harp appeared
particularly radiant, invoking an ironic sense of absent royalty and song.

Pedestrians who were able to get close enough to the works discovered each
aquarium to be meticulously subtitled with inlaid inscriptions on each of
the metal tank frames. Under the figures of Bush and Blair, viewers could
read an enigmatic, perhaps haunting phrase:

      I Don=B9t Speak German.

The words under the headless, dressed figure were a little more obvious:

      Unknown Iraqi Civilian. Cluster.

Under the golden harp there was a simple phrase, perhaps more difficult to
immediately interpret, a seeming exhortation:

      Lament for the Makers.

At first the immediate crowd appeared stunned by the content of the works
and then variously sad and furious. "Is this supposed to be us?" many asked
while others resisted, "This is not us," repeating it over and over again,
as if in disbelief that anybody would do this. Occasionally, a particularly
angry person yelled out, "Why not Hussein? Why not Hussein?"

It took more than a hour for London=B9s Bobbies to break up the crowd and
carry the works away in a Yard van for booking as evidence, and that still
without any knowledge of the perpetrator. Indeed some of crowd argued
whether or not the work was by Damian Hirst and how or why he could have
gone "this far."
 =20
"I cannot imagine Hirst being foolish enough to make this kind of career
move," a man with a kind of knowing authority spoke. "His work, as the
critics say, might be into interrupting urban boredom, but this kind of
publicity will kill him. Rich collectors, politically conservative as most
of them are =AD unless maybe they are Arabs - will just say no way."

"It's hard to believe anyone can be this cynical," someone added. "The Iraq
invasion and Occupation is just not this bad."

It took hours for normal traffic to resume at Piccadilly. In fact, the rest
of the morning London=B9s Bobbies worked themselves to pull down dozens of
climbers down from holding on to the wings of Eros.

=A9 Gothic News Service  2003

May be freely distributed over the Internet.

Subject:      Poetics in the Streets
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

A few of us in Seattle are planning a rather special protest on Saturday:

________________________

Saturday, April 26th, 12pm-2:00pm,
Seattle Art Museum, downtown site

Artists and others will gather to mourn the casualties and loss of life in
Iraq, as well as the looting and destruction of various Iraqi cultural
institutions. We also grieve the many acts of "looting" being done by the
American government.

Please dress in black funeral attire and meet under "Looting Man" (aka
Hammering Man, the Jonathon Borofsky sculpture outside the main entrance on
1st Avenue) at 12 o'clock sharp. We will proceed in silence around the
museum block for two hours.

No signs, no chants, no coffins. We are sympathetic mourners, slowly walking
together around the museum. With enough of us, we can encircle the museum/
block entirely. It is an act of grief and we are the (symbolic) missing ring
of protection.

A simple flyer explaining the action will be given to interested on-lookers.

Please, PLEASE pass the word along and feel free to print and Xerox this
e-mail.
______________________

Two hours might be a bit much! Still, the reason I'm forwarding this is to
try and provoke some interest from artists and writers in other cities to
perform a similar action. Perhaps the sizable contingent of poets in New
York City on this list might want to gather around the Metropolitan Museum
at noon. People in L.A. might choose the L.A. county museum on Wilshire.
Etc.

It would be a shame, after all the energies of mobilization provoked by the
war, to simply retreat to our various hermeticisms. We need to find new ways
-- poetic, artistic, and on the streets -- to say "no" to this most
repellent of administrations and all its plans.

Joe Safdie

Tom Bell & others interested:

Here are a few sources for those interested in cognitive science & its
interdisiplinary applications. The literature is _enormous_, so this is
only a tiny sampling!

Also, if anyone would like the link to my online dissertation, which deals
in part with "neuropoetics," please backchannel. I just gave a talk for
Small Press Traffic in San Francisco: "Poetry on the Brain, or, My
Homunculus, the Poet." Hopefully it will be published at some point.

I've found Lakoff & Johnson particularly helpful in thinking about the
conjuctions of linguistics and cognitive science.

The physical side of cognition suggests, I think, an interest in
phemonemenology & embodied consciousness. As Lewis LaCook suggested,
Merleau-Ponty is a pivotal thinker in this respect, and in many ways
constructs bridges between philosophy and cognitive science. _The Visible
and Invisible_ sounds poetic at times, as if he's struggling for a new
language to express the leveling of the field of subject/object relations
and perception, and a dismantling of Cartesian modes of cognition & what he
disparagingly calls "high-altitude thinking."

I'm also particularly interested in the intersections of cognitive science
and Buddhism, and Varela is helpful here. There's a big tome on the subject
called _Zen and the Brain_, which I vow some day to read! If anyone knows
of an analysis of the ancient Indian Buddhist Nagarjuna from a cogsci
perspective, please tell me!

Camille


Armstrong, Este. "The Limbic System and Culture: An Allometric Analysis of
the Neocortex and Limbic Nuclei." Human Nature 2, no. 2 (1991): 117-36.

Baars, Bernard J. A Cognitive Theory of Consciousness. Cambridge: Cambridge
University Press, 1988.

Blonder, Lee Xenakis. "Human Neuropsychology and the Concept of Culture."
Human Nature 2, no. 2 (1991): 83-116.

Chalmers, David. The Conscious Mind: In Search of a Fundamental Theory. New
York: Oxford University Press, 1996.

Cytowic, Richard E. The Man Who Tasted Shapes: A Bizarre Medical Mystery
Offers Revolutionary Insights into Emotions, Reasoning, and Consciousness.
New York: Warner Books, 1993.

Damasio, Antonio R. Descartes' Error: Emotion, Reason, and the Human Brain.
New York: Avon Books, 1994.

Dennett, Daniel. Consciousness Explained. Boston: Back Bay Books, 1991.

Edelman, Gerald M. Bright Air, Brilliant Fire: On the Matter of the Mind.
New York: BasicBooks, 1992.

Elster, Jon. Introduction to The Multiple Self. Cambridge: Cambridge
University Press, 1985, 1-34.

Gazzaniga, Michael S. The Mind's Past. Berkeley: University of California
Press, 1998.

Hayward, J., and F.Varela (Eds.). Gentle Bridges: Dialogues between the
Cognitive Sciences and the Buddhist Tradition, (Shambhala Publishers,
Boston, 1992).

Lakoff, George, and Mark Johnson. Philosophy in the Flesh: The Embodied
Mind and Its Challenge to Western Thought. New York: Basic Books, 1999.

Ledoux, Joseph. The Emotional Brain: The Mysterious Underpinnings of
Emotional Life. Touchstone Books, 1998.

Nagel, Thomas. "What Is It Like to Be A Bat?" Philosophical Review 83
(1974): 435-50.

Sobel, C. P. The Cognitive Sciences: An Interdisciplinary Approach.
Mountain View, CA: Mayfield, 2001.

Varela, Francisco, E. Thompson and E. Rosch. The Embodied Mind: Cognitive
science and human experience (MIT Press, Cambridge, 1991).

Varela, F. (Ed.). Sleeping, Dreaming and Dying: Dialogues between the
Sciences and the Buddhist Tradition (Wisdom Book, Boston, 1997).

Varela, F. Autopoiesis and Phenomenology, (Interview by H.Kawamoto),
Gendai-shiso (Japan), No.4, 1999, pp.80-93.

Varela, F. Ethical Know-How, Stanford Univ. Press, 1999

Varela, F. What a relief! I don't exist: Buddhism and the Brain (Wes
Nisker), Inquiring Mind, vol.16 No.1, 1999, p.7-9. [haven't read this one,
but I love the title!]

The following "poem" (Google-based collage) is drawn
from the Google search source material left unused in
K. Silem Mohammed's poem, "Merit", which appears at

http://listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0304&L=poetics&D=1&P=51307

The Google Advanced Search instructions: Find Results
With All of the Words "poem" and with the Exact Phrase
"'I am a traitor'", yielding 55 citations:

http://www.google.com/search?as_q=poem&num=100&hl=en&ie=ISO-8859-1&btnG=Google+Search&as_epq=%22I+am+a+traitor%22&as_oq=&as_eq=&lr=&as_ft=i&as_filetype=&as_qdr=all&as_occt=any&as_dt=i&as_sitesearch=&safe=images

Whereas Mohammed incorporated the original search key
words into his poem, I do not, and I do not use any of
the quotes he did; but, otherwise, our sources are
identical, just different selections.

My poem's title also comes from the source material.
The poem was composed last night, my first flarf.


-------------------------------------------------------

WRITE ME BACK AND TELL ME IF I SHOULD PUBLISH IT OR
NOT


My brain is aching from breaking my promise,
indulging in this wicked activity

---steps out onto the stage alongside "The Living."
He said his lines. "Dark Journey Home"
begins to play.   He was alone, bucky boy
you are implying.

When I want to stop/recover I won't be told that
you'd never betray the light and the sparks and
Firebird falls as the sun began to lower in the west.

On the pale face of a shower scattered over
possibly a useless generation,
he barely whispered.  He avoided all eye contact.
After several minutes he finally spoke.

Taking the gloves off the next morning,
you set off, with sword.  Innocent girl, she dropped
whilst she dares not speak
nor has the words for what she wants to say.  She
says,
very softly, "And I was very wedding morn.

Hidden emperor flavor be somewhat the weaker."

I received yesterday fifty emails saying
there is a carefully written tragic legend.
Now how can that be.

The infamies that exist today
in capitalistic society are fast becoming
a species that has progressed beyond
the bounds of history,
written on the back of God's palm.

It may be part of the formulaic style of
every single soul at the bottom beyond infinity,
or it may be a concession to a twelfth-
century audience familiar with
awakening

in the same way that one recites in class
without any thought to the words.

Intricate tissue of myth and reality
once was fed even some of the so-called
shadows of the pines, now starves.

She wants those concerning herself
to blossom forth!
Sadly, she turned around and left the store.
I cried after reading it, entitled "Saint Antichrist,"
without comment or signature

He hit himself saying, "Fie on me!"
Task is done. Boo as hard as you can.

From: Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>

>I was hoping someone could be more specific.  What specific styles,
techniques, methods, forms, diction, whatever, has theory contributed to
contemporary poetry?  Are these good?  Why?
>
>Let me indulge my skepticism for a sec (as if I ever do anything else).
Take a book such as _My Life_.  Now, I find this work punishingly boring.
Others don't.  Fine.  But, based on my recollection, which may not be
accurate, correct me if I'm wrong, it seems to me that one *might* say that
Hejinian owes just about everything to Stein and other modernist poets, and
that her debt to theory is not really visible on the page.  And perhaps,
risking another possibly insipid assertion, one could say that what is
usually taken to be "experimental" writing today likewise owes 99% of its
styles, techniques, mannerisms, etc., to modernist models.  (Re-read
Kenner's chapter on "Words Set Free" in _The Pound Era_ if you need to
remind yourself just how little difference there is, formally, between what
Williams was doing in _Spring And All_ and what scads of young poets are
doing today.  And how much better Williams was, too, of course.)
>
>So, if all theory has done is to encourage poets to think that imitating
Stein or some other traditional poet will give their work philosophical or
political bite, then theory has not done much more for poetry than
re-certify (within the academy at least) certain models for literary
imitation.  OR?
>
>Andy
>

.Here's a recent overview of
Pennebaker's work:
*Pennebaker, J.W. (2002). What our words can say about us: Toward a broader
language psychology. Psychological Science Agenda, 15, 8-9. A brief and
light summary of recent findings concerning the power of words in revealing
personality and social situations.  and this:
*Pennebaker, J.W. & Stone, L.D. (in press).  Words of wisdom:  Language use
over the lifespan.  Journal of Personality and Social Psychology.  As people
age, the words they use in everyday language changes.  This is based on
analysis of over 3000 individuals writing about emotional topics and the
collected works of 10 famous authors

I'm really looking for something that shows how different areas of the brain
are lit up by oral versus written poetry?  My guess is that the oral is
closer tied to emotional areas than written which tends to be cognitive or
rational?

How and where the two are 'linked' is really what makes poetry, though. I
would think.

I think another issue worth exploring would relate to the 'action' of poetry
in the sense that cognitive explanations tend to be about or theoretical
rather than dynamic or action oriented and tend to explore the geography of
mind as if that explains how anything 'happens'

tom bell
not yet a crazy old man
hard but not yet hardening of the
arteries as there are still some sparks going on down
there

and poetry by Olivia Silva, in 1977 at Solentiname, Nicaragua:

LOS HIJOS DE MARCOS JOYA

Los hijos de Marcos Joya mueren sin medicina,
escuelas no hay para lo de Ricardo Reyes,
ni los ancianos puedan alimentarse
pero Samoza tiene armas modernisimas para matar.


THE CHILDREN OF MARCOS JOYA**

The children of Marcos Joya are dying for lack of medicine,
there's no school for the son of Ricardo Reyes,
and the old folks can't get enough to eat,
but Somoza has all the newest weapons for killing.




ARCHIPIELAGO DE VERDES ISLAS

Archipielago de verdes islas
con bandadas de patos buceando junto a lost corrales de piedras
bajo los frondosos guabos.
En mayo lost guises construyen sus nidos
con las primeras lluvias brillan en las noche los hachones
y se comienza a sembrar el maiz.
Los dias son calmos
hace much calor.


ARCHIPELAGO OF GREEN ISLANDS**

Archipelago of green islands
with flocks of ducks diving in stony coves
under thick-leaved guava trees.
In May the guises build their nests,
when the first rains come torches glow at night
and we start to plant our corn.
The days are calm,
it is very hot.

**Translated by David Gullette


**Translated by David Gullette

Dear fellow peace activist/artist,

My name is Jim Mann, I am an American graphic designer living in
Barcelona, Spain.

Here in Barcelona, the anti-war movement is very strong and
demonstrations against the war in Iraq are being held daily.

This war is different in many ways. Beside the fact that virtually the
whole world community is against it, there has been an overwhelming
display by the people in the streets holding various anti-war posters.
Some of the posters have images and messages that are serious, others
use humor and satire to get their points across.

My goal is to put together some of the best posters from around the
world. Even if the book is published after the war ends, the messages
from these posters will live on into history, and that is one of the
goals of producing this book.

I am aware that many of you are very busy with organizing events and
recruiting people, but I ask for a few minutes of your time to send me
artwork either through email or by post.

Names of artists and organizations will be credited appropriately

The book will be printed at A3 (european tabloid size) and shall include
130 to 150 images color or black and white.

A portion of the Profits from the sale of the book will go to those
peace organizations who submit artwork, or to organizations which the
artists themselves choose.

Also organizations will be able to sell the book on their web sites or
at peace rallies or meetings. All images in the book will be copyright
free and available for individual use by the purchaser of the book.

Submissions can be in the form of printed paper or on cd-rom or floppy
diskette.
digital format: .eps, .jpeg, .pdf  adobe illustrator, photoshop, quark
express etc.
size: at least 11x17 or A3
resolution: 150 to 300 dpi

Deadline for submissions is June 1st 2003

Please mail submissions to:

Jim Mann
c/Duana 3,  1-1
08003 Barcelona
Spain

or email artwork to mann@opus5.info

Thankyou very much for your time, I look forward to receiving artwork
from you very soon. Please pass this email along to other interested
parties.

Peace,

Jim Mann
--

Any insights from Ray Gibbs, my old high school buddy, who wrote The
Poetics of Mind?  it's about metaphor and cognitive psych.

At 9:00 PM -0500 4/23/03, Camille Martin wrote:
>Tom Bell & others interested:
>
>Here are a few sources for those interested in cognitive science & its
>interdisiplinary applications. The literature is _enormous_, so this is
>only a tiny sampling!
>
>Also, if anyone would like the link to my online dissertation, which deals
>in part with "neuropoetics," please backchannel. I just gave a talk for
>Small Press Traffic in San Francisco: "Poetry on the Brain, or, My
>Homunculus, the Poet." Hopefully it will be published at some point.
>
>I've found Lakoff & Johnson particularly helpful in thinking about the
>conjuctions of linguistics and cognitive science.
>
>The physical side of cognition suggests, I think, an interest in
>phemonemenology & embodied consciousness. As Lewis LaCook suggested,
>Merleau-Ponty is a pivotal thinker in this respect, and in many ways
>constructs bridges between philosophy and cognitive science. _The Visible
>and Invisible_ sounds poetic at times, as if he's struggling for a new
>language to express the leveling of the field of subject/object relations
>and perception, and a dismantling of Cartesian modes of cognition & what he
>disparagingly calls "high-altitude thinking."
>
>I'm also particularly interested in the intersections of cognitive science
>and Buddhism, and Varela is helpful here. There's a big tome on the subject
>called _Zen and the Brain_, which I vow some day to read! If anyone knows
>of an analysis of the ancient Indian Buddhist Nagarjuna from a cogsci
>perspective, please tell me!
>
>Camille
>
>
>Armstrong, Este. "The Limbic System and Culture: An Allometric Analysis of
>the Neocortex and Limbic Nuclei." Human Nature 2, no. 2 (1991): 117-36.
>
>Baars, Bernard J. A Cognitive Theory of Consciousness. Cambridge: Cambridge
>University Press, 1988.
>
>Blonder, Lee Xenakis. "Human Neuropsychology and the Concept of Culture."
>Human Nature 2, no. 2 (1991): 83-116.
>
>Chalmers, David. The Conscious Mind: In Search of a Fundamental Theory. New
>York: Oxford University Press, 1996.
>
>Cytowic, Richard E. The Man Who Tasted Shapes: A Bizarre Medical Mystery
>Offers Revolutionary Insights into Emotions, Reasoning, and Consciousness.
>New York: Warner Books, 1993.
>
>Damasio, Antonio R. Descartes' Error: Emotion, Reason, and the Human Brain.
>New York: Avon Books, 1994.
>
>Dennett, Daniel. Consciousness Explained. Boston: Back Bay Books, 1991.
>
>Edelman, Gerald M. Bright Air, Brilliant Fire: On the Matter of the Mind.
>New York: BasicBooks, 1992.
>
>Elster, Jon. Introduction to The Multiple Self. Cambridge: Cambridge
>University Press, 1985, 1-34.
>
>Gazzaniga, Michael S. The Mind's Past. Berkeley: University of California
>Press, 1998.
>
>Hayward, J., and F.Varela (Eds.). Gentle Bridges: Dialogues between the
>Cognitive Sciences and the Buddhist Tradition, (Shambhala Publishers,
>Boston, 1992).
>
>Lakoff, George, and Mark Johnson. Philosophy in the Flesh: The Embodied
>Mind and Its Challenge to Western Thought. New York: Basic Books, 1999.
>
>Ledoux, Joseph. The Emotional Brain: The Mysterious Underpinnings of
>Emotional Life. Touchstone Books, 1998.
>
>Nagel, Thomas. "What Is It Like to Be A Bat?" Philosophical Review 83
>(1974): 435-50.
>
>Sobel, C. P. The Cognitive Sciences: An Interdisciplinary Approach.
>Mountain View, CA: Mayfield, 2001.
>
>Varela, Francisco, E. Thompson and E. Rosch. The Embodied Mind: Cognitive
>science and human experience (MIT Press, Cambridge, 1991).
>
>Varela, F. (Ed.). Sleeping, Dreaming and Dying: Dialogues between the
>Sciences and the Buddhist Tradition (Wisdom Book, Boston, 1997).
>
>Varela, F. Autopoiesis and Phenomenology, (Interview by H.Kawamoto),
>Gendai-shiso (Japan), No.4, 1999, pp.80-93.
>
>Varela, F. Ethical Know-How, Stanford Univ. Press, 1999
>
>Varela, F. What a relief! I don't exist: Buddhism and the Brain (Wes
>Nisker), Inquiring Mind, vol.16 No.1, 1999, p.7-9. [haven't read this one,
>but I love the title!]

This site offers a clever parody (on several levels) of the kind of theorizing
that may be ending. Note that the prose is generated by a computer program,
"the Dada engine, a system for generating random text from recursive grammars."
Are graduate schools still producing similar engines, in the form of budding
young scholars?

<http://www.elsewhere.org/cgi-bin/postmodern>http://www.elsewhere.org/cgi-b
in/postmodern

Joseph

Date:         Thu, 24 Apr 2003 12:57:02 -0400
Reply-To:     olsonjk@delhi.edu
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Kirby Olson <olsonjk@DELHI.EDU>
Organization: SUNY Delhi
Subject:      Re: cognitive poetix
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Robert Bly in his book Leaping Poetry tried to build a theory based on David
MacLean's Tri-Une Brain theory that great poetry is a leap between the
neo-cortex and the limbic system (rational and instinctive parts of the brain).
The book is probably dated in terms of the cognitive map that MacLean offers
(his book was published in the early seventies, and Bly's book is now probably
two decades old at least).

There have been lots of studies by neuroscientists who can now track what parts
of the brain are firing when a pianist plays at a large concert hall.  It does
seem to be a link between these two parts of mind that MacLean (I think that's
his name) calls neocortex and limbic.

It's apparently more rare for men to be able to make this leap than women.
We're hard-wired differently.  Bly argues that if you get used to making the
leap you'll make a royal road between the two, and that poetry has a great
importance in our culture because it is an attempt to build this royal road.

This is maybe the direction of evolution -- women (and men) want their lovers to
be versed in poetry -- and if so there's a green light -- so therefore it seems
to be an evolutionarily favored activity.  Poetry does appear to be part of the
mating ritual at this point -- perhaps because it points to something that we
want in mates -- the ability to negotiate the impasse between logic (neocortex)
and instinct (limbic), as one without the other is incredibly dull.

But few can do it.  Bly claims this is why there are so few poets, but the few
we have we place so high.  He claims they're building a new path in our brains.

-- Kirby

Date:         Thu, 24 Apr 2003 13:02:33 -0400
Reply-To:     poetry@hypobololemaioi.com
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Kevin Magee <poetry@HYPOBOLOLEMAIOI.COM>
Subject:      Cognitive Values
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

Unbearable, the writing bearing the pressure of the material being
read. Research material uncited indicting. What was she reading, the
source, the authority for the material she was reading, studies found
somewhere that could not have been hard to find in the library for
the one who was writing, mechanically at first, exposition, reciting,
when the affect from the reading began to affect the writing, reading,
writing. Somebody had been studying the condemned. Some book or
another had studied their death. What had been what was being.
Cellblock. Twenty-four hour surveillance. Isolation. Regulation. The
writing repeated another language, its discursive distancing
mechanisms repeating with difference the difference made, emoting. The
subject made a difference to the one writing from the book from the
library that said at the time of the execution the prisoner is already
dead, she wrote, reciting the words from the book, withdrawal,
passivity, regression among the technical terms taken. The camera, the
always-present camera, and monitored the one being monitored must know
they are monitored, their bodily functions no longer belong to
them. Their bodies no longer belong to them. Their bodies belong to
the state's remote, delegated procedures. They die, the book said,
they are dead before they are executed. This must have been what
overwhelmed the writing, one page's typing going off the margins,
erratic punctuation marks, sparks, maybe some anger. Then despair
returned and the paper ended at the assigned numbered pages turned in
on time. But there'd been time enough for tracing the technique for
evacuating being from the bodies of those marked by the state for
execution. Being can be reduced to matter. Being can be reduced to
matter when science and technology are applied to it. Everyone can
understand this. Everyone can stand this. For as long at least as they
are reading far away from the subject condition of the one subjected
to this regime. Discourse offers such protection, so much protection,
for those compelled to audit the spectacle of the appointed
incineration of the less than. Human? The subject? What was that. It
can't be what it once was, prior to its insertion into machinic
processes. Designs for future architectures of confinement and control
are drawn along these lines. Inside the state, the prisoner, outside
the state, the enemy. But there is no outside to the state that is
everywhere. Everyone not an enemy of the state not prisoner, political
prisoner.

--

http://hypobololemaioi.com
"Will we recognize our emancipators when they emerge from the ditch?"

from NOW online:



POETRY IS A SEX TOY
AFTER ALL, IT'S A HANDY DEVICE THAT CAN HELP YOU GET LAID
BY MARNIE WOODROW
While national poetry month is indeed winding down, it's not too late to
celebrate the power of poetry in your sex life. The way I see it, you have
three options. You can fuck a poet, become one or simply use the poetic
works of others to get yourself laid before month's end. Consider this.
Ninety-nine per cent of all poems are about sex or death, and we could all
stand a little break from the latter. Bottom line: April, month of sonnets
and unfettered free verse, is an awesome time to get yourself some ass. It's
up to you to turn it from the cruellest month into the wettest.

Fucking a poet during Poetry Month is a very nice thing to do because, as
everyone knows, poets are lonely, complicated souls who need more TLC than
most people. At this time of year they may also be suffering from acute
bitterness, especially if they weren't invited to perform their brilliant
works at one of the 200 venues currently featuring readings.

Canada Council rejection letters have arrived by now, so finding a poet
won't be too difficult: simply visit a bar. After a night of hot, grateful
sex, poets will often leave sleazy haikus on the night-table, provided they
leave. Make sure they do. That said, keep all such post-rut love notes. If
your poet fuck becomes famous one day, you can sell his or her scribbled
scrap on eBay for a large sum. (Be patient.)

And if it's your deep wish to be immortalized, elevated from one-night stand
to god/goddess, do sleep with a poet. Like elephants, poets never forget.
Plus, they'll almost always remember you as well endowed.

A person who has devoted his life to creating beauty and obsessing over
rhythm is generally quite good in bed. And because of their notorious talent
for staying up all night, they're less likely to fall asleep on you
mid-romp. Yes, in this our country of bards it is pretty much your patriotic
duty to fuck a poet. (Poets, feel free to carry this column around with you
for the rest of the month, with my sincere hopes that it works like a
charm.)

Option number two: become a poet. If masochism's your thing, go for it. If
not, skip to option three.

When I suggest using the poems of others in order to facilitate a pickup or
seduction, I am not talking about Wordsworth. Dreamily murmuring "I wandered
lonely as a cloud" in a packed bar isn't going to get you any.

Poetry functions best as a courtly weapon, as in the case of the hand-copied
poem in a card or letter. Just remember, whether copied, trilled-out or
whispered, some poets are sexier than others.

If you're disinclined to quote aloud from literature because it's an
undeniably pretentious habit, please note that this is Poetry Month, the one
time of year you can get away with recitations. Or why not copy a few lines
of a truly hot poem on a cocktail napkin and pass it to your object of
desire?

Again, choose carefully. e.e. cummings will get you laid; Robert Frost might
not. (I guess it depends where you hang out on a Friday night.) Anne Sexton
is hotter than Sylvia Plath, but those suicide poets do have a certain hint
of danger about them. Consider using these lines from Canadian poet Lorna
Crozier's suite The Sex Lives Of Vegetables: "Carrots are fucking / the
earth. A permanent / erection, they push deeper / into the damp and dark."
Who wouldn't be enticed by that? Granted, it might work better in a garden
centre than a bar, but you never know.

Whatever you do, make sure to make the most of what's left of Poetry Month
by using poetry in your mating call. Time is of the essence! Make haste! Of
course, you might also choose to enter into the month of May (National
Masturbation Month) alone, holding a copy of Les Fleurs Du Mal in your free
hand. Marnie Woodrow's novel, Spelling Mississippi, features a poet who gets
lucky.

NOW | APR 16 - 22, 2003 | VOL. 22 NO. 33

this turn of fate, this monument:: <::> this transformation
<==> you can meet her in the dark <::> it's the best
place:: lit by the fires of the burning of the national archives -
koranic interlude - you can wait on the floor -
there are always times for bodies
i just got this guitar today
so I thought I might use it in the performance.
but then I don't think it would work
since I didn't plan ahead of time for a guitar
but I couldn't resist this one, it cost $40
(that's almost 40 Euros!!!!)
thank yoU! thank you!!!
can you hear me!
thank you!Q thank you!Q
the guitar cost forty Euros -
anyway....
on the left anja schmidt on the right foofwa d'imobilite
foofwa the immobilized -
whenever one moves, there's a relationship with an object

embedded in time and space-varying projections
transforming him into an object - you're seeing the object

oh oh oh I'm beside myself now!
I"M BESIDE MYSELF NOW!

so anyway - you're seeing the object up there on the screen
- which is in front of me and what if I couldn't type this fast?
I'd be at a loss
becauxe when you work three-dimensionally it's all,
not even object-oriented,
but it's the object itself - it'
s the object itself - going inside and outside of the object -
whatever happened to the body 0-
it moves through violent spaces
        EACH SPACE IS AN ARCHIVE
        EACH SPACE HOLDS ITS OWN AS AN ARCHIVE
        YOUI CAN'T IMAGINE, YOU JUST CAN'T IMAGINE..
        `       parameters...there are always
        parfameters movinag -moving - parameters at work
caressing the space
forcing you through it / into it
THIS IS THE SPACE OF ARCHIVES
THIS IS THE SPACE THAT WAS DESTROYED IN IRAQ
the space in which an object appears in fifty-thousand
or onehundredseventythousand forms and formats.
a FOREST OF SPACES AND APPEARANCES

information carried down to the molecujlar level
look on the LEFT - the viruses from SARS
look on the right - who or what is in the LAST STAGES -

SO WHEN YOU STUDY HITTITE
you learn in cuneiform that there are...
strata,l layers, images, viewpoints -
for example, you might want to write MY FATHER
which is my name in hebrew - avi - but you would
use Akkadian - in the middle of the Hittite - you'd
write ABU.YA - like that - you can see the resemblance,
but the hittite's gone, just like it
s gone when sumerian or other forms, mitanni for example,
start to take over - it's ALL a matter of layers and images -
and their destruction - their overt destruction.
what we need is something else - another form/at - for
example the mouth - or a litany of plants and animals
and humans on the way to extinctions...
as plato would say - you get the IDEA....
Kant you understand?
by the way Florian is here, hello Florian! we were waiting...

which reminds me - that there are no end to them,
the protocols and codes and codecs and levelling,
no end at all to them....
so what you're seeing now... flattened images,
collapsed parameters - every image is already an imperialism,
a destruction - every image loses the memory of its creation....
thank you very much for coming and remember
that the war isn't over yet
that people and archives are being destroyed
that no protocol can rescue them
that everything is invaded from within
that i'm playing a guitar with five strings
that the six one is gone as in 'gone world' -

> we have we place so high.  He claims they're building a new path in our
brains.

Of course it's much more complex than leaping from the limbic system and the
neocortex, while the limbic system itself consists of many inacting sites.
Bly used MacLean's work to press a psychological, not a neurological, point.
He didn't claim to be versed in neuroscience. MacLean participated in a very
interesting conference, the papers from which were published in A.
Harrington, Editor, "So Human a Brain: Knowledge and Values in the
Neurosciences." Boston, MA., 1992

I've been thinking about how Bly's most recent book, "The Night Abraham
Called to the Stars" displays how this leaping process works in a mature
poet. It's amazing how many risks he is willing to take. It shows how older
poets can be as evocative as younger poets, that creative abilities only
wither if we let them. And this goes to the whole range of one's life. So
that if a poet becomes politically conservative, for example, it will also
stagnant one's willingness to take risks with the poems. This applies to all
creative work, all the arts and sciences. I think you're addressing
creativity not just poety.

-Joel W.

From:         Derek R <derek@DEREKROGERSON.COM>
Organization: DerekRogerson.com
Subject:      What is a standing paragraph?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit


Hello list,

I'm doing research on complete, determinate, and singular things and I
cannot seem to get my head around the meaning/usage of the word
'paragraph.'

My understanding of paragraph is 'to divide or arrange,' so that, a
paragraph (by definition) cannot exist as a singular entity, but
requires plurality to exist (i.e. the act of division, to divide).

A paragraph, then, would appear to be similar to 'article,' in that
there must be 'one of several' in order for proper (definitive)
existence.

** So then, what definitively is called a single item of text, of which
there is no more and none before? **

My best guess, to this point, would be a generic term like 'content' or
'text.'

Is there no proper antonym of 'paragraph' in literary terminology?

Any help/thoughts to define this would be appreciated.






=========================================================================
Date:         Thu, 24 Apr 2003 15:36:18 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Joseph Thomas <jtthoma@ILSTU.EDU>
Subject:      Re: What is a standing paragraph?
In-Reply-To:  <001001c30a9b$d6995ed0$9caa5bd1@satellite>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

You might look at George Lakoff's work on radial categories, and Bruce
Hawkin's articles applying those ideas to grammar. Lakoff argues (I think
convincingly) that categories aren't neat and tidy in the way your question
suggests, that they radiate outward from a typical case prototype evincing
certain central tendencies. Perhaps a more fruitful question would be what
are the central tendencies of the things folks commonly call paragraphs. I
don't think "division" is necessarily the defining trait of the paragraph.

Best,
Joseph

              painter Michael Cajero; plus Hollo talk Friday afternoon

REMINDER:

POG

presents
poet Anselm Hollo and painter Michael Cajero
Saturday, April 26, 7pm
Dinnerware Gallery, 135 East Congress
Admission: $5; Students $3

Additional Event: “Innovative Poetry: Life Outside the Box,” a talk by
Anselm Hollo followed by discussion: Friday, April 25, 2pm, UA English
Department, Modern Languages Building 451; this event is free and open to
the public.  (For directions, or advice about parking, phone POG at 615-7803
or email pog@gopog.org.)  Co-sponsored by Arizona Quarterly and the UA
Poetry Center.

Anselm Hollo was born in Helsinki, Finland, and was educated there and in
the U.S. In his early twenties, he left Finland to live and work as a writer
and translator, first in Germany and Austria, then in London, where he was
employed by the BBC's European Services in their Finnish Program from 1958
to 1967. Translations into Finnish from that time include Allen Ginsberg's
Howl and John Lennon's In His Own Write.
For the last thirty years, Hollo has lived in the United States, teaching
creative writing and literary translation at numerous colleges and
universities, including SUNY Buffalo, The University of Iowa, and The
University of Colorado. He is now Associate Professor in the Graduate
Writing and Poetics Department at The Naropa Institute.
Hollo has published more than thirty-five books and chapbooks, most recently
Corvus (Coffee House Press, 1995) and AHOE (Smokeproof Press, 1997). He has
also translated many contemporary Finnish poets, among them Paavo Haavikko
and Pentti Saarikoski, as well as fiction, plays, and poetry from the
German, French, Swedish, and Finnish.
Hollo's honors and awards include the New York State Creative Artists'
Public Service Award (1976), a National Endowment for the Arts Poet's
Fellowship (1979), the P.E.N./American-Scandinavian Foundation Award for
Poetry in Translation (1981), the American-Scandinavian Foundation Award for
Poetry in Translation (1989), Fund for Poetry Awards for Contributions to
Contemporary Poetry (1989, 1991), The Finnish Government Prize for
Translation of Finnish Literature (1996), and a Gertrude Stein Award in
Innovative American Poetry 1995-1996 (1996).
(excerpted from http://www.cyberpoems.com/abtans-h.html)

Michael Cajero. It was back in grad school, at Kent State University,
thatCajero first came under the spell of the ephemeral. He had been doing
regular two-dimensional paintings, applying pigment to the flat surfaces of
cloth or paper, when he started hearing about process art and arte povera.
These two schools emphasized what Cajero calls the "physicality of
materials" and "raw forms," giving equal value to such highly prized media
as oils and marble and mass-marketed goods. Cajero started experimenting
with junk materials designed not to last--masking tape and cheap wrapping
paper and newsprint. He twisted them into sculptural forms and spattered
them with paint.

After picking up a master's in painting, sculpture and art history, Cajero
came back home to his native Tucson. Immersed once again in the folkloric
imagery of the Hispanic Southwest, he began to see that the materials of
arte povera would make a perfect marriage with the icons of Mexican folk
art. Mexican artists of necessity have long used cheap, transitory materials
for their works--bread, sugar, clay--and Cajero mimicked this practice by
using paper and tape to make Mexicanesque skeletons and dancers and
musicians. Over the years Cajero, who teaches regularly at Pima College, the
Tucson Museum of Art and the UA, has taken these folkloric figures into new
territory. In 1992, the 500th-year anniversary of Columbus' arrival in the
New World, Cajero filled an entire room in the University of Arizona Museum
of Art with giant "light altars" chronicling the disasters of the Spanish
Conquest.
(excerpted from http://www.tucsonweekly.com/tw/1999-09-09/review.html)

POG events are sponsored in part by grants from the Tucson/Pima Arts
Council, the Arizona Commission on the Arts, and the National Endowment for
the Arts.  POG also benefits from the continuing support of The University
of Arizona Poetry Center, the Arizona Quarterly, Chax Press, and The
University of Arizona Department of English.  We also thank the following
POG donors: Patrons Roberta Howard, Tenney Nathanson, Liisa Phillips, Austin
Publicover, and Frances Sjoberg; Sponsors Barbara Allen, Chax Press, Alison
Deming, Elizabeth Landry, Stefanie Marlis, Stuart and Nancy Mellan, Sheila
Murphy Associates, and Tim Peterson.

for further information contact POG: 615-7803; mailto:pog@gopog.org;
www.gopog.org

TRACY GRINNELL & PAUL FOSTER JOHNSON reading from a collaborative work
and music from THE ROBBERS and WAKING VISION

Joe Diebes creates works that converge around the categories of concert
music, sound installation, and conceptual art. Recent works include his
opera, Strange Birds, and presence, a sixteen channel music installation for
a phantom chamber orchestra.

Tracy Grinnell is the author of music or forgetting (O Books, 2001). She
lives in Brooklyn and edits Litmus Press and Aufgabe, a journal of new
poetry. Paul Foster Johnson received his MFA from Brown University in 2001.
His work has appeared in a number of poetry journals, including Aufgabe,
Conundrum, Washington Square Journal, and Pom2.

Waking Vision are John Shannon (twelve-string guitar, voice), Peter
Stoltzman (keyboards), Mitch Cohn (bass), and Martin Valihora (drums and
percussion).

The Robbers' CD, OrphanEndorphinDolphinDorsalFin, was released last year.

MONDAY APRIL 28 [8:00pm]
MARIANA RUIZ FIRMAT AND CHRIS MARTIN
Mariana Ruiz Firmat is orginally from Southern California. Her poems have
appeared in Tool, 6x6, and Poep.

Chris Martin, formerly of San Francisco and St. Paul, now resides in
Brooklyn. He is the co-editor of Puppy Flowers, an online journal, and Bench
Press Books. His recent work can be found or is forthcoming in Lungfull!,
Old Gold, Pom2, Swerve, Fuori, Den Del's Devil's Gate Auto Repair Magazine,
Cypress Magazine and Accurate Key. A collaboration with kari edwards, Gross
Exaggerations, has been published as an ebook by Xpress. A book of love
poems co-authored by Caroline Miller, This Is Going to Be a Long Courtship,
is forthcoming from singlepress.

WEDNESDAY APRIL 30 [8:00pm]
ELAINE EQUI AND SPECIAL GUEST
Elaine Equi's newest collection of poems is The Cloud of Knowable Things
from Coffee House Press. Other books include Surface Tension, Decoy, and
Voice-Over which won the San Francisco State Poetry Award. She teaches at
NYU and in the graduate writing programs at City College and The New School.
Robert Creeley writing on The Cloud of Knowable Things says, "These
deceptively forthright poems prove fabliaux of unique kind. Their collective
story is not only that of this rare and accomplished poet, but of the
echoing life we share with her - and see here, through her immaculate eye,
with wistful and enduring clarity."

Plus special guest, details to follow early next week.

***

POETS FOR PEACE

Poets for Peace invites all poets to read poems against the war on Friday
April 25 and Thursday May 1 from 1-3pm on the steps of the main branch of
The New York Public Library (at 42nd St and 5th Ave) near the southmost
lion. All are invited to attend and read from their own or others' anti-war
poems. Rain or shine. Look for the "Poets for Peace" banner.

For more info: www.poetsagainstthewar.org

***

Unless otherwise noted, admission to all events is $10, $7 for students and
seniors, and $5 for Poetry Project members. Schedule is subject to change.

The Poetry Project is located in St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery at 131 E.
10th Street, on the corner of 2nd Avenue in Manhattan. Trains: 6, F, N, R,
and L.

The Poetry Project is wheelchair accessible with assistance and advance
notice. Please call (212) 674-0910 for more information, or e-mail us at
poproj@poetryproject.com.

Announcing the second issue of 26, a journal of poetry
and poetics. This issue of 26 is organized around,
among other things, current notions and
conceptualizations regarding the “lyric.”

26: b contains poems by Dale Smith, Gillian Conoley,
Maria Rivera (trans. from Spanish by Jen Hofer),
Carmen Gimenez-Rosello, Sarah Veglahn, Steven
Hemenway, Angelica Tornero (trans. from Spanish by Jen
Hofer), Bob Harrison, Rick London, Jeanne Heuving,
Paige Menton, Brent Cunningham, Geraldine Monk, Stacy
Szymaszek, Jim Peterson, Karl Krolow (trans. from
German by Maxine Chernoff), Joseph Kolb, Adriano
Spatola (trans. from Italian by Paul Vangelisti),
Elizabeth Treadwell, Dan Featherston, Anne Shaw, Hoa
Nguyen, Sawako Nakayasu, Vera Linhartova (trans. from
French by Keith Waldrop), Jen Hofer, Nicole Brossard
(trans. from French by Robert Majzels & Erin Moure),
Jean Day, Beth Anderson, David Miller, Peter Gurnis,
Valerie Coulton & Ed Smallfield.

In addition there are essays and reviews, by Lewis
Ellingham & Kevin Killian “She is the She of the Next
Sentence: Bobby Lennon and the Berkeley Renaissance”,
Mark DuCharme “Radial Lyricality”, Hoa Nguyen “State
of the Lyric”, Tiff Dressen “Pronouns: More than
Substitutes”, Kristina Krause “The Left Hand of
Parenthesis”, Julia Bloch “Aidan Thompson’s Particle
and Probability” and Laura Moriarty “Poetics of
Distribution”.

Selections from issue “a” are on-line at
www.26magazine.com.  Selections from issue “b” will be
available soon.

26 is co-edited by Avery E. D. Burns, Rusty Morrison,
Joseph Noble, Elizabeth Robinson & Brian Strang.

Cover Price is $10. Subscriptions are also available
for $10yr and checks should be made out to -
St. Mary's College, 26.

Copies are available through Small Press Distribution.

Geez, I wish this were true. I mean, the part about older poets taking
risks certainly is, often moreso than younger poets. Bly of course has
never taken a risk in his life, but that's another matter. What I wish were
true is the connection between political conservativism and creative
stagnation. Lots of examples to the contrary, but  Celine will do for now.

Mark


>I've been thinking about how Bly's most recent book, "The Night Abraham
>Called to the Stars" displays how this leaping process works in a mature
>poet. It's amazing how many risks he is willing to take. It shows how older
>poets can be as evocative as younger poets, that creative abilities only
>wither if we let them. And this goes to the whole range of one's life. So
>that if a poet becomes politically conservative, for example, it will also
>stagnant one's willingness to take risks with the poems. This applies to all
>creative work, all the arts and sciences. I think you're addressing
>creativity not just poety.
>
>-Joel W.

Date:         Fri, 25 Apr 2003 00:50:11 +0000
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         michael helsem <graywyvern@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Re: What is a standing paragraph?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

>From: Derek R <derek@DEREKROGERSON.COM>
      (snip)
>My understanding of paragraph is 'to divide or arrange,' so that, a
>paragraph (by definition) cannot exist as a singular entity, but
>requires plurality to exist (i.e. the act of division, to divide).
>
>A paragraph, then, would appear to be similar to 'article,' in that
>there must be 'one of several' in order for proper (definitive)
>existence.
>
>** So then, what definitively is called a single item of text, of which
>there is no more and none before? **
>

well, a window is divided into "panes", & if a window is just
made up of a single pane you don't say it is paneless.

if a novel were composed of one gigantic paragraph the fact
would be noted in so many words (& such have probably been
written, i imagine). you could say "it's not divided into
paragraphs" as well.

there are plenty of "single paragraph" stories in the genre
known as "sudden fiction". and many prose poems have that
same construction, & are not miscalled "paragraphs".

some of us are apt to notice the resemblance between this &
the classic koan of clapping.

but (& i have to explain these to ESOL students every week) the
subject of articles in English has never been satisfactorily
explained, & is unlikely to ever be--for English is a non-linear
language.

that way lies madness...

m.

---------------------------------------------
ALLAH BLESS AMERICA.

Subject:      Re: What is a standing paragraph?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

>that way lies madness...<

or: that way madness lies (!)


living in King Lear's capital, as in, 'Hie we then to Leicester' I am
acutely aware of insanity, when I walk by the local river and ponder where
he and Cordelia and Richard the Third all lie buried I often reflect on
these issues, to no result ever. As for standing paragraphs, it depends how
much they've had to drink, I think, ouch, sorry for the rhyme, I've
definitely seen them falling over in bars at the end of the night.

Wink!

Best

Dave





David Bircumshaw

Leicester, England

Home Page

A Chide's Alphabet

Painting Without Numbers

http://homepage.ntlworld.com/david.bircumshaw/index.htm

Subject:      Re: What is a standing paragraph?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

> The phrase, or the sentence is complete unto itself in poetry.  See Ron
> Silliman's "The New Sentence."

that's an outstanding paragraph...

the sentence might answer this quandry.  the simple definition is that it
expresses a complete thot.  but then the sentence is divisible as well into
words, and words into letters, and letters into lines and curves and bears
oh my.

but seriously, paragraph seems to suggest a singular multiplicity; a span of
language.  the fact it can be named means it exists, at least on the level
of nomenclature, as a fixed whole.

**So then, what definitively is called a single item of text, of which there
is no more and none before?**

that depends on the larger system used to lock the text the single item is
being removed from, i.e. the alphabet is composed of letters, the sentence
is dependent on words as a subunit, a paragraph requires sentences, I should
probably be sleeping, etc...

this email is a fixed item of text as soon as I'm finished typing it.  sure
it can be altered and changed, but to do so requires that it existed in the
first place.  Das ding en Sict...

didn't flaubert dream of the perfect novel as a composition dependent
entirely on its own logic, built solely from itself with no reference to any
outside reality?

and then there's politics and context, cultural moments, and what the gravy
is made with at my work (i'm convinced they sell mushroom gravy as beef...).

jc

yardpress
Englush Department
University of Calgary

www.angelfire.com/poetry/jasonchristie
http://thinfragilair.blogspot.com
www.ucalgary.ca/~cwh

"get in, get out.  leave no context."

Gabriel,
This looks to be, on the face of it, a very expensive and lucrative
scholarship fund for Bush administration supporters' kids and educational
facility directors, administrators, presidents, and the corporations
affiliated with them.

Interesting...  I guess that if I had just a bit more time and courage, I
would submit hundreds or thousands of serious applications on the part of
_______, or maybe from ________ here, and surely members of congress as well
as prime CEO's or execs from not-so-nice companies, or "bashers" (jerks on
stock forums like Yahoo Finance and Lycos Raging Bull, in some cases paid by
hedge funds and boiler rooms who talk trash and tell lies about stocks in
order to get naive and "newbie" investors/traders to panic and sell their
shares on otherwise temporal downtrends so that they can pick up the shares
cheaply or cover short positions with greater profits).  Anyway, give the
ORAU arm of the Homeland Security Department plenty enough applicants to
keep their screening committee busy.

Then again, though, isn't all of that money for these great monthly stipends
(none for English, Philosophy, Humanities, or Languages students) coming out
of federal tax dollars.  Hmmm.

ORAU is, apparently, Oak Ridge Associated Universities, a "consortium of 86
colleges and universities that  promotes and manages partnerships between
member universities, industry and the Department of Energy."  www.orau.org
The vast majority of the colleges are southern, presumably more
heavily-weighted with evangelicals and the right-wing's voting constituency.
http://www.orau.org/academic/members/membersalpha.htm

I suspect it wouldn't be difficult to find out who (or what department)
corresponds with dhsed.  http://www.orau.gov/dhsed/grad.htm  and
dhsed@orau.gov <mailto:dhsed@orau.gov>.

Probably wouldn't be a bad idea to query any major newspapers like the NY
Times or the Washington Post.  They may have folks interested in taking
advantage of these great opportunies or getting their kids into the program
for free educations.  Yep.
Or Poets-against-the-war, they may want to encourage members to apply.
Looks like a good opportunity to me.  Never hurts to try and try and try.
And maybe with a little bit of pressure, the Dept. of Homeland Security
could open these taxpayers' national security educational program and "free"
scholarships to students enrolled in colleges in California, which along
with most of the west looks rather under-represented:
http://www.orau.org/academic/members/members.htm.  Umm, come to think of it,
most of the Northeast colleges and their students appear to be ineligible
for these opportunities, also.  Geesh, that's almost illegal or
discriminatory, isn't it?
Yeah, the more I look into this, the more I get the impression that a lot of
folks are being left out and, frankly, I paid my taxes (didn't make enough
last year to get any tax breaks).  Is this program fair?
Ummm, damn.
Steve Tills



Microcomputer/Software Specialist
MIS Dept.- G.W. Lisk Company, Inc.

Operation binoculars=20

The shortly after September 11, I should have awaked me American. The
metamorphosis did not have anything of surprising. It arrived! In Paris.
In Copenhagen. In Ankara... Alchemy of the loan to be carried. But me?
To find me in my bed, similar with the day before, had what to worry the
neighbors. I touched myself. What arrives? What arrives to us? However,
I looked at television. Like everyone. I did not take down a settee.
Like everyone. And like everyone, I did not believe my eyes of them.
Impossible! Impossible! The film passed and passed by again. Without
stop. The advertising page jumped. Deferred series. Not question of
fiction. Documentary incredible. INOUI! It is the direct one. In my
agitated sleep, it passed to the idle. The two binoculars subsided on my
chest. I started. I relit television. That started again. By interval,
the camera angle changed. I was sounded by the catastrophe. The images
ate me the glance. Diabolic puffs raised me the heart. What arrives to
me?=20

I test difficulties of finding the formula for saying what occurs.
Analyses abound. With carries part. The words do not miss. And of the
neologisms. The newspapers provide us each day of it. The metamorphosis
developed. And me? Despite everything my efforts and a goodwill with the
top of any suspicion. But perhaps had I unconscious reserves to
cooperate. That requires a thorough examination.=20

The third day, I p=E9t=E9 leads. Name of God! My cranium bursts. Inside, =
it
is a pulp. It is necessary that that ceases! Move yourself! I =
trifouill=E9
the meter with a nail-clippers. Clac! Roasted the cathode ray tube. I
rub the hands. I did not metamorphose myself but I acquired
mischievousness. It is perhaps frustration not to be American like
everyone. That taps me. The pile of newspapers to the dustbin. I would
never have time to read... What a relief!=20
I became insane. To bind.=20
As this character of Gogol which loses its nose while crossing the
street. Fortunately, I had a strong cold. A respite...=20
- Now that the tele one is ruined, you are satisfied! me engueule it.
With what that does advance you? If you are not rotten to even make the
share of the things!... I warn you: you repair it or you buy another of
them! And fissa!=20
...=20
The lexicon is treacherous... One can say what one wants. But when you
do not awake like everyone, there is what to be alarmed. It is much more
serious. The neighbor of stage does not say any more hello. They all are
there in front of, to await the elevator; and you, you take the
backstairs. What changed? How to know? You broke the tele one... There
is average, the radio functions. The emissions are more intelligent. The
voice does not puff out the brain like the image.=20
I calm myself. I do not include/understand what is told. It is not with
me that one speaks. Return to me the words of a reader: "It is your
language. But you do not write the language of yours. In addition, you
live outside! How thus think you of contributing to an unspecified
national avant-garde?" A little brutal, hypocritical reader ...=20
"the avant-garde, told me If Nacer, these were six gray sheep that one
renewed with each crossing of the Maurice line. Bigeard had discovered
the trick. During the operation binoculars, it sent shepherds as a scout
systematically.   "... I often thought of this thin herd. No monument
celebrates their sacrifice with the fatherland. Very early, this
anecdote sowed suspicion in my spirit.=20
However, I made the barricades!=20
It is Stratis the sailor who saved me drowning. It trailed me with a bar
of the Bastille. To speak, one is better. The salted almonds untie the
language. Of goal in white: "Then? Does the policy, that really interest
you?... The praxis? Of course! But this deserted policy public places.
The ra=EF makes fury. Drop all that. You are conspicuous. And a man of =
the
past! You, you do not require that clogged companions attach you to a
mast to listen to the song of the sirens...=20
By bits. Glanant per Ci. Jumping by there. Advancing straight. Turning
over me. Forking. Fragmentation of the thought. That turns in round.=20
"This sudden passion is equivocal", said Kateb. With Malek, we looked it
with recognition. Something in the intonation. We were alone to seize
the nuance. That put balsam in the heart to us. But here is an
inaccessible event. I did not find words to transmit it. Not facts. In
oneself, without interest. But magic of the situation. Kateb, if
worthy...=20
_ this order me ravit. Thank you, unknown friends, to have made me sign.
Thank you in you, Pierre, to have communicated my address... It said in
the mouth of the wolf . Eh, well? Where is the need? It is always a
question of form.=20
S=E9nac, cut out holes in its books to him. "With time, the world, one
carries it inside oneself. One has very few words to make fly." I
represent our discussion. Because the body was not there any more. The
revolution abhorred its stripped plaster boards of management. Which
fault made voiceless our following days?=20
I learned how to work. With me to conceal. The poet must be erased.=20
Not to choke the poem.=20
What arrives? One spends time to see it. More one supplement to realize
some. Baghdad was shaven. Grenade fell. And Jerusalem  ? The dates run
up against the wickets. Rotted pot of the memory... Since the beginning,
the Arabs remember a radiant future hopelessly. To two range of arc.
This great nation resulting from the son of the maidservant is made type
on the fingers. And that lasts. Is this genetic? How all that programmed
is? Too much, it too is!=20
The friends die in a number. Also those die which I do not know. To

From:         kari edwards <terra1@SONIC.NET>
Subject:      San Francisco Chronicle fires a technology reporter for
              protesting war
In-Reply-To:  <Law10-OE32pkeAQMe6E000002e1@hotmail.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v552)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

By Chris Gaither, Globe Staff, 4/24/2003

SAN FRANCISCO - The San Francisco Chronicle fired
Henry Norr, one of its technology reporters, one
month after suspending him for taking a day off
from work to protest the war in Iraq.

Norr, 57, was one of about 1,400 protesters
arrested here on March 20, the day after American
bombs began falling on Baghdad. The four-year
veteran of the Chronicle spent the day in jail,
along with his wife and 25-year-old daughter.
Each was charged with being a pedestrian in the
road, for blocking traffic.

Though the paper dismissed Norr for improperly
claiming sick leave that day, his situation also
illustrates the difficulty in balancing
journalists' desire to express their political
views and news organizations' desire to appear
objective to their audiences.

Aly Colon, an ethics professor with the Poynter
Institute, a journalism school in St. Petersburg,
Fla., said he found it ''ironic'' that
newspapers, often watchdogs for the right to free
speech, sometimes act against employees for
expressing their views outside of work. He
questioned whether terminating Norr was the best
solution, but said the Chronicle must protect its
credibility.

''When individuals stand for something that
causes people to question whether they can be
fair in what they do, something has to be done to
address that,'' Colon said.

Norr said he never hid his arrest from his
bosses. He said he sent e-mail to his editors,
late on the eve of the protests, telling them of
his intention to be arrested. He also asked for a
month's leave earlier in March to devote all his
time to protesting - a request that he said went
unanswered.

Yet when he filled out his timecard on March 21,
he marked the missed time as a sick day. He said
he regrets having done that, rather than putting
in for a vacation day. But he said he never hid
his reasons for missing work, and that his
manager signed the card the following Monday, two
days before his suspension.

''If they had a column on the timecard for `jail
day,' I would have put that,'' he said in an
interview yesterday.

The Chronicle pulled Norr's next column, about
technology that prevents unwanted e-mail, before
publication, then suspended him on March 26. The
paper fired him this week.

Representatives of the Chronicle, owned by Hearst
Corp., declined to comment, saying they do not
discuss personnel issues.

In a termination letter sent to Norr late Monday,
Chronicle editor Phil Bronstein cited the
''falsification'' of Norr's timecard and ''an
improper claim for paid sick leave'' as
sufficient grounds for dismissal. ''Your personal
political activities are no excuse to permit a
false claim,'' Bronstein wrote.

But he suggested that Norr's political activities
played a role in the decision to fire him. While
on unpaid leave, Norr was arrested and hit with
wooden pellets fired by police in other protests
around the Bay Area, actions that Bronstein
called ''persistent violations'' of the
newspaper's ethics policies.

''Even if you had not claimed a paid workday, we
would not permit you to return to work in the
Chronicle newsroom,'' Bronstein wrote. ''To do so
would irreparably compromise our journalistic
standards and the expectations we have for
everyone in the newsroom.''

Norr, however, said his protests violated none of
the Chronicle's ethics policies at the time.
Since his suspension, the newspaper has amended
its policies to explicitly prohibit antiwar
protests by its staff members.

The local newspaper union, the Northern
California Media Workers Guild, has filed
grievances against the newspaper for the
suspension, the termination, and the changes to
the Chronicle's ethics policy.

Norr is due in court today. He has not yet
entered a plea. The charge against his daughter
has been dismissed; his wife is awaiting a court
appearance.

Chris Gaither can be reached at
gaither@globe.com.

This story ran on page E4 of the Boston Globe on
4/24/2003.
=A9 Copyright 2003 Globe Newspaper Company.

> Geez, I wish this were true. I mean, the part about older poets taking
> risks certainly is, often moreso than younger poets. Bly of course has
> never taken a risk in his life, but that's another matter. What I wish
were
> true is the connection between political conservativism and creative
> stagnation. Lots of examples to the contrary, but  Celine will do for now.
>
> Mark
>

Anyone familiar with Robert Bly's life, poetry, theories, and political
activities over the past forty years, I suggest would find your contention
that he "has never taken a risk in his life" to be an arrogant, ignorant
remark.

As for the connection between political conservatism and creative
stagnation, it was more inspired than factual, more about connecting the way
one writes to one's awareness of how the world interconnects. I would choose
Wallace Stevens, to refute myself. I hope some scholars here will be moved
take up the question as to how one's politics effects, or doesn't effect,
the range of one's poetry.

-Joel W.

[English to German to French to English]

The Collar
         -- by George Herbert

I the advice struck and cried, no more.
                 I abroad.
         What? Sigh and pin of I never?
My lines and lives are free; freely as road!
       release as large wind therefore like the shop.
       Is it that I must always be in the clothes?
        Don't I have harvest, but a thorn?
         Let not restore my blood and
which I lost with the cordial fruit.
                 Reliably there was wine
before my sighs dried it: it was there from the corn
         before my tears drowned it.
Is the year lost only at me?
         Don't I have departments to crown?
No flowers, no merry country? all blew?
         Did everything waste?
     Not also my heart: but there are fruit
                 and branches to be handed around.
      The whole age sighs and winds accumulate
         again on double delights: leave the cold conflict
             from what is not adapted.
         The rope of the sand places a cage on it,
which the small thoughts made and made at the good cable of thee,
                 in order to force upon and draw on thy lawn
while thou didst from the eye flashes and wouldst there be blinded,
         Far; Seizing attention:
         I abroad.
The calls in death's brain steer themselves there: fasten thy fears!
They serve themselves over and over for their own, and its, need:
         its load earns.
But, while I developed and my rickets-having savages smile
         at each word,
and so I of the thoughts was brought a calling: a child!
         And I answered, belonging,
         "My gentleman."

Thanks, Hal. I'll amend: Bly found a manner a long time ago.

I've always found him superficial, and his poetry, post-Machado, Neruda,
etc., usually decorative at best.

But sometimes not.  I think it was in 1969 that I heard him read at Barnard
College a poem that was then one of his signature pieces--I can't remember
what it was called, and I don't have time to try to dig it out of my
disorganized library. The protagonist, explicitly meant to be himself,
discovers, while walking along the beach after the Santa Barbara oil spill,
a dying sea lion. Every day for a week he goes back to check on its agony.
On the seventh day he finds it dead and the sky of the poem opens into a
Wordsworthian moment.  It wasn't hard to agree with the sentiments, but it
seemed a bit strange to be told by the poet what a nice, sensitive guy he
is when he should clearly either have called the SPCA or put the animal out
of its misery himself.  Of course it would have been a shorter poem.

So there was the morality pretended to and the morality rendered dishonest
by a cloud of narcissism.

I don't, and didn't, trust the poems.

I've used up my message quota for the day--any potshots will have to remain
unanswered.

Mark

From:         michael helsem <graywyvern@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Re: What is a standing paragraph?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

>From: Brennen Lukas <blukas@COX.NET>
      (snip)
>Could someone elaborate on this idea? I'd like to be edified.

the same articles "a" & "the" are used to mark two unrelated
distinctions of definite/indefinite, & first mention/already
mentioned, as well as special uses which indicate typical, &
the title of something. (this is off the top of my head, &
probably not exhaustive). only a familiarity with the vast
amount of common contexts can teach which article to use on
which occasion, as there is no set of hard-&-fast rules in
English (unlike most every other language in this situation).
newcomers usually hit upon a set of conventions that can
be used to translate what their own language does into
something that is at least recognizable as English. but
people who have been fluent in English as a second language
even for ten years, still make this kind of mistake occasionally.

m.

ALLAH BLESS AMERICA.

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

> I guess that means we disagree. And I imagine that everyone who disagrees
> with you is arrogant and ignorant.

Sorry Mark. Bly's an old friend, and my reaction to your put-down was from
the gut. Probably no one has introduced so many poets from around the world
to US readers as he's been doing since his The Fifties journal. I also find
his latest book, as I read deeper into it, quite astounding for their energy
and erudition. The work does resound with  poems he's been writing for many
decades; however, I suggest they've reached a maturity here, which I find
exciting.

>
> For the record, for the most part I stopped following Bly's career after
he
> started banging on drums.

That was a stage. Silly, maybe. He has always felt that poets have a social
responsibility, and the men's groups were a way to promote poetry in a more
intimate format than giving readings. They were a way of integrating poetry
into the psychic life of non-poets. Drumming it in, so to speak.

> Bly found a manner very young and rode it to death. The risks I referred
to
> are aesthetic risks, and they have been scant.

The problem with finding "a manner" when young and sticking with it is an
important issue. While many painters, for example, have distinct "periods"
they go through as they develop, most poets don't. I don't know why. Perhaps
we can discuss this?

Best,
Joel W.

collection of essays on idiolect, contact theory, and healing quest in
poetics of the Americas.

Reply-To:     info@whiteboxny.org, info@whiteboxny.org
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
