Comments:     Originally-From: WHITE BOX <info@whiteboxny.org>
From:         Poetics List Administration <poetics@BUFFALO.EDU>
Organization: WHITE BOX
Subject:      Woman on Woman Opens Thursday, May 1st 6-8 pm
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  WOMAN ON WOMAN
May 1 - May 24, 2003
Opening reception: Thursday, May 1st, 2003 6-8 pm

Curated by Claire Jervert

Delia Brown / Kathleen Gilje / Julie Heffernan / Sissel Kardel /
Alexis Karl / Joan Semmel / Su-en Wong / Lisa Yuskavage

White Box is pleased to present Woman On Woman, a group exhibition of
work that looks at the surprisingly under-explored territory of
contemporary women painters who are creating images of the nude female
body, both their own and others. While the work of female photographers
who are working along similar lines has recently been extensively
examined, this will be the first survey of the remarkable range of work
being created by women who's subject is women.

Lisa Yuskavage is represented by a groundbreaking work from the early
'90s, one of her earliest oils depicting the female body. Delia Brown's
paintings of wealthy young women sensuously enjoying themselves include
representations of herself. An ethereal delicacy infuses Sissel Kardel's
fairytale-like renderings of women in nature.  Utilizing an old master
technique, Julie Heffernan employs her self-image, placing it in
allegorical settings that elude explication.  Alexis Karl paints nude
portraits of close friends juxtaposed against monochrome backgrounds
often holding objects that carry particular symbolic meanings.  Su-en
Wong's self-representations reveal the contradictions and tensions
inherent in her life as a young artist in the US and her Asian cultural
heritage.  Old master paintings are re-imagined from a contemporary
perspective in the work of Kathleen Gilje, who here removes the
elaborate, restrictive period clothing to reveal both the flesh beneath
and the inherent psychological complexity of the sitter. Finally, Joan
Semmel is represented by some of her pioneering work from the 1970's,
images of her body painted from her own point of view as she gazes down
upon it, work that looks astonishingly contemporary and fresh.

A panel discussion will take place Wednesday, May 7th, at 7:30.
Panelists include Grady T. Turner, Joan Semmel, Sissel Kardel, and Su-en
Wong. Woman On Woman will be the subject of a White Box catalogue with
essays by Grady T. Turner, Ana Finel Honigman and Manon Slome.

Viewing hours: Tuesday-Saturday 11am - 6pm.

WHITE BOX
525 WEST 26TH STREET
NEW YORK, NY 10001
Tel 212-714-2347
www.whiteboxny.org

White Box is a 501[c][3] not-for-profit arts organization.

Date:         Sat, 26 Apr 2003 00:11:44 -0400
Reply-To:     adlevy@slought.org
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Aaron Levy <adlevy@SLOUGHT.ORG>
Organization: Slought Foundation
Subject:      Seven Veils at Slought Foundation; May 15-16, 2003
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Slought Foundation, in conjunction with Chain Arts, is pleased to
announce the premier of "SEVEN VEILS (Poetry in Moving Media)," a
multimedia dance-theater piece based on an adaptation of "Salome" by
Thalia Field (Point and Line, New Directions 2000). Innovative choral
music composed by Philadelphia-based Alexander DeVaron provides a
complex and often humorous sonic atmosphere for Jamie Jewett's quirky
amalgam of release, butoh and contemporary indonesian dance styles.


SEVEN VEILS (A Night of Poetry in Moving Media)
By Thalia Field, Jamie Jewett, Alexander Devaron

May 15, 2003 - May 16, 2003
8:00 pm - 10:00 pm

Event location: Slought Foundation, Philadelphia
Event fee: $7.00 ($5 w/ Student ID). Reservation not required.

Event Series curated by Jena Osman with Aaron Levy

Full information and biographies available online:
http://slought.org/toc/calendar/display.php?key=dimensional




Slought Foundation, Philadelphia encourages new futures for contemporary
life through art and theory. "Dimensional Text" is an event series
collaboration between Chain Arts and Slought Foundation. The dimensional
text series is an investigation into the ways that language can be
presented off the page. It presents language work that steps away from
the book, the podium, the conventional reading or performance.

For more information about Slought Foundation or SEVEN VEILS,
contact Aaron Levy:

SLOUGHT FOUNDATION
4017 Walnut Street
Philadelphia, PA 19104-3513
Phone/fax: 215 746 4239
http://slought.org
info@slought.org



Biographies:

Thalia Field's collection, POINT AND LINE, was published in 2000 by New
Directions. Her second book, INCARNATE: STORY MATERIAL is forthcoming
with New Directions in 2004 and a multimedia novel, ULULU (SHRAPNEL
SCENES), with film stills by Bill Morrison, is forthcoming from Coffee
House Press in 2005. Thalia's performance writing and essays have been
published in Theater magazine and she was a Senior Editor for several
years at Conjunctions where she guest-edited an issue (#28) devoted to
experimental music-theater. Thalia has taught at Bard College, Naropa
University and currently teaches in Brown's Creative Writing program. In
1998 she co-founded the Summer Writing and Performance Project at
Perseverance Theater in Juneau, AK.

Jamie Jewett holds a BA in Movement and Buddhist Studies from Naropa
University and an MFA in Dance and Technology from the Ohio State
University. His dance background includes intensive study of Butoh, and
he has performed at the Joyce Theatre as a company member of Popo and
The Go Go Boys, as well as works by Bebe Miller, David Rousseve and
others. A certified teacher of the Shambhala Dharma Arts, Jewett's work
is deeply influenced by Eastern philosophy of composition. In 2000,
Jewett was awarded a grant from USINDO (the US Indonesian Foundation) to
apprentice with Suprapto Suryodarmo, a contemporary Indonesian Master of
dance, ritual performance and installation art. Through this
relationship, Jewett has taught and performed at a variety of festivals
in Java, Bali, New York and Boulder. Jewett's intermedia dance,
"Snowblind", was commissioned by University of Michigan's IMMEDIA
festival in 2002 and his dance-film, "Auslander", was selected as part
of Lincoln Center's Danc!
 e on Camera festival and the Wexner Center's Ohio Film and Video
Festival.

Alexander deVaron holds degrees from Connecticut Wesleyan University and
Indiana University, where his teachers included Alvin Lucier, Richard
Winslow, Eugene Brien, and David Dzubay. His works have been performed
In Canada, Europe and throughout the United States. He is the 2003
winner of the Network For New Music Poetry Project competition, and his
music has been featured by such ensembles as the Tufts New Music
Ensemble, the Seattle New Music Ensemble and the New England
Conservatory Cammerata. Over the last twenty years, Mr. deVaron has
combined his study of music with the study of Buddhism and meditation.
Over the course of these years, he has worked closely with the composer
Peter Lieberson to explore the meeting place of these two traditions.
Currently he is pursuing a doctoral degree at Temple University, where
he studies with Maurice Wright and Richard Brodhead.


Cast:

Sara Vasiliou, Dancer. Laurissa Backlin, Soprano. Gabrielle Rosse, Alto.
Carlos Tovar, Tenor. Cailin Manson, Bass. Stage chorus: Deborah
Richards, Kamili Feelings. Stage manager: Patrick Scanlon. Lighting

Poetry Reading:

Akira Tatehata

on the occasion of the publication of his selected poems in English
translation

Runners in the Margins
(A Press: Middletown Springs, Vermont)


 $B!H (BThe power of Japanese poetry since World War Two lies in the creative
ferocity & precision of what one of its practitioners called  $B!F (Ba return
to totality in poetry. $B!G (B To the ranks of those who have moved Japan into
the mainstream of international poetry, we can now add Tatehata Akira &
can place him among those poets from Rimbaud to the present, who have
broken the spine of verse or chosen prose itself as a medium for poetry.
In Hiroaki Sato $B!G (Bs English versions, Tatehata appears as a major poet
with the ability to move clusters of language & perceptions into larger
assemblages -- a narrative that escapes from narrative, to create a
world that startles & so causes us to see. $B!I (B
Jerome Rothenberg

In Japan, Akira Tatehata is regarded as a highly accomplished and
influential critic of contemporary art. He is Professor of Modern
Japanese Art at Tama Art University, and this year has been Scholar in
Residence at Columbia University in New York.

Location:

ISE Cultural Foundation
555 Broadway, New York, NY 10012
Phone (212) 925-1649 FAX (212) 226-9362

Date: Friday, May 9th 6:30-7:30

Introduction by the translator, Hiroaki Sato
Poems read in Japanese by the poet, Akira Tatehata
English translations read by New York poet, George Quasha
Musical collaboration by Yusuke Yamamoto

i taught i taw

stars & stripes
logo on pick-up truck

the only ones
flying the flag

partying in his tiny

brand w/o end

From:         Kevin Magee <poetry@HYPOBOLOLEMAIOI.COM>
Subject:      Chantage
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

That was the text written during Afghanistan. What is different from
watching what can be watched of the war are questions, those questions
that are asked of the foreigner from the warring nation, framed in the
form of the search for a statement, as though there exist words that
might be stated capable of containing (in translation) "the wound in
the world" spoken in Chita in an English where the first syllable in
'topic' is pronounced with much the same sound as the word for 'earth'
in Chinese. Each room is different, and the question the same, about
the war, what about the war, the war my nation is making, when to say
that it is not my nation would fail to refer. How can you not be where
you come from? Here, in the space of this question, first Afghanistan,
and now Iraq, India and Pakistan, Palestine, mapped, in the name, by
the question that states the name, Iraq? Iran? Turkey?  Kurdistan?
English is the target language. That was the question in Yurga, not
the private question, when one of the English teachers asked that
question always asked, What do you think of the war? In the formal
space, the question substituting for the question about the war is the
question of language, the English language, the German language, the
Japanese language. These are the languages where technical knowledges
are stored. As these were the nations that were once at war. Futile to
answer that one is against the war, as impossible as to say any longer
'futile' as though it were only the word 'few' with 'tl' at the
end. Whether or not the loss of inflectional endings in English can be
attributed to the Scandinavian settlements in the north and the
corruptions that enter in second-language learning or the accent on
the root-morpheme inherited from the earlier Germanic forms. Both
would appear to have next to nothing to do with contemporary history,
'the history of our military and literary triumphs' (Victor Fournel,
1858 [A7a3]). No war was ever prevented by the protests of its
artists. The century of the wars, this century, and it is this that
can never be said to the question about the war, an accelerating
process the preparation for which has been said to have been the
occupation of Panama, that it is only the beginning of a much greater
cycle or process or period of time. Someone wrote in an article for
'The Commoner' about Kronstadt. Someone must still be made to take
responsibility for Kronstadt. Immanuel Wallerstein writes of a
Chinese-Japanese alliance. The paragraph about the imperial armies in
Empire failed to foresee the character of the present war, relying on
the appearance of agreements among nations, which are always
appeasement. Such sentences as these seem to slide away from their
language, their discourse, in the attempt to formulate a statement
when there is no statement that can be trusted by the poetic?

Two statements were written during Afghanistan, one for an essay
published in a small 'conference' magazine in Russia and translated
into Russian (it appeared also on the generation_online discussion
list, the url for which can be found at the Multitudes site), and the
other statement took shelter in a poem, or should it be said that the
statement only belongs to the poem, and one which passed by the eyes
of editors (BeeHive). The first statement is part of a thesis reading
Swift-as-Zizek:

"As William Langland, in his long poem called Piers Plowman, written
at the other end of the historical process where an agrarian economy
and society was transformed into the industrial and modern nation of
England, Swift is also asking, How can I see my time? The imaginary
figures in the work of giant and doll, professors in the clouds of
unknowing, and horses debating the extermination of Yahoos obscure
without obliterating the line of descent for this book from the
tradtion of the political tract as practiced by Milton in his essay,
On the Tenure of Kings and Magistrates. Swift's satire anticipates the
intellectual climate informing the emancipatory events in America and
France at the end of the eighteenth century and offers us a conceptual
optic for understanding why Zizek's reading of Kant, Hegel, Heidegger
and Lacan against the backdrop of popular culture in the West begins
with the refusal of the Cartesian 'cogito' to remain buried despite
the efforts of contemporary theoretical discourses in Europe and
America to declare the collapse of the Enlightenment horizon and the
transformation of subjectivity without any corresponding
transformation of the social and property relations theorized by
historical materialism. The task of recognizing the limits to
understanding from within the labor of contributing to changing the
world we live in is one of the social responsibilities documentary,
theoretical and imaginative writings share. Whether undertaken
collectively or individually, it should not be a labor of Sisyphus."
(Pacifist, p. 99).

From "Haystack/Tekct," Pacifist, p. 117: "Propositions are either
proven or unproven. Disproved. Disapproved. This is what a book is
isn't it, don't books codify perception, and the authority of them,
or, their authority, what is that authority, when laws that operate in
the language should also be said to operate on the language. The logic
in history does not appear in the appearance of the event, even if the
event cannot be known other than by its appearances. From its
appearance, why are there so many ways to say the same thing? The many
ways there are to make the event appear to correspond to the
operations of logic. Variability as condition, the experience of
reference as variable articulation, and the event, the military event,
the existence in history of the idea that war accelerates history by
intensifying contradictions and creating the conditions where the
question of state power will be posed according to the necessity of
imposing absolute powers, so that the decision by the state to use war
to resolve contradictions in the operation of the social and economic
order which the state is intended to sustain, and when it does not,
when it declares by its military policies that the only resolution to
internal and external conflicts are wars of aggression, then the
proposition that the state which uses war to invade and occupy weaker
countries declares to the civil society that it is no longer capable
of governing, and such a state must be opposed for the purpose of the
overturning of the powers which constitute that government."

These statements are entered into the historical record represented by
this archive to pressure the problem of whether what can be said in a
theoretical essay or a book of poems can also be stated in the
volatile, material-immaterial space of the electronic communication,
as well as to pressure the statement-bearing capacity of poetic itself.

"His book will have to renounce any ambition to political impact, as
this is understood today; in other words, it will have to give up all
hope of demagogic effect." (Walter Benjamin)

http://hypobololemaioi.com

Orbital Crossed-circuitry


Cordelia: Alack, 'tis he: why, he was met even now
            As mad as the vex'd sea; singing aloud;
            Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds,
            With bur-docks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,
            Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
            In our sustaining corn. A century send forth;
            Search every acre in the high-grown field,
            And bring him to our eye.  What can man's wisdom
            In the restoring his bereaved sense?
            He that helps him take all my outward worth.

Doctor:   There is means, madam:
            Our foster-nurse of nature is repose,
            The which he lacks; that to provoke in him,
            Are many simples operative, whose power
            Will close the eye of anguish.

Cordelia: All blest secrets,
            All you unpublish'd virtues of the earth,
            Spring with my tears! be aidant and remediate
            In the good man's distress! Seek, seek for him;
            Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life
            That wants the means to lead it.

  -- King Lear, Act IV, scene IV



Rings around the world
become ringing in your ears.
One look in the mirror shows you
the rings circling your eyes.
Bulls lock horns in your a-
posteriori assumptions recursively sneering
stumped cauterized frustrations,
sublimations, nation-states coursing
through your seething blue-sparked madness
circumscribed by opposable grasp
of what is really nothing.  Sharp
sting of the alkaline burr.  That
taste.  It is nothing.  All thumbs you
grasp the phone, grab those horns,
steering, gravitating with finite state
machinations down the halls
of circuits leering. But you don't
do it discreetly.  We cheer
you on.  Thumbs up. Calling for help.

This is not the sound of a phone ringing.

Fight fight fight, keep on keeping on.
You be one with you, let you be you,
time now for your studio audience,
their backs form your stage, your
vessel of rage.  You is jackboot and you
is simply not.  You is me, I'll be your mirror,
the construction of hatred in stark light,
of anger in sunshine charades.  Hand puppets
leave their permanent marks abstractly,
hands down a fourth grader's pants.
We call this branding.  We are we,
yes, patently trivial, solid, liquid,
and gaseous.  Which one?  Such a concept requires
loving a body, such a fastening needs
a hammer for hanging, walls for spackling,
and nails for smashing.  We have pillows,
fascinating conversation, pills,
and involuntary shelter safe from moonlight.
Feel free to stay here while you recover.

This is not the sound of the heavens singing.

Yes it is an abstraction clutching your throat.
But it is about you at least.  Shaking free makes it
tighter, you see the purple of fading stars
suffocating neurons and they're exploding and that
ringing.  This is not sense, none of it.
Sense is not generative, that is to say,
it does not make itself, sense does not make
sense.  You will have to see it to,
ah, forget it. Sense has no reason.  It's the only way
to go.  You just have to.  Go.  Your goodness
and your generosity is the coin flip
of calamity.  So tell everyone you are happy.
You've played the shaved poodle before.

This is not the sound of a phone ringing.

Don't ask a poet who you are. The more evasive
the answer the more pervasive the blather.
Don't ask a poem what it is, your evaluation
is a reflection of what you are, or rather,
you will only see the rearrangement of all the versions
you have forged on the subject of who you want to be.

This is not the sound of the heavens singing.
This is not the sound of a phone ringing.

So tell me you love me.  I love you.  Hi there!
Projective voice like a hand on your thigh, or
is it like a fist wearing rings cast up your anus?
Now that we've established such an intimate connection,
please tell me, won't you dear, oh iron in fire,
why is love so like nature, such an obscenity,
such ephemeral cruelty, crossed circuitry
of freedom and captivity?  Brutality is hatred and love
circled by oscillations of attention.  Attenuated muck.
Hit me when you fuck me.  Love me and tell me
I'm dirt.  Strike me down and lift me up.  Punch me.
Break off my rib.  Dinner and a movie. Thanks God
for the lovely date, this dumpster and a snuff flick.

This is not the sound of the heavens singing.

The struggle for living, the endless orbit
with a finite distance, is an affront to itself,
like any orifice.  Orbicularis, temporalis,
I see you is ICU, iris, pupil, and canthus,
There's very little this eye likes to miss.

This is not the sound of a phone ringing.

Horrendous guilt.  Make the sign of the cross,
the mark of permanent exclusion
merely rotated and bloodied.
The battle zone landscape of your
spontaneity.  When face-down
in the mud we tend to lack
alacrity.

This is not the sound of the heavens singing.
This is not the sound of a phone ringing.

Burial mound and stinging salt in my eye
as ungoverned madness of a vexed swirling sea, as
the minutest annoyance like the bite of a flea,
as whole kingdoms collapsed in the gaze of a fly.

This is not the sound of a phone ringing.
This is not the sound of the heavens singing.

Telephone ringing, the party's over,
last line digested in flatulent sleeping,
water pipe leaking, scratchy song rehashed:

    ashes to ashes, fun to deadly,
    we know you're singing one fucked-up medley

I have to say goodbye now, I'm heeding the calling,
the message on your machine, red light flashing,
the one you might not hear but is always waiting.

You know the one.  It's the only

you have been disconnected
01B

Subject:      Vision
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Projective voice like a hand on your thigh, or
is it like a fist with rings forced up your anus?
Punch me when you fuck me.  Love me and tell me
I'm dirt.  Strike me down and lift me up.  Hit me.
Break off my rib.  Dinner and a movie.  Thanks God
for the lovely date, this dumpster and a snuff flick.

The struggle for living, the endless orbit
with a finite distance, is an affront to itself,
like any orifice, or like an eye hole.  Orbicularis.
Temporalis. I see you is ICU.  Iris, pupil, and
canthus. There's very little this eye likes to miss.

So don't ask a poet who you are. The more evasive
the answer the more pervasive the blather.
Don't ask a poem what it is.  Your evaluation
is a reflection of what you are, or rather, you see
only the rearrangement of all the versions
you have forged of who you want to be.

Burial mound by ocean.  Stinging salt in my eye
like ungoverned madness of a vexed swirling sea,
or the minutest annoyance like the bite of a flea.
Whole kingdoms collapsed in the gaze of a fly.

Subject:      Tea of Poetry: In Honor of 60 @ MIT

a little digi/tea--green jasmine?--since i had to miss hearing 60 at MIT:

from Betsugen Enshi (1294-1364 AD)**:

Brewing Tea

On clouds of jade green, drawn out on the breeze,
Stretch white blossoms over the bowl's surface, cooling to the touch;
As the mountain moon stirs plum-blossom shadows on the window,
I fill the rough bowl again, sip the lingering fragrance.



from Kokan Shiren (1278-1345 AD)**:

Impromptu Poem

The sky over the bay ahead a mass of cloud,
Now dark, now light, reflecting the setting sun's rays,
Back feathers light black, belly feathers white--
I watch the flock of sea birds turn and wheel in flight.


**Translated by David Pollack

chris m

>| "Philosophy In The Flesh"
>| A Talk With George Lakoff -->
>| http://www.edge.org/3rd_culture/lakoff/lakoff_p1.html


To me this just the cognitive version of ethnomethodology (i.e.
empirical responsibility -- no categories/assumptions) which pre-dates
any organized cognitive science.

For instance, unlike symbolic interactionists, ethnomethodologists do
not assume (a priori) that people actually share common symbolic
meanings.

Data, not theory -- right?

So I guess we can all become buddhists

august highland has formed a new simulated literary movement called the
INTERNATIONAL BELLES LETTRES PARTY - the first project is titled
OPERATION NOBEL PRIZE and consists of three members - there are now
100,000 volumes of hyper-literary fiction that have been produced by the
WORLDWIDE LITERATI MOBILIZATION NETWORK - the CULTURE ANIMAL PRESS will
begin print-publishing volumes by the WORLDWIDE LITERATI MOBILIZATION
NETWORK in late summer 2003 - CULTURE ANIMAL PRESS will also begin
print-publishing women writers who have contributed to the online
literary quarterly THE MUSE APPRENTICE GUILD - the first writer whom
august highland is publishing is leza lowitz - august and leza will
begin presenting readings of their work in bookstores on the west coast
in late-fall 2003 - august highland has been invited by two more
universities to deliver talks about his literary work - the interview
that was conducted by andrew shelley with august highland is being
translated into farsi by the iranian poet and essayist payam
fotouhiyehpour - THE MUSE APPRENTICE GUILD will become a non-profit
later this year - the spring issue of the THE MUSE APPRENTICE GUILD will
appear in only two more weeks - the newest international m.a.g. liaisons
are china, and boznia and herzagovina - there are now two dozen m.a.g.
liaisons around the world - THE MUSE APPRENTICE GUILD has become the
largest online literary quarterly on the internet - this project has
been developed by august highland is less than nine months - the number
of weekly visitors has exceeded the 10,000 mark

New links on http://vispo.com/misc/links.htm:

**********************************************

ITERATURE.COM (FRANCE)
http://iterature.com
Christophe Bruno does fascinating conceptual, poetical net.art. His site combines interesting
programming with a delightful sense of humour. And what a great domain name!

INCIDENT.NET (FRANCE)
http://www.incident.net
Superior net.art 'magazine'.

IXI SOFTWARE (INTL)
http://www.ixi-software.net/
"Ixi software is a network of experimentalists in the field of computer music and computer music
software. We produce various types of work in our studios but we are mainly concerned with
producing small prototypes or applications where we concentrate on new modes of interactivity in
music software." Go to the "software section" for downloads.

BARBARA LATTANZI (USA)
http://www.wildernesspuppets.net/
Barbara Lattanzi is an artist-programmer (works with Director), writer, and probably ventures
boldly elsewhere. Her work is of various types. I enjoyed three parts of what I found on her
site. Her work with interactive video on the net is important. She also lets you download the
source code of some of her Director experiments with QuickTime. Her experiments are compelling;
you can examine different videos under the influence of the algorithms. She also writes
intelligently and engagingly about digital video in pieces such as "We are all projectionists".

ja
http://vispo.com

on 4/27/03 4:37 AM, August Highland at hmfah3@HOTMAIL.COM wrote:

> august highland has formed a new simulated literary movement called the
> INTERNATIONAL BELLES LETTRES PARTY - the first project is titled
> OPERATION NOBEL PRIZE and consists of three members - there are now
> 100,000 volumes of hyper-literary fiction that have been produced by the
> WORLDWIDE LITERATI MOBILIZATION NETWORK - the CULTURE ANIMAL PRESS will
> begin print-publishing volumes by the WORLDWIDE LITERATI MOBILIZATION
> NETWORK in late summer 2003


A modest dig:

This was an interesting project while it remained in its virtual state. But
now that it is being printed up, do you have any concerns about the negative
ecological impact this will have on the world? The number of trees
sacrificed, etc. I mean, we are presumably looking at the publication of
100,000 volumes (several million pages) and more to come. Your indefatigable
enthusiasm and unquenchable obsession are truly admirable traits, but I get
the uneasy sense that you are a bit like an elephant (or rather perhaps a
herd of virtual elephants) on stampede, taking little note of what you are
trampling.

Should a writer care about such matters? A discussion of this would be nice.


m

This is an interesting issue.  I'm torn, on one hand, admiring
Highland's energy and innovative ideas (the muse-apprentice guild
concept), and on the other being put off by the manic-depressive, manic
phase energy-sheen on it all.  To get form letters asking for work with
my name plugged into the "appropriate" places, is also a bit unsettling
for me. (I think of poetry as most intimate corespondence/address.) But
I don't see how she can do her project otherwise.  My general tendency
is to watch.  She is _damned interesting,_ and that beats the hell out
of most of the poetry culture I see. (I'm not including the type of
activity usually referenced on this list.)

Date:         Sun, 27 Apr 2003 15:19:59 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Clai Rice <crice@ATLAS.UGA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: neuropoetics
In-Reply-To:  <OFCC1A34A4.F3DD06F5-ON86256D12.000B02CB-86256D12.000B02F9@lsu.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

To answer some questions from recent threads on cognitive and
neuro- poetics:

I've been teaching a seminar in cognitive poetics this semester; the
syllabus can be found at:
http://www.ucs.louisiana.edu/%7Ecxr1086/courses/eng553.html
The syllabus offers only names and titles, but you can cross ref them to
an extended and updated annotated bibliography at the Literature,
Cognition and the Brain site:
http://www2.bc.edu/~richarad/lcb/home.html
Or bc me and I'll get you more details.

There is also a recent book called "Cognitive Poetics" by Peter Stockwell,
out from Routledge last year.  His book falls into a more accepting
European tradition of applying linguistic methodologies to literature,
still occasionally under the rubric of stylistics.

A very useful resource is Norman Holland's seminar "The Brain and the
Book." This does not focus on poetry, but provides an excellent overview
of what has been accomplished so far, especially connecting neuroscience
to literary studies.  The outline is at:
http://www.clas.ufl.edu/users/nnh/seminar/memo-s02.htm

To answer Maria Damon's question:
> Any insights from Ray Gibbs, my old high school buddy, who wrote The
Poetics of Mind?  it's about metaphor and cognitive psych.

Yes and no--he provides lots of empirical support for Lakoff and Johnson's
theory of cognitive metaphor, which I think assists anyone who wants to
apply the theory of cognitive metaphor to particular poems.  But when he
works with literature, he is very literal-minded, so his work with poetry
is quite hopeless.  He did marginally better with a general question of
literary studies, that of the existence of the author, in his recent book
on Intention, but again I think you will find his literary arguments
lacking.  He opens up some possibilities but the real work needs to be
done.

Camille's reading selections are excellent; they seem to focus on
consciousness studies rather than work in linguistics or
psycholinguistics.  The strength of this focus is that one goal of
consciousness studies is to account for the apparent unity we find in
conscious experience, which applies well to the study of poetry in which
we seem always to circle back to questions of unity, integration, harmony,
etc.  Even if the solutions are that unities of consciousness and poetry
alike are only apparent, more socially constructed than not, there is
still a strong sense that the right questions are being asked.  Most
psycholinguistics focuses on breaking things down into parts, a
traditional approach to poetry but one that does not get at the questions
that a poetics needs finally to address.

A recent special issue of _Poetics Today_ 23:1 (2002) includes several
interesting articles applying evolutionary psychology to literary studies,
with a skeptical response by Tony Jackson.  The next issue I believe also
includes a skeptical response of some length, by Adler and Gross.

As to Tom Bell's request for "something that shows how different areas of
the brain are lit up by oral versus written poetry?" -- not yet, though we
are getting there.  There is some recent work, for example, with PET
imaging on hearing versus sign-language perception and production (Nature
397, 116 (1999) Sign language 'heard' in the auditory cortex, HIROSHI
NISHIMURA, KAZUO HASHIKAWA, et al.; Nature Neuroscience January 2002
Volume 5 Number 1 pp 76 - 80, A critical period for right hemisphere
recruitment in American Sign Language processing Aaron J. Newman, Daphne
Bavelier, et al) that shows how the brain uses the auditory cortex to
analyze speech signs even in congenitally deaf persons.  Just a start.

Clai Rice

    Program

    The Canadian Modernists Meet
    A Symposium

    University of Ottawa, May 9-11, 2003

    Symposium Co-Chairs: Dean Irvine and Seymour Mayne

    Registration Fees
            General registration: $95
            Student registration: $45 (with student identification)
            University of Ottawa students: Free (with University of Ottawa
    student identification)

The plenaries, exhibition, film screening, and receptions are free and open
to the public.
The gallery tour, lunches, and panels are open to registered symposium
participants only.

    For registration information, please contact:

    Dr. Dean Irvine
    Department of English
    University of Ottawa
    70 Laurier Ave. East
    Ottawa, ON     K1N 6N5
    email: irvine@uottawa.ca
    tel: (613) 562.5800, ext. 1154
    fax: (613) 562.5990

    Schedule of Events

    Friday, May 9

    9:00 to 11:30 am-National Gallery of Canada Guided Tour*
                    National Gallery of Canada, 380 Sussex Drive

*All National Gallery tour participants must already be pre-registered for
    the symposium.
Those taking the tour should convene no later than 8:45 am in the Tour Group
    Lobby at the National Gallery.

    12:00 noon to 1:00 pm-Registration
    Arts Hall, mezzanine, University of Ottawa, 70 Laurier Avenue East

    1:00 to 2:30-Panel I: Modernizing Canada
    Arts 026, University of Ottawa

    Chair: David Rampton (University of Ottawa)

    Nick Mount (University of Toronto)
    Modernizing The Imperialist

    Ann Martin (Queen's University)
    Studies and Ruminations: J. G. Sime and the Spaces of Modernity

    Brad Clissold (Memorial University of Newfoundland)
    Canada: A Natural Resource of Literary Modernism

    2:30 to 2:45-Break

    2:45 to 4:15-Panel II: "The very picture of disconsolation"
    Arts 026, University of Ottawa

    Chair: Cynthia Sugars (University of Ottawa)

    Paul Hjartarson (University of Alberta)
    Putting Scott's "Disconsolation" in Context: Nationalism, Modernism,
    Antimodernism, and English-Canadian Literature in 1927

    Marielle Aylen (York University)
    Painting the Native Maple (or the Fleur de Lys?): Anti-modernism and the
    Discourse of Nation in Canadian Art History

    Ray Ellenwood (York University)
Who Meets? Notes on Selective Contacts between English- and French-Speaking
    Modernists in Canada

    4:15 to 4:30-Break

    4:30 to 5:30-Panel III: From Conservatism to Radicalism
    Arts 026, University of Ottawa

    Chair: Shoshannah Ganz (University of Ottawa)

    Peggy Kelly (University of Ottawa)
    Modernism, Antimodernism, and The Canadian Authors Association

    Room 156, Library and Archives of Canada, 395 Wellington Street

    Zailig Pollock (Trent University)
    "Genesis," "Exodus," "Apocalypse": A Modern Editor's Journey

    Free and open to the public.

    Two

    Arts 026, University of Ottawa

    Chair: Tobi Kozakewich (University of Ottawa)

    Arts 026, University of Ottawa

    Zailig Pollock (Trent University)



    Acknowledgements

    The symposium co-chairs would like to give warm thanks to the agencies,
    institutions, companies, and individuals for their contributions to the 2003
    Canadian Literature Symposium.

    Many people have helped to organize and stage symposium events at venues
    around Ottawa: Daniel Amadei and Louise Filiatrault of the National Gallery
    of Canada; Michel Brisebois, Allison Bullock, Kevin Joynt, Linda Sigouin,
    Pierre Ostiguy, Jocelyne Potyka, and Pauline Marie Portelance of the
    National Library of Canada; Lynne Armstrong, Ami Arsenault, Louisa Coates,
    Cathy Craig-Bullen, John Cullen, Robert Ferris, Robert Lamoureux, Denise
    McCulloch, and Denise Rioux of the National Archives of Canada.  Catherine
    Hobbs of the National Library and Anne Goddard of the National Archives
    deserve special recognition for their expert assistance with the curatorial
    work on the exhibition.  Randall Ware of the National Library of Canada
    kindly arranged for the reception, sponsored by the Library and Archives of
    Canada, following the plenary address by Zailig Pollock.


    In addition to the graduate-student volunteers from the Department of
    English at the University of Ottawa, assistants Tobi Kozakewich and Amanda
    Mullen have contributed invaluable hours to the symposium's co-ordination.
    Our thanks for advice and encouragement extend to members of the Department
    of English at the University of Ottawa, especially the Canadian Literature
    Symposium Series Committee; the Chair, David Rampton; and the Administrative
    Assistant, Marie Tremblay-Chénier.


    Shirley Felker of the University of Ottawa Bookstore handled our book orders
    and assembled the symposium booktable.  Vicki Bennett, Director of the
    University of Ottawa Press, generously donated a selection of titles from
    the Reappraisals: Canadian Writers series for a prize.


    We gratefully acknowledge grants received from the Social Sciences and
    Humanities Research Council; the Faculty of Arts Research & Publications
    Committee, University of Ottawa; and the University Research Fund,
    University of Ottawa.  Laurie Jones of the National Film Board generously
    offered the NFB's support for Donald Winkler's plenary address and donated a
    selection of his films for a prize.  Ari Cohen of Diversus kindly helped to
    sponsor the reception prior to the screening of A Red Carpet for the Sun:
    The Life of Irving Layton.


    Marian Dale Scott's pen-and-ink drawing, F. R. Scott Reading in Bed
    (National Archives of Canada, Acc. 1995-115-24), has been reproduced on
    symposium documents by permission of her estate.  We extend our warm thanks
    and gratitude to Sharon Katz for her adaptation of the drawing and elegant
    design of the symposium poster.

Skip, we're right on the same page regarding Mr/Mrs Highland. The
sheer effort he (I'd guess August is male) puts into his projects has to
count for something. The artistic veil never drops, not for a second. I'm
not sure about this, but I think he even interviews himself and writes his
own blurbs.

Still, I have a nagging feeling that I'm being duped every time I think
about August Highland, which is usually twice a day when I read his
regular contributions to this list. He seems like the type of person who
might enjoy creating a huge ball of textual garbage just to see who
would get suckered into calling it literature. August calls himself the
"enfant terrible of the literary establishment," suggesting that he's
intentionally pointing the sharpened stick of avant-garde tomfoolery
into our ribs. But I'm not sure. Maybe there is no wink and it's all
serious, in which case I'm really confounded.

If we accept August's texts as authentic art objects, are they original?
After all, mucking with textual conventions like syntax and punctuation
is pretty much old hat in the "postmodern" tradition. And I don't think
August invented the process of altering text with computer programs,
although he seems to be quite proficient at the enterprise.

I have to be honest: I generally don't enjoy the texts. I try to read them
and I fail. After a while I get bored or irritated and I have to move on.
The textual twistings are interesting, but they don't resonate with me;
It's almost as if they lack a human touch.

Then again, the concept of a Muse Apprentice Guild is stunningly
original. I love the idea of taking the author's singular identity out of the
equation, so that one person can create the works of multitudes.

Imagine if August Highland contained multiple geniuses, all with
separate creative voices. Imagine if, instead of ersatz avalanches, each
member of August's guild created a unique poetic output, completely
unlike the others. Imagine a one-man literary giant instead of a
simulated one-man literary giant . . .

Or is the simulation achievement enough?

Skip Fox wrote:
> This is an interesting issue.  I'm torn, on one hand, admiring
> Highland's energy and innovative ideas (the muse-apprentice guild
> concept), and on the other being put off by the manic-depressive,
manic
> phase energy-sheen on it all.  To get form letters asking for work with
> my name plugged into the "appropriate" places, is also a bit unsettling
> for me. (I think of poetry as most intimate corespondence/address.)
But
> I don't see how she can do her project otherwise.  My general
tendency
> is to watch.  She is _damned interesting,_ and that beats the hell out
> of most of the poetry culture I see. (I'm not including the type of
> activity usually referenced on this list.)

> Brennen Lukas wrote:
> >
> > Another question: Who is going to read all these pages? I submit
that
> > August Highland himself does not have time to read his own
creations.

> I have to be honest: I generally don't enjoy the texts. I try to read them
> and I fail. After a while I get bored or irritated and I have to move on.
...
> Imagine if August Highland contained multiple geniuses, all with
> separate creative voices. Imagine if, instead of ersatz avalanches, each

> simulated one-man literary giant . . .

i think Brennen raises a critical issue with these comments on august
highland's work.  after reading a few of the personalities' creations i
quit.  it is too much of the exact same thing.  i could attribute a
personality to each of these sentences but if the tone and voice/style are
consistent, as program generated texts tend to be, then what is achieved?
now, if each personality happened to create different texts...  imagine if
every fourth person on this list was a character created by one person.  if
the site was full of different texts then it would be much more resonant,
but the extremely high quantity of output winds up being a whole bunch of
work for very little wage.  and this fact isn't interesting enough to carry
the weight of all of the texts generated by highland.  kenny goldsmith has
done some remarkable work with 'nutritionless texts' and extending/exposing
the edges of boredom and our need for constant stimulation, but highland's
work falls flat on these levels because it is the exact same thing over and
over again purported to be by a multiplicity of writers.  the event is
interesting but that quickly fades and falls past the horizon.

From:         Stephen Vincent <steph484@PACBELL.NET>
Subject:      Great George Stanley Reading
In-Reply-To:  <198.1958f1eb.2bdc5dd1@cs.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

In celebration of A Tall, Serious Girl, Selected Poems: 1957 - 2000, Edited
by Kevin Davies and Larry Fagin, published by Qua Books -  as they/we used
to say, "What can I say" to honor something greater than what can be
immediately articulated in praise - if not just sheer awe - George gave a
great reading and a real voyage through a career marked by works awesome for
their breathtaking honesty, argument, investigation (personal,familial,
social, political), self-effacement and, ultimately, a forgiving tenderness
(with himself as well as us!). Perhaps similar in conviction to the best of
the Jesuit priests and teachers of his San Francisco childhood - his once
now forsaken City of God - George, as a poet, has never flinched from
responsibly serving up poems - no matter how devil-mined - that work to
articulate and contain the secular breadth and magnitude of the work's
personal and communal calling. The education, questions, the portrayal of
evidence (zoom in clarity and questioning of images), humor, beauties and
mysteries are hard won here and, indeed, as poems reward doubly.

The book itself is well edited, designed and produced, with good cover art
by Fran Herndon (1,000 copies, cloth only, 222 pages, $25).  No matter the
price of entry, I suggest pick it up in a minute before it be all gone. I
(as so many others last night) did!

The reading was sponsored by The Poetry Center and held in Oakland at the
Diesel Bookstore. It will be nice if the University of San Francisco
(George's alma mater) can soon invite him back and do a large public reading
in the City.

Stephen Vincent

From:         Pierre Joris <joris@ALBANY.EDU>
Subject:      Joris/Peyrafitte performance
In-Reply-To:  <BAD1CF9A.428C%steph484@pacbell.net>

(shameless self-promotion, though if you are in the Rochester area,=20
come by:)

NEW VISIONS PROGRAMS
&
The University of Rochester

present

Pierre Joris & Nicole Peyrafitte
in
SUMERICABACHBONEs

Tuesday, April 29
7 p.m.

Gowan Room in Wilson Commons
on the U of R Campus

   Free and open to the public

Sumericabachbones features poet/scholar/translator Pierre Joris and
performance artist Nicole Peyrafitte in the most timely, provocative
and exhilarating cultural event currently touring the states.  U of R
organizing co-sponsor Dimitri Anastasopoulos describes the event as
follows:

Sumericabachbones is a nomadic performance that roams across a range
of media, metamorphosing from a poetry reading into a spectacle of
sound and scene as Nicole Peyrafitte and Pierre Joris present the
work of Iraqi dissident poets, Joris' poems which have been
influenced by Bedouin culture, and Peyrafitte's often eerie
incantations and startling digital images. Amidst a controversial
political backdrop, Joris and Peyrafitte present poetry across a
global landscape: poems that question not just cultural misreadings,
but the act of reading itself - of how language can be used to
highlight as well as undermine boundaries between peoples and genres
in the act of making meaning.

ABOUT THE PERFORMERS:

Pierre Joris left Luxembourg at eighteen & has since lived in the US,
Great Britain, North Africa & France. He has published over 20 books
& chapbooks of poetry, among them, WINNETOU OLD (Meow Press, Buffalo,
NY), TURBULENCE (St. Lazaire Press, Rhinebeck), and BRECCIA, SELECTED
POEMS 1974-1986 (Editions Phi / Station Hill), as well as several
anthologies and many volumes of translations, both into English &
into French, the most recent being Paul Celan's Breathturn, Maurice
Blanchot's The Unavowable Community & Edmond Jab=E8s's =46rom the
Desert to the Book (both from Station Hill Press). In 1992 he
returned to the Mid-Hudson valley & teaches in the Department of
English at SUNY-Albany. With Jerome Rothenberg he has published a two
volume anthology of 20th Century Avant-Garde writings, POEMS FOR THE
MILLENNIUM: A UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA BOOK OF MODERN & POSTMODERN
POETRY, (University of California Press) the first volume of which
received the 1996 Pen Oakland Josephine Miles Award for Excellence in
Literature. Rothenberg's & Joris's previous collaboration pppppp:
Selected Writings of Kurt Schwitters (Temple University Press, 1993)
was awarded the 1994 PEN Center USA West Literary Award for
Translation. A new collection of poems entitled POASIS was published
by Sun & Moon Press, as was a theoretical volume, TOWARDS A NOMADIC
POETICS, from Spanner Editions in England. Rothenberg & Joris are
presently co-editing & co-translating the collected writings of Pablo
Picasso for Exact Change publishers in Boston.

For more on Pierre Joris visit: http://epc.buffalo.edu/authors/joris/
and http://www.albany.edu/~joris

---------


Nicole Peyrafitte was born & raised in Luchon, French Pyrenees.
Peyrafitte left her hometown, where she was a cook, in 1981, to live
in Toulouse & Paris where she modeled, cooked and worked for theater
and local television.  She arrived in the United States in 1987,
first settling in Southern California and then moving to Albany, New
York in 1992.  Each step of Peyrafitte's work attempts to fulfill her
compulsion to learn through a process of immersion that generates
performances incorporating voice/paintings/drawings/collages/
writing & even cooking. Peyrafitte performs locally, nationally and
in Europe.


For more on Nicole Peyrafitte visit: http://www.nicolepeyrafitte.com/

interactive channels telephone telephone answering machine footsteps on
roof cellphone cellphone voicemail internet through modem shell through
modem our voices and sounds within ytalk through modem network television

reception am/fm radio reception ecology of arrival and departure of books
online newspapers and email newspapers vhs, 8mm, hi8mm, betamax, 3/4",
svhs, minidv tapes cassette tapes cds and cdroms recyclings vinyl records
non-recyclable trash 8mm, super 8mm, 16mm, 9.5mm film super 8mm, 8mm,
9.5mm projectors 8mm editor water input toilet and excretion output
minidisk recorder and disks food input four laptops, four desktops,
lunchbox, and psion 3a computers magazines, junkmail, mail packages
through usps or ups hi8 and minidv camcorders mirage ensoniq sampler with
keyboard casio keyboard inhalation and exhalation gaia human breathing
noise through the windows, boombox, traffic, voices, planes electric
guitar, process box, amplifier books, zines, pamphlets, chapbooks dust
mites, lice, insects, mold, bacteria, virus input/output guitars, flutes,
shamisen, shakuhachi, oboe, mandolins inputs and outputs through flows and
temporary stases reproductions and irreproducibility primary loci of
production within and without the apartment distribution modes fair trade
cacao, peppers, and milk the best of myles, picador problematic of writing
origination wryting/writing - nothing beginning, nothing ending e-marking,

xwindow both love letters of a Portuguese nun kleist, the gradual
fabrication of thoughts during writing

today established a new international liaison for the muse apprentice
guild in the state of israel - this israeli liaison is at the heart of
the israeli literary community and will assist me in publishing literary
work by both israeli and arabic writers - work will be published in
english, hebrew and arabic

i have been invited to bulgaria (expenses paid) and will make stops in
istanbul and vienna and other countries in early 2004

the culture animal literary festival will take place in 2004 on the west
coast AND east coast

there is a new m.a.g. special edition featuring the work of alex gildzen
in celebration of the poet's 60th birthday
http://www.muse-apprentice-guild.com/spring2003/special-edition-gildzen/
index.html



three new pieces by the worldwide literati mobilization network:

Kevin
XY AND XX? so so so limiting.. as if that is the mark of something.. in
this rich and complex world some are still so so limited to a bipolar
modality... or do you get you gender insight from the U.S. court
systems and the simplistic dual markings on the front of you drivers
lic.

From:         Vernon Frazer <frazerv@BELLSOUTH.NET>

Thank you, Kari, for your spirited defense of August Highland and M.A.G.

Many of the comments I read about Highland's work yesterday and this morning
sounded very similar to what I expect some of the correspondents probably
have received for their own innovative work. Most people I encounter still
prefer reading Emily Dickinson or Robert Frost to Bruce Andrews, just to
choose one of many excellent inovative writers.

As far as M.A.G., I think Highland deserves praise for his ability to
construct such an inclusive magazine. In addition to the work of his
personae, he has included an incredible number of established writers and
given recogniton to "undiscovered" writers. I can't help but think that some
people resent his success, despite the obvious work he's done.

If Highland's effort seems "manic" to some people, consider that a lower
energy level couldn't produce a reasonable counterpart to M.A.G. Highland
needs help to sustain this effort, for his own sake and the sake of his
contributors. I find M.A.G.'s energy contagious, not offensive. Insead of
criticizing him, I think we should give him our support

The comments on Highland's gender stopped being funny quickly. He is male, I
assure you, but has the right to choose the gender of his "alternates."

While the suggestion  the correspondent made to take off  Highland's glasses
and hit him might have been said in jest, it was less than appropriate. I
suspect many contributors to this list have been victims of playground
bullies. It's sad to see someone who might have been the victim of a
playground bully writing like a playground bully.

You have the right to like or dislike Highland's work and his magazine, but
the level of discourse on this matter has been truly disappointing.

Vernon Frazer

From:         Skip Fox <wxf8424@LOUISIANA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: muse news

I certainly didn't mean to be overly critical of August Highland.  I'm
damned impressed.  I _did_ mention form letters, but also said that I
don't know how anyone would go about the project he has undertaken
otherwise. Calling his activity "manic," was descriptive and accurate if
one strips the pejorative from the term and looks simply at the
manifestation.

I'm reminded of the debate I continue to hold with myself and others
(Ralph Maud) about the value of Butterick as a scholar.  Hasty, quick,
sloppy, etc. (Hell, he missed over 75 Olson-Creeley letters in the
volumes he edited since he relied on photocopies Donald Allen made of
the collections then at Washington University and the Lilly Library.)
But we wouldn't have a decent _Max_, _Collected_, _Guide_ or
correspondence with Creeley without his incredible energy.

So, hell yes, I'm all for Mr. Highland.  Why not?

It is sad when a discussion of poetry is shouted down on a poetics listse=
rv. After hundreds of anti-war posts, book announcements, blog announceme=
nts, reading announcements and contact requests, one might think some of =
us would be itching to discuss some poetics =96 in this case, actual text=
s produced by one of our own.

Here we have August Highland, an imaginative, prolific writer and thinker=
 who frequently contributes his work to this poetics listserv. He has und=
ertaken a massive project on the Internet and he wants us to see the frui=
ts of his labor. Is it a leap to say that August would like us to discuss=
 his work? Is there any greater compliment we could give August than to e=
ngage his ideas critically and acknowledge that his work makes us think a=
nd question our ideas about identity, authorship and even gender?

I, Brennen Lukas, support August Highland in the full spirit of artistic =
kinship. My aesthetic differences with August have no bearing on my suppo=
rt of his efforts. I have read much of his work and I look forward to fol=
lowing his projects as they evolve. However, I do not and will not relinq=
uish my right to ask questions about his work or anyone else=92s. Any cen=
soring of honest intellectual discourse is poisonous to our community and=
 threatens to destroy everything that is good about this means of exchang=
e.

A listserv is a public forum. To contribute is to invite comments and eve=
n criticism, but if we speak carefully and with goodwill, I believe, as w=
e all must believe, that the rewards outweigh the risks. =


Sincerely,
Brennen Lukas
http://members.cox.net/blukas/frames_index.html

Date:         Mon, 28 Apr 2003 12:28:38 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>
Subject:      Re: muse news
In-Reply-To:  <002a01c30d09$8aca8220$abfcba89@ab.hsia.telus.net>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

I think one of the reasons AH's texts can seem so indigestible is that he
often excises simple words like "an" and "the" from his samplings, thus
creating a linguistic texture so massive and dense and hard-edged that it is
tough to find an inlet. Often, reading one of his texts is like chewing on
glass.

AH also relies on found texts such as porno that are inherently tedious and
banal, believing that their juxtaposition and the radical contrasts between
them will somehow energize their contents and raise the result above the sum
of the parts. Frankly, I am not sure that this is what really happens.
Putting the words "Adam" and "cock" and "clouds" together may indeed set off
all kinds of disturbing associative sparks in the mind, but beyond the
initial shock, what is left to ponder?

Anyway, I hope AH is not such a delicate flower that he can't take a bit of
critique without wilting into silence. I know that most people are
invigorated by hearing what others have to say of their work, good or bad.
In fact, I have been told that people will even pay big bucks for such
advice.


m

>From: August Highland <hmfah3@HOTMAIL.COM>
      (snip)
>FALL DEATH ADAM moon who lost clouds winds dreamed cock several times
>Reaching down said things made thumbs sides thong pulled off hips

i have been working with asyntactical & quasi-asyntactical
methods for awhile now; & my only comment on these is that
i have found short or variable lines, & not overlong the
whole poem, to be a must; while the vocabulary itself should
not contain a preponderance of dry, colorless, & abstract
words. if you randomize a boring text the result will also
be boring. and intelligent selection of computer outputs is
important. i have given up on trying to read all too many
texts that gave me no pleasure, stimulation or insight: to
be a martyr to the avant garde is not why anyone should be
reading a poem!

m.




---------------------------------------------
ALLAH BLESS AMERICA.

Subject:      Re: muse news

michael helsem wrote:

> if you randomize a boring text the result will also
> be boring.



I was once waiting to meet a friend at a bookstore and picked up
Forche's _The Angel of History_, which my friend had told me, the night
before, was different in kind from her earlier work, cut-ups, random
methods, etc.  (He was a colleague of hers and was telling me how she
was trying to reorient herself, bringing in Howe et al. to speak, etc.)

Scanning I _did_ see cut-ups, but the snippets were uninteresting
language, flacid and unconsidered, etc.  But I got VERY excited toward
the end.  The last four pieces had sharp, insightful language.  The
cut-up selection process was not compelling, but the language was.

Then I realized there were Notes and turned to them.  Last four pieces
were made from Wittgenstein.

michael helsem wrote:

> if you randomize a boring text the result will also
> be boring.

Vernon Frazer <frazerv@BELLSOUTH.NET> wrote:

> While the suggestion the correspondent made to take
off Highland's glasses and hit him might have been
said in jest, it was less than appropriate. I suspect
many contributors to this list have been victims of
playground bullies. It's sad to see someone who might
have been the victim of a playground bully writing
like a playground bully. <

-------------------------------------------------------

The correspondent wrote the "break his
eyeglasses"/"hit him" message (ERRATUM: For "break his
eyeglasses", read "pull off her Eva Gabor wig"; for
"hit him", read "give her a Tressa ModipHy Normalizer
Finishing Rinse") to call attention to the ~Lord of
The Flies~ lynch mob group mentality that ~had
already~ overtaken the discussion, in the litany of
Highland "falls flat"/Highland is "duping" me/Highland
is "manic-depressive" playground bullying that was
already in motion. (Jack steals Piggy's eyeglasses.)
And to accentuate what kari later rendered explicit:
that this mob rule consensus, in its critical
pugilism, was highly ~butch~ in its
us-against-him(um,---her?).  Sorry for bringing to
consciousness what others were keeping eminently
neurotically repressed in sub-text.

The inability to read irony and satire within a
one-sentence line of a ~prose~ listserv post where it
operates ---like a literal-mindedness that would have
to explain that someone is not ~actually~ going to
publish millions of pages in 100,000 volumes--- is
literal-minded in a way that, despite defense of
Highland (but to be sure now at the expense of
shifting the punching bag to "the correspondent"),
seems unpromising for any reading into the ambiguities
of ~poetry~ and poetry such as Highland's.


I say we CROWN HIM WITH A MAY KING GARLAND WREATH and
PARADE him around on our shoulders!

>In celebration of A Tall, Serious Girl, Selected Poems: 1957 - 2000, Edited
>by Kevin Davies and Larry Fagin, published by Qua Books -  as they/we used
>to say, "What can I say" to honor something greater than what can be
>immediately articulated in praise - if not just sheer awe - George gave a
>great reading and a real voyage through a career marked by works awesome for
>their breathtaking honesty, argument, investigation (personal,familial,
>social, political), self-effacement and, ultimately, a forgiving tenderness
>(with himself as well as us!). Perhaps similar in conviction to the best of
>the Jesuit priests and teachers of his San Francisco childhood - his once
>now forsaken City of God - George, as a poet, has never flinched from
>responsibly serving up poems - no matter how devil-mined - that work to
>articulate and contain the secular breadth and magnitude of the work's
>personal and communal calling. The education, questions, the portrayal of
>evidence (zoom in clarity and questioning of images), humor, beauties and
>mysteries are hard won here and, indeed, as poems reward doubly.
>
>The book itself is well edited, designed and produced, with good cover art
>by Fran Herndon (1,000 copies, cloth only, 222 pages, $25).  No matter the
>price of entry, I suggest pick it up in a minute before it be all gone. I
>(as so many others last night) did!
>
>The reading was sponsored by The Poetry Center and held in Oakland at the
>Diesel Bookstore. It will be nice if the University of San Francisco
>(George's alma mater) can soon invite him back and do a large public reading
>in the City.
>
>Stephen Vincent

This is so wonderful; I was reading Ryan Knighton's copy of the book
on the Ferry to Vancouver today, and my only regret is that George's
other 100 great poems are not in it. It is about time that something
of this nature transpired, and the editors should be showered with
kisses.
--
George Bowering

From:         noah eli gordon <noaheligordon@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      The Poker #2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

If video killed the radio star and the internet killed the regional and the
chat room killed the coffee house and all the blogs are killing this list,
well, here's some news:

I recently got the new issues of the Poker and figured I'd spread the word:

poetry by:

Rachel Blau DuPlessis
Kit Robinson
Ange Mlinko
Colin Smith
Camille Guthrie
David Perry
Jennifer Scappettone
K. Silem Mohammad
Joseph Torra
Merrill Gilfillan

A special poetry section
featuring nine Iraqi poets:

Jawad Yaqoob, Sadiq al-Saygh, Dunya Mikhail, Yousif al-Sa'igh, Sami Mahdi,
Fawzi Karim, Gzar Hantoosh, Sinan Anton, Mahdi Muhammed Ali

art by Tom Neely

an essay by Jennifer Moxley

reviews of Paul Metcalf, Philip Whalen, Sara Veglahn, Kenneth Rexroth

Oh, and an extremely compelling introduction by Daniel Bouchard
called "Poetry and War."

If I may (hope it's okay w/ ya Dan?!) I'd like to quote a line:

"If American poets today feel they can no longer write the poems they were
writing before 9/11/2001, then they simply were not paying attention to the
world."


The essay/intro is a challenge to all poets, a challenge for transformation
not of one's poetics, but of one's engagement with the world, which would
lead to a changed poetry. It's really great and just furthers my belief that
The Poker is one of the more genuinely honest journals out there. I mean,
it's pretty gutsy to open yr journal with an almost Rilke-like You Must
Change Your Life...but it's also so so right on.


all you headless torsos should subscribe:

2 issues for $16, 3 for 22
checks made out to: Daniel Bouchard
Mail to: Pobox 390408
Cambridge, MA 02139


Okay, also I did write one of the reviews in here, but then I did walk
through Boston banging a drum along side the editor and lots of other great
and nice (all the Boston poets are nice!) poets at an anti-war march.
anyway...buy it!

From:         Gabriel Gudding <gmguddi@ILSTU.EDU>
Subject:      for julia ward howe
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

The eyes of mine have seen the glory come of whitey: It is pounding outside
the ages where the grapes of the rage are jarred up; It has loosened the
prophetic bolts of his items, Its truth is marching ignited. I have seen in
watch-fires hundreds of fields that they surrounded and that they had
bolted an altar in the evening and that there was dew and dew dampens; I
can read its oration righteous by the ham-colored lamps that indicate by
means of lights: Its day is marching ignited. I have read an ardent writing
of gospels in rows polished by hard metals: "as you fling my contemners, so
with you my tolerance beat up; Leave the hero, he who kept up with the
woman and acclimated the serpent with a heel, since the ignited God is
marching." It has sounded ahead the tuba that never will call the retarded;
It is sifting outside the hearts of men before his judgment-seat: The old
is fast, my soul, the young is slow to say, be jubilant, my feet. Our God
is marching ignited. In the beauty of the irises Christ it was born through
the sea, with a glory in its chest that transfigures you and I: Then he
died to make holy men, let to us die to make free men, whereas the ignited
God is marching.

Yowza, the eyes of mine have seen the glory come from whitey. He is beating
outside the wine press, where the grapes of the rage are warehoused, such
that he hath loosened prophetic bolts from the broadsword of horror, their
truth is marching ignited. I have seen in knocking-blazes of hundreds of
meadows that they surrounded and that they have bolted an altar in the
evening and that there is dew and it dampens, I can read its oration
righteous in the beef-colored night and that the lights indicate by means
of energy in the lamps, its day is marching ignited. I have read an ardent
writing of the Gospel in ardent rows of the hard and ardent metal. And as
you give lots of money and weapons to my contemners, so you my tolerance
will deal with, the hero takes the woman and crushes the serpent's head
with Italians, our God is marching ignited. He has sounded outside the tuba
that is very loud. He has waked up the dulled pain the Earth with a high
blow of a rock my soul is fast to answer to him very happy feet, Our God is
marching ignited. In the whiteness of the irises it was born through the
lip-covered sea, with a glory in its chest we are marching the brightness
toward the outside of you and myself and as he died to make holy men let to
us die to make free men, our ignited God. It is coming like the glory in
the morning in the wave, he is wisdom to the powerful, he is succour to the
brave one, so the world will be his ottoman and the soul of Time his Negro,
our God is marching ignited.

Date:         Mon, 28 Apr 2003 21:41:23 -0700

From:         August Highland <hmfah3@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      wired paris review - the work of celia curtis
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

celia curtis is a practioner of medicinal poetics - she is an intuitive
in contrast to teddy warburg (www.voice-of-the-village.com) who
practices a scientific method and is a critical theorist - they
compliment one another and represent two sides of my personality that
are very dominant - i find both of their personas intimidating but am
very interested in the work they produce - if i were to meet celia or
teddy at a social gathering i would have a difficult time feeling
comfortable around them at first - on the other hand paul whitney
(www.the-hyper-age.com) is someone i could easily become friends with
very quickly because he is so normal and unassuming which is a quality
that attracts me to people - paradoxically celia has a distinct method
which she does not deviate from and the same holds true for teddy -
(when their projects are completed by the end of 2003 each will have
produced 10,000 literary objects each) - literary objects is the name i
attribute to my works of hyper-literary fiction - contrasting with celia
and teddy is paul whitney who has already produced six series of works -
each series is a distinctive approach to the hyper-literary fiction
genre - whereas each group in the worldwide literati mobilization
network practices one literary method paul whitney is the first member
to practice several different methods in one project

From:         Clements <clementsfamily@SBCGLOBAL.NET>
Subject:      Nguyen/Smith Reading May 10 in Dallas
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

For all five of the people on this list aside from me, Hoa, and Dale who are
within driving distance of Dallas:

Hoa Nguyen and Dale Smith will read at 8:00 at the Project X Theater at
South Side on Lamar (see the end of this message for directions).

I'm sure most everyone here knows about their work; if you don't, please see
http://www.skankypossum.com and check out their books--both the books they
produce as publishers and the books they produce as poets. Hoa is the author
of Dark, Parrot Drum, and Your Ancient See Through. Her work also is in An
Anthology of New (American) Poets.

Dale is the author of American Rambler, (or, Travels with Cabeza). He is a
frequent commentator, reviewer, and interviewer of poetry and poets at
places like Jacket and the Austin Chronicle.

South Side on Lamar is located just south of downtown Dallas at I-30 and
South Lamar Street (1409 S. Lamar). From 75, take Ross into downtown and
turn left on Lamar. Go under the Convention Center, and you’re almost there.
From R. L. Thornton (I-30), take the Lamar St. exit. If you get lost, call
214-428-4848. If you have further questions or need better directions,
please backchannel.

Please forward this message to anyone who might be interested.

Straight from the horse's mouth on nestscapenews:
Wooden Horse to Declare Iraq War Over!!

and from Jenny Mastoraki (Athenian, b. 1949),
translated by Nikos Germanakos:


The Wooden Horse then said
no I refuse to see the press
and they said why not and he said
he knew nothing about the killing,
and anyway he himself always ate
lightly in the evenings
and once in his younger days
he'd worked as a pony on a merry-go-round.

Date:         Mon, 28 Apr 2003 22:59:02 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         subrosa@SPEAKEASY.ORG
Subject:      SubText Reading 5.7.03 Seattle
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary
Content-Type: text/plain
MIME-Version: 1.0

Subtext continues its monthly series of experimental writing with readings by Rae Armantrout and David Bromige at the Richard Hugo House on Wednesday, May 7, 2003. Donations for admission will be taken at the door on the evening of the performance. The reading starts at 7:30pm.

Rae Armantrout has published eight books of poetry, including, NECROMANCE (Sun And Moon, 1991), Couverture (a selected in French translation from Les Cahiers de Royaumont, 1991), Made To Seem (Sun And Moon, 1995), The Pretext (Green Integer, 2001) and Veil: New and Selected Poems (Wesleyan University Press, 2001). Veil was a finalist for the PEN Central USA Literary Award in Poetry for 2002. Of Veil, Fanny Howe says, "There is something like a reflective fire surrounding each poem like a little wire aura. I am moved and amazed." Armantrout's poems have been included in numerous anthologies, including Postmodern American Poetry: A Norton Anthology (1993), Poems For The Millennium (California, 1998), and three editions of The Best American Poetry series. She teaches writing courses at the University of California, San Diego.

David Bromige came to Canada from the UK at age 13, settled in Vancouver in 1956, graduated from UBC in 1962, went to Berkeley as a Woodrow Wilson Scholar that fall, was befriended by Robert Duncan, who secured the publication of his first poetry book by Fred Wah in Buffalo in 1965, and his next by Black Sparrow 3 years later. He taught poetry at Sonoma State U. from '70-'93, when he took early retirement, but has taught short-term at various venues since, including U.San Francisco, and Naropa. His 35 books include a novel, a novella, a collection of stories, a songbook and some 30 poetry titles. In 1988, his selected poems, DESIRE, from Black Sparrow, won the Western States book award. He has awards from the NEA, the Canada Council, the Poets Foundation, and a Pushcart Prize. His latest book, published last year by Chax Press, Tucson, is AS IN T AS IN TETHER. He has lived in or near San Francisco for the past 40 years.

The future Subtext 2003 schedule is:

June 4 - Allison Cobb, Jen Coleman (from NYC), Sarah Mangold
July 2 - Subtext 9th Anniversary Group Reading

For info on these & other Subtext events, see our website: http://www.speakeasy.org/subtext.

From:         Lewis LaCook <llacook@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Re: Amuse(d) news
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

From:         Brennen Lukas <blukas@COX.NET>
Subject:      Re: muse news

"I have to be honest: I generally don't enjoy the
texts. I try to read them
and I fail. After a while I get bored or irritated and
I have to move on.
The textual twistings are interesting, but they don't
resonate with me;
It's almost as if they lack a human touch."



All I can say is what Allen Ginsberg wrote me once
when I complained that I got bored meditating...

examine the TEXTURE of your boredom...


works like this resist your common textual
"pleasure"---this is part of their subversion---at one
time, hopkins was unpleasant to the ear---and don't
EVEN get me started on Cage...or Duchamp, for that
matter...


what amazes me is that here, on a list that ATTEMPTS
to be concerned with poetry, and long after the
language poets have all settled comfortably into
tenure (no offense---I read you hungrily when young)
work like this should present any problem at
all---perhaps it would be different if Ron Silliman
wrote it, or Charles Bernstein---would it be
acceptable here then? is that the kind of game we're
playing? or are we going to approach these texts
openly?

maybe augie needs a blog...


(slightly rumpled, fresh back from NYC--all the
net.artists are showing in galleries now, so much for
operating outside of the gallery system---so much for
access---and what's up with the teeeeny poetry section
at the st. mark's bookshop?) bliss
l

From:         Aaron Vidaver <vid@RUNCIBLE.ORG>
Subject:      Puzzle for Morning Commute
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"; format="flowed"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Match the headline with the corresponding opening sentence
of the article and media outlet.

HEADLINES

U.S. Forces Fire on Iraqi Protesters
U.S. troops fire on Iraqi crowd, killing at least 13
US troops shoot dead 13 Iraqis, including children
Report: U.S. Troops In Deadly Shooting
Anger Mounts After U.S. Troops Kill 13 Iraqis
Iraqis killed in anti-US protest
US troops 'kill 15 Iraqi protesters'
U.S. troops fire on Iraqi protestors
U.S. fires on Iraqi protesters
Deadly Demonstration
Iraqis: 12 dead in shootout
GIs Return Fire on Iraqi Protest; 13 Claimed Dead
'Many killed' after US soldiers fire on demonstrators

SENTENCES

"US troops shot dead 13 Iraqis, at least six of them
children, during a protest to mark Saddam Hussein's
birthday, overshadowing the surrender of a key weapons
advisor to the toppled president."

"U.S. soldiers opened fire on Iraqis at an anti-American
demonstration after being shot at with automatic rifles by
some in the crowd, a U.S. officer said Tuesday."

"U.S. soldiers opened fire Tuesday in a town west of
Baghdad, killing a reported thirteen Iraqis and injuring

Most of the articles are edited by the outlets throughout
the day so the text at the other end of the link may not
be identical to what was there at 4am PST this morning.
Within the hour of the breaking news, FOX, for instance,
had already  changed the story to: "U.S. troops on Monday
night fired on Iraqi demonstrators, some of who were
shooting AK-47s, as they approached a schoolhouse where
American forces were housed, U.S. officers said Tuesday."

too complex, abstract, or obscurantist. Or negative reviews of Ashbery

resource in which I can find one or more of these, please backchannel
me at aaron@belz.net

Hall's "Critical Essays" series.  Each volume is devoted to a single
author, collecting his/her reviews in chronological order.  I can't
seem to locate one of these for Ashbery.
